title: Transformer Architectures in Intelligent Process Mining and Optimization
authors: Prajwal Hegde N, Chanakya Kumar Jha, Abhinav Pratap Singh, Renukhadevi M, B. Tapasvi, Pallavi Jha
publish: 2025 5th Asian Conference on Innovation in Technology (ASIANCON)
abstract: Process mining has emerged as a critical discipline for analyzing and optimizing business processes through event log data. Traditional process mining techniques often struggle with complex, long-range dependencies and temporal patterns in event sequences. This paper introduces a novel transformer-based architecture specifically designed for intelligent process mining and optimization. We propose a self-attention mechanism enhanced with temporal positional encoding to capture intricate process behaviors and predict next activities with high accuracy. Our approach is evaluated on three real-world datasets: BPI Challenge 2012, Sepsis Cases, and Road Traffic Fine Management, achieving superior performance compared to LSTM and GRU baselines. Experimental results demonstrate that our transformer model achieves 94.3% accuracy in next activity prediction and reduces mean absolute error in remaining time prediction by 23% compared to state-of-the-art methods. The proposed architecture enables real-time process optimization and anomaly detection, providing actionable insights for business process management.

title: From Contributor to Leader: Navigating the Transition
authors: Mahima Bansod, Tashwin Khurana
publish: 2024 IEEE Women in Engineering (WIE) Forum USA East
abstract: Transitioning from an individual contributor to a managerial role is a significant career milestone and a complex challenge. In today's fast-paced and ever-evolving industrial environment, new managers must shift from executing technical tasks to leading teams and driving strategies with virtually little to no transition time. This study provides a comprehensive guide for navigating this transition, highlighting the development of essential leadership skills, the importance of strategic vision, and the alignment of team efforts with organizational goals. The study also examines various managerial styles that can be leveraged by new managers and leaders, analyzes common pitfalls such as micromanagement, ineffective communication, failure to delegate, and provides pitfall avoidance approaches. Through industry case studies and established transition frameworks, this study offers practical strategies for new managers to lead their teams successfully, and for organizations to help with such transitions. Emphasizing continuous learning, effective communication, and team development, this study aims to help newly minted managers achieve personal growth and drive organizational success.

title: Hybrid-Strategy Enhanced Particle Swarm Optimization for Array Antenna Interference Suppression
authors: Yilong Zhai, Feng Yang, Yulin Xiao
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Networks, Communications and Information Technology (CNCIT)
abstract: This paper proposes an enhanced Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO) algorithm to address conventional LCMV limitations in array anti-jamming systems, particularly insufficient null depth under low snapshots and ineffective coherent interference suppression. The method optimizes antenna weights through SINR fitness extremum-seeking with hybrid strategies, enhancing global search and convergence. Simulations demonstrate superior anti-interference performance with precise convergence in snapshot-deficient scenarios, effective broadband/coherent interference suppression, and maintained computational efficiency. The approach provides a possible alternative to LCMV in jamming environments mentioned above.

title: Chatbot-Based Local POI Recommendation Without User Profiles and Mitigation of Popularity Bias
authors: Sumet Darapisut, Komate Amphawan
publish: 2025 International Conference on Power, Energy and Innovations (ICPEI)
abstract: Location-Based Social Networks (LBSNs) offer rich data for developing personalized and context-aware recommender systems. However, conventional methods often rely on user profiles or historical data, which limits their effectiveness in cold-start scenarios and introduces popularity bias by disproportionately favoring globally popular venues. In this paper, we propose the Local Point-of-Interest (POI) Chatbot Recommender (LPCR), a framework that does not require user profiles and actively mitigates popularity bias. The core of LPCR is Localized Popularity Graph Ranking (LPGR), an enhanced HITS-based algorithm incorporating fairness terms to identify locally relevant POIs by leveraging insights from local experts. LPCR then generates a Top-N POI list and employs a chatbot-based explanation powered by LLaMA to provide interactive rationales for each recommendation. Experimental results demonstrate that LPCR effectively addresses both popularity bias and recommendation accuracy, particularly for new users without historical data.

title: Efficient Designated Verifier Aggregate Signature Scheme for Massive Terminals
authors: Yan Lijing, Li Shuai, Yang Ying, Liu Han, Song Yifan
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Networks, Communications and Information Technology (CNCIT)
abstract: With the construction of smart grids and the rapid development of Internet of Things technology, a vast number of smart devices such as smart meters, distributed energy sources, energy storage units, and EV charging piles are being integrated into power systems, posing significant challenges to device authentication. These large-scale access scenarios involve diverse device types, high concurrency, real-time requirements, and strong security demands. Authentication must not only verify device legitimacy and prevent malicious access but also ensure data privacy and integrity. However, traditional methods struggle to meet these needs due to the limited computing power of devices, complex network environments, cumbersome certificate management in PKI systems, and key escrow issues in identity-based schemes. To address this, the paper proposes an efficient certificate-less specified designated verifier aggregate signature (CL-SDVAS) scheme that requires only three bilinear pairings for verification. It also supports designated verifier functionality, ensuring that only the intended verifier can validate signatures, thereby enhancing the confidentiality and security of authentication information in large-scale smart grid environments.

title: Scalable Via Array Substrate for Programmable Packaging Applications
authors: T. Y. Ouyang, Y. P. Chan, L. C. Chang, C. I. Li, Y. S. Chang, H. H. Chang
publish: 2025 20th International Microsystems, Packaging, Assembly and Circuits Technology Conference (IMPACT)
abstract: A scalable via array substrate is manufactured, enabling the provision of small-volume, large-variety production packaging producibility evaluation. This scalable via array substrate is comprised of pre-fabricated redistribution layers and customized redistribution layers. The pre-fabricated redistribution layers consist of four metal levels of copper RDLs and 180 µm height through mold vias. Dual active switch dies were embedded in the through mold vias, which act as a bridge to program and modulate signal transmission between integrated heterogeneous chips (Bluetooth, flash memory, and microcontroller unit). With the integration of various functionality chips, we can define the routing interconnection traces using simplified 2P1M customized redistribution layers, reducing the complexity of layout design. A scalable via array substrate provides a cost-effective packaging architecture and is expected to be a promising solution for high-performance system-in-package. The pre-fabricated redistribution layers guarantee a stable manufacturing yield, shortening 50% the time-to-market and reducing the production cost.

title: Research on Single-Phase Grounding Fault Characteristics in 20kV Distribution Networks with Low-Resistance Neutral Grounding Systems
authors: Weihao Liu, Yuantao Wang, Weifeng Yang, Wei Ma, Quanhua Jiang, Dongran Liu, Ruiqing Zhang
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Mechatronics Technology (ICEEMT)
abstract: To quantify the single-phase grounding fault characteristics in $\mathbf{2 0 k V}$ distribution networks with low-resistance neutral grounding systems, this paper presents the electrical characteristics of the main transformer and grounding transformer in the type of distribution network. Then, the zerosequence network was established to derive calculation formulas for the zero-sequence current in the neutral point, the zerosequence current in the non-fault line, and the zero-sequence current in the fault line. Finally, based on the $110 / 20 \mathrm{kV}$ Aoti transformer substation of Hangzhou Power Supply Company, a simulation model was built in Simulink to verify the accuracy of the derived formula.

title: Prediction of Grinding Removal Amount for Pneumatic Eccentric Grinding Head Based on MultiSensor Data Fusion
authors: Guolei Wang, Weiwei Men, Yuqi Yang, Pin Zhang, Qingbiao Zhang, Yuxiao Pu
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Mechatronics Technology (ICEEMT)
abstract: Aiming at the problems that the vibration velocity of the pneumatic eccentric grinding head is difficult to measure accurately and the prediction accuracy of the grinding removal amount is not high, a method for accurately predicting the grinding removal amount of the pneumatic eccentric grinding head based on multi-sensor data fusion is proposed. Firstly, the main factors affecting the mobile grinding removal amount of the pneumatic eccentric grinding head are analyzed; secondly, a noncontact measurement method for the vibration velocity of the pneumatic eccentric grinding head based on a force sensor is proposed; then, a removal amount prediction model integrating grinding force, sandpaper grit size, grinding head vibration velocity, grinding head revolution velocity and feed rate is established based on the Multi-Layer Perceptron (MLP) architecture; finally, the accuracy of the proposed method and model is verified by experiments. The test results show that the measurement error of the vibration velocity is $\leq 3 \%$, the Root Mean Square Error (RMSE) of the model on the test set is no more than $0.30 \mu \mathrm{~m}$, and the Mean Absolute Percentage Error (MAPE) is $\mathbf{3. 8 2 \%}$. Compared with the Preston model, the proposed model has obvious advantages in prediction accuracy and generalization ability.

title: Chronic Kidney Disease Classification Using Machine Learning with SHAP Explainability
authors: Pramod Kumar, Tapas Si
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Advances in Computing Research On Science Engineering and Technology (ACROSET)
abstract: Chronic Kidney Disease (CKD) is a major worldwide health burden that frequently goes undiagnosed until it is advanced due to its asymptomatic nature. The estimated Glomerular Filtration Rate (eGFR) and serum creatinine, two conventional diagnostic techniques, have drawbacks in terms of early detection and population variability, respectively. For proper training, a machine learning model depends heavily on features. Interpreting a model, however, requires an understanding of how specific features affect a prediction. It is important to understand which features give a forecast credibility because this information illuminates the inner workings of the model. This work investigates how to improve CKD classification while maintaining clinical interpretability using Explainable Artificial Intelligence (XAI). Multi-Layer Perceptron (MLP), Random Forest (RF), Adaptive Boosting (Adaboost), and eXtreme Gradient Boosting (XGBoost) are used to classify kidney data using a publicly available dataset from the UCI Machine Learning Repository. Performance is assessed using F1-score, accuracy, sensitivity, specificity, false-positive rate, precision, and Geometric-Mean (GM). XAI techniques, specifically Shapley Additive Explanation (SHAP) are applied to elucidate model decisions, identifying key predictors like haemoglobin, Specific gravity, and red blood cell count. The study demonstrates that XAI not only maintains high predictive performance but also fosters clinician trust by providing transparent insights into the AI-driven diagnostics.

title: A Legal-BERT Validated RAG Framework for Trustworthy AI-Assisted Legal Reasoning
authors: Pardeep Kumar, Vijay Dhir
publish: 2025 5th Asian Conference on Innovation in Technology (ASIANCON)
abstract: The integration of Artificial Intelligence (AI) into legal workflows presents both transformative potential and critical challenges, particularly regarding the reliability and legal validity of generated content. While large language models (LLMs) like GPT-4 demonstrate impressive fluency, they often fall short in domain-specific legal reasoning. This paper proposes a conceptual framework that enhances Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) by incorporating Legal-BERT as an active validation layer. The architecture consists of five core components: document preprocessing using LayoutLMv3, summarization via BART, context retrieval with Dense Passage Retriever (DPR), generation through GPT-4, and legal validation using Legal-BERT. Central to the framework is a Hybrid Verification Loop, which iteratively refines outputs based on feedback from the validation stage. Designed for modularity and extensibility, the framework aims to produce legally compliant and interpretable outputs. While empirical evaluation is planned—initially focused on the Indian Penal Code—this work offers a foundation for future development of trustworthy legal AI systems, with potential for reinforcement learning-based enhancements.

title: Research on Fault Analysis and Diagnosis of Fiber Channels
authors: Yaojun Zhang, Yuxin Yang, Dong Liu, Fenying He, Zhiyong Liu, Jie Li, Bin Shao
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Mechatronics Technology (ICEEMT)
abstract: Relay protection devices are crucial for protecting power lines, accurately collecting analog quantities and issuing tripping commands to ensure safe, stable operation. Differential protection, a key and sensitive main protection, detects faults by comparing current vector differences across power lines. Both sides transmit data and commands via fiber channels. Fiber channel failures often disable protection during maintenance, leaving power lines unprotected. This paper analyzes fiber channel fault types, studies their mechanisms, develops troubleshooting logic methods, aids on-site maintenance, and improves power line reliability.

title: Educational Transformation through Virtual Reality: Improving Understanding of the Integration of Chemical and Biochemical Processes in Tequila Production
authors: Dariana Graciela Rodriguez-Sanchez, Raul Villarreal-Lara, Laura Eugenia Romero-Robles, Jackeline Iturbe Ek
publish: 2025 IEEE Digital Education and MOOCS Conference (DEMOcon)
abstract: Virtual reality (VR) has emerged as a promising tool in engineering education, enabling simulation of complex industrial processes within immersive digital environments. This paper examines the application of VR in chemical and bioprocess engineering, using unit operations in tequila production processes as a case study.A VR-based simulation was developed to replicate a tequila production facility, allowing students to explore each unit operation in a guided, interactive format. The simulation aimed to replicate realistic industrial conditions, providing students with access to environments typically inaccessible in academic infrastructures.The study was conducted with third-year students, enrolled in a Biotechnology Engineering program. Two control and two experimental groups were formed to evaluate VR-based simulation implementation. Knowledge and satisfaction tests were assessed at the end of the course for each group. Within the virtual environment groups, students were required to calculate key parameters related to fermentation and distillation processes, including temperature, inoculum and substrate concentrations, fermentation time, and the volume of fermented must for distillation.This task-based approach facilitated the contextual application of theoretical concepts. Preliminary findings indicated that students exposed to VR simulation demonstrated increased motivation, engagement, and conceptual understanding compared to those instructed through traditional methods.The immersive experience enabled experiential learning by allowing students to manipulate variables in a controlled setting, thereby reinforcing their comprehension of process kinetics and the impact of operational decisions on product outcomes. These results suggest that VR-based academic activities can enhance the development of professional competencies in chemical and bioprocess engineering education, providing a scalable strategy to improve learning outcomes in courses involving complex process systems with an improved academic experience.

title: Accelerating Innovation-Based Learning with Low-Cost Hardware for Full-Stack IoT Development
authors: Nethshan M. Narasinghe, Sandamini Neththikumara, Collins P. Obeng, Ryan Striker, M W P Maduranga, Enrique Alvarez Vazquez
publish: 2025 IEEE Digital Education and MOOCS Conference (DEMOcon)
abstract: Innovation-Based Learning (IBL) is a transformative educational approach that empowers students to solve real-world problems through hands-on experimentation. In developing countries, IBL offers a unique opportunity to unlock creativity and technical potential. However, for novice learners, mistakes are part of the process, and hardware damage can become a recurring setback. Delicate, expensive hardware discourages exploration and places financial burdens on families and institutions. The novelty of this approach lies in reducing the cost of such failures, enabling affordable, even free learning opportunities.To address this, we introduce a low-cost, beginner-friendly hardware platform designed for full-stack IoT development. The board supports the WeMos D1 Mini (ESP-12F) and integrates an OLED display, relay, buzzer, push buttons, RGB LED, and full GPIO access. Its tangle-free, all-in-one design makes it ideal for both classroom and remote learning, allowing students to prototype ideas without fear of damage. This platform costs just 40% of an Arduino UNO and 25% of a Raspberry Pi, making it highly accessible.By minimizing hardware-related barriers, students can focus on learning, coding, and implementing solutions. Developments like this pave the way for accessible, low-cost, hybrid education models shaping the future of inclusive and scalable learning. Beyond hardware, a suite of sample lessons and structured instruction makes this STEM focused platform a powerful tool to accelerate IBL across diverse learning environments.

title: Integration of Machine Learning with Quantum Computing: Compilation of Quantum Circuit for Efficacy on Noisy Intermediate-Scale Quantum Devices
authors: M. Praba, Ahmad Abdelhafiz Ali Samhan, V. Samuthira Pandi, A. Sowmiya, Navyatha Ravi, G. Karthikeyan
publish: 2025 5th Asian Conference on Innovation in Technology (ASIANCON)
abstract: Hybridizing machine learning (ML) with quantum computing has become an attractive strategy to increase computational power on Noisy Intermediate Scale Quantum (NISQ) devices. Although these can be potentially quantum advantage devices, their qubit numbers and noise are bounded and there are challenges when it comes to practical quantum circuit realization. This work concentrates on the creation of optimized quantum circuits via ML-based strategies, to enhance the performance of the circuits, to reduce the error rate and to accommodate the particular noise profile of the hardware of NISQ devices. The resulting suboptimal mappings with little or no consideration of noise and hardware topology in traditional quantum compilers can ruin the fidelity of quantum algorithm. Leveraging machine learning, and specifically reinforcement and supervised learning methods, our method learns to optimize compilation strategy for specific quantum hardware architecture. The paper proposes a framework that uses machine learning models to predict qubit mappings, gate decompositions, and transpilation paths that minimize gate depth and error accumulation. We also investigate transfer learning methods for propagating the learned compilation strategies to novel NISQ machines. Such methods are empirically validated on both simulated and real quantum hardware backends, providing evidence of circuit depth, execution time and error reductions. The results show that ML-assisted compilation can achieve better success probabilities for benchmark quantum algorithms like VQE and QAOA than conventional compilers. Furthermore, the work examines the interpretability of ML models providing hardware-aware optimization recommendations and understanding the noise patterns and methods of error correction. Our work highlights the key role of ML for transferring between theoretical quantum algorithms and their practical NISQ implementations. This integration boosts the immediate applicability of existing quantum devices and provides a basis for adaptive and scalable likelihood-based compilation for the era of fault-tolerant quantum computation. Our results motivate further investigation of hybrid classical-quantum workflows, in which ML iteratively improves compilation in accordance with changing hardware noise and capabilities. By improving quantum circuit compilation onNISQ computers, this work is taking steps toward the realization of quantum advantage in application scenarios such as optimization, cryptography, and quantum simulation without needing to wait for fully fault-tolerant large-scale quantum computers.

title: Elevating Construction Safety: AI enhanced Attire Monitoring and GPS for Tracking Compliance
authors: Jaweedh Ahmed N, Keerthana J, Abishek V, Anusha S
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Advances in Computing Research On Science Engineering and Technology (ACROSET)
abstract: Construction worker safety is usually undermined by non-adherence to personal protective equipment (PPE) and hazardous environments. This paper introduces a sophisticated safety monitoring system that utilizes artificial intelligence (AI) and Internet of Things (IoT) technologies to improve worker protection. The system incorporates a YOLOv8 object detection model to guarantee PPE adherence by categorizing worker clothing into seven safety classes. In addition, IoT sensors such as an MPU6050 accelerometer for detecting falls, a pulse sensor for monitoring heart rate, and a rain sensor for detecting water immersion offer real-time safety information. A Neo-6M GPS module and SIM900A GSM module facilitate location tracking and emergency notification. The system proposed here provides a scalable and data-driven risk mitigation strategy with real-time monitoring and instant response to safety breaches or health emergencies. Experimental findings validate its effectiveness in enhancing compliance and decreasing accidents in risky construction settings.

title: Design and Implementation of a Low-Cost BJT-Based Prototype for Flight Control
authors: Nandana S Raj, Niranjana Anil, Sreya B Sabu, Rahul Lal, Suma H, Anjana J G
publish: 2025 5th Asian Conference on Innovation in Technology (ASIANCON)
abstract: This project presents a low-cost prototype for basic flight control using fundamental electronics and embedded systems. The prototype emphasizes key educational principles such as transistor-based motor switching, inertial sensing, and Bluetooth-Enabled communication using microcontrollers. By eliminating the need for complex electronic speed controllers and brushless motors, the system provides an accessible platform for understanding the foundations of flight control. Though not intended for autonomous navigation, the model offers a valuable base for students and hobbyists to explore real-time control mechanisms in small-scale aerial systems and unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs).

title: Federated Learning for Privacy-Preserving Diabetes Detection: A Robust Framework for Heterogeneous Healthcare Data
authors: C Dhiya, Umesh Gjh, U Kavya, G Sivashankar, S Nagendra Prabhu
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Innovative Data Communication Technologies and Application (ICIDCA)
abstract: Fragmented healthcare data and strict privacy laws pose challenges in the early detection of diabetes. Federated learning (FL) can be used to collaboratively train prediction models without sharing raw records. But issues such as non-IID data, label skew, and interpretability challenge prevail in real-world set-ups. We customize a unified FL framework for diabetes prediction that (a) combines differential privacy and Paillier-class homomorphic encryption to protect updates, (b) performs dynamic domain adaptation to address distributional differences between the EHRs and continuous glucose/wearable signals, and (c) uses a hybrid Transformer + 1D-CNN local model whereby attention maps provide meaningful clinical explanations. Other components are a fairness audit that rebalances the losses for underrepresented subgroups, secure aggregation of local SHAP/LIME explanations into a global interpretability map, and a global calibration step to smoothen probability reliability. Measured on multi-modal data (simulated splits of MIMIC-IV and OhioT1DM across three clinical sites), this framework achieves an AUC-ROC of 88.3% (near-centralized performance), reduces membership-inference leakage by ~92%, and improves F1 for underrepresented groups by 12.7% over FedAvg/FedProx baselines. The system delivers competitive accuracy, stronger privacy guarantees, and actionable explainability for clinicians.

title: Analysis of Heel Pain using Pedobarograph
authors: Devadharshini R, Elakkia S, Sanmathi S, Bhuvaneswari M
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Innovative Data Communication Technologies and Application (ICIDCA)
abstract: Plantar heel pain significantly affects the quality of life for millions around the world. It causes discomfort at the bottom of the heel, which worsens with activities like walking, running, or standing. It is a common condition that most commonly accompanies the diagnosis of plantar fasciitis, where the plantar fascia, a necessary tissue that supports the foot arch, protrudes out. In the past this issue was considered to be inflammatory. However, the heel pain, according to new studies, in most instances is the result of the degenerative processes of the plantar fascia structure that results in the occurrence of micro tears and structure alterations. Plantar heel pain is necessary to be diagnosed and treated because it has a serious impact on normal life, productivity, and well-being. This article determines the potential benefits of pedobarography, a form of diagnostic methodology to determine the distribution of the foot pressure during the walking or standing. The data provided by pedobarography provides useful numbers related to the foot mechanics that can be used in the identification of the causes of heel pain. Through these forms of pressure, the clinicians can be able to identify areas of over-stress especially in plantar fasciitis. This direction may lead to more specific treatments programs. It can be assumed that the growing use of pedobarography in clinical and research practice will be able to improve patient outcomes significantly. One of the main causes of the pain in the heel is plantar fasciitis and it may strike a very heterogeneous population such as both athletes and less active individuals. It is experienced as pain in the heels and in most instances is worst during the initial steps taken in the morning or when the individual has held up in a sedentary position. Plantar part (bottom of the) fascia inflammatory and injurious effects are typical of the disease.

title: Real-Time Fileless Malware Detection Using LSTM on System Logs
authors: Kommaraju Rupa Kusuma, Venkanna Babu Pamarthi, Praveen Das Pallipamu, Soniya Meka
publish: 2025 5th Asian Conference on Innovation in Technology (ASIANCON)
abstract: Fileless malware, operating in-memory using trusted tools like PowerShell and WMI, evades signature-based detection systems. This paper proposes an AI-driven framework for real-time fileless malware detection using Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) networks to analyze temporal patterns in system logs. By monitoring network activities, registry changes, and execution sequences, our system achieves 98.44% accuracy and a 1.56% false positive rate on a 1.75M-element synthetic dataset. A web-based dashboard provides real-time alerts and visualizations, enhancing cybersecurity response. This approach outperforms traditional methods by focusing on temporal behavior, offering a scalable solution for enterprise systems.

title: Autonomous UAV Design with Real-Time Obstacle Avoidance for Emergency Services
authors: Soumitra Keshari Nayak, Vivek Kumar Vishwakarma, Shiv Pratap Singh, Aryan Gaikwad, Jay Hepat, Anil Kumar, Pardeep Kumar
publish: 2025 5th Asian Conference on Innovation in Technology (ASIANCON)
abstract: Unmanned Aerial Vehicles (UAVs) are increasingly utilized in logistics, surveillance, and emergency response industries. While existing drones are capable of object detection and payload delivery, they often lack an integrated system for real-time detection and obstacle avoidance in dynamic environments. This paper presents a lightweight UAV designed to carry a payload with integrated real-time object detection and obstacle avoidance capabilities. The drone features a streamlined body constructed from ABS plastic and carbon fiber, ensuring strength and aerodynamic efficiency. The UAV integrates advanced sensors for real-time proximity sensing, with provisions to enhance situational awareness. Embedded AI algorithms, including potential field-based path planning and rule-based avoidance logic, enable autonomous detection and maneuvering around obstacles. The UAV is equipped with an automated payload release mechanism that operates based on mission-specific altitude and location constraints, ensuring precise and reliable delivery. By integrating robust navigation, intelligent obstacle avoidance, and efficient load management within a compact and adaptable design, the proposed system provides a practical and effective solution for critical applications such as disaster relief and medical supply transport.

title: A Method for Assessing Distribution Network Reliability Integrating Uncertainty Modeling of Wind and Solar Power with V2G Coordination
authors: Jiajun Zhang, Xiangyu Lv, Deixin Li, Jiarui Wang, Haiyang Guo, Yutong Liu
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Mechatronics Technology (ICEEMT)
abstract: With the advancement of the “dual carbon” strategy, the large-scale integration of wind power, photovoltaic (PV), and electric vehicles (EVs) into the grid increases the volatility and randomness of distribution network output. Traditional reliability assessment methods struggle to accurately capture the correlation between wind and solar output and the spatiotemporal uncertainty of EV behavior. This paper proposes a novel method for assessing distribution network reliability that integrates uncertainty modeling for wind and solar power with V2G coordination. First, a joint probability model for wind and solar power incorporating correlation is constructed using Frank-Copula functions. Second, a logarithmic normal distribution-based model for daily EV mileage and a probability model for initial battery state of charge are established. Sequential Monte Carlo simulation is employed for system state sampling, and a dynamic power balancing strategy is introduced in scenarios where isolated islands form after faults. To validate the proposed method, simulation analysis is conducted using the IEEE 33-node system as an example. Results demonstrate that compared to traditional deterministic evaluation methods, the proposed approach achieves more accurate reliability assessments by accounting for the correlation between wind and solar power generation and the randomness of $\mathbf{E V}$ operation.

title: TinyFaceDL Lightweight Transformer CNN Hybrid Model for Face Recognition on Low Power IoT and Edge Devices
authors: G. Ramkumar, Ahmad Al-Qerem, G. Kalyani, A. Vamsi, Devolla Manogna
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Innovative Data Communication Technologies and Application (ICIDCA)
abstract: Detection of faces on low-power Internet of Things (IoT) and edge computing devices is a very much challenging task due to the limitation of less computational resources, limited energy, and other environmental factors including illumination, occlusion, and pose changes. In response to these difficulties, the current study advances TinyFaceDL, a minimal hybrid architecture, which combines Transformer-Based feature coding with an optimized Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) backbone. The proposed model uses CNN layers to extract local features with high efficiency and uses Transformer modules to capture long sequence dependencies and global contextual features that can guarantee strong representation even in real-world situations. A compression scheme that combines both pruning and quantization is also integrated to drastically minimise the size of memory and computation cost and thus the system can be embedded on resource-constrained devices. Experimental confirmation on standard face recognition benchmark datasets indicates that TinyFaceDL matches state of the art models in terms of accuracy, consuming less than 40 percent of the parameter size and inference time. The findings underscore the possibility of TinyFaceDL to run on low-power IoT and edge machines to provide secure real-time face recognition applications to applications in the area of smart surveillance, access control, and human-computer interaction.

title: Securing Autonomous Vehicle Systems through Machine Learning based Intrusion Detection in Connected Environments
authors: Rachna Shah, Rakshit Tandon
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Innovative Data Communication Technologies and Application (ICIDCA)
abstract: Connected with the existing transportation system, AVs not only present efficiency but also introduce some minor cyber-physical risks. As such, V2X connectivity are crucial for the real-time data exchange upon which autonomous operation of vehicles is highly dependent on and in some way has further laid open all sensors-machine interface, machine-machine communication as well interface to external network including cloud etc. This paper examines cyber-security threats against the environment of autonomous vehicles' (AV) and considers two machine learning-based countermeasures: Random Forest Classification (RFC), and Auto-encoder based Anomaly Detector. The supervised intrusion detection is done with the Random Forest model by using the structured network traffic, and for detecting the unknown or new threats; Autoencoder is used that it trains normal patterns of communication and then on receiving unusual it tries to predict them. The approaches are evaluated in the simulations of attacks and verified its sensitivity on identification of spoofing, DoS and message tampering problems. The results demonstrate that hybrid machine learning techniques have potential to enhance the in-vehicle connected car systems with real-time perception of hazards. The findings highlight the importance of lightweight, explainable and scalable ML designs in regards to safety-critical components for autonomous transportation infrastructures.

title: Exploring the Role of Data Science in Mental Health Assessment via Digital Platforms
authors: Vucha Charan Sai
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Innovative Data Communication Technologies and Application (ICIDCA)
abstract: A suspected bonfire of mental health problems is currently being lit across the world, and the only thing to stop it is fast study and diagnosis. The utility of data science in disentangling mental health has expanded as more people are turning to digital tools. In this essay, they consider how data science is employed in online mental health tests using ‘big data’ techniques, especially machine learning, natural language processing (NLP), and predictive analytics to structure patient information. It examines how such technology is being employed with online platforms, mobile apps and smart tech to monitor, assess, and even predict mental health. Finally, the essay discusses the problems and ethical concerns related to the application of data science in mental health (privacy of data, correctness of results, bias within algorithms). There are recommendations for mental health centres to have in place a series of principles to enable tools based on data science to be utilized with scalability, accessibility and real-time monitoring at the forefront. Based on these results, data science could transform the measurement of mental health, in turn leading to a more personalized and effective data-driven mental health care. Next steps should include solving ways around the present difficulties and figuring how well such tools work in real-life medical settings.

title: Children Emotion Detection Deep Learning: A Comparative Study
authors: Ramesh Dadi, Gaddam Sai, Adapala Vamshikirishna
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Innovative Data Communication Technologies and Application (ICIDCA)
abstract: This paper discusses different deep learning models used in detecting and predicting children's emotions. Emotional well-being in children is a key area of mental health that affects cognitive development, school performance, and social skills. Detection of emotional states like anxiety, sadness, happiness, or anger at an early stage is crucial for early intervention and overall psychological growth. This research takes advantage of cutting-edge methods in emotion prediction and analysis through machine learning and big data processing. Our methodology combines various sources of data, such as facial expressions, tone of voice, behavioral patterns, and online interactions, to increase the reliability of emotion detecting systems. This paper also discusses some of the most significant challenges in the field, such as data privacy, ethics, and the necessity for interdisciplinary collaboration between teachers, mental health professionals, and data scientists. The study also explores novel solutions, such as the utilization of wearable technology for real-time emotional tracking, emotion-aware educational materials, and the incorporation of child-specific databases in order to create more individualized and adaptive systems.

title: Predicting Netflix Show Success: A Sentiment Analysis Approach Using BERT
authors: Audya Florencia, Christine Kosasih, Diana, Shania Priccilia
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electronic and Electrical Engineering and Intelligent System (ICE3IS)
abstract: User-generated information, such as reviews, comments, and social media posts, is abundant on online platforms in today’s digital environment. Sentiment analysis has developed into a potent instrument for evaluating audience responses, assisting studios and filmmakers in determining public sentiment. This study investigates how well BERT- based sentiment analysis predicts the popularity of Netflix series. We propose a new method that leverages BERT-based sentiment analysis to predict the success of Netflix series. We seek to ascertain the relationship between sentiment trends and a show’s success by examining audience sentiments. We categorize reviews as either positive or negative and analyze their influence on viewership trends using machine learning techniques, specifically BERT. Our research will help streaming platforms make data-driven decisions by shedding light on the function of sentiment analysis in content appraisal. The results indicate that BERT-based sentiment analysis can effectively predict Netflix series popularity, demonstrating a strong correlation between audience sentiment and viewership trends.

title: Concrete Crack Identification Through Hu Moment Shape Analysis and K-Nearest Neighbors Models
authors: Yessi Jusman, Ahmad Zaki, Ahmad Firdaus, Agil Priambada
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electronic and Electrical Engineering and Intelligent System (ICE3IS)
abstract: Crack detection in concrete structures is critical for ensuring safety and long-term structural integrity. This study proposes an automated classification system utilizing Hu moment invariant descriptors combined with K-Nearest Neighbors (KNN) classifiers to distinguish three concrete crack levels. The methodology involves image acquisition at a resolution of $225 \times 225$ pixels, preprocessing through RGB-tograyscale conversion and adaptive histogram equalization, and feature extraction using Hu moment invariants method. Three KNN models, namely Coarse, Cubic, and Medium, were evaluated using 10 folds cross validation with standard performance metrics including accuracy, precision, recall, specificity, F1-score, and ROC analysis. The coarse KNN model demonstrated the best performance, achieving an average testing accuracy of $77.3 \%$, precision of $75.7 \%$, recall of $73.0 \%$, specificity of $81.7 \%$, F1-score of $73.3 \%$, and an Area Under Curve (AUC) of 0.94. These results indicate a reliable, computationally efficient system suitable for real-world structural health monitoring applications, particularly in resource-constrained environments.

title: Implementation of Random Forest Algorithm for Predicting Customer Churn in Fiber to the Home Services
authors: Amalia Audah, Faqih Hamami, Riska Yanu Fa’Rifah
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electronic and Electrical Engineering and Intelligent System (ICE3IS)
abstract: Customer churn remains a significant concern in the telecommunications industry, as the loss of subscribers can significantly increase operational costs and reduce profitability. In Indonesia, where internet penetration has reached over 85% and competition among internet service providers continues to intensify, maintaining customer loyalty is increasingly challenging. PT XYZ, a Fiber to the Home (FTTH) service provider, faces difficulties sustaining customer growth and retention despite the expanding digital market. This study proposes a churn prediction model using the Random Forest algorithm, optimized with GridSearchCV and 5-fold crossvalidation. The model achieves an accuracy of 92% and identifies subscription tenure as the most influential factor in churn decisions. Partial dependence analysis confirms that short-tenure customers with low capacity usage have higher churn risks, highlighting key segments for proactive retention. The model is deployed as a user-friendly web application that enables automatic churn prediction, visualization, and result export for operational use. Limitations include dependency on historical internal data and exclusion of external behavioral factors.

title: Ultraviolet Index Prediction Using A Machine Learning Approach
authors: Afif Izaaz, Chayadi Oktomy Noto Susanto, Soni Miftah Pratama, Benyamin Heryanto Rusanto, Anton Widodo, Maulana Putra, Marzuki Sinambela, Laila Ma’Rifatul Azizah
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electronic and Electrical Engineering and Intelligent System (ICE3IS)
abstract: Accurate UV Index prediction is vital for public health, yet conventional measurement tools are often costly and impractical in remote areas. This study investigates the predictive capabilities of two machine learning models—Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) and Artificial Neural Network (ANN)—for hourly UV Index estimation using four years (2021-2024) of data from the GAW Bukit Kototabang Station in Indonesia. The dataset were resampled, normalized, and converted into UV Index values based on erythemal weighting. Both models were optimized using Keras Tuner and evaluated in terms of MAE, RMSE, SMAPE, and $\mathbf{R}^{\mathbf{2}}$. Results indicate that the LSTM model outperformed the ANN model, achieving a lower MAE ($\mathbf{1. 5 8 0 0}$ vs. 1.7411), lower RMSE ($\mathbf{2. 4 1 3 0}$ vs. 2.5708), and higher $\mathbf{R}^{\mathbf{2}}$ (0.8809 vs. 0.8648). Visual comparisons further confirm that the LSTM model closely follows realistic diurnal UV patterns, whereas the ANN exhibits erratic spikes. This research provides a comparative assessment of memory-based and feedforward models for UV Index forecasting and supports the deployment of LSTM as a cost-effective monitoring solution in resource-limited environments.

title: Integrating Traditional and Advanced Algorithms through Voting Classifiers for Improved Crack Severity Analysis
authors: D. Bujji Babu, P. Sai Nikhitha
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Innovative Data Communication Technologies and Application (ICIDCA)
abstract: Disasters such as earthquakes of massive magnitude cause intensive loss of life and infrastructure, and important highways are essential in the supply of relief and emergency services in the disaster scene. Nevertheless, bad roads provide a difficulty in transport following earthquakes or even aftershocks. The paper reports the creation of a new dataset that is a collection of field studies in regions heavily affected by the earthquakes of the 6th of February 2023 in Turkey and divided into the images of asphalt cracks, which are categorized as needing immediate repair (Major) or not (Minor). The original research, based on using the VGG16 model and pre-trained CNNs, accomplished a classification accuracy rate of 80.32 per cent through the Combined Metaheuristic Optimisation-Relieff (CMO-R) technique. This is an update that utilizes an even more polished Voting Classifier to increase precision. Incorporating 3 different but well-performing algorithms, the Random Forest, Naive Bayes, LDA, and XGBOOST, the Voting Classifier applies the majority voting scheme to reinforce the reliability and correctness of the prediction. Through these thorough tests, it has been shown that this Gram-enhancing-based strategy will offer a better classification structure and therefore can serve a good functionality in terms of road maintenance prioritization following an earthquake.

title: Enhancing Multi-Layer Perceptron with Bayesian Optimization for Coffee Leaf Disease Classification
authors: Andrian Sah, Lukman Azhari, Mohammad Imam Shalahudin, Rohmat Indra Borman, Yessi Jusman
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electronic and Electrical Engineering and Intelligent System (ICE3IS)
abstract: Coffee leaf diseases can significantly reduce production, making early detection crucial. Digital image processing based on machine learning offers an automated solution for plant disease classification. Multi-Layer Perceptron (MLP) is a more computationally efficient alternative, but its performance is highly dependent on the selection of optimal hyperparameters. This study develops a coffee leaf disease classification model based on MLP optimized with Bayesian Optimization. The model is built through image preprocessing (RGB to HSV conversion and Otsu Thresholding segmentation) and feature extraction using HSV Histogram and Local Binary Pattern (LBP). Evaluation results show that MLP optimized with Bayesian Optimization achieved an accuracy of $96.44 \%$, an improvement of 9.32% compared to the non-optimized model $(88.22 \%)$. This success is attributed to the selection of more optimal hyperparameters, allowing the model to recognize complex patterns more effectively.

title: A Web-Based Ticketing System for Traffic Violations Using YOLO and OCR for Real-Time Detection
authors: Avicena Naufaldo, Hanif Fakhrurroja, Dita Pramesti
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electronic and Electrical Engineering and Intelligent System (ICE3IS)
abstract: Traffic violations, particularly helmet noncompliance, are a leading cause of road accidents. This study presents a web-based electronic ticketing system that enhances enforcement through violation detection. The system utilizes Raspberry Pi 5 with Pi Camera and an embedded YOLOv11 model for helmet detection, while OCR extracts license plate numbers. Relevant data is transmitted via API to a backend server, which handles notifications (SMS, WhatsApp, email) and fine payments through a gateway. Validation testing showed 93% helmet detection accuracy, $94.36 \%$ license plate detection accuracy, and a 9% OCR error rate. Usability testing with 20 vehicle owners and 3 police officers yielded SUS scores of 72.88 and 85, along with positive SEQ ratings, demonstrating the system’s effectiveness in supporting enforcement and user workflows.

title: ML-Classify: A Dual-Classification Approach for Learning Material Categorization
authors: Marlon Juhn M. Timogan, Maureen M. Villamor
publish: 2025 Eight International Conference on Vocational Education and Electrical Engineering (ICVEE)
abstract: The increasing volume and complexity of digital learning materials have challenged traditional manual classification methods, highlighting the need for scalable and efficient automated solutions. This study introduces ML-Classify, a dual-classification system categorizing educational materials by topic and difficulty. Leveraging natural language processing and machine learning techniques, the system integrates a fine-tuned DistilBERT model for topic classification and a pipeline combining Sentence Transformer embeddings with a Multilayer Perceptron (MLP) for difficulty prediction. The models were trained and evaluated using a balanced dataset of PDF materials sourced from Open Educational Resources (OERs), achieving 95% accuracy for topic classification and 61% for difficulty classification. Deployed via Hugging Face Spaces and integrated into a FastAPI-powered web interface, the system supports real-time, page-level inference. Results demonstrated high topic classification precision and moderate success in difficulty prediction, particularly distinguishing easy and hard texts. Future work includes expanding datasets, incorporating human-annotated labels, and refining linguistic features to enhance performance and usability. This research emphasizes the potential of dual-label machine learning systems in improving content accessibility, personalization, and instructional design in educational environments.

title: Multi Class Skin Lesion Detection and Classification via Teledermatology
authors: T. Manivannan, M. Sai Krishna, G. Sudheer, S. Thanveeruddin
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Advances in Computing Research On Science Engineering and Technology (ACROSET)
abstract: An innovative method to help with the early identification and classification of skin illnesses is presented by the "Multi-Class Skin Lesion Detection and Classification via Teledermatology" initiative. Using a Raspberry Pi microcontroller, this system employs the MobileNetV2 Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) to classify skin lesions into three categories: benign, melanoma, and eczema. The model is used for real-time inference after being trained on a dataset obtained from Kaggle. The system includes a buzzer to signal problematic circumstances, a GSM module for remote notifications, and an LCD to display classification findings. Adapters provide power, and connections make it easier to integrate components. This teledermatology technology supports patients and medical professionals in remote locations by offering an easy, portable, and effective way to diagnose skin diseases in their early stages.

title: Educational App for Traffic Sign Recognition Using Convolutional Neural Networks
authors: Kerr Micko D. Lanante, John Michael E. Revilla, Jonathan Andrei B. Fabi, Ma. Windie C. Velarde, Ritchell S. Villafuerte, Eric O. Sta. Singh, Raymond M. Daylo
publish: 2025 Eight International Conference on Vocational Education and Electrical Engineering (ICVEE)
abstract: Recognizing traffic signs is vital for the safety of both drivers and pedestrians navigating Philippine roads. Despite the implementation of traffic regulations, insufficient public education has led to significant knowledge gaps regarding these crucial indicators, consequently elevating the risk of road accidents. This research addresses this critical issue by presenting a user-friendly Android application designed to empower individuals with the ability to instantly identify unfamiliar traffic signs through the convenience of smartphone scanning. This application implements the power of deep learning algorithms, specifically convolutional neural networks (CNNs), to achieve accurate and rapid identification of road signs. The system's efficacy is rooted in a comprehensive dataset of traffic signs sourced directly from the Filipino Driver’s Manual, published by the Land Transportation Office. To optimize the data for the CNN models, the collected images underwent a rigorous preprocessing stage utilizing OpenCV, involving grayscale conversion and precise cropping. The researchers employed Google Colab as the platform for training various state-of-the-art CNN models, including MobileNetV2, EfficientNet Lite, and ResNet50. This strategic selection of models aimed to evaluate different architectures for optimal performance in terms of accuracy and efficiency. The successful development and execution of the application yielded practical and positive results, demonstrating its potential as a valuable tool for enhancing road safety awareness and promoting a better understanding of traffic signs among the Filipino public. The findings of this study underscore the significant role that accessible technology can play in bridging educational gaps and fostering safer road environments.

title: Performance Analysis Resource Allocation with Waterfilling Power Control Scheme using Genetic Algorithm for Device-to-Device Communication
authors: Fawwaz Ido Adi Pratama, Budi Prasetya, Rudzidatul Akmam Dziyauddin, Nasrullah Armi
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electronic and Electrical Engineering and Intelligent System (ICE3IS)
abstract: Device-to-device (D2D) communication is a form of communication between two devices without the need to go through a Base Station. This method is implemented to reduce the base station’s workload, increase data rates, coverage area, and reduce network latency. In the future, D2D communication will provide solutions as the demand for smartphone-based communication continues to grow. This could lead to an increase in data rates and impact power efficiency. In D2D systems, unlike Cellular User (CU) systems, devices must transmit signals through a base station in Long Term Evolution (LTE) communication, which requires significant power. This study uses a genetic algorithm with a Water-Filling Power Control scheme as the resource allocation algorithm. It is then compared with a Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO) algorithm using the same Water-Filling Power Control scheme. After all resources have been successfully allocated, performance parameters such as Average User Throughput, Spectral Efficiency, and D2D fairness are calculated. Simulation results show that more users reduce these values, and the Genetic Algorithm is better than PSO ($\mathbf{1. 2 ~ M b p s, ~} \mathbf{0. 2 4 5 ~ b p s} / \mathbf{H z}, \mathbf{0. 6 4}$ fairness vs. 1.1 Mbps, $\mathbf{0. 2 3 4} \mathrm{bps} / \mathrm{Hz}, 0.63$), whereas more Resource Blocks increase them, again with the Genetic Algorithm ($\mathbf{2. 1 8 ~ M b p s}, \mathbf{0. 1 8 4 ~ b p s} / \mathbf{H z}, \mathbf{0. 7}$ fairness vs. 2.14 Mbps, 0.178 bps/Hz, 0.7).

title: Real-Time Lane and Traffic Sign Detection for Self-Driving Vehicles Using Deep Learning
authors: Virendra Kumar Shrivastava, Pullagugra Datta Sri Harsha, Annabathini Lokesh, Kanneluru Harsha Vardhan
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Advances in Computing Research On Science Engineering and Technology (ACROSET)
abstract: In today’s fast-paced urban environments, maintaining accurate and reliable traffic conditions are crucial. Real-time traffic sign and lane detection have become essential building blocks for facilitating autonomous systems. In this model, an effort has been made to address the issues of lane and traffic signs detection in dynamic and variable environmental conditions. It is driven by the need to enhance the safety and reliability of autonomous vehicles by endowing them with a strong perception module that can handle the visual stream data in real-time. The proposed model aims to explore the realization of a deep learning-based lane and traffic sign detection system that is both high-performance and highly accurate. As a result of the massive evolution of neural networks and computer vision, this study achieves lane detection and traffic sign classification in one system to implement self-driving to enhance navigation and decision-making for different situations: lighting, road conditions, and even traffic sign appearance. The deployment incorporates the utilization of cutting-edge frameworks and tools like Keras, and OpenCV for model training and real-time image processing. YOLOv8 (You Only Look Once) architecture is used for detecting traffic signs, whereas custom convolutional neural networks are used to detect lanes. The system is trained on big data sets and fine-tuned for precision utilizing Python-based libraries. The outputs are tested and proved on video and image inputs to guarantee consistent performance in real-life situations. This study introduces a complete real-time assistance system that combines lane discovery, traffic sign recognition, doziness monitoring, distance estimation, and steering angle predicting within a single model.

title: Kaarya Setu: A Community Rental Marketplace for Sustainable Resource Utilization
authors: V. Ragavarthini, Sonu Kumar, Anand Kumar, Rohit Kumar Singh, Adarsh Kumar
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Innovative Data Communication Technologies and Application (ICIDCA)
abstract: Excessive consumption culture hinders the use of available resources, burdens the economy with additional financial strain as well, and causes environmental degradation. Lack of a trust mechanism (there is no trust; there is only a contract between the buyer and seller), no geo location service, and no complete set of product categories (that will cover the needs of underserved groups like students and farmers) in current rental marketplaces also represent weak points. To fill these gaps, it develops Kaarya Setu, a peer-to-peer rental marketplace for lending of underutilized products over different categories with a community approach. It features a trust building review system, geo-location services, secure authentication, and AI AI-driven recommendation system. To accomplish this, our implementation relies on the Flutter framework for cross- platform compatibility and Supabase for backend services to serve as a scalable, secure, and user friendly app. Consequently, the performance evaluation conducted indicates very high user engagement with a 78% transaction completion rate, an 82% user retention, and a 25% reduction of consumer spending concerning traditional ownership models. The performance is especially demonstrated in the semi-urban and rural markets, as specialized equipment is not accessible to the customer. In addition, this research makes a contribution to the sharing economy literature with an alternative to ownership that is favorable for sustainability, with the addition of economic benefits for both product owners and renters.

title: Stratus Cloud: Security Expert’ An Automated Web Application Securtiy Assessment Tool
authors: Kanishka Jha, Shreya Limkar, Shubhangi Kharche, Sujit Londhe, Jailingam Santhanakumar, Ankit Sharma, Shreelakshmi Nair
publish: 2025 5th Asian Conference on Innovation in Technology (ASIANCON)
abstract: Stratus Cloud: Security Expert is a cloud-deployable, lightweight CLI tool that scans web application vulnerabilities automatically. It detects SQL Injection, XSS, insecure HTTP methods, and misconfigured directories through multi-threaded payload analysis. In contrast to AI-powered scanners, it keeps false positives below 5% and attains 92%+ accuracy. With subdomain enumeration, SSL analysis, WHOIS lookups, and port scanning features, Stratus offers a scalable, actionable, and accessible solution for security audits. Comparison with OWASP ZAP, Nikto, Arachni, and Nmap indicates that Stratus beats in terms of automation, scan time, and modular control. This work reports its architecture, comparative outcomes, performance assessment, and considers future enhancements.

title: Multi-Stage ML-Based Prediction and Classification of Liver Cirrhosis Progression
authors: Puneeth Thotad, Vijeeta Patil, Medha Kudari, Shanta Kallur, Suman Yaligar, Anupama Nandeppanavar
publish: 2025 5th Asian Conference on Innovation in Technology (ASIANCON)
abstract: Liver cirrhosis is a progressive condition that often remains asymptomatic until advanced stages, making early detection critical for improving clinical outcomes. This study proposes an automated, multi-stage machine learning framework for the prediction and classification of liver cirrhosis progression. The model pipeline leverages clinical, biochemical, and demographic data to emulate clinical decision-making processes: initially identifying at-risk individuals, subsequently assessing disease severity, and ultimately forecasting disease progression. Various machine learning algorithms, including Random Forest, XGBoost, and Histogram-Based Gradient Boosting Classifier are evaluated at each stage. Cross-validation and hyperparameter tuning are employed to ensure optimal model performance. Analysis of the importance analysis identifies key biomarkers that enhance interpretability and clinical relevance. The proposed framework demonstrates high accuracy and robustness across all stages, outperforming baseline clinical models. Results indicate the potential of multi-stage machine learning systems to serve as effective decision-support tools for early detection and personalized monitoring of liver cirrhosis.

title: A Multi-Model Ensemble Learning Approach for Cyberbullying Detection in Social Networks
authors: Natrayan L, Sirisha J, J V Rama Kumar, Seeniappan Kaliappan, Ramya Maranan, Siva Kumar Pathuri
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Advances in Computing Research On Science Engineering and Technology (ACROSET)
abstract: Cyberbullying is prevalent with the advent of social media, and it has a severe impact on others’ mental health. Online harassment can be complex and constantly changing, leading to low accuracy and high false-positive rates in traditional methods of detection. This study suggests an ensemble machine learning paradigm for improved cyberbullying detection in social media. The ensemble model incorporates multiple classifiers (like ERFGB) to improve predictive accuracy and compare the accuracy obtained from the proposed classifier with SVM and Decision Tree classifiers. In this paper we preprocess dataset containing feedback from users from Twitter and other social media platforms using NLP techniques, such as tokenization, stemming, and feature extraction. The performance of the ensemble is tested on multiple benchmark datasets along with individual classifiers and ratio of accuracy, precision and recall is better in comparison to independent classifier. The results indicate that the ensembled approach provides a more reliable and efficient method for detecting cyberbullying, contributing to safer online environments which when compared with base classifiers i.e., 96%.

title: The Influence of Blockchain in Online Games Innovation: TAM Approach
authors: Rudy Tjahyadi, Huandika Ekaputra
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electronic and Electrical Engineering and Intelligent System (ICE3IS)
abstract: The integration of blockchain technology is rapidly transforming the online gaming industry, bringing new opportunities and challenges. This research aims to understand the factors that influence the adoption and innovation of blockchainbased online games from a technology acceptance perspective. Using the Technology Acceptance Model (TAM) as a theoretical framework, this research examines the impact of Perceived Ease of Use, Perceived Usefulness, Perceived Risk, Perceived Enjoyment, and perceived Benefits of Blockchain-Based Online Games on innovation in the field. A quantitative approach is proposed, including an online survey of at least 200 active online game players to collect data on the variables studied. Structural equation modeling (SEM) techniques will be used to analyze the data and test the hypothesized relationships. The findings in this research will provide valuable insights for game developers, technology providers, and the gaming industry in optimizing the adoption, the integration of blockchain technology in online games, and balancing innovation with accessibility for mainstream acceptance. This research also contributes to understanding the factors driving the successful implementation of blockchain in the gaming sector and its potential to revolutionize the digital economy

title: Machine Learning-Powered AI Chatbots in Pharmacy Practices: A Survey of Techniques, Applications, and Future Directions
authors: Salwa Aurelia Putri Dasirin, Anita Agustina Styawan, Muhammad Thesa Ghozali
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electronic and Electrical Engineering and Intelligent System (ICE3IS)
abstract: Artificial intelligence (AI) and machine learning (ML) technologies have increasingly transformed pharmacy practice by enhancing medication management, pharmaceutical counseling, and adverse drug reaction (ADR) monitoring. Among the most impactful innovations are MLdriven chatbots, which integrate natural language processing (NLP), deep learning, and reinforcement learning to simulate pharmacist-patient interactions. These chatbots offer round-the-clock, personalized drug guidance, improve medication adherence, and reduce pharmacist workload, particularly in underserved areas. This survey presents a comprehensive review of machine learning methodologies employed in pharmacy chatbots, including supervised, unsupervised, and hybrid models. Real-world applications are analyzed, focusing on medication adherence monitoring, prescription validation, patient education, and pharmacovigilance. The paper also explores current limitations, such as data privacy risks, linguistic challenges, and fragmented regulatory standards. Ethical concerns, including algorithmic bias and lack of transparency, are discussed. Finally, future research directions are proposed, emphasizing the need for explainable AI, federated learning for data protection, and integration with wearable devices. By addressing these gaps, ML-generated chatbots can be positioned as reliable, scalable, and patientcentered tools within digital healthcare ecosystems, supporting safer and more efficient pharmacy services.

title: Power Load and Price Forecasting Based on Spatiotemporal Decoupling and Explainable Artificial Intelligence Interaction Perception
authors: Chen Yan, Hebin Ruan
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Mechatronics Technology (ICEEMT)
abstract: This study proposes a hybrid deep learning framework combining Temporal Convolutional Networks (TCN) and Transformer architectures for electricity price and load forecasting. TCN captures short-term fluctuations, while the Transformer models long-range dependencies and cross-variable interactions. To enhance interpretability, Local Interpretable Model-agnostic Explanations (LIME) and permutation importance are applied to reveal local and global feature contributions. The framework is evaluated on multiple public datasets with comprehensive preprocessing and sliding-window construction, and benchmarked against Adaptive Boosting (AdaBoost) and eXtreme Gradient Boosting (XGBoost). Experimental results under abnormal conditions, such as price spikes and extreme weather, demonstrate superior accuracy, robustness, and interpretability of the proposed model.

title: Retraction Notice: T2VBench: Benchmarking Temporal Dynamics for Text-to-Video Generation
authors: Pengliang Ji, Chuyang Xiao, Huilin Tai, Mingxiao Huo
publish: 2024 IEEE/CVF Conference on Computer Vision and Pattern Recognition Workshops (CVPRW)
abstract: While text-to-video (T2V) generative models produce exceptionally realistic videos, they lack a comprehensive evaluation across the temporal dimension, with a limited focus on basic dynamics including camera transitions, movement, and event sequences. In this work, we introduce T2VBench, a comprehensive T2V evaluation benchmark enriched with temporal dynamics lexicons derived from curated temporal words on Wikipedia. T2VBench is a hierarchical evaluation framework comprising over 1,600 temporally rich prompts and 5,000 generated videos with human ratings, spanning 16 critical temporal evaluation dimensions. We assess three leading text-to-video models, including ZeroScope and Pika, to gauge their proficiency in handling temporal dynamics. Our analysis highlights the strengths and limitations of these models across various temporal aspects. Furthermore, we provide insights into future directions for enhancing text-to-video evaluation metrics and offer a detailed analysis of these models’ performance across the temporal dimensions. Overall, T2VBench is the first-of-its-kind comprehensive benchmark fully focused on temporal dynamics for text-to-video evaluation. It aims to facilitate scientific benchmarking of both generative models and automated metrics on text-to-video generation.

title: A Review on Deep Learning based Multi-Class Non-Destructive Potato Quality Assessment Techniques
authors: Kavita Kahar, Prashant Panse
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Advances in Computing Research On Science Engineering and Technology (ACROSET)
abstract: Potato is one of the world's four basic food crops, considerably impacting agricultural methods and culinary traditions, especially in India. This study examines the significant impact of potato quality evaluation, specifically its implications for food safety, customer preferences, economic viability, processing efficiency, and sustainable agriculture. With an average yearly consumption of 25.4 kg per person in India by 2021, assuring the quality of non-destructive multiclass potatoes has become increasingly important. Dimensions (abnormal, medium, big, tiny), form (oval, round, asymmetric), color (black, red, green skin), and the presence of physical defects (bruises, wounds, rot, sprouting) and internal flaws (hollow, black spot, illness) are all important quality indicators for potatoes. The uneven forms and susceptibility to flaws provide quality control issues. Traditional analytical procedures, such as HPLC (High Performance Liquid Chromatography), GC-MS (Gas Chromatography-Mass Spectrometry and PCR (Polymerase Chain Reaction), are labor-intensive and expensive for the quality assessment of potatoes. This article reviews modern potato quality assessment technology to improve quality efficiency, ensure compliance with potato safety requirements, and increase overall marketability. By utilizing this approach, the sector can safeguard public health, maximize resource utilization, and promote sustainable farming practices, resulting in a more reliable and secure food supply chain.

title: IoT-Based Realtime Battery Monitoring System for Unmanned Aerial Vehicles (UAVs)
authors: Yadhurani Dewi Amritha, I Made Yogaswara Dipta
publish: 2025 International Conference on Smart-Green Technology in Electrical and Information Systems (ICSGTEIS)
abstract: Unmanned Aerial Vehicles (UAVs) have become increasingly important in applications such as logistics, agriculture, surveillance, disaster management, and smart city services. Reliable battery performance is essential to ensure mission success and flight safety, yet most small- to mediumscale UAVs still rely on manual checks or proprietary battery systems that are costly, closed-source, and not optimized for weight and energy constraints. This research addresses these limitations by developing a low-cost and open-source IoT-based battery monitoring system utilizing the ESP8266 microcontroller. The system employs a voltage divider network and TP4056 module for safe lithium-ion battery integration, while leveraging ESP8266 Wi-Fi capabilities to transmit realtime voltage data to the Blynk platform. UAV operators can monitor both raw voltage and estimated battery percentage through an intuitive mobile interface. Performance testing across 30 trials demonstrated an average error of 2.52% and accuracy of 97.48% compared with calibrated multimeter readings, classifying the system as highly reliable. The modular architecture allows for scalability and potential commercialization as an affordable add-on for UAVs, while also supporting sustainable practices through improved battery lifecycle management.
