title: Preparation of Dicyclopentadiene Resin-sealed Power Modules and Comparative Power Cycle Tests under High Temperature and High Humidity Conditions
authors: Nobuhito Kamei, Naoki Fukumoto, Masayuki Hikita, Masahiro Kozako
publish: 2025 20th International Microsystems, Packaging, Assembly and Circuits Technology Conference (IMPACT)
abstract: Epoxy resin and silicone gel are commonly utilized as encapsulation materials in power modules due to their processability and electrical insulation properties. However, both materials reliability present challenges under demanding operating conditions. Epoxy resins are prone to void formation during molding, and their high rigidity can induce cracking or mechanical damage to semiconductor chips and bonding wires under thermal cycling stress. Silicone gels, while more compliant, are susceptible to partial discharge phenomena such as electrical treeing and void generation when subjected to prolonged high electric field exposure [1] .

title: Random Forest-Based Step Length Classification Utilizing Inertial Measurement Unit (IMU) Sensor Data and Body Height
authors: Ilham A.E. Zaeni, Dyah Lestari, Soraya Norma Mustika, Dessy Rif'a Anzani, Muhammad Khusairi Osman, Khairul Azman Ahmad
publish: 2025 International Conference on Smart-Green Technology in Electrical and Information Systems (ICSGTEIS)
abstract: The present work confirms that it is possible to conduct the classification of step length using IMU sensors effectively. Data were recorded by means of accelerometers and gyroscopes; afterward, the signals were preprocessed and filtered, and features were extracted in order to enhance the accuracy of the models of classification. This study will compare three models. The model 1 used a decision tree based on four attributes and underperformed the other models. The model 2 utilized four attributes normalized by the subject's height. It achieved a more balanced performance across all classes with fewer misclassifications than the model 1. The model 3 used a Random Forest method based on the same attributes as the model 2 but normalized. It achieved an accuracy on the classification as <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{8 1. 4 8 \%}$</tex>. The Random Forest model performed quite strongly overall but appeared to suggest that some misclassification was occurring between classes 1 and 2, therefore needing further refinement. Nonetheless, at this stage, the Random Forest model performed better among other models in regard to the balance of accuracy and error rate, hence could turn out effective for step length classification.

title: IoT-Enabled Sensor Position Optimization for Passive In-Vehicle Alcohol Detection and Alert Systems
authors: Saanthana Laxmi A. Muthukarpan, Muzammil Jusoh, Mohamed Nasrun Osman, Thennarasan Sabapathy, Mohd Ilman Jais, Muhammad Iqbal Ahmad
publish: 2025 IEEE International RF and Microwave Conference (RFM)
abstract: The increase in drunk driving incidents, often caused by drivers' disregard for road regulations and selfish behavior, has led to tragic consequences. Conventional breathalyzer approaches prove impractical for everyday use, thereby spurring the creation of the “Sensor Position Analysis for Passive In-Vehicle Alcohol Detection and Alert System.” This innovative system aims to identify the best position for the MQ-3 alcohol sensor in the vehicle, ensuring utmost precision measurement. It encompasses a real time alcohol detection mechanism to gauge the driver's intoxication level and notification system to alert their family members. Operated by an Arduino Mega 2560 microcontroller and validated through experimentation with sanitizer, the system able to identify the driver's side door area as the most effective sensor placement. Additionally, drunkenness analysis with two test subjects indicated that women may get intoxicated faster than men. By implementing this system in all vehicles, it can significantly reduce drunk driving incidents and enhance road safety.

title: Compact Dual-Band Implantable Antenna for Reliable Fat-IBC at 2.45/5.8 GHz
authors: Muhammad Ridzuan Hafiz Zuriene Heslin, Mohamad Zoinol Abidin Abd. Aziz, Noor Badariah Asan
publish: 2025 IEEE International RF and Microwave Conference (RFM)
abstract: This paper presents a compact dual-band implantable antenna designed for industrial, scientific, and medical (ISM) applications, operating at 2.45 GHz and 5.8 GHz. The antenna represents the first dual-band design tailored for fat-intrabody communication, Fat-IBC. The antenna is designed to be embedded in fat tissue, with the dimensions of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{2 0. 5} \times \mathbf{2 3} \times \mathbf{1. 2 7} \mathbf{m m}^{3}$</tex>, and has a half-ground plane structure on a high-permittivity substrate. The design is designed and optimized through simulations, and validated through measurements in a three-layer tissue-equivalent phantom. The fabricated prototype has been tested in tissue-equivalent phantom and the measured results show that they match well with the simulated results. The antenna exhibits notable reliability in adipose tissue environments, with performance that is dependent on the antenna's orientation. The prototype achieved gains of −0.32 dBi and −6.5 dBi, and path losses of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$2.3 \text{dB} / \text{cm}$</tex> and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$3.2 \text{dB} / \text{cm}$</tex>, at 2.45 GHz and 5.8 GHz, respectively.

title: A Computational Intelligence Approach Towards Identification of Hormone Binding Proteins
authors: Tamim Alkhalifah
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Biomedical Signal and Image Processing (ICBIP)
abstract: Hormone-binding proteins are considered important proteins for the growth of hormones. Therefore, it is very important to understand its functionality by properly identifying this kind of protein. In this paper, we are trying to build a consistent model based on a machine learning algorithm that identifies this protein from other protein sequences. For this purpose, we downloaded the dataset from UniProt. Then we applied the feature extraction method based on tripeptide composition. To remove inappropriate information and noisy data we applied various feature selection methods to select optimal features. To evaluate model performance a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{5}$</tex>-fold cross-validation was used in which one-fold is used to train the data and the remaining folds are used for testing and gives 79.3 % overall accuracy. Furthermore, we compare the performance of our classifier with other existing models.

title: A Bibliometric Review of Taxonomy-Based Approaches in Sentiment Analysis
authors: Shaiful Bakhtiar bin Rodzman, Abdullah bin Mohd Saidi, Zamri Abu Bakar
publish: 2025 IEEE 15th International Conference on System Engineering and Technology (ICSET)
abstract: This study presents a comprehensive bibliometric analysis of research trends in sentiment analysis using taxonomy, a methodological approach that enhances sentiment classification through hierarchical categorization. Despite the growing adoption of sentiment analysis in computational linguistics, limited scholarly attention has been given to the taxonomy-based subset of this field. To address this gap, data were collected from the Scopus database using a well-defined Boolean search strategy, focusing on relevant keywords and filtering for English-language publications in the computer science domain. The analysis spans publications from 2004 to 2025 and employs a suite of bibliometric techniques, including descriptive statistics, keyword co-occurrence mapping, author co-citation analysis, and network visualizations. Key findings indicate a sharp increase in scholarly output after 2018, with peaks in 2024. Influential contributors such as Cambria, E. and institutions like Nanyang Technological University were identified as central to the field. Thematic mapping revealed evolving research focuses, transitioning from traditional models to advanced deep learning and transformer-based approaches. Furthermore, dominant keywords and citation clusters underscore the interdisciplinary nature and methodological diversity of the research. The study highlights the field's intellectual structure and emerging trends, offering valuable insights for researchers, practitioners, and policymakers. It also lays a foundational framework for future work on dynamic taxonomy development, cross-domain applications, and explainable AI in sentiment classification.

title: Ability of a Spherical Reflector Antenna for Multi Beam Application
authors: Yoshihide Yamada, Ayuni Afiqah Arjunaidi, Norazah Abdullah, Kamilia Kamardin, Hiroshi Hashiguchi, Naobumi Michishita, Muhammad Azmal Aizzat Mohd Anaur
publish: 2025 IEEE International RF and Microwave Conference (RFM)
abstract: In satellite communication and broadcast services, multi beam radiation patterns are required for satellite-mounted antennas to achieve precise beam coverage for peninsular Malaysia and Borneo. To achieve excellent multi beam performance with similar beam shapes over a wide angular region, a spherical reflector antenna is a suitable choice. However, since a spherical reflector lacks a focal point, antenna efficiency is reduced. In this paper, the available electrical performances of a spherical reflector antenna are summarized. Firstly, antenna efficiency reduction depending on antenna structural parameters is shown by electromagnetic simulations. For multi beam performance, focal region ray tracing results are presented. Secondly, a method for improving antenna gain by employing a shaped sub-reflector is proposed. Ray tracing results of the shaped sub-reflector are obtained to show the effectiveness of sub-reflector shaping. As a practical example, the radiation characteristics of a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1 0 0}$</tex>-wavelength-diameter antenna are simulated. In order to examine the effect of the shaped sub-reflector, a constant phase surface is proposed. Nearly uniform and constant phase distribution is obtained on the constant phase surface. Aperture amplitude and phase distributions, as well as antenna radiation patterns are presented. With the addition of shaped sub-reflector, antenna efficiency is improved from <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{4 4} \boldsymbol{\%}$</tex> (spherical only) to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{4 9 \%}$</tex>.

title: Design of a Transmission-Type Ferrite Faraday Rotator for 80-100GHz
authors: Xiaomeng Chen, Danli Wen
publish: 2025 18th IEEE United Conference on Millimeter Waves and Terahertz Technologies (UCMMT)
abstract: A transmission type faraday rotator work at 80 100 GHz is proposed in this paper. The design and optimization process of the faraday rotator are demonstrated. The impedance matching is achieved by adjusting the thickness of the quartz glass plate which are placed on both side of the ferrite plate. The simulation results shown that the vswr is less than 1.3 at the work band. By using a tunable polarizing grid, a concise testing method is given. The testing results shown that the insertion loss of the faraday rotator is about 0.8 dB and the isolation is 19 dB at W band.

title: A Novel Plasmonic Nanoantenna for Cancer Sensor Applications
authors: Samuele Scarpulla, Marco Scalici, Patrizia Livreri
publish: 2025 18th IEEE United Conference on Millimeter Waves and Terahertz Technologies (UCMMT)
abstract: Plasmonic nanoantennas are powerful tools for enhancing electromagnetic fields at the nanoscale, offering promising perspectives in Terahertz biosensing. This work introduces a novel Fractal V-Fork nanoantenna, specifically engineered for the detection of cancer biomarkers in the <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1 - 1 0 ~ T H z}$</tex> range. The structure, composed of gold on a silicon substrate, features a fractal-inspired V-shaped geometry with internal openings that improve both field confinement and absorption at resonance. Electromagnetic simulations reveal four distinct resonances at <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$1.29,3.05,3.82$</tex>, and 5.10 THz, with absorption peaks reaching -37 dB. The single nanoantenna achieves a sensitivity of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$240 \text{GHz} / \text{RIU}$</tex>, further enhanced in a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$2 \times 2$</tex> array configuration. The device is fabricated using Electron Beam Lithography, enabling high-resolution patterning. Thanks to its multiband response and sensitivity, the Fractal V-Fork nanoantenna represents a promising candidate for next-generation THz biosensing platforms aimed at early-stage cancer diagnostics.

title: Relaying Pulsed Millimeter Wave Magnetrons for Fusion Plasma Heating
authors: Jin Zhang, Wen Dang, Xiaodong Chen
publish: 2025 18th IEEE United Conference on Millimeter Waves and Terahertz Technologies (UCMMT)
abstract: We propose relaying multiple pulsed magnetrons for continuous wave (CW) operation, to adapt magnetrons for applications in fusion plasma heating. Simulations of a magnetron unit in the relaying array were conducted, using injection signal for phase locking. Rectangular waveguides are connected to a side cavity of the magnetron, with a port for input and output phase locking signals. The simulated S-parameters indicate good transmission at 94.26 GHz on port 1 and 94.28 GHz on port 2, agreeing with operating <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\pi$</tex>-mode in cavity. The simulated signals at phase locking port and output port show that the injected 93.4 GHz 5 kW signal could enable phase locking for the 211-kW output signal. These results confirm the feasibility of relaying multiple pulsed magnetrons for CW operation with applications in fusion plasma heating.

title: Tool-Agnostic Pulse Reverse Electroplating for High Aspect Ratio Through Glass Vias in Advanced Packaging
authors: Dennis Fiedler, Grigory Vazhenin, Holger Schulz, Henning Hübner, Mustafa Oezkoek, HeeBum Shin, Tobias Sponholz
publish: 2025 20th International Microsystems, Packaging, Assembly and Circuits Technology Conference (IMPACT)
abstract: High aspect ratio (HAR) through glass vias (TGVs) are critical enablers for advanced electronic packaging, offering vertical interconnects with excellent dimensional stability. This study presents a tool-independent pulse reverse electroplating (PRE) process for copper filling of TGVs, developed and validated using a generic 20-liter plating setup. The process was optimized across multiple via geometries (400 × 70 µm, 590 × 90 µm, and 800 × 100 µm), achieving inclusion-free results and significantly reduced plating times. While the influence of cuprous ions and additive dynamics is acknowledged, the focus remains on practical outcomes. Ongoing work includes electrochemical and simulation-based studies to further understand the process mechanisms and explore the potential of geometry- and agitation-optimized plating tools for next-generation packaging demands.

title: Power Equipment Damage Prediction in Typhoon Environment Based on XGBoost and LSTM
authors: Shaoqun Yang, Zhuangling Zhang, Xiuzhen Hu, Songyuan Zheng, Caina Chen, Xianhua Dai
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Computer Information Technology (AICIT)
abstract: Power equipment in coastal areas is highly susceptible to damage caused by typhoons. However, there is a scarcity of studies that integrate typhoon-related data (such as wind speed and precipitation) with power grid equipment information to provide early warnings for power equipment damage. To address this gap, this paper develops a power equipment damage prediction model under typhoon disasters by combining the XGBoost and LSTM algorithms. Drawing on data from China Southern Power Grid and practical experience in the power system, nine key factors closely associated with power equipment damage during typhoons are identified. Among these factors, two time-dependent dynamic variables—typhoon wind speed and precipitation—are input into the LSTM for modeling, while the remaining seven static factors are processed using the XGBoost algorithm. Finally, the outputs of the two models are integrated to generate the final prediction results for power equipment damage under typhoon conditions. Experimental findings demonstrate that the proposed model achieves an accuracy rate of up to 88% in predicting the status of power equipment during typhoons, outperforming algorithms such as Support Vector Machine (SVM) and Multi-Layer Perceptron (MLP). The application of this prediction model can provide accurate and efficient prediction and decision-making support for the safe operation of power grid equipment.

title: A ROM-Less DDS with a Double Integrator Using a Current Mirror
authors: Naoto Komiyama, Hideyuki Nosaka
publish: 2025 IEEE International RF and Microwave Conference (RFM)
abstract: This paper proposes a ROM-less direct digital synthesizer (DDS) equipped with a double integrator using a current mirror. This DDS generates pulse signals with high frequency purity by reducing jitter contained in the accumulator output signal using the double integrator. The core double integrator is characterized by being constructed solely from unidirectional current sources using a current mirror. This suppresses errors caused by bidirectional current sources to achieve high precision and also simplifies circuit design since matching of positive and negative elements is not required. Evaluation of the prototype DDS demonstrated high-speed frequency switching within two clock cycles and a spurious-free dynamic range (SFDR) of 50.4 dBc.

title: DSSC Output Power and Efficiency Based on the Electrolyte Gel Viscosity
authors: Rukmi Hartati, Poppy Sari, Rahmah Budiandari
publish: 2025 International Conference on Smart-Green Technology in Electrical and Information Systems (ICSGTEIS)
abstract: Dye-Sensitized Solar Cell (DSSC) is a solar cell based on natural dyes as photon absorbers replacing synthetic dyes which are commonly used in DSSCs, this is because natural dyes have more affordable prices, are abundant in nature, safe for the environment and can be renewed. Not only natural dyes have an influence on DSSC efficiency, but also the electrolyte used in the DSSC system which functions to replace electron losses in the High Occupied Molecular Orbital (HOMO) band. The aim of this research is to analyze the effect of polyethylene glycol (PEG) 1000 levels used as gel electrolyte on DSSC output power and efficiency. Utilizing chlorophyll from papaya leaves extract, as well as immersing the Fluorine-doped Tin Oxide - Titanium Dioxide (FTO-TiO2) disposition in chlorophyll for 60 hours, the FTO-TiO <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">${ }_{2}$</tex> disposition was then coated with a PEG 1000 based gel electrolyte solution with 5 levels of PEG 1000 content given, namely 0 gram, 1.25 grams, 2.5 grams, 3.75 grams and 5 grams. The research was carried out with 3 groupings. Analysis was carried out on the extract energy gap, the short circuit current value (Isc), open-circuit voltage value (Voc), fill factor (FF) value to obtain the efficiency value (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\eta$</tex>). From the results of research that has been carried out, DSSC based on polyethylene electrolyte gel was obtained with papaya leaves extract energy gap of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$2,428 \text{Ev}$</tex>, Vmpp of 0.547 V, Impp of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$7.1 \times 10^{-5} ~\mathrm{A}$</tex>, Voc of 0.549 V, Isc of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$1 \times 10^{-4} ~\mathrm{A}$</tex>, Jsc of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$2.89 \times 10^{-4} \text{Acm}^{-2}$</tex>, fill factor 0.676 and efficiency of 0.440 % with radiation of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$677.03 \mathrm{w} / \mathrm{m}^{2}$</tex> from the standard 1000 <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$w / m^{2}$</tex> in DSSC prototyping treatment with 2.5 grams of PEG 1000.

title: RF MEMS Switch Reliability and Lifetime: A Review and Strategy Framework for Creep Suppression
authors: Jiangtao Wei, Xiaolong Li, Yulong Zhang, Zewen Liu
publish: 2025 IEEE International RF and Microwave Conference (RFM)
abstract: RF MEMS (Microelectromechanical System) switches have become vital components in modern RF systems due to their remarkable advantages. However, metal cantilever beams in RF MEMS switches are prone to creep deformation, which severely compromises switch reliability and lifetime. In this paper, we present a comprehensive review of the key factors influencing creep behavior-namely material, temperature, and stress-based on our previous research. Building upon this review, we propose a set of strategies combining alloy design, fabrication control (electroplating and annealing), chip-scale thermoelectric cooling, and algorithm-guided structural optimization to suppress creep. These measures offer actionable design strategies and valuable insights to improve the reliability and lifetime of next-generation RF MEMS switches.

title: Research on Enhancing Automated Material Handling System Performance in PCB Factories Using MCS Intelligent Assistant
authors: Yuh-Chang Wu, Charles Kao, Scott Hsiang, Ally Hsu
publish: 2025 20th International Microsystems, Packaging, Assembly and Circuits Technology Conference (IMPACT)
abstract: With the rapid advancement of smart manufacturing and Industry 4.0, Automated Material Handling Systems (AMHS) have emerged as a critical element for enhancing production efficiency, reducing operational costs, and strengthening market competitiveness [1][8]. Currently, PCB factories still heavily rely on manual scheduling and monitoring, which is inefficient and highly struggle to respond to rapidly changing production demands. However, in highly complex processes and high-value material scenarios presented in PCB substrates factories, the implementation of automated material handling equipment such as Automated Guided Vehicles (AGVs), Overhead Hoist Transports (OHTs), and Panel Stockers faces significant challenges in handling efficiency, task scheduling, system stability, and data utilization [1][2].This study proposes a MCS Intelligent Assistant digital solution to overcome material handling bottlenecks and maintain a high throughput rate. The proposed system involves automatically gathering real-time operational data from both MES and MCS systems. Then cleans and formats the data to ensure data integrity and availability. After preprocessing, the system calculates KPIs, such as task completion time, equipment utilization, handling failure rate, and system response time. Analytical charts that visualize transportation routes, equipment status, task allocation, and abnormal events will be provided for visual representation. MCS Intelligent Assistant system can then empower engineers to identify latent problems such as task delays, equipment idleness or route conflicts. The system could analyze transportation tasks, equipment operations and route traffic to accurately locate bottlenecks or high-risk equipment and support more informed scheduling decisions.This research method can overcome the limitations in manual improvement of bottlenecks and maximize AMHS performance. In usual practice, it can achieve more than 25% reduction in problem solving time and regain productivity. In future work, it is possible to integrate advanced technologies such as Large Language Models (LLMs), the Internet of Things (IoT), and Digital Twin to further enhance this MCS Intelligent Assistant for smart manufacturing and ultimately realizing the grand vision of Industry 4.0.

title: Biopolymer Chitosan Based Monopole Antenna for Hybrid Piezoelectric-RF Enegy Harvester Applications
authors: Noor Amalina Ramli, Mohd Saiful Riza Bashri, Nur Najahatul Huda Saris, Maziati Akmal Mat Harttar Mohd Hatta
publish: 2025 IEEE International RF and Microwave Conference (RFM)
abstract: This paper presents the design, simulation, and experimental evaluation of a monopole antenna fabricated on a biocompatible chitosan substrate. The use of chitosan, a natural biopolymer with its piezoelectric capability, enables environmentally friendly hybrid piezoelectric-radio frequency energy harvesters. A monopole antenna operating at frequency of 2.4 GHz was designed and simulated using ANSYS HFSS. The prototype was fabricated using a chitosan film prepared through a solution casting method. The performance of the proposed antenna was validated through its return loss and radiation patterns. Results show good impedance matching performance at 2.4 GHz with simulated and measured reflection coefficient values of 10.7 dB and 13.9 dB respectively. The simulated peak gain of the antenna is 2.3 dBi. The study demonstrates the potential of chitosan-based substrates in developing hybrid piezoelectric-RF energy harvesters.

title: Cyber Attack Detection for Industrial Control Systems with Few-Shot and Class Imbalance: An Improved DA-LSTM-UNet Scheme
authors: Ruiyao Xu, Bo Yang, Dong Zhao, Feng Lv, Ruoyu Sun
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Control, Robotics and Cybernetics (CRC)
abstract: Cyber attacks on industrial control systems are characterized by sparse occurrence, making large-scale attack samples difficult to obtain, while accurate labeling requires expert involvement and incurs high costs. These constraints lead to significant performance degradation in existing detection methods, failing to meet the security monitoring requirements of industrial operations. To address these challenges of few-shot and class imbalance, this study proposes a scheme from both data preprocessing and model design perspectives. At the data level, a lightweight interpolation-based data augmentation strategy is employed to balance the distribution of the dataset by adding reasonable noise, thereby expanding sample diversity and enhancing model robustness against disturbances. In terms of model design, a U-Net architecture integrated with long short-term memory (LSTM) modules is designed for the effective capture of temporal dependencies in industrial data. The resulting LSTM-UNet model based on data augmentation preprocessing is tailored for few-shot and class-imbalanced settings. Experimental results on the SWaT dataset, particularly on gradual attacks, demonstrate the model’s superior performance in such challenging scenarios.

title: BlockRoyalty: Royalties Management Using Blockchain and Smart Contracts
authors: Nour El Zahabi, Nour El Madhoun
publish: 2025 9th Cyber Security in Networking Conference (CSNet)
abstract: In the digital era, managing royalties for creative works remains a major challenge. Existing systems are often outdated and lack the transparency and efficiency required to meet the growing demands of digital content distribution. This paper presents BlockRoyalty, an application based on blockchain and smart contract technologies, designed to modernize royalty management for digital books. The system automates the registration of authors, publishers and buyers. It manages book publication, applies dynamic pricing based on sales trends and ensures real-time royalty distribution. All transactions are securely and recorded in a verifiable manner on the blockchain, fostering trust among stakeholders.

title: Enabling On-the-Fly Automotive Suspension Health Monitoring with Vision-based Vibration Model
authors: Leonardo Pezenatto da Silva, Antônio Augusto Fröhlich, José Luis Conradi Hoffmann, Luiz Fernando Martins Pastuch
publish: 2025 XV Symposium on Computing Systems Engineering (SBESC)
abstract: Predictive Maintenance plays a vital role in improving cost-efficiency of commercial fleets while improving reliability and safety metrics. This work presents a lightweight, vision-based framework for vibration-based suspension health monitoring that leverages video-derived vertical acceleration signals to detect anomalies on-the-fly. By classifying driving events that naturally excite the suspension (e.g., traversing speed bumps and potholes), our approach triggers condition-aware assessment of suspension health that uses a deep Autoencoder trained solely on health behavior where the reconstruction error serves as a proxy for degradation severity. The proposed solution employs CARLA simulator with custom maps and suspension configuration to emulate a wide range of fault scenarios, overcoming the lack of high-fidelity, labeled datasets. Experimental results demonstrates the model’s ability to detect suspension degradation, with a mean detection error of 19.13%. The framework operates without the need for dedicated vibration sensors or labeled data, making it highly suitable for real-world deployment in fleet-scale predictive maintenance systems.

title: MLBFA: A Machine Learning-Guided Framework for Efficient Bit-Flip Attacks on Deep Neural Networks
authors: José Ronaldo, Otávio Alcântara de Lima, Nayra Sousa
publish: 2025 XV Symposium on Computing Systems Engineering (SBESC)
abstract: The deployment of Deep Neural Networks (DNNs) in safety-critical systems necessitates resilience against hardware threats like the Bit-Flip Attack (BFA). This challenge becomes particularly nuanced for quantized networks. Unlike their floating-point counterparts where single flips can be catastrophic, the inherent robustness of quantized models—the exclusive focus of this work—makes identifying critical bits computationally prohibitive. We introduce the Machine Learning-Guided Framework for Efficient BFAs (MLBFA), a novel framework that leverages Machine Learning (ML) to execute highly efficient Bit-Flip Attacks (BFAs). MLBFA operates in three stages: (1) it builds a Vulnerability Model (VM) from a limited statistical fault injection campaign using a multidimensional feature set; (2) it uses the VM to predict and rank the vulnerability of all parameters across the network; and (3) it exploits this ranking to guide advanced search algorithms (Greedy, Evolutionary, and Progressive) in identifying the minimal set of bit-flips required to neutralize the DNN. On quantized ResNet architectures, crucial for embedded systems, MLBFA consistently outperforms state-of-the-art methods, neutralizing a ResNet-32 with only six bit-flips and reducing the required flips by nearly 50% on deeper models like the ResNet-56. This work demonstrates that a holistic, ML-guided approach provides a superior strategic map for executing more potent hardware-level attacks with fewer resources.

title: The Study of THz Direct Modulation Wireless Communication System
authors: Liu Jun, Hao Xiaolin, Liu Bowen, Liang Shixiong, Li Yaming, Song Ruiliang, Liu Ning
publish: 2025 18th IEEE United Conference on Millimeter Waves and Terahertz Technologies (UCMMT)
abstract: A 12 Gbps wireless communication system based on THz direct modulator is designed. Compared with traditional mixing architecture, the THz direct modulation wireless communication system has a very simple system architecture and has broad application prospects and value. The modulator is designed and fabricated with GaAs Schottky Barrier Diode (SBD) and packaged with waveguide. The characteristics of the modulator is measured by Vector Network Analyzer and the insertion loss is 6.5 dB, and the switching ratio is 11.2 dB. Based on this modulator, a THz direct modulation wireless communication system is built. This system works at 330 GHz, and realizes 12 Gbps transmission rate at 5 cm.

title: Optimization and Power Enhancement of W-Band Extended Interaction Multi-Beam Klystron Resonator with Compression Ring Structure
authors: Xinyuan Zhang, Dongfeng Li, Ying Wei
publish: 2025 18th IEEE United Conference on Millimeter Waves and Terahertz Technologies (UCMMT)
abstract: This paper presents a design study on the resonant cavity structure of a W-band high-power extended interaction klystron (EIK), aiming to overcome the power limitations of vacuum electron devices in the millimeter-wave regime. By leveraging the advantages of both sheet-beam and multi-beam klystrons, an improved dumbbell-shaped EIK resonant cavity is proposed. The design employs three electron beams (each with a current of 0.8 A) and a three-gap configuration, incorporating a compression ring structure at the junction between the drift tube and the cavity gap. By maintaining a constant gap width (g) while reducing the compression ring width (g1), the issue of a sharp drop in characteristic impedance (R/Q) when increasing the coupling coefficient (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$M$</tex>) is mitigated, thereby maximizing the effective impedance (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{R} / \mathrm{Q} \cdot \mathrm{M}^{2}$</tex>). Simulation results indicate that the optimized structure achieves an R/Q value of 126.85Ω at <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{g} 1{=}$</tex> 0.2 mm, representing an 83 % improvement over the original design under comparable <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$M$</tex> values.

title: Tunable Terahertz Beam Splitter Based on Graphene
authors: XingYu Guo, Yan Teng, Ling Jiang
publish: 2025 18th IEEE United Conference on Millimeter Waves and Terahertz Technologies (UCMMT)
abstract: Conventional reflective metasurface unit cells typically adopt a metal-dielectric-metal structure, where the metallic components determine fixed functionality upon design with no post-fabrication tunability. Recent advances in tunable materials have enabled the integration of graphene, vanadium dioxide (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{VO}_{2}$</tex>), niobium nitride (NbN), and other dynamic materials into metasurface designs. This paper presents a graphene-based metasurface unit cell capable of modulating reflected wave amplitude through Fermi level tuning. Furthermore, the structure exhibits polarization conversion characteristics, enabling the generation of a phase difference via the Pancharatnam-Berry (PB) phase through the rotational patterning of surface elements. As a proof of concept, we designed a beam splitter based on coding metasurface principles and experimentally demonstrated far-field beam intensity modulation under different Fermi level configurations.

title: Compact Dual-Band OAM Antenna Via Mirrored UCA with Hybrid Stubs and Slots: IEEE UCMMT 2025
authors: Xiao-Wen Gong, Jun Hu, Huang-Yan Li, Xiang Wang, Si-Wen Zhang
publish: 2025 18th IEEE United Conference on Millimeter Waves and Terahertz Technologies (UCMMT)
abstract: With the rapid development of communication technologies such as the fifth generation (5 G), the demand for channel capacity and spectrum efficiency is increasing. This paper proposes a compact dual-band multi-mode orbital angular momentum (OAM) antenna array for enhanced spectrum utilization. The design features rectangular patch elements integrated with an E-shaped slot and a folded L-shaped stub, enabling independent control of S-band (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$2.15-2.20 \text{GHz}$</tex>) and C band <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(4.90-5.70 \text{GHz})$</tex> resonances. Through parametric optimization, a mirror-symmetric uniform circular array (MSUCA) is implemented, generating OAM modes <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$l=0$</tex>, <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\pm 1$</tex> across both low-frequency (2.15-2.20 GHz) and high-frequency (4.905.70 GHz) bands.

title: The History of IPv6 in Norway
authors: Jan Marius Evang
publish: 2025 IEEE History of Electrotechnology Conference (HISTELCON)
abstract: Norway was an early participant in what later became the Internet, establishing a digital connection to the USA as early as 1970. This paper explores the evolution of the next generation internet and IPv6 in Norway, detailing milestones, early adoption efforts, and challenges in deployment. It highlights significant projects such as 6bone, the Norwegian Internet2 initiative, and WEMAN (Wireless Experimental Metropolitan Area Network), which provided insights into IPv6 mobility, wireless networking, and long-distance connectivity. Additionally, we examine the impact of network architecture shifts on adoption rates. Despite the official launch of “Internett2” in 1998, IPv6 has yet to replace the 40+ year-old IPv4 protocol as of 2025, reflecting the complexity of transitioning to a next-generation Internet. Norway's case highlights the intersection of technological progress, policy intervention, and industry adaptation, offering valuable lessons for future Internet evolution.

title: Real-Time Evaluation of Client-Side DTLN Noise Suppression for WebRTC in Diverse Noise Environments
authors: Meyti Eka Apriyani, Moch. Nadi Rafli Maulana, Elok Nur Hamdana
publish: 2025 8th International Conference of Computer and Informatics Engineering (IC2IE)
abstract: WebRTC-based real-time communication is highly vulnerable to background noise, which negatively affects both perceptual speech quality and intelligibility. Traditional suppression techniques, such as spectral subtraction and Wiener filtering, are computationally efficient but perform poorly in non-stationary environments. To address this gap, this paper proposes a client-side implementation of the Dual-Signal Transformation LSTM Network (DTLN) within a WebRTC framework. Unlike previous server-side or offline approaches, the system is deployed entirely in the browser using ONNX Runtime-Web and Web Workers, ensuring low-latency and privacy-preserving processing. The novelty of this work lies in its real-time, browser-based, and multilingual evaluation, covering English and Indonesian datasets. The system was tested across 1,360 audio mixtures combining clean speech with 17 noise types from six categories and four SNR levels. Results demonstrated significant improvements in perceptual quality (average PESQ = 1.656), particularly in stationary noise such as transportation (PESQ = 1.877), while intelligibility gains were more modest (average STOI = 0.537). Statistical analysis confirmed the significance of improvements, and a small-scale Mean Opinion Score (MOS) test with bilingual listeners validated perceptual quality results. These findings underscore the potential of browser-based noise suppression while highlighting current limitations and avenues for improvement through hybrid architectures and multilingual optimization.

title: Interval Type-2 Fuzzy SEIR Modeling of COVID-19 with Virus-Load-Driven Parameters and Control Measures
authors: Matin Vesaltalab, Iman Zamani
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Control, Instrumentation and Automation (ICCIA)
abstract: This paper presents an Interval Type-2 Fuzzy SEIR (Susceptible-Exposed-Infected-Recovered) model for analyzing the dynamics of COVID-19 transmission under uncertainty. Unlike traditional SEIR models, the proposed approach integrates virus-load-driven fuzzy parameters, where infection, recovery, mortality, and latent rates vary with viral load and control measures such as treatment, vaccination, and health protocols. To handle the uncertainty in parameter estimation, an Interval Type-2 Fuzzy Logic System (IT2FLS) is implemented, and the Karnik-Mendel (KM) algorithm is employed for defuzzification. The basic reproduction number (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\Re_{0}$</tex>) is computed as an interval [LMF, UMF] and analyzed for system stability under different scenarios. Extensive simulations are conducted for multiple values of viral load and control parameters, demonstrating that the proposed IT2FLS-based SEIR model provides more robust predictions compared to Type-1 fuzzy and crisp models. The results highlight the effectiveness of interval Type- 2 fuzzy modeling in epidemic forecasting and decision-making under high uncertainty.

title: Adaptive Optimal Impedance Control of Reconfigurable Robot System for Human-Robot Interaction
authors: Bo Dong, Yubo Zhang, Jingkai Liang, Zebin Ji, Bing Ma, Tianjiao An
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Control, Robotics and Cybernetics (CRC)
abstract: A technical challenge of modular and reconfigurable robots (MRRs) during human-robot interaction is associated with addressing optimal compensation for model uncertainties enhancing control precision and avoiding excessive interaction forces. In this paper, an impedance control strategy based on adaptive dynamic programming is presented to address torque sensorless MRRs in human-robot collaboration scenarios. A human motion intention recognition algorithm generates the desired trajectory for human-robot interaction, and neural networks approximate the cost function to derive the optimal control law. Via neural network compensation strategy, the optimal control problem is formulated as an optimal compensation issue of uncertainty. In the controller, impedance control is introduced to address the compliance issue during interaction. Interactive force compensation and impedance parameter adjustment address human-robot interaction control with precision and compliance. The asymptotic stability of the closed-loop MRR system is proved by using the Lyapunov theory. At last, experiments are performed to verify the effectiveness of the proposed method.

title: The Design and Implementation of a Mobile Dual-Arm Robot for Smart Kitchen Services
authors: Danqi Chen, Yong Zhang, Xintong Mu, Hao Liu
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Control, Robotics and Cybernetics (CRC)
abstract: To address the critical challenges faced by existing kitchen robots, such as poor adaptability to dynamic tasks, lack of multimodal perception, and insufficient multi-device coordination, this research proposes and implements a mobile dual-arm robot system specifically designed for smart kitchen environments. Its key contributions and validated capabilities are as follows: a customized dual-arm design optimized for spatial constraints in kitchen environments, a multi-modal gripper control system that enables high-precision adaptive manipulation in dynamic scenarios, and a scalable distributed architecture based on the "ROS + Arduino + CAN" heterogeneous communication protocol stack. Experimental results demonstrate the system’s capability to complete the entire operational process of “autonomous mapping→dynamic obstacle avoidance→precise grasping→cooperative placement” successfully, confirming its suitableility for kitchen service tasks. Additionally, this modular architecture lays a foundation for smart kitchen equipment ecosystems.

title: Multi-Level Process Mining Analysis of Congestive Heart Failure
authors: Riris Matua Lubis, Angelina Prima Kurniati, Adiwijaya
publish: 2025 8th International Conference of Computer and Informatics Engineering (IC2IE)
abstract: Congestive Heart Failure (CHF) represents one of the most costly and complex chronic diseases, posing major challenges for healthcare systems such as Indonesia’s Social Security Agency for Health. Most existing studies model CHF care processes at a single ICD-10 level, which often oversimplifies patient pathways and overlooks important clinical and operational variations. To address this gap, this study applies a multi-level process mining approach to analyze CHF patient care flows at the Chapter, Group, and Specific Code levels of ICD-10 using Social Security Agency for Health event log data from 2015–2018. By employing the Inductive Miner algorithm, the study demonstrates that different abstraction levels yield varying model quality and identifies the most optimal level for balancing accuracy and interpretability. The findings provide new insights into how multi-level modeling can capture the complexity of CHF care pathways, offering evidence-based recommendations to improve service efficiency and support healthcare policy within the JKN-KIS framework.

title: Analysis of Intense Flash Flood Events from a Convective Tropical Thunderstorm
authors: Harry Sucitra Roslan, Mohd Riduan Ahmad, Nor Azlan Mohd Aris, Muhammad Haziq Mohammad Sabri, Muhammad Zuhair Bolqiah Edris, Ahmad Rifhan Salman, Ho Yih Hwa, Yuji Takayanagi, Takeshi Morimoto, Zen-Ichiro Kawasaki
publish: 2025 IEEE International RF and Microwave Conference (RFM)
abstract: Flash floods are a frequent and destructive natural hazard in Malaysia, often associated with intense convective thunderstorms. This study investigates the relationship between lightning activity, rainfall intensity, and cloud top height (CTH) during a significant flash flood event in Malacca on November 29, 2024. Flash floods were reported at 23 sites across three districts, triggered by prolonged heavy rainfall exceeding <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$20 ~\text{mm} / \mathrm{h}$</tex> for over one hour. Lightning observations, conducted using a Fast Antenna (FA) system, revealed 33 flashes, including 10 negative cloud-to-ground, 3 positive cloud-to-ground, and 20 intracloud flashes, indicative of strong updrafts within the storm. Radar data from CAPPI showed persistent rainfall intensity, while Himawari-8 infrared satellite imagery confirmed consistently high CTH values between 14 and 18 km, signifying robust deep convection. These findings underscore the importance of monitoring lightning activity, precipitation rates, and CTH to improve flash flood forecasting and early warning systems. The study highlights the integration of lightning data into predictive models as a critical tool for mitigating flash flood impacts in tropical regions.

title: A Multi-Platform System for Monitoring Military Training Cycles
authors: Roger C. Primo, Vladimir Y. Mariano, Mideth B. Abisado
publish: 2025 IEEE 15th International Conference on System Engineering and Technology (ICSET)
abstract: Training is the backbone of military readiness. For the Armed Forces of the Philippines (AFP), particularly under the Training and Doctrine Command (TRADOC), preparing soldiers to be skilled, adaptable, and mission-ready is vital. Yet, current monitoring practices still rely on paper records, and scattered spreadsheets. These gaps make it difficult to track individual progress, plan future programs, and ensure units are fully prepared for mobilization. This paper proposes A Multi-Platform System for Monitoring Military Training Cycles, a web and mobile solution designed to centralize and streamline training records. The system will feature real-time reporting, automated notifications, certificate validation, and customizable dashboards, all while following TRADOC standards and safeguarding data privacy. More than just a record-keeping tool, it aims to empower commanders with accurate insights for decision-making and help soldiers take ownership of their career development. The study uses a mixed-method approach and the Rapid Application Development (RAD) model, ensuring continuous feedback from users through surveys, interviews, and pilot testing. By bridging technological innovation with the unique needs of the AFP, the proposed system supports the military's modernization efforts and strengthens readiness. Ultimately, it seeks to build a more efficient, accountable, and future-ready defense force.

title: High-Resolution Ultra-Wideband Lightning Observation and Real-Time 3D Imaging Project in Malaysia
authors: Takeshi Morimoto, Yuji Takayanagi, Muhammad Haziq Mohammad Sabri, Manabu Akita, Mohd Riduan Ahmad, Farah Hani Nordin, Mohd Zafri Baharuddin
publish: 2025 IEEE International RF and Microwave Conference (RFM)
abstract: This paper presents an overview of an international collaborative project aimed at advancing lightning science and technology in Malaysia. The project focuses on the development of a high-resolution, real-time lightning observation network and a forecasting system for mitigating lightning-related risks. The research addresses fundamental unresolved aspects of lightning, such as the mechanisms of its initiation and the dynamics of charge distribution within thunderclouds. The project utilizes a combination of Ultrawideband radio receivers to create a comprehensive observation network in the coastal area of the Straits of Malacca in Malaysia. This research project mainly consists of to establish the world's highest lightning observation network and estimation of charge structure in thundercloud. Measurements of radio waves in various frequency bands and high-energy radiations. A novel 3D model for estimating charge distributions inside thunderclouds is developed. The real-time imaging will be used to create a nowcasting system. This predictive capability is being integrated into social implementation products to enhance the resilience of energy infrastructure and provide early warnings for severe weather events.

title: An Efficient Finite Element Domain Decomposition Algorithm for Complex Electromagnetic Calculations
authors: Zhicheng Ye, Yanghui Pu, Qi Zhang, Ting Wan
publish: 2025 18th IEEE United Conference on Millimeter Waves and Terahertz Technologies (UCMMT)
abstract: This article introduces an electromagnetic calculation method based on the finite element domain decomposition method. Compared with the traditional finite element method, this approach enables parallel computing using different subdomains, which significantly enhances the computational efficiency. An example of microstrip patch antenna array was introduced and compared with the simulation software results, thereby verifying the feasibility of the method.

title: A Compact Horizontally Polarized Bidirectional Antenna for Wi-Fi Applications
authors: Zheng Qu, Lei Guo
publish: 2025 18th IEEE United Conference on Millimeter Waves and Terahertz Technologies (UCMMT)
abstract: This paper presents a compact, horizontally polarized bidirectional antenna designed for enhanced coverage in WiFi applications. By geometrically compressing and modifying the current distribution of a traditional Alford loop, a compact bidirectional radiation pattern is achieved. The proposed antenna operates over a measured impedance bandwidth of 4.92 - 5.62 GHz (13.3 %) and delivers a peak gain of 4.8 dBi in both directions. The simulated and measured results are in agreement, confirming the effectiveness of the design in achieving compact size, high gain, and stable bidirectional radiation. These features make the antenna a good candidate for integration into modern indoor wireless communication systems.

title: Development of a Lightweight Spatio-Temporal Attention Network for Visual Speech Recognition
authors: Teerapong Ngampromwong, Luepol Pipanmekaporn, Kanabadee Srisomboon, Wilaiporn Lee, Akara Prayote
publish: 2025 Research, Invention, and Innovation Congress: Innovative Electricals and Electronics (RI2C)
abstract: Visual speech recognition (VSR) aims to translate silent lip movements into spoken words. Although various approaches have been proposed to enhance accurate VSR systems, two major challenges hinder their extensive practical use. Firstly, deep learning-based VSR models often rely on complex network architectures, resulting in substantial computational and memory demands, which lead to prolong processing times. Secondly, the presence of lip-movement homophones, where distinct words exhibit similar visual lip patterns, may result in misclassifications. To address these issues, this study presents an innovative lightweight VSR model designed to balance between recognition accuracy and computational efficiency. The proposed model employs a 3D Convolutional Neural Network (3D CNN) for capturing short-term spatio-temporal features, followed by a sequence of lightweight residual blocks inspired by ResNet to enhance spatial representation. We incorporate stacked Bidirectional Gated Recurrent Units (GRUs) to capture the temporal dynamics of lip movements across video frames, while an attention-based aggregation mechanism selectively emphasizes the most informative temporal features. This hybrid design substantially reduces the number of parameters and inference time with competitive performance. Experiments conducted on two challenging subsets derived from the LRW dataset demonstrate that the proposed model achieves top accuracy scores of 84% and 74%, respectively, comparable to baseline models.

title: The Effect of Noise Removal on Enhancing Sentiment Analysis Performance Using NaïVe Bayes and SVM Methods
authors: I Gusti Agung Gede Arya Kadyanan, Ni Made Ary Esta Dewi Wirastuti, Gede Sukadarmika, Ngurah Agus Sanjaya ER, I Wayan Trisna Wahyudi
publish: 2025 International Conference on Smart-Green Technology in Electrical and Information Systems (ICSGTEIS)
abstract: This study investigates the impact of noise removal on the performance enhancement of text document retrieval analysis using Naïve Bayes and Support Vector Machine (SVM) methods. In the current digital era, text processing particularly sentiment analysis and information retrieval has become a vital tool for extracting meaningful insights from user-generated content such as online reviews. However, such textual data often contains various forms of noise, including spelling errors, informal language, emojis, and excessive punctuation, which can negatively affect the performance of sentiment classification models. To address this issue, we apply noise removal techniques as a preprocessing step and evaluate their influence on the classification performance of Naïve Bayes and SVM algorithms. The dataset used in this study consists of 46,652 annotated text documents labeled with sentiment categories (positive, negative). We conduct experiments by training and testing both models on two versions of the dataset: with noise (raw text) and without noise (cleaned text). The total data collected was 5,309 reviews for Ruangguru, 4,597 reviews for Halodoc, and 36,746 reviews for Maxim. From the average results show a notable improvement in all metrics after applying noise removal. For Naïve Bayes, the accuracy increased from 89.01 % to 89.726 %, precision from 89.12 % to 89.83 %, recall from 89.01 % to 89.726 %, and F1-score from 89 % to 89.72 %. Similarly, the SVM model showed an accuracy improvement from 89.73 % to 89.96 %, precision from 89.88% to 90.06 %, recall from 89.73 % to 89.96 %, and F1-score from 89.72 % to 89.95 %. These findings demonstrate that noise removal significantly enhances the performance of sentiment analysis systems, particularly when combined with robust machine learning algorithms. This study emphasizes the importance of data preprocessing in improving the effectiveness and reliability of text-based classification tasks in natural language processing.

title: Wideband High Efficiency Extended Continuous Power Amplifier Using a Novel Matching Network
authors: Minshi Jia, Haoming Yan, Zhiqun Cheng, Zhigang Zhou, Hang Li, Zheyi Xiong
publish: 2025 18th IEEE United Conference on Millimeter Waves and Terahertz Technologies (UCMMT)
abstract: In this paper, we propose a novel matching network for designing high efficiency broadband harmonic-controlled power amplifiers (PAs). This network structure is composed of a pair of sectorial microstrip lines and four parallel open circuit microstrip lines (POCML). Each POCML corresponding to a quarter of wavelength for different frequencies. This structure can through improve the out-of-band suppression effect to improve the efficiency and bandwidth. A highly efficient PA with more than an octave bandwidth is used to verify the validity of the proposed networks using a 10W GaN HEMT device. The results show that the 39.8-42.5 dBm output power (Pout), <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$59.7 \%-78.6 \%$</tex> drain efficiency (DE), and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$1 0. 8 - 1 3. 5 ~ d B$</tex> gain are achieved at <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$0. 5 - 2. 5 ~ G H z$</tex>.

title: Design of Broadband Backscatter Amplifier for Long-Range Sensor Tag Applications
authors: Lei Guo, Ruixu Hu, Peng Chu, Ke Wu
publish: 2025 18th IEEE United Conference on Millimeter Waves and Terahertz Technologies (UCMMT)
abstract: Backscatter communication enables ultra low-power consumption communication for Internet of Things applications. In this letter, a broadband backscatter amplifier circuit is proposed based on the negative differential resistance characteristic of tunnel diodes for backscatter communication. Based on a high-stage low-pass topology, a broadband impedance bandwidth exceeding 50% is achieved. The proposed broadband backscatter amplifier can amplifier low-power RF signal in the designed frequency band with a low power consumption of only 0.48 mW. The proposed amplifier circuit is successfully demonstrated in a RFID sensor tag, with a communication range of 20 meters, under a sensitivity of -90 dBm. The sensor tag shows significant potential in wireless nodes for IoT applications.

title: Task offloading in UAV-IoT using Multi-Objective Exponential Weighted Olympic Champion Algorithm
authors: Anand R Umarji, Dharamendra Chouhan
publish: 2025 5th Asian Conference on Innovation in Technology (ASIANCON)
abstract: Unmanned Aerial Vehicles (UAVs) are resource-constrained devices, which play a prime role in civilian and military applications. Owing to the development of UAV-Internet of Things (UAV-IoT) networks, effective task offloading is needed to increase performance, minimize latency, and prolong the system lifetime. Furthermore, task offloading mechanisms are required to provide reliability as well the scalability in UAV-assisted IoT deployments. Still, the task offloading in UAV-IoT is complex, because the networks are operated in unpredictable and dynamic environments with varied network conditions, workloads, and mobility. For solving such issues, this article develops the Exponential Weighted Olympic Champion Algorithm (EWOCA) with multi-objective fitness parameters for task offloading in UAV-IoT. Initially, the UAV-IoT is simulated, and the task computation is carried out. Following that, the tasks are uploaded, and then the task offloading is done by the EWOCA with multi-objective parameters like load, energy, time, and cost. The effectiveness of EWOCA-based task offloading in UAV-IoT is validated by considering metrics like energy, time, and load. Moreover, the developed model attains better residual energy, time, and load of 0.513J, 0.657s, and 0.105.

title: A Data-Driven Framework for Disease Detection using Medical Imaging Analysis
authors: Sunil Kr Pandey, Sivaneasan Bala Krishnan, Udit Mamodiya, Prasun Chakrabarti
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Innovative Data Communication Technologies and Application (ICIDCA)
abstract: The exponential growth of digital medical imaging, coupled with the demand for timely and reliable diagnosis, has intensified the need for intelligent, interpretable decision-support systems in clinical radiology. Traditional deep learning models, although accurate in controlled settings, frequently lack adaptability, transparency, and robustness when deployed across heterogeneous, real-world medical datasets. This study addresses these limitations by introducing a multimodal, self-supervised framework that fuses image-based representations with structured clinical metadata. Leveraging a hybrid CNN–Vision Transformer (ViT) backbone, the architecture is designed to extract both fine-grained spatial cues and global contextual semantics. Integrated attention-based explainability mechanisms and fairness-aware optimization modules further enhance clinical interpretability and demographic generalization. Experimental evaluation across ChestX-ray14, BraTS 2021, and ISIC 2019 datasets demonstrates superior classification performance, with AUC-ROC scores consistently exceeding 0.92 and F1 scores reaching up to 0.92. The inclusion of metadata and self-supervised pretraining contributed to measurable gains in both accuracy and model stability under limited supervision. This research offers a reproducible, scalable, and clinically-relevant foundation for AI-assisted diagnostics, paving the way for transparent, equitable deployment of medical imaging systems in diverse healthcare settings.

title: Dual Vision Transformer Integration for Race and Gender Recognition Based on Facial Images
authors: Rezky Arisanti Putri, Lilik Anifah, Ricky Eka Putra, Yuni Yamasari, Rafy Aulia Akbar
publish: 2025 Eight International Conference on Vocational Education and Electrical Engineering (ICVEE)
abstract: Race and gender recognition based on facial images is a part of soft biometrics that has wide applications in identification systems. However, challenges such as dataset bias, variation in expression, pose, and inconsistent race definition remain major obstacles. In this study, the authors propose the integration of two Vision Transformer (ViT) models to improve the accuracy of race and gender classification. The first model, ViT-Face, is trained on the VGGFace2 dataset to extract static facial structure features, while the second model, ViT-Emotion, is trained on the FER-2013 dataset to capture dynamic features of facial expressions. Features from both models are combined and classified using Support Vector Machine (SVM) with parameter optimization through grid search. The dataset used is DemogPairs with 10,800 face images in six balanced classes. The experimental results show that the combination of features from ViT-Face and ViT-Emotion gives the best performance with an accuracy of 0.92, a precision of 0.92, a recall of 0.92, an F1-Score of 0.92, and an ROC AUC of 0.9948. This multi-domain feature integration has proven to be more effective than using a single feature. This approach opens up opportunities for developing smarter, fairer, and more inclusive face-based identification systems. In addition to accuracy, this study also highlights fairness across demographic subgroups and discusses ethical implications of AI-driven demographic classification, ensuring the system is more inclusive and responsible.

title: Stress Classification using Vanilla Transformer Encoder on Multi-Channel Physiological Sensor Time Series
authors: Sivashanmugam Thangavel, S Sujatha, R. Jagadeesh Kannan, Bhanumathi M, K Sasikala, Akash P
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Innovative Data Communication Technologies and Application (ICIDCA)
abstract: The study introduces an effective stress classification framework using the Vanilla Transformer encoder architecture to examine multi-channel physiological sensor time series data. The method is designed to tackle the issue of real-time psychological stress identification using continuous, multimodal bio signals obtained from wearable sensors. The WESAD dataset serves as the principal source of physiological recordings, including electrodermal activity, heart rate, respiration, accelerometer data, and skin temperature signals. The signals undergo preprocessing into time-synchronized segments, which are then input into a positional embedding module prior to classification using self-attention layers in the Transformer encoder. In contrast to traditional recurrent models, the attention-based approach in this architecture enables the model to dynamically concentrate on the most relevant temporal patterns related to stress reactions. The suggested technique attains a classification accuracy of 97.80 percent, with a precision of 95.88 percent, a recall of 93 percent, and an F1-score of 94.42 percent. The findings underscore the Transformer model's potential to discern subtle physiological differences and enhance multi-class stress detection, facilitating the development of adaptive, individualized mental health monitoring systems in wearable and edge computing contexts.

title: Intelligent Battery Health Monitoring System for Optimizing Uninterruptible Power Supply
authors: Safira Firdaus Mujiyanti, Amelia Rizqi Nur Aida, Akhmad Ibnu Hija, I Putu Eka Widya Pratama, Murry Raditya, Yus Putri Arum Segar
publish: 2025 Eight International Conference on Vocational Education and Electrical Engineering (ICVEE)
abstract: Sudden power outages can damage electronic devices and disrupt operations. To mitigate this, an Uninterruptible Power Supply (UPS) system is commonly used to provide backup power. However, the health and performance of the UPS battery can degrade without proper monitoring and control. This study presents the development of an intelligent battery health monitoring system integrated with the Internet of Things (IoT) to optimize UPS performance. The system monitors real-time battery parameters including voltage, current, temperature, State of Charge (SoC), and State of Health (SoH), while also performing automatic control during charging and discharging processes. SoC estimation is conducted using a combination of Open Circuit Voltage (OCV) and Coulomb Counting methods. The system is built using INA219 current sensors, a DS18B20 temperature sensor, an Arduino Uno, and ESP32 for wireless data transmission to a smartphone application. Data is also stored in Firebase for remote access and record-keeping. Experimental results show the system functions effectively with sensor accuracies above 97%. The battery, rated at 7.5 Ah, sustained a 5 W load for 23 hours and 30 minutes from 90% to 20% SoC, and required 2 hours and 47 minutes to recharge from 35.84% to 90% SoC. The calculated SoH of 95% indicates that the battery remains in excellent condition, ensuring UPS reliability and efficiency.

title: EmotiCare: An Emotion-Aware Conversational Agent for Mental Health Support
authors: Mary Valentina Janet A, Alexander R, G. Brindha
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Innovative Data Communication Technologies and Application (ICIDCA)
abstract: The rise of mental health problems around the world demands intelligent digital interventions that are also privacy-preserving. Traditional chatbots are thus often limited by rule-based logic and shallow sentiment mapping, failing to stay contextually sensitive in their tracking of emotions. EmotiCare is an AI agent with multi-component functionality for mental health support that combines all three elements of real-time multi-label emotion classification, empathetic dialogue generation, and long-term mood tracking with LLMs. Some important features include SQLite-based emotion logging, spontaneous dynamic coping responses, and emergency guardian alerts in severe cases. The system is designed to combine local inference with ethical design, achieving personalization, privacy, and scalability. All evaluation metrics, such as precision, recall, F1-score, accuracy, hamming loss, confusion matrix, and ROC-AUC, indicate more than 95% accuracy on a 27-emotion classification task with only a minimal amount of misclassification. The system addresses ambiguities in input, invokes user trust, and manifests highly human-like empathy. The comparison conducted confirms that the approach stands superior to the existing set of models in creating a sustainable and proactive paradigm for mental health intervention.
