title: Empowering Sustainable Education Through Competency Pattern Mining in Instructional Website Design
authors: Yeni Anistyasari, Shintami C Hidayati, Ekohariadi
publish: 2025 Eight International Conference on Vocational Education and Electrical Engineering (ICVEE)
abstract: This study explores student competency patterns in instructional website design to support sustainable educational practices. Employing a mixed-methods approach, data were gathered from 98 undergraduate students enrolled in educational technology courses at a university in Indonesia. Competencies were evaluated through Likert-scale questionnaires addressing pedagogical, technological, managerial, and ethical aspects, supplemented by open-ended reflective questions. Hierarchical clustering analysis revealed three distinct competency groups: low, moderate, and high. Additionally, students' reflective writings were assessed based on their relevance, completeness, and elaboration. Findings demonstrated that students in the high-competency group produced richer and more thoughtful reflections compared to their peers. However, correlational analyses indicated only a weak relationship between self-perceived competencies and reflective skills. These results suggest varying levels of readiness among students. Lecturers are therefore encouraged to tailor instructional strategies accordingly, while institutions can leverage these insights to design targeted student development programs. Overall, the study offers essential groundwork for fostering adaptive, data-informed, and sustainable education practices.

title: Comparative Clustering of Earthquake Data in Central Java Using DBSCAN, HDBSCAN, STDBSCAN, and Fuzzy C-Means
authors: Irma Kurniawati, M. Aryono Adhi, Supriadi, Sulhadi, Hanifullah Hafidz Arriza, Marzuki Sinambela
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electronic and Electrical Engineering and Intelligent System (ICE3IS)
abstract: Accurate identification of earthquake clusters is essential for understanding seismic behavior and improving hazard mitigation strategies in tectonically complex regions. While clustering algorithms have been widely applied to seismic data, few studies have conducted a comprehensive comparison of multiple methods in Central Java—a region with overlapping fault zones and heterogeneous seismic activity. This study addresses that gap by evaluating four clustering techniques: Density-Based Spatial Clustering of Applications with Noise (DBSCAN), Hierarchical DBSCAN (HDBSCAN), Spatio-Temporal DBSCAN (ST-DBSCAN), and Fuzzy C-Means (FCM). A dataset comprising 3,175 earthquake events from 2009 to 2023 was sourced from Indonesia’s Meteorological, Climatological, and Geophysical Agency (BMKG). Standard preprocessing and grid search optimization were applied to tune parameters consistently across all models. Clustering quality was assessed using Silhouette Score, Calinski-Harabasz Index, and Davies-Bouldin Index. DBSCAN produced the most compact and well-separated clusters (Silhouette $=0.82; \mathbf{C H}=$ 1828.66; $\mathrm{DB}=0.28$) but excluded 96.47% of events as noise. HDBSCAN achieved broader spatial coverage with minimal noise, while ST-DBSCAN effectively captured short-term temporal swarms, and FCM modeled overlapping tectonic boundaries. Although no single method proved universally optimal, DBSCAN emerged as the most precise in isolating dominant seismic features. A hybrid approach is recommended to balance spatial compactness with data inclusivity, supporting more robust seismic hazard mapping in complex regions like Central Java.

title: A Proposal of SQL Query Description Problem in SQL Programming Learning Assistant System
authors: Ni Wayan Wardani, Nobuo Funabiki, Htoo Htoo Sandi Kyaw, Putu Sugiartawan, I Nyoman Agus Suarya Putra
publish: 2025 Eight International Conference on Vocational Education and Electrical Engineering (ICVEE)
abstract: Nowadays, SQL (Structured Query Language) is widely taught in universities and professional schools worldwide. SQL is a powerful domain-specific language designed for managing and querying relational databases. Previously, we have developed the Programming Learning Assistant System (PLAS) to support self-study of popular programming languages by novice students. PLAS offers various exercises at different learning levels, including the Grammar-Concept Understanding Problem (GUP), the Comment Insertion Problem (CIP), and the SQL Syntax Description Problem (SSDP). In this paper, we introduce a new exercise called the SQL Query Description Problem (SDP) for studying basic SQL queries in database programming. An SDP instance consists of a series of questions and a database table, where each question requires a simple SQL query based on the table. Any student answer is checked through string matching with the correct one. For evaluations, we prepared 19 SDP instances on fundamental SQL queries, and assigned them to 32 undergraduate students at the Indonesian Institute of Business and Technology (INSTIKI) enrolled in the database programming course. Their solution results and System Usability Scale (SUS) scores from the usability questionnaire confirmed the effectiveness of the proposed approach.

title: Hypersensifit: A Mobile-based Application for Hypertension Prediction and Diet Plans using K-Nearest Neighbor Algorithm
authors: Reymon M. Santiañez, Drake R. Carcellar, Michelle D. Almen, Karen M. Gervacio, Hannah Joy O. Hotricano
publish: 2025 Eight International Conference on Vocational Education and Electrical Engineering (ICVEE)
abstract: The rapid advancement of digital tools and applications has accelerated the growth of health information technology, which plays a vital role in addressing global health challenges. In the Philippines, hypertension remains one of the leading causes of death, highlighting the need for accessible and innovative solutions to support prevention and management. This study aimed to develop HyperSensiFit, a mobile application designed to predict the risk of hypertension and provide dietary guidance. The application collects and analyzes key health indicators, including age, blood pressure, cholesterol, and other medical attributes. To build its predictive model, the dataset was preprocessed through training, balancing, and the removal of null values to enhance accuracy. The prediction model employs the K-Nearest Neighbor (KNN) algorithm, a simple yet effective classification method widely used in medical predictions. Through experimentation, the optimal K-value was determined to be 13 using the elbow method, achieving an accuracy rate of 85.76% with a balanced trade-off between accuracy and recall. Findings demonstrate that HyperSensiFit offers a reliable tool for assessing hypertension risk. The application has the potential to assist both patients and healthcare professionals by supporting early intervention, guiding lifestyle adjustments, and improving the overall management of hypertension.

title: Performance Analysis of Aphid Infestation Disease Detection in Plants
authors: Shivangi, Pramod S. Nair
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Advances in Computing Research On Science Engineering and Technology (ACROSET)
abstract: Crop health and output are severely compromised by plant stem infections, which can cause a broad variety of symptoms. Aphid infestation, a prevalent and detrimental condition produced by tiny sap-sucking insects, is the primary subject of this research, which examines several kinds of stem infections in plants. Several ML models, such as Random Forest, Support Vector Machine (SVM), Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs), and gradient boosting approaches, were tested using image data of sick plant stems. The outcome demonstrates that CNNs, especially with transfer learning (e.g., ResNet-50), perform better than other models in diagnosing stem illnesses connected to aphids, using measures like accuracy, precision, recall, and F1 score. The deep learning’s application is to automate and improve plant disease diagnostics is highlighted in this article.

title: Forecasting Stock Prices with Sequential Deep Learning: A Long Short-Term Memory Approach
authors: Ervin Yohannes, Aldin Febriansyah, Nisa Dwi Septiyanti, Suparji, Agus Wiyono, Aries Dwi Indriyanti, Fitri Utaminingrum, Chih-Yang Lin, Kahlil Muchtar, Avirmed Enkhbat
publish: 2025 Eight International Conference on Vocational Education and Electrical Engineering (ICVEE)
abstract: Investors often face significant challenges in predicting fluctuating stock price movements, which can lead to uncertainty and suboptimal investment decisions. This study aims to evaluate the performance of the Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) deep learning model in forecasting stock prices. The dataset utilized is derived from the Pakistan Stock Exchange (KSE 100), and the model’s performance is assessed using evaluation metrics including Mean Absolute Error (MAE), Mean Squared Error (MSE), Root Mean Squared Error (RMSE), and Mean Absolute Percentage Error (MAPE). The experimental results demonstrate that the LSTM model achieves strong predictive performance, with the lowest recorded MSE of 0.0004, RMSE of 0.0210, MAE of 0.0141, and MAPE of 0.0209, corresponding to an accuracy rate of 97.91%. These findings highlight the effectiveness of the LSTM model in stock price prediction and provide valuable insights for investors seeking to enhance decision-making through data-driven forecasting approaches.

title: Real-Time Recognition of ASL Alphabets Using MediaPipe Hand Landmarks on Raspberry Pi 5
authors: Erika Loniza, Hanifah Rahmi Fajrin, Usman Umar, Zulkarnay Bin Zakaria, Muhammad Dimas Adhitya, Afif Pranaditya
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electronic and Electrical Engineering and Intelligent System (ICE3IS)
abstract: Deaf individuals frequently encounter communication barriers because of their limited hearing capacity, particularly at hearing levels below 20 dB. Interaction between the public and deaf individuals is restricted since not all individuals comprehend sign language. The objective of this research is to create a learning and communication tool that can identify the letters of the American Sign Language (ASL) alphabet and present them as letters on a screen. The system employs a camera to capture real-time hand images, which are subsequently processed by a Raspberry Pi 5. The MediaPipe library is employed to identify 21 landmark points on the hand during the processing procedure. The input vectors for a classification model that has been trained using an artificial neural network are the coordinates of these points. The system achieved an average accuracy rate of 97.2% in recognizing the majority of the ASL letters, as indicated by the test results. The letters M, R, and U exhibited lesser success rates, while a total of 23 out of 26 letters were recognized with 100% accuracy. The results of this study indicate that the system has significant potential as an adaptive educational and communicative solution. It has the potential to enhance the quality of life and accessibility of deaf individuals by adopting a more inclusive approach to non-verbal communication.

title: Object Identification for Sequence Diagram based on Use Case Scenario using Text Semantic: Case Study of IdVar4CL Artefact
authors: Moch. Alif Rachmanda, Yudi Priyadi, M. Faris Fathoni
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electronic and Electrical Engineering and Intelligent System (ICE3IS)
abstract: Inconsistencies in the creation of Unified Modeling Language (UML) artifacts occur due to differences in interpretation by each individual. These differences may arise because each individual has a different understanding of the causes and effects in an environment/system, influenced by experience, learning process, insight, intuition, and assumptions. In the process of identifying variables in a case study called IdVar4VL, there is an inconsistency between the artifacts, making this case an example of implementation in identifying UML artifacts for conformity. Our research aims to identify objects derived from all Use Case Scenario tabulations, and then use the resulting objects for the Sequence Diagram. This research has implemented stages to identify objects that produce datasets in the form of Use Case Diagrams consisting of 3 actors. The Use Case Scenario tabulation produces 10 Step-Perform documents, namely d2 to d11. After all stages are completed, this research produces an alternative dataset for UCD in the form of OCR text document, forming object tabulations based on 10 Step-Performs from 10 UCS and making improvement recommendations for Step-Performs in UCS artifacts. Additionally, the validity and reliability of the generated object tabulation against the Step-Performed score is 0.23, calculated using Gwet’s AC1 formula. The resulting scores fall into the “Fair Agreement” category based on Gwet’s AC1 index, making the generated object tabulation a reference for forming a complete Sequence Diagram.

title: Bridging Clinical Expertise and AI: Deep Learning for Automated Knee Osteoarthritis Diagnosis
authors: Ishani Rana, Narinder Kaur, Bhuvneshwari, Sonia F Panesar, Prabhneet Singh, Ajeet Kumar
publish: 2025 5th Asian Conference on Innovation in Technology (ASIANCON)
abstract: Knee osteoarthritis affects the knee sections, and its severity gets worse over the course of 10 to 15 years. Knee osteoarthritis makes it tougher for older people to stay active and do what they need to do. The skill level of doctors has a big effect on how they analyze visual exams. Finding problems early on requires methods that provide quick operation and accurate detection while yet being cost- effective. Deep learning (DL) uses convolutional neural networks (CNN) to find the best way to diagnose knee osteoarthritis. Convolutional neural networks need a lot of input data to learn. An automated X-ray analysis that uses deep learning technology makes it easier to extract features and shortens the time it takes to train models. Researchers have found that a deep learning system that uses a trained VGG16 network on five-class knee X-rays can use SoftMax to accurately tell the difference between normal, questionable, mild, moderate, and serious issues. Two deep convolutional neural networks (CNNs) are used by an automated system to grade patients with knee osteoarthritis (OA) using the Kellgren-Lawrence (KL) criteria. The study included 1650 different knee X-ray scans, which were split into two separate groups. The dataset has 514 normal cases, 477 questionable cases, 232 mild cases, 221 moderate cases, and 206 severe cases of knee osteoarthritis. The suggested model for finding knee osteoarthritis (OA) using X-ray radiographs has a classification accuracy of over 95%. The training results were 95% accurate, and the validation results were 87% accurate.

title: Integrated Recurrent Neural Network-Based Model Engineering (RNN-MBE) for Intelligent Systems
authors: Shweta Singh, Garima Mathur, Priyanka Singh, Siddharth Singh Parihar
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Advances in Computing Research On Science Engineering and Technology (ACROSET)
abstract: To tackle issues of resource provisioning and scheduling in IIoT applications in a cloud environment, this research proposes an integrated Recurrent Neural Network-Based Model-Based Engineering (RNN-MBE) framework. Based on modelling the observed data stream with the help of the Recurrent Neural Networks (RNNs), the presented method improves data collection, workload prognoses, and scheduling. RNN-MBE synergistically combines sensing, control, and data planes to co-optimize the task response time, energy consumption, and the viability of the Virtual Machine (VM). Based on experimental findings, RNN-MBE demonstrates a 40 percent make-span improvement, a 35 percent decrease in energy in comparison with baseline models (CNN-MBE and DNN-MBE). In addition, it showed a 50 percent reduction in the task response time. The architecture harmonizes IIoT data with cloud resources employing iterative optimizations and optimization and workload under various workloads. This mixed approach reveals the prospect of integrating deep learning signals with Model-Based Engineering of smart systems to advance IIoT, innovate production dependability and operational performance.

title: Phishing Detection with Adaptive Virus Colony Optimization-based Distributed Bidirectional Long Short-Term Memory enabled Artificial Neural Network
authors: Mohd Shoaib
publish: 2025 5th Asian Conference on Innovation in Technology (ASIANCON)
abstract: In this modern digital era, phishing attacks are a major threat to web users as online phishing attacks escalate the privacy credentials of the users, creating a vulnerable impact on internet users. The existing phishing detection models suffered from high false positive rates, data loss, high computational costs, malware infections, and identity theft. To address these challenges, a new Adaptive virus colony optimization-based Distributed Bidirectional Long Short-Term Memory enabled Artificial Neural Network (AdVCO-Di-BiLAN) model is developed that effectually identifies the malicious Uniform Resource Locator from long-range dependencies with the utilization of optimized feature selection method. In the proposed AdVCO-Di-BiLAN model, the AdVOC algorithm is designed for fine-tuning the Di-BiLAN model, where the AdVOC algorithm is designed based on the spreading and retrieving characters from the diverse environments that improve the convergence rate through minimizing the optimal problems. Meanwhile, the performance efficacy of the AdVCO-Di-BiLAN outperformed the conventional techniques with the positive predictive value (PPV), accuracy, and negative predictive value (NPV) of 0.982, 98.18%, and 0.977, separately.

title: Boosting LLM Performance on Boolean Questions with Cluster-Based Embeddings
authors: Aditya Narvekar, Trisha Mukherjee
publish: 2025 5th Asian Conference on Innovation in Technology (ASIANCON)
abstract: LLMs have demonstrated excellent performance with various tasks that require pattern recognition, language understanding and content generation. This study focuses on the ability of language models (small and large) to answer Boolean questions. This study demonstrates a technique to improve the performance of language models on Boolean type questions. This study outlines an innovative approach which generates clusters from the lower dimensional representation of the embeddings of questions in the BoolQ dataset. The learned embeddings are then added to the questions before being fed into GPT-4o (large model) and GPT-4o-mini (small). This technique leads to a significant improvement in performance of GTP-4o and GPT-4o-mini when the learned embeddings are injected in the context of Boolean questions.

title: AI-Powered Seed Viability Assessment in Hydroponic Systems: A Comparative Review of Computer Vision and Deep Learning Approaches
authors: Hemlata Parmar, Parth Gupta, Singh Manas Mukundkumar, Abhinav Mukherjee
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Advances in Computing Research On Science Engineering and Technology (ACROSET)
abstract: This review paper provides a comparative review of research studies that focused on AI computer vision models for the detection of ungerminated seeds in hydroponic systems. Hydroponic farming is becoming increasingly popular as operating a more sustainable form of agriculture unlike traditional farming practices; nevertheless, challenges remain for efficiency in resource use. The identification and early detection of non-viable saplings allows growers to utilize their water, nutrients, and energy for viable products while improving sustainability overall. This paper details the methods that were employed in studies found in recent literature which focused on CNNs, served with hyperspectral imaging, hybrid DL models, along with a comparison of performance metrics, dataset qualities and practical application. Furthermore, potential future research directions directed at continuing to enhance AI-based seed viability assessment and provide options for real-time decision making in this area are delivered.

title: Robust Adversarial Image Detection using Advanced Deep Learning Techniques: An Ensemble-based Approach
authors: S. Regilan, Sudha D, J. Vijay, D. Vasvini Mary, D. Kadhiravan, Jenitha J
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Innovative Data Communication Technologies and Application (ICIDCA)
abstract: Deep learning models are seriously threatened by adversarial attacks, which covertly alter input data to skew classification. By combining convolutional neural networks (CNNs), autoencoders, generative adversarial networks (GANs), and ensemble learning models, this study offers a sophisticated machine learning method for adversarial image detection. With an accuracy of 96.5%, the suggested ensemble model surpasses current techniques like Defense-GAN (94.7%), Bayesian Uncertainty Estimation (93.0%), Spectral Signatures (91.3%), Local Intrinsic Dimensionality (89.0%), and Feature Squeezing (85.2%). In addition, the ensemble model maintains the lowest false alarm rate of 0.03 and achieves precision of 0.96, recall of 0.95, and AUC-ROC of 0.97, greatly lowering the misclassification of clean images. FGSM, PGD, and DeepFool attacks were used to create adversarial examples, and statistical analysis, frequency domain transforms, and local intrinsic dimensionality were used as feature extraction methods for reliable detection. The suggested model's scalability and efficacy are demonstrated by its superior generalization across several datasets, such as MNIST, CIFAR-10, and ImageNet. Comparative research demonstrates that this method improves security in deep learning-based systems by offering a flexible and effective defense against hostile attacks. Future research will focus on adaptive learning and real-time implementation to continuously improve against changing adversarial tactics.

title: Surface Defect Inspection of Steel based on Improved YOLOv8
authors: Jin Yang, Haiming Li, Qiquan Wu
publish: 2025 10th International Seminar on Computer Technology, Mechanical and Electrical Engineering (ISCME)
abstract: Aiming at the problems of low detection accuracy and high missed detection rate in current steel surface defect algorithms, a model for steel surface defect detection based on YOLOv8n is proposed. The main improvement is to add CBAM attention mechanism in the feature extraction network to enhance the attention to important features, and replace the original loss function with EIOU loss function to further improve the accuracy of the model’s position prediction. Conduct experiments using the NEU-DET dataset released by Northeastern University. Experiments have shown that the improved YOLOv8n algorithm achieves an average detection mean of 85.3%, which is 9.7% higher than the original algorithm. The detection performance is also better than other mainstream detection models, making it more suitable for detecting surface defects in steel.

title: Continuous and Accurate Heart Attack Risk Assessment via a Real-Time Data Pipeline with Data Fusion and Spark-based Machine Learning
authors: Yasashwini Sai Gowri P, V. Divya, S. Saravanan
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Innovative Data Communication Technologies and Application (ICIDCA)
abstract: Cardiovascular disease remains one of the main reasons of death globally, highlighting the importance of early detection and continuous monitoring for dynamic risk changes. This paper presents a real-time heart attack risk prediction system designed to promptly, continuously, and accurately evaluate patient risk levels. The proposed system gathers data from multiple sources such as user inputs, laboratory reports, and real-time wearable sensor readings. Later, the proposed system analyzes critical health metrics such as blood pressure, heart rate, cholesterol levels, and lifestyle factors. The system is built on a robust big data infrastructure by utilizing Kafka for real-time data ingestion, Apache Spark Streaming for rapid data processing, MongoDB for secure and scalable storage, and Streamlit for visualizing patient risk patterns. The machine learning pipeline, developed with PySpark’s MLlib, involves feature transformation and the application of distributed Random Forest model. To tackle imbalance in dataset and prediction reliability, the Synthetic Minority Oversampling Technique (SMOTE) is employed in this work. Risk evaluations are performed every five minutes for approximately 2,000 patients with a final risk decision consolidated through majority voting after 12 prediction cycles (over one hour). The distributed Random Forest model achieved the highest accuracy by reaching 97.91% on the test set. High-risk patients receive immediate alerts to enable timely medical intervention and reducing the likelihood of severe cardiac events.

title: Research on Adaptive Grid-forming Strategy for Photovoltaic-storage system based on Model Predictive Control
authors: Tianchi Ding, Xiangxue Su, Yanzhao Chang, Jiannan He
publish: 2025 10th International Seminar on Computer Technology, Mechanical and Electrical Engineering (ISCME)
abstract: With the high-penetration development of renewable energy, virtual synchronous generator (VSG) control has been widely applied due to its advantages in providing grid-connected inverters with damping and inertia characteristics, thereby enhancing system inertial response. Existing common VSG grid-connected inverter controls have constant inertia and damping parameters, resulting in poor disturbance rejection capabilities when subjected to interference during operation. This paper proposes an adaptive grid-forming control strategy for photovoltaic-storage coordination based on Model Predictive Control (MPC) to enhance system frequency stability and improve the disturbance rejection capability of photovoltaic-storage systems. First, a grid-forming control method based on model predictive control is proposed, establishing a prediction model for the photovoltaic-storage system to achieve rapid response of the energy storage system to changes in photovoltaic output. Building on this foundation, an adaptive control algorithm for dynamic adjustment of inertia and damping parameters is introduced, leading to the development of a coordinated adaptive grid-forming control strategy for photovoltaic-storage systems. Finally, a simulation validation platform is built in MATLAB/Simulink, and experimental results verify the effectiveness of the proposed control strategy.

title: Intelligent diagnosis model for abnormal noise of power transformer based on multi-channel wavelet convolution
authors: Meng Gao, Ran Zhuo, Zengxin Pu, Fan Zhang, Deyuan Yu
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Mechatronics Technology (ICEEMT)
abstract: Abnormal acoustic signals from transformers can reflect mechanical and electrical defects. This paper proposes an intelligent diagnosis model for abnormal transformer acoustic signals by combining wavelet convolution with MobileNetV2. First, a set of time-frequency plots is constructed using learnable multicategory wavelet convolution. Parameter training is used to find the optimal frequency band parameters and extract the characteristics of the acoustic signal’s different frequency bands. Waveforms from different wavelet basis functions can also be used to extract different characteristics. Feature extraction and classification are then performed using the lightweight MobileNetV2 model, reducing hardware dependency and improving the model’s lightweight deployment capabilities. Experimental training was conducted using abnormal noise data collected from normal operation, DC bias, discharge, and winding deformation. Results show that the proposed model achieved an average accuracy of 97.64% and a maximum accuracy of 99.35% for abnormal noise recognition after 30 training rounds. This model also achieved a 10.7% improvement in training efficiency compared to traditional CNN models. Combined with the advantages of MobileV2’s lightweight deployment, it has significant application value in the field of intelligent diagnosis of abnormal transformer noise.

title: Reliability Characterization of Vacuum Printable Compound for SiP Encapsulation in Wireless Connectivity : USI Corporation
authors: Chao-Hsuan Wang, Li-Cheng Shen, Hung-Yi Tsai, Kuo-Hsien Liao, Chung-Ping Chang, Hsiu-Lieh Cheng, Ming-Hung Chang, Chung-Ping Chang, Tai-Lin Wu, Heng-Chang Wu, Ping-Chi Hong, Yu-Feng Hung
publish: 2025 20th International Microsystems, Packaging, Assembly and Circuits Technology Conference (IMPACT)
abstract: To achieve miniaturization in module level and board level, component pitch and terminals are getting finer, denser, and smaller, in which the solder joint are getting less to provide a reliable joint strength, thus encapsulation is required to protect the joint to achieve reliability requirement. As wireless products begin to adapt System in Package (SiP) product architecture which use different board material (substrate, substrate like and FR4), chip design and encapsulation methods (underfill, transfer molding and compression molding). To achieve products with high stability and reliability, where molded underfill (MUF) by transfer molding (T-Mold) or compression molding (C-Mold) has been recognized to provide robust reliability and miniaturization for high density and fine pitch components. Due to the high process temperature (175C) and high mold flow pressure (5~8Mpa), the thermal and mechanical stress is not only sever to sensitive component but also requires BT substrate as a MUST. Unfortunately, the lead-time and cost of BT substrate and the mold tools usually become a bump in the road to innovations, especially in emerging or hi-mix low-volume early applications.Therefore, we use VPE (low temperature and low pressure encapsulation method) with liquid printable compound can use on the FR4 PCB ; we select three wireless products with different module sizes and PCB structures (Substrate, substrate like and FR4) as test vehicles, and use printable compound for VPE; after completion, we conduct reliability test (MSL3 TCT) and function test (FCT) to analyze the performance of SiP modules, which can achieve the same performance as the original mold encapsulation method. It proves that vacuum printing encapsulation can provide a miniaturization competence of time-to-POC, time-to-delivery, time-to-quality, time-to-cost and consequently totally 12+ weeks quicker time-to-market than standard SiP with T-mold or C-mold from POC to production and keep same reliability level and pass FCT test.

title: Multi-fault diagnosis of lithium batteries based on GAF-CNN-OCSSA-LSSVM
authors: Wang Yi, Liao Li, Xingke Li, Quanxin Zheng
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Computer Information Technology (AICIT)
abstract: Accurate and rapid identification of various types of faults in lithium-ion battery packs is essential for the safe operation of electric vehicles. However, due to the high similarity in feature characteristics among different faults, misclassification remains a significant challenge. To address this issue, this paper proposes a novel multi-fault diagnosis strategy based on GAF-CNN-OCSSA-LSSVM. First, the original battery time-series signals are transformed into image representations using the Gramian Angular Field (GAF), preserving temporal correlations and key feature patterns. Then, a Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) is constructed to automatically extract deep image features. On this basis, an improved Chaos-enhanced Sparrow Search Algorithm (OCSSA) is employed to optimize the hyperparameters of the Least Squares Support Vector Machine (LSSVM) classifier, enabling better global optimization performance. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed method achieves high accuracy and robustness in the identification of multiple fault types in lithium-ion batteries, outperforming conventional feature extraction and classification approaches.

title: Development of High-temperature Lead-free solders: Zn-Sn-Al-Cu Based Alloy
authors: Yu-Sheng Chen, Ssu-Chen Pan, Siao-Wei Guo, Yee-Wen Yen
publish: 2025 20th International Microsystems, Packaging, Assembly and Circuits Technology Conference (IMPACT)
abstract: This study aims to develop high-temperature lead-free solder. This research uses Zn-Sn-Al-Cu as the primary solder components, adjusting their proportions to modify the characteristics of the solder alloy, such as its metallographic microstructure, solidification precipitation phases, and liquidus temperature. Trace elements such as Ni and Ge were also added to the alloy, primarily to improve its wettability and mechanical properties. In addition, the study also investigates the relationship between the mechanical properties (such as hardness and tensile strength) of the developed solder and the added elements. The research results show that after the Zn-Sn-Al-Cu based alloy was heat-treated at 950 °C for 72 hours, phases such as (Zn) + β-Sn + CuZn<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">5</inf> precipitated. The liquidus temperatures are all from 275 to 375 °C, and an increase in Zn content leads to a corresponding increase in the liquidus temperature. The hardness values of this alloy are from 24 to 85 HV, and the maximum tensile strength is from 51 to 86 MPa. Both hardness and tensile strength increase with increasing Zn and Al contents.

title: QA-DETR: Oriented Detection Transformer with Quality-Aligned Optimization
authors: Minjian Zhang, Heqian Qiu, Lanxiao Wang, Chenghao Qi, Hongliang Li
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Intelligent Perception and Computer Vision (CIPCV)
abstract: Oriented object detection (OOD) serves as a foundational research area within the field of remote sensing image analysis, with significant application value in disaster management and surveillance. The detection transformer employs one-to-one matching to achieve the end-to-end object detection, drawing increasing attention in the field of oriented object detection. However, the existing transformer-based OOD methods often ignore the misalignment between classification scores and localization quality in training. This misalignment can lead to predictions with high localization quality being treated as negative samples in one-to-one matching. In addition, misalignment between classification and localization tasks may cause discrepancies in the optimization of loss functions, leading to inefficient network training. To solve these problems, we introduce the QA-DETR method, an oriented detection transformer designed to achieve quality alignment between classification and localization. The method comprises two key components: a quality-aligned cost (QAC) and a quality-aligned loss (QAL). Specifically, the quality-aligned cost is determined by employing various joint representation of classification and localization at different training duration. This approach ensures that samples with high localization quality are recognized as positive samples during one-to-one matching. The quality-aligned loss leverages the localization metrics to supervise the classification prediction scores, ensuring consistency in the optimization of both classification and localization during training. Our method achieves superior performance on the DOTA dataset, outperforming existing transformer-based OOD methods with fewer epochs.

title: A CNN-Based Approach for Gaussian, Shot and Impulse Noise Cancellation in Communication Systems
authors: Mauriya R, Thanuja S, Harshak G, Shreyas M, Bajarangbali R
publish: 2025 5th Asian Conference on Innovation in Technology (ASIANCON)
abstract: Noise is a pervasive phenomenon impacting the integrity of transmitted information in Communication Systems. This paper investigates the efficacy of Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs) alongside adaptive algorithms. CNNs, specialized artificial neural networks tailored for structured grid data processing, are explored for their capability in signal estimation. Adaptive noise cancellation which employs adaptive filtering to estimate and nullify noise interference within the primary signal, is examined. In this paper, we also explore the various noise types, including Gaussian, shot, and impulse noises. Each type demonstrates unique distribution characteristics and impacts on communication systems. Our results emphasize the benefits of Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) models compared to the traditional least mean squares (LMS) method across both Signal-to-Noise Ratio (SNR) and Mean Squared Error (MSE). MATLAB serves as the primary simulation environment.

title: Modeling and AC Noise Analysis of Power Distribution Network for System-on-Wafer
authors: Xinyu Chen, Lin Gu, Chenhao Liu, Jiayi Wang
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Mechatronics Technology (ICEEMT)
abstract: To predict and evaluate the electrical performance of System-on-Wafer (SoW), a power delivery network (PDN) modeling method which integrates electromagnetic simulation and circuit analysis was proposed. The methodology involves three primary steps: First, the PDN was modularly decomposed, and the RLC parasitic parameters of each unit were extracted by combining electromagnetic field analysis and numerical calculation; Second, an equivalent circuit model is constructed based on the physical layout; Finally, the accuracy of model is verified through 3D full-wave simulation, followed by ADS-based investigations into AC noise sensitivity to operating frequency, current-source excitation waveform parameters, and on-chip decoupling capacitor density. Results demonstrate that the model’s self-impedance curve closely aligns with 3D full-wave simulation data. Voltage stability and AC noise improvements can be achieved through optimized frequency selection within specific operational ranges, current-source excitation adjustments (reduced static power consumption and increased duty cycle), and implementation of large-size on-chip decoupling capacitors.

title: Machine Learning-based Brain Tumor Classification using ACCF and BPPF Features with Linear Regression, Naïve Bayes, and Additive Regression
authors: Radhika Sethuraman, Gururama Senthilvel P
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Innovative Data Communication Technologies and Application (ICIDCA)
abstract: The classification of brain tumor is a preliminary medical diagnosis, which helps medical practitioners in the discovery of the tumor at a very early stage and come up with a sufficient treatment plan. Manual processes: These must be integrated with AI as they are costly in time and lead to human errors when executing cell classification tasks. The analysis measures the performance of machine learning models when features are extracted using Auto Color Correlogram Filter (ACCF) and Binary Patterns Pyramid Filter (BPPF) and classified using Linear Regression, Naive Bayes and Additive Regression classifiers to classify tumors. The dataset used in the study was the Kaggle Brain Tumor Dataset which contained 7023 MRI scans containing glioma and meningioma tumors and no tumor type at all. BPPF in combination with Linear Regression gave the highest accuracy of 97.39% in comparison with BPPF in combination with Naive Bayes (97.28) and ACCF in combination with Naive Bayes (97.02). Models based on Naive Bayes were the fastest to compute with respect to BPPF+Additive Regression that required 0.25 seconds to execute and got an accuracy of 82.97. The association of BPPF+Linear Regression and Naive Bayes-based classifiers is the most appropriate as it offers the most accurate results and at the same time consumes the least computational resources, thus classifying tumors in real-time.

title: Federated DataOps in FinTech and Retail Enabling Privacy-Preserving AI at Scale
authors: Rakesh Reddy Charla, Raghavender Reddy Tuniki, Raj Sonani, Ramesh Somayajula
publish: 2025 5th Asian Conference on Innovation in Technology (ASIANCON)
abstract: The development of a sensitive approach to data management is needed to support the increasing popularity of Artificial Intelligence (AI) in FinTech and retail businesses due to being scalable and privacy-sensitive. The existing traditional centralized data, led by strict data protection laws, a bewildering chain of data silos and the demands of real-time intelligence are proving to be unsuitable. In this paper, I have presented a new Federated DataOps framework which combines the ideas of DataOps and federated learning to allow privacy-preserving and decentralized AI processes to be run over heterogenous data sources. The architecture is based on federated orchestration, secure multi-party computation (SMPC), differential privacy, and policy-aware automation, which are three approaches that guarantee data compliance and resiliency without sacrificing model accuracy. Our tests include real-life implementations in FinTech transaction analysis and retail demand forecasting where we can show dramatic increases in data agility, governance, and even predictive performance. Our federated idea has been demonstrated to be effective, as experimental findings report a maximum of reduction, as much as 35 percent, in the models drifts and as much as 42 percent improvement in cross-domain model generalization. The suggested framework would provide a blueprint of scalable, secure, and regulation-connected AI systems within industries deemed to be at high risk that includes data-sensitive industries.

title: Digital Twin of Self-Regulated Learners: Effects of Metacognition, Feedback, and Task Complexity
authors: Gayane Grigoryan, Meryem Yilmaz Soylu, Jeonghyun Lee, Eric Sembrat, Stephen Harmon
publish: 2025 IEEE Digital Education and MOOCS Conference (DEMOcon)
abstract: While self-regulated learning (SRL) is essential to student success, its recursive and social dimensions are difficult to capture with traditional models. This paper develops and analyzes an agent-based simulation model that integrates the SRL framework with task complexity and the Community of Inquiry (CoI) constructs of teaching presence (instructor feedback) and social presence (peer feedback) to better understand learners’ performances. The model simulates a population of learners progressing through four SRL phases-task definition, goal setting, enacting tactics, and adaptation-while dynamically updating internal attributes such as self-efficacy, effort allocation, metacognitive awareness, and monitoring. Simulation findings show that the presence of both instructor and peer feedback significantly improves learner performance, particularly under high task complexity. Learners exposed to both feedback types consistently reached the adaptation phase more frequently and displayed higher mean effort and metacognitive awareness than those without feedback. In contrast, when feedback was disabled, performance remained consistently the same without any increase or improvement. Notably, task complexity had minimal effect on performance unless mediated by feedback. These findings underscore the importance of combining instructional and social support in promoting efficient learning environments based on personalized learning dynamics in digital twin settings.

title: Weakly-Supervised Chromosome Segmentation via SAM and Uncertainty-Guided Pseudo-Labeling
authors: Neelam Umbreen, Sara Ali, Hasan Sajid, Khawaja Fahad Iqbal, Yasar Ayaz, Muhammad A. B. Fayyaz, Muhammad Baber Sial
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Biomedical Signal and Image Processing (ICBIP)
abstract: Accurate instance segmentation of metaphase chromosomes is essential for cytogenetic diagnostics, yet existing models generalize poorly under wide variations in chromosome shape, staining, overlap, and background noise. The Segment Anything Model (SAM) performs well on natural images but under-segments fine-grained biomedical structures. We introduce an uncertainty-guided refinement framework that improves the weak segmentation masks initially produced by SAM. Coarse bounding boxes from weak COCO-style annotations are used to prompt SAM and extract initial masks. These are then evaluated using Monte Carlo Dropout with 20 stochastic forward passes to estimate pixel-wise epistemic (model) and aleatoric (data) uncertainty. A lightweight U-Net architecture, trained with edgeaware loss and spatial dropout, is used to refine the masks. During training, we apply an uncertainty weighted loss, which assigns greater importance to high-uncertainty regions, encouraging the model to focus on ambiguous boundaries and poorly segmented chromosomes. We conduct a detailed analysis over 100 training epochs, revealing a strong negative correlation between total uncertainty and segmentation accuracy, and demonstrating progressive improvement in uncertainty calibration. On a test set of 1,200 metaphase images, our framework achieves a Dice score of 96.5 %, representing an improvement of 7.3 percentage points over the SAM-only baseline and 3.1 percentage points over a standard U-Net trained on the same data. Notably, the model maintains high accuracy (above 96 %) even in high-uncertainty regions. These findings highlight uncertainty as a valuable signal for segmentation refinement and reliability estimation, offering a foundation for active learning, quality control, and robust cytogenetic analysis.

title: Real-Time PV Power Forecasting Using LSTM-Attention, Transformer & XGBoost Hybrid Model
authors: Elahe Safishahi, Ali Akbar Safavi, Pariya Khalili
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Control, Instrumentation and Automation (ICCIA)
abstract: In this paper, an integrated model for short-term high-frequency photovoltaic (PV) power forecasting based on meteorological and historical data is proposed. It is a combination of Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) with attention (SolNetPlus), Transformer (PVClientPlus), and XGBoost models. The preprocessing of the data involves merging datasets, calculation of solar zenith angles through pvlib, missing values imputation using K-Nearest Neighbors (KNN), and feature selection using mutual information regression. Optuna is applied for model optimization, and on the Zone_A6 dataset, an <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{R}^{\mathrm{2}}$</tex> of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$0.999 \pm 0.001(95 \%$</tex> CI: <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$0.995-0.998)$</tex> and MSE of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$151.87388 \pm 0.00005 ~\mathrm{W}^{2}$</tex> (95 % CI: 0.0025-0.0035) are achieved with 5-fold cross-validation. With zenith angles and ensemble approaches, predictive accuracy is enhanced to enable real-time solar grid optimization and cost reduction in renewable energy management. This works more efficiently than existing models by taking into account temporal and meteorological heterogeneity, offering stable solutions for good grid incorporation.

title: A Neural Network-Based Inverse Kinematics Solution for a 6-DoF Industrial Robotic Arm with Spherical Wrist
authors: Ahmed Abdelhamed, Sinem Görmez
publish: 2025 IEEE 15th International Conference on System Engineering and Technology (ICSET)
abstract: Solving the inverse kinematics problem plays a crucial role in enabling robots to perform precise and adaptive movements. However, traditional numerical and analytical methods used to solve the problem become quite complicated for robots with higher degrees of freedom and have several limitations. This research presents a data-driven solution to the inverse kinematics problem for a 6-DoF articulated robot with a spherical wrist. While prior studies have primarily focused on refining learning model architectures, they have often overlooked the importance of sampling strategies within the robot's workspace. To build the dataset, Sobol's sequence was used to sample the robot's sixdimensional configuration space. For training, a feed-forward neural network was then trained on this dataset to predict joint angles from given poses. Finally, a refinement algorithm using forward kinematics and adaptive coordinate descent is applied to improve the accuracy of the predictions. The combination of Sobol's sequence sampling and the refinement stage significantly improved performance compared to previous approaches in the literature, particularly in terms of accuracy and generalization.

title: Wideband Circular Patch Antenna with Double U-Slot Design for Ku-Band Applications
authors: Alif Fathoni Zidni, Aditya Inzani Wahdiyat, Catur Apriono, Eko Tjipto Rahardjo
publish: 2025 IEEE International RF and Microwave Conference (RFM)
abstract: Ku-band circular patch antenna design and development are presented in this study, utilizing a double U-Slot technique to enhance antenna performance. The double U-Slot configuration effectively broadens the antenna's resonant bandwidth, achieving up to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$9.63 \text{GHz}(8.33-17.96 \text{GHz})$</tex>. The radiation patterns across multiple resonant frequencies are nearly identical, indicating minimal variation in resonant modes, with a peak gain of 8.1 dBi at 11.5 GHz. The antenna is further configured into a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$4 \times 1$</tex> linear array to evaluate its performance in array applications and investigate mutual coupling effects. The measured mutual coupling between adjacent elements is approximately −25 dB, demonstrating improved isolation due to the double U-slot design. Additionally, the influence of inter-element spacing on array performance is analyzed to understand its impact on gain and radiation characteristics.

title: AI-Based Robust Linear Quadratic Regulator Controller for Quadcopter System
authors: Ali Taleb Obud Alisari, Shoorangiz Shams Shamsabad Farahani, Roohollah Barzamini, Mohammad Arabian
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Control, Instrumentation and Automation (ICCIA)
abstract: Accurate performance control of a quadcopter system necessitates rapid response and effective tracking of control variables such as speed, position, and torque. While traditional methods, such as the PID control approach, ensure stability in closed-loop control, they often fail to account for the nonlinear conditions present in the environment. Uncertainties can arise from unmodeled dynamics and nonlinear effects that are overlooked during the linearization of the system equations, as well as from disturbances and noise. In this paper, we employ a robust proportional-derivative(double)+LQR method as the primary control strategy. Our study focuses on four state variables–altitude, roll angle, pitch angle, and yaw angle–to manage quadcopter movements. To optimize the PDD parameters, we utilize the DEA algorithm. This approach demonstrates effective real-time tracking of parameters while accommodating disturbances.

title: Energy Consumption in Computing over the Decades: Trends, Efficiency, and Measurement Challenges
authors: Thalita Nazaré, Erivelton Nepomuceno
publish: 2025 IEEE History of Electrotechnology Conference (HISTELCON)
abstract: This study presents a historical and technical analysis of energy consumption in computing systems, tracing its evolution from the mid-20th century to the present. It examines the trajectory from the energy-intensive operation of early mainframes to the contemporary emphasis on energy-efficient data centres and software engineering practices. The emergence of energy metrics such as Power Usage Effectiveness (PUE), the adoption of virtualisation, and advances in cooling and workload management are discussed as critical responses to environmental pressures and operational demands. In parallel, the evolution of software, from low-level optimisation to modern green software engineering, has played a significant role in shaping the energy footprint of computational systems. The study also explores the positive feedback loop formed between hardware efficiency, sustainable software development, and the growing use of computing in climate science, highlighting how these interrelated domains contribute to broader sustainability goals. Current challenges in energy measurement, lifecycle assessment, and distributed computing environments are outlined, and future research directions are proposed. The findings underscore the importance of integrated strategies in addressing the complex relationship between computing and energy, with implications for both technological development and environmental stewardship.

title: State of Charge Estimation for Lithium-ion Batteries Based on IBP Neural Network and Unscented Kalman Filter
authors: Yaojiang Li, Shiping Zhao, Quan Ran, Yuxuan Yao, Yi Yang, Haoran Zhang
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Computer Information Technology (AICIT)
abstract: With the widespread adoption of lithium-ion batteries in energy storage and electric vehicle systems, accurately estimating their State of Charge (SOC) has become a critical component of battery management systems (BMS). This paper proposes a SOC estimation approach that integrates an Improved Backpropagation (IBP) neural network with an Unscented Kalman Filter (UKF). The IBP network is designed to capture nonlinear relationships among voltage, current, and temperature inputs through an adaptive learning rate mechanism, thereby improving estimation accuracy and model generalization. The UKF further refines the IBP output by dynamically filtering noise and correcting errors, enabling high-accuracy and high-robustness SOC estimation without relying on equivalent circuit models. Experimental results under standard driving cycles (FUDS, DST, and US06) and multi-temperature environments (0°C to 40°C) demonstrate that the proposed method maintains an estimation error within 5.5%, outperforming standalone neural networks and traditional model-based estimators in terms of accuracy, stability, and temperature adaptability

title: Physics-Informed Convolutional Neural Network for Electromagnetic Simulations
authors: Nan Nan Sun, Yi Long Liu, Zheng Xu Li, Wen Jing Min, Hui Ran Zeng, Kai Li
publish: 2025 IEEE International RF and Microwave Conference (RFM)
abstract: Physics-informed neural network (PINN) has been broadly applied in computational physics because of its effectiveness in solving partial differential equations (PDEs). As opposed to conventional numerical solvers, PINNs employ deep neural networks to find the solution of physical equations by incorporating physical constraints and boundary conditions into data-driven models. However, the original PINNs utilizing fully connected neural networks exhibit inherent limitations and poor performance in solving high-dimensional PDEs because the complex features are hard to capture. In this paper, a novel approach using a physics-informed convolutional neural network framework (PI-CNN) was proposed to solve the electromagnetic waves simulation in the Earth-ionosphere waveguide structure. Specifically, the loss function was formulated based on a bi-modal driving mechanism grounded in both empirical data and physical laws. The proposed PI-CNN model has been proven to be effective in simulating the propagation of electromagnetic waves in the Earth-ionosphere waveguide. The numerical results showed the effectiveness in approximating solutions for electromagnetic wave simulation based PI-CNN framework, and provide a potential method for solving complicated physical formulas.

title: A multi-scale fusion-based satellite super-resolution network
authors: Shibin Wei, Jiaming Wang, Ziyue Yang, Xitong Chen, Yuchuan Tian, Mengting Wu
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Computer Information Technology (AICIT)
abstract: Transformer architectures excel at capturing global image features, making them widely used in remote sensing super-resolution (SR). However, remote sensing images often have significant spatial redundancy (e.g., repetitive textures) with many irrelevant features. This forces computationally heavy Transformer-based SR networks to perform redundant calculations during training, reducing final SR performance. Moreover, single-scale SR models struggle with the complex, diverse textures in remote sensing images, further degrading results. To tackle these challenges, we propose a multi-scale fusion-based satellite SR network. To enhance multi-scale feature extraction in Transformers, we introduce a novel Multi-Scale Sparse Attention (MSA) multi-head attention, and simultaneously redesign the feed-forward layer into a Multi-Scale Feed-forward Neural Network (MFFN) to capture hierarchical texture details in remote sensing images. Essentially, the proposed framework achieves an average improvement of 0.1 dB over state-of-the-art methods across multiple quantitative metrics for image SR.

title: Development of Vessel Automatic Weather Station Using Smart Weather Sensor Based on Internet of Things
authors: Ahmad Furqon, Naufal Ananda, Santoso Soekirno
publish: 2025 International Conference on Smart-Green Technology in Electrical and Information Systems (ICSGTEIS)
abstract: Indonesia is one of the largest archipelagic nations, relying heavily on maritime transportation for interisland connectivity, with approximately 90 % of goods transported via sea. However, this country faces significant challenges in maritime weather monitoring due to unpredictable and extreme weather conditions such as high waves and strong winds, which have contributed to over 70 % of maritime accidents, according to the International Maritime Organization (IMO). This study aims to develop a Vessel Automatic Weather Station (VAWS) based on Internet of Things (IoT), instrument with smart weather sensors capable of providing real-time and accurate data to support navigation safety and operational efficiency. System comprises two main components: hardware and software. Hardware includes a ClimaVUE smart weather sensor, CR1000X datalogger, wireless communication modules, and solar-powered supply. Software presents real-time data in a web-based dashboard accessible via desktop or mobile devices. To evaluate accuracy of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{t}$</tex> developed sensors, comparative tests were conducted against to standard sensors, including Wilcor, Vaisala, and PTB210, across five parameters: air temperature, humidity, air pressure, sea surface temperature, and wind speed. The results showed that air temperature, humidity, and air pressure sensors achieved high accuracy with <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$R^{2}$</tex> values above 0.93. Sea surface temperature achieved an <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$R^{2}$</tex> of 0.9054, while wind speed measurement showed moderate correlation (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{R}^{2}=0.5830$</tex>). These findings indicate that proposed VAWS system is viable for vessel-based weather monitoring, although further optimization is required for wind speed measurements to meet maritime operational standards.

title: A Tumor Ablation Impedance Measurement Method Based on Center-Driven and Frequency Difference
authors: Wei Zhang, Jingang Wang, Wei He, Yuxin Fang
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Biomedical Signal and Image Processing (ICBIP)
abstract: Monitoring and evaluation of tumor ablation is an extremely important step in the treatment process. However, traditional monitoring and evaluation methods (postoperative CT, MRI and intraoperative X-ray imaging, etc.) cannot comprehensively and conveniently grasp the surgical situation of patients. This paper presents a Central Drive Frequency difference electrical impedance tomography(CD-FDEIT) method. The method uses the intra-body electrode and the body surface electrode to measure the impedance data, and by applying a sweeping excitation, using a specific central drive measurement mode to focus on the impedance changes in the ablation area. Simulation results show that this method can reflect the real changes of ablated tissue well. The measuring equipment is mainly composed of the intra-body electrode on the surgical instrument and the non-invasive body surface measuring electrode. The relative error (RE), correlation coefficient (CC), and structural similarity index (SSIM) achieved by the CD-FDEIT method were 0.392, 0.889, and 0.788, respectively, compared with the traditional EIT method, they have been improved by 5.1%, 4.4%, and 12.2% respectively, suggesting improved accuracy in tracking the ablation status of tumors and offering practical reference for clinical monitoring.

title: Dielectric Properties of Flexible Medical Material as a Potential Substrate for Wearable Application
authors: Syara Hadira Mohd Helmen, Noor Asmawati Samsuri, Mohd Fairus Mohd Yusoff, Nabilah Ripin, Mohamad Kamal A Rahim
publish: 2025 IEEE International RF and Microwave Conference (RFM)
abstract: The integration of flexible materials into wearable antenna requires substrates with stable dielectric properties and resilience to environmental factors, particularly moisture. This study compares the dielectric properties of medical-grade materials which are Materials A, B, C, and D, under different moisture conditions and layer thicknesses. Measurements were conducted using an open-ended coaxial probe method connected to a 9 GHz Vector Network Analyzer. Each material was stacked with multiple layers (to meet the minimum thickness of 5 mm), and then exposed to three levels of moisture content (11%, 15%, and 19%) by weighing dry and wet samples to calculate moisture content. The study observed that the dielectric constant decreased by 1.2% and 8.1% for Material B and D, respectively, with a five-layer increase, while Material A showed a slight 0.5% increase. However, the loss tangent is decreased by 8.6%, 2.4%, and 72.7% for Materials B, C, and D, respectively, when the layers are increased by five. The dielectric constant of each material is increased when the moisture content is at 11%, 15% and 19%. Material A and C exhibited the most stable dielectric properties under different layer thickness and moisture variations, suggesting their potential as substrates for wearable antennas in medical applications. This work may be beneficial for wearable antennas in patient monitoring systems for medical applications.

title: Vector Sum Phase Shifter Using Mixed-Signal Folding Circuits with Two's Complement Converter
authors: Yotaro Mune, Anji Miura, Fuka Kamei, Asaka Kobayashi, Hideyuki Nosaka
publish: 2025 IEEE International RF and Microwave Conference (RFM)
abstract: This paper describes a linearly controlled vector sum phase shifter using the proposed mixed-signal folding circuits. The mixed-signal folding circuits realize a pseudo-sine-cosine function by combining analog differential amplifiers that cover 180 degrees and digital two's complement converters that fold back the phase above 180 degrees to below 180 degrees. Compared to the conventional full-analog folding circuits that cover 360 degrees, the number of differential amplifiers can be reduced to one-third. The prototype phase shifter shows a 360-degree linear phase shift characteristic with an RMS phase error of 2.6 degrees at 2.5 GHz. The phase switching time is 650 ns.

title: Successful Practices for Avatars in Virtual World Learning: Perspectives from Experienced Educators
authors: Arghavan Nova Ebrahimi, Harini Ramaprasad
publish: 2025 IEEE Digital Education and MOOCS Conference (DEMOcon)
abstract: Desktop Virtual Worlds (DVWs) can enhance learning experiences by allowing students to use avatars for embodied learning, identity exploration, and collaborative activities. While the use of DVWs in education is expanding, more research is needed to identify and understand the specific avatar practices that can enhance learning experiences across different contexts. To address this gap, we conducted semi-structured interviews with 14 experienced educators from the Virtual World Education Consortium in Second Life to answer the following research question: What successful avatar implementation practices do experienced educators use to enhance student learning experiences in DVWs? Through thematic analysis, we identified four distinct approaches. Our first finding revealed how educators strategically leveraged avatar-mediated identity to create what one educator called a "protective layer" between students and their academic environment, facilitating a progression from structured anonymity to authentic identity disclosure. Second, we identified context-adaptive avatar representation practices where educators customized avatar guidelines based on educational context, ranging from block-style avatars for younger students to photorealistic representations for professional environments. Third, our analysis distinguished between task-oriented and identity-oriented avatar approaches, with the former suitable for individual asynchronous activities and the latter better supporting community building. Finally, we identified instructional avatar duality practices where educators maintained multiple instructor avatars for different teaching functions, enabling simultaneous content delivery and student support during complex activities. This dual-avatar approach created enhanced instructional capabilities through strategic role-modeling and presence techniques. These findings provide valuable insights for educators seeking to create meaningful student experiences in DVWs.

title: A Survey of Multimodal Large Models: Architecture, Technologies, Applications and Suggestions
authors: Xiaofei Dong, Huiqi Gong, Qianna Wang, Xueqiang Zhang, Dan Zhang, Feng Cao
publish: 2025 International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, Digital Media Technology and Social Computing (ICAIDS)
abstract: By integrating various data types as text, image, audio, video, and more, the multimodal large models (MLMs) realize efficient processing and comprehensive analysis of cross-modal information, and promotes the intelligent transformation and innovative development of various industries. In this paper, we propose a survey of MLMs from the perspective of architecture, technologies, applications and suggestions, respectively. Specifically, the paper first outlines the architecture of MLMs, which includes modality encoders, input projectors, output projectors, the backbone network of large language models (LLMs), and modality generators. Subsequently, it presents the key technologies, including modal alignment, multimodal fusion, model training, model fine-tuning, and computational optimization. Finally, it summarizes the typical applications of MLMs in various fields and provides relevant development suggestions in terms of data, model architecture, and applications.

title: Integrating RFID and xAPI to Secure Online Laboratory Systems
authors: Luis Felipe Zapata-Rivera, Catalina Aranzazu-Suescun, Michael Stalford
publish: 2025 IEEE Digital Education and MOOCS Conference (DEMOcon)
abstract: RFID (radio frequency identification) technology uses radio frequency waves to transmit information to identify and track people and objects. The system includes a tag that has a memory and a chip used to store the information and send it to a reader when is required. Several applications use the RFID technology, such as access control, luggage and passenger tracking, warehouse inventory, and contactless payments. In the line of access control, RFID technology can help in the compliance of security policies defined by an institution, where only authorized people can access specific locations or resources. In the context of education, this technology can be used to manage users authentication and authorization on learning management systems and other online learning tools.xAPI initially proposed by Advanced Distributed Learning (ADL) and later standardized and published by IEEE in 2022, defines a standard methodology to log and report learning experiences generated during online interaction.Using RFID technology together with xAPI standard enable both security and traceability to the actions of users with the learning systems. The attempts of users authentication and attempts to access specific resources in the system may require the identification of the user using RFID and can also leave a log using the xAPI statements that are logged on a centralized server known as the Learning Record Store LRS.This paper presents a proof of concept of authenticator and authorizer implemented using RFID and xAPI in the context of online laboratories. This work provides an alternative for learning tools developers to secure their systems using hardware, software, and educational standards.

title: Research on Text Classification for News Editor's Notes based on Machine Learning
authors: Hao Zheng, Zhijun Yue, Ruiyan Wang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, Digital Media Technology and Social Computing (ICAIDS)
abstract: This study compares editor's notes written by journalists with those generated by artificial intelligence. Using web crawlers, 2226 news articles from major Chinese platforms in education, tourism, and agriculture were collected. Corresponding editor's notes were generated using a large language model, creating an experimental dataset. Seven machine learning algorithms classified notes as either journalist-written or AI-generated. Differences were analyzed through keywords, ROUGE evaluation, and cosine similarity. Results show machine learning effectively distinguishes between the two. Key differences appear in pronoun usage. AI-generated content mimics overall style but shows lower similarity in specific content.

title: Securing Connected Future Toward 5G-Enabled IoT: A Comprehensive Analysis on 5G-IoT Scenarios
authors: Manpreet Kaur, Soniya
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Advances in Computing Research On Science Engineering and Technology (ACROSET)
abstract: The Internet-of-Things (IoT) has enabled widespread technology by boosting the availability of the internet in numerous global potentials uses. By enabling effortless communication between multiple networks of things, IoT has completely changed the way think about and collaborate with world. For rapid connectivity communication of information, IoT connects billions of items into a collective, particularly in a 5G working atmosphere during data gathering as well as analysis. Fifth-generation (5G) technology is currently regarded as one of the most difficult and intriguing research fields in technological advancement. The 5G networks are anticipated to significantly grow the current Internet of Things, boosting cellular operations, addressing network difficulties related to security issues related to the IoT. This paper provides an in-depth examination of these significant enabling technologies alongside discusses recent developing application scenarios of 5G-IoT that are being driven by the advancements in currently underway 5G endeavors, the architecture of applications for the Internet of Things with 5G technology, fundamental enabler for IoT to connect devices in 5G technology, Enabled Technologies: 5G and IoT and its standardization open issues. tremendous challenges. Further study imperfections and upcoming directions are also covered in this piece of content. The use cases for IoT in 5G systems are also addressed. As a result, discuss a portion of the key 5G IoT studies approaches.

title: Skin Cancer Detection Using Vision Transformers: An AI-Driven Approach for Precision Dermatology
authors: Manjot Kaur Sidhu, Navjot Kaur, Chaitanya Singla
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Advances in Computing Research On Science Engineering and Technology (ACROSET)
abstract: Timely identification of skin cancer, particularly melanoma, is crucial for effective intervention and improved patient outcomes. This study proposes a Vision Transformer (ViT)-based framework to classify skin lesions into malignant and benign categories, leveraging advanced AI techniques for precision dermatology. The methodology incorporates robust preprocessing, fine-tuned ViT architecture, and comprehensive evaluation metrics to ensure clinical reliability. Achieving an accuracy of 91.2% and an AUC-ROC of 0.94, the proposed system demonstrates superior performance compared to traditional convolutional neural networks. Enhanced interpretability through attention visualizations further supports its clinical utility, positioning the framework as a scalable tool for automated skin cancer screening in biomedical systems.

title: Fuzzy Logic-Based System for Monitoring and Emergency Level Classification in Fire Alarm Control Panel
authors: Luthfansyah Mohammad, Shakila Anjalinya Farran, Didi Alfandi, Lisa Yihaa Roodhiyah, Aulia Istiqomah, Sudaryono
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Internet of Things and Intelligence Systems (IoTaIS)
abstract: Fire incidents continue to pose significant threats to public safety, industrial operations, and the environment. This study proposes the development of a monitoring and classification system for fire emergency levels using a fuzzy logic-based Fire Alarm Control Panel (FACP). The system integrates an STM32F4 microcontroller for signal processing and hardware control, and an ESP32 microcontroller to perform Sugeno fuzzy logic classification based on data from conventional smoke detectors. Emergency levels are categorized into four conditions: Normal, Alert, Hazard, and Critical, determined by the number of active smoke detectors and active segments. The ESP32 also manages RFID-based access control and transmits monitoring data to a remote MQTT server for PC-based supervision. The classification process is designed to improve response time, reduce false alarms, and provide more informative alerts compared to traditional fire alarm systems. The implementation demonstrates the capability of fuzzy logic to enhance fire emergency assessment by offering a flexible and context-aware decision-making mechanism.

title: Influence of Aluminum Bond Pad Characteristic toward Wire Bond Intermetallic Compound Growth
authors: Lee Kuan Fang, Ng Hong Seng
publish: 2025 20th International Microsystems, Packaging, Assembly and Circuits Technology Conference (IMPACT)
abstract: Long term microelectronic device reliability is important for crucial applications. There is a high percentage of field reliability failure related to wire bond defects. This pointed out that device reliability and system reliability are significantly affected by wire bond reliability. In the scenario of gold wire bonding on aluminum metallization, Excessive intermetallic compound (IMC) growth is a major reliability concern. IMC growth is contributed by gold and aluminum diffusion process. This is an ageing process that will eventually cause high resistance and open circuits of the product. In this study, aluminum bond pads with various characteristics were carefully evaluated to understand IMC growth behavior. Physical factors such as aluminum layer thickness and grains size are the focus of the study. Gold wire material was fixed during wire bonding for all samples, as well as wire bonding parameter settings. Subsequently after wire bonding, accelerated ageing conditioning was applied to the wire bonded samples. High Temperature Storage Life (HTSL) and Temperature Cycle (TC) are two common accelerated ageing methods for device reliability assessment. HTSL treatment exposed wire bonded samples with continuous high temperatures for a long duration. Meanwhile, TC treatment conditioned the sample between cold and hot environments. Both ageing methods will accelerate IMC growth of Au-Al bonding. Ball bond cross-sectioning was conducted at various phases of HTSL and TC. SEM images were obtained from cross-sectioned samples for close examination of IMC growth patterns. This is followed by a wire bond shear test to evaluate the integrity of Au-Al bonding. The level of IMC growth influenced by aluminum layer thickness and grain size are highly interested in this study. These two characteristics are determined by deposition rate and temperature used in wafer fabrication process. In view of this, data obtained from this study is valuable information for bond pad structure design and improvement activity in wafer fabrication process.
