title: Metaheuristic Optimization for DC Fast Charging Advancing Efficiency with Thunderstorm Algorithm
authors: Samsurizal, AN. Afandi, Mohamad Rodhi Faiz
publish: 2025 International Conference on Smart-Green Technology in Electrical and Information Systems (ICSGTEIS)
abstract: DC fast charging systems face challenges in adjusting charging speed, thermal management, and battery health support. Conventional strategies often prioritize charging but often compromise battery health due to critical warm corruption. This investigation assesses the adequacy of the Thunderstorm Algorithm (TA) as a metaheuristic approach to optimize DC fast charging. TA is outlined to powerfully direct the charging current to keep the greatest battery temperature under 45° C, reducing thermal stress. Simulations show that TA can preserve the State of Wellbeing (SoH) of the battery up to 98% after the charging handle is completed, compared to the routine strategy, which only achieves <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$92 \% \text{SoH}$</tex> despite completing charging speedier (36 minutes compared to 44 minutes with TA). In expansion, the TA illustrated prevalent control proficiency by optimizing the control dissemination between 50 kW to 200 kW, whereas the routine strategy utilized 200 kW inactive control which expanded the warm stretch on the battery. These results confirm the TA's capacity to decrease battery degradation while guaranteeing way better thermal management., making it a costeffective alternative to existing fast-charging systems. This study makes a noteworthy commitment to the advancement of a more effective vitality administration system, bolsters the appropriation of renewable vitality, and energizes more secure and more solid fast charging operations. Assist inquiring about is required to test the execution of TA in real-world scenarios to move forward its versatility and execution on a more extensive extent of the vitality frameworks.

title: Fast Near-Field Millimeter Wave Radar Imaging by Compressive Sensing with LSMR-OMP Algorithm
authors: Yuhui He, Yuan Yu, Fangzheng Zhang
publish: 2025 18th IEEE United Conference on Millimeter Waves and Terahertz Technologies (UCMMT)
abstract: In order to achieve fast near-field millimeter wave (mmWave) radar imaging, a compressive sensing (CS) method using least squares minimal residual (LSMR) orthogonal matching pursuit (OMP) algorithm is proposed for image reconstruction. Since the LSMR method enhances the efficiency and speed of signal coefficient estimation, the proposed LSMROMP algorithm can greatly enhance the image construction efficiency. The proposed method is verified through near-field imaging using a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$77-\text{GHz}$</tex> TI mmWave radar. With nearly the same imaging quality, the proposed LSMR-OMP algorithm achieves <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\sim 60 \%$</tex> reduction in imaging time compared with traditional OMP algorithm.

title: A High-Balance Quadrature Coupler with Nonuniformly Spaced Coil and Defected Ground Shield
authors: Shirong Xu, Jincai Wen
publish: 2025 18th IEEE United Conference on Millimeter Waves and Terahertz Technologies (UCMMT)
abstract: This paper presents the analysis and design of a high-balance differential quadrature coupler. By meeting specific physical parameters, the directional coupler generates quadrature signals. Building upon this, by preserving coupling-line spacing while expanding parasitic-line gaps, the influence of parasitic effects on the phase mismatch can be reduced; by adding a defected ground shield (DGS) to suppress substrate effects and fine-tune the coupling coefficient <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\boldsymbol{k}$</tex>, the magnitude balance can be improved and the bandwidth can be broadened. Thus, high image rejection ratio (IRR) is achieved. The proposed coupler is implemented in 180 nm CMOS process, occupying an area of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$482 \times 482 \mu \mathrm{m}^{2}$</tex>. The simulation results show that, within the 10.5–13 GHz frequency range, the magnitude mismatch between the quadrature outputs is less than 0.08 dB, and the phase mismatch is less than 0.52°, corresponding to an image rejection ratio exceeding 46 dB. This performance makes the design well suited for high-IRR mixer applications.

title: A Reconfigurable Beam-Scanning Origami Reflectarray Antenna
authors: Bingxiang Zhu, Wenjing Zhang, Liwei Song
publish: 2025 18th IEEE United Conference on Millimeter Waves and Terahertz Technologies (UCMMT)
abstract: In this paper, A beam-scanning origami reflectarray antenna (BSORA) was designed utilizing reconfigurable technology. First, a 1-bit reconfigurable thin-film microstrip unit suitable for origami configurations was proposed. Then, an optimized partitioned array layout design was implemented on the Flasher origami pattern, which allowed the maximum number of reconfigurable units to be retained while avoiding interference from folding lines, thereby maintaining both high folding ratio and lightweight characteristics. Finally, the beam-scanning performance of the origami reflectarray was analyzed. Simulation results demonstrated that at the operating frequency of 15 GHz, a gain of 21.9 dBi was achieved with a beam scanning range of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\pm 60^{\circ}$</tex>, while excellent main beam directivity was maintained, validating the effectiveness of the design.

title: A W-Band Bandpass Filter Based on the Microstructure Electrochemical Fabrication Process
authors: Xiaoyu Gu, Feng Huang
publish: 2025 18th IEEE United Conference on Millimeter Waves and Terahertz Technologies (UCMMT)
abstract: In this paper, a method for designing a bandpass filter operating at <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$W$</tex>-band is presented with microstructure electrochemical fabrication technology. Two coupled air-filled rectangular cavities developed for a second-order Chebyshev response constitute the BPF. By virtue of adjusting the relative position of two feeding probes, can effectively excite the TE<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">101</inf> mode and suppress the TE<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">102</inf> mode. Moreover, the bandwidth can be improved by adjusting the coupling distance. The simulation results exhibiting the BPF central frequency at 82 GHz and the return loss is better than 20 dB, wide stopband suppression is achieved.

title: A Brief History of the Digital Audio Workstation
authors: Clara Hollomey, Peter Hackl-Lehner
publish: 2025 IEEE History of Electrotechnology Conference (HISTELCON)
abstract: We describe the conceptual roots and the technical innovations that led to the advent of Digital Audio Workstations (DAWs). DAWs facilitate access to recording, editing, and sound design tools that were once limited to professional studios. By integrating multi-track recording, digital signal processing, and real-time processing into a single software environment, DAWs have significantly lowered the economic and technical barriers to audio creation. This shift has enabled a broad spectrum of users, from independent musicians and podcasters to educators and filmmakers, to produce high-quality audio content with minimal infrastructure. As an integral part of current music production, DAWs have influenced new modes of expression, collaboration, and media distribution. Thus, they are not merely a technical innovation, but a cultural enabler that continues to shape the way sound is created, shared, and experienced.

title: Embedded Operation Effort Estimation: A Machine Learning Performance-Efficiency Trade-off Analysis
authors: Enzo Nicolás Spotorno, Leonardo P. Horstmann, José Luís C. Hoffmann, Antônio Augusto Fröhlich
publish: 2025 XV Symposium on Computing Systems Engineering (SBESC)
abstract: Real-time monitoring of a vehicle’s operational effort is critical for enhancing dependability and enabling predictive maintenance in modern automotive systems. Implementing this on resource-constrained on-board computers, however, requires navigating a trade-off between prediction accuracy, data-label efficiency, and computational cost. This paper investigates this trade-off through a comparative analysis of four distinct methods: a simple heuristic baseline, a semi-supervised clustering model (K-Means), a semi-supervised hybrid model, and a fully supervised XGBoost benchmark. Using a tailored dataset from the CARLA simulator, we evaluate the prediction performance of each model. We validate their feasibility for on-board deployment by benchmarking their computational workload in C++ on a RISC-V-based platform, measuring execution time and energy consumption. Our results reveal a clear performance-efficiency spectrum, demonstrating that the hybrid model offers a compelling engineering compromise by achieving robust predictive performance while remaining label-efficient and computationally lightweight. This analysis provides a guide for model selection for on-device intelligence under the practical constraints of automotive systems.

title: Towards a Scalable Server-Side Architecture for Real-Time Distributed Image Analysis
authors: Nivardo A. L. Castro, Cidcley T. Souza, A. Wendell O. Rodrigues, Carlos H. L. Cavalcante
publish: 2025 XV Symposium on Computing Systems Engineering (SBESC)
abstract: The growth of camera networks in various areas has increased the demand for scalable intelligent real-time image processing solutions in surveillance and analytics. Python, known for its extensive AI and machine learning ecosystem, is a popular choice for image analysis tasks, but its limitations, such as the Global Interpreter Lock (GIL), pose challenges for efficient parallel processing. This paper presents a distributed architecture that uses message-oriented middleware (MOM) to orchestrate scalable, asynchronous data pipelines and enable Python-based image analysis. Using standard protocols such as RTSP, the architecture ensures compatibility with existing camera systems and supports seamless integration. Performance is evaluated using M/M/c queuing theory metrics, showing significant scalability improvements and near-linear throughput gains. The proposed architecture demonstrates not only scalability improvements but also applicability across a range of high-throughput scenarios.

title: NeuroHLS: A Flexible Framework for Accelerating SNNs on FPGAs
authors: Renan Carlos Gomes de Farias, Fernando Pedrazzi Pozzer, Mateus Beck Rutzig
publish: 2025 XV Symposium on Computing Systems Engineering (SBESC)
abstract: Field-Programmable Gate Arrays (FPGAs) have emerged as a promising platform for accelerating AI applications in IoT devices. In this context, Spiking Neural Networks (SNNs) have demonstrated superior energy efficiency compared to traditional artificial neural networks when implemented on FPGAs. Although various frameworks have been proposed for mapping SNNs onto FPGAs, none of them have leveraged High-Level Synthesis (HLS), which facilitates faster development cycles and greater design transparency. This work introduces NeuroHLS, an HLS-based framework for implementing SNNs on FPGAs. NeuroHLS offers both resource- and latency-optimized implementation strategies, and supports fine-grained parameter customization at the layer level. To validate the framework, a 784128-10 SNN was implemented and evaluated on the N-MNIST dataset. Performance was benchmarked against existing state-of-the-art frameworks. Experimental results demonstrate that both implementation strategies offered by NeuroHLS significantly outperform existing approaches in terms of inference latency and energy efficiency. In particular, one configuration achieved an inference latency of 0.8us and an average energy consumption of 2.16uJ per inference.

title: Design of a Payload-Level 16-Channel TR Module
authors: ZHANG Zhenlong, WANG Zelin, Liu Weiqiang, WANG Weidong, YANG Peisong
publish: 2025 18th IEEE United Conference on Millimeter Waves and Terahertz Technologies (UCMMT)
abstract: In this paper, the design and fabrication method of a 16-channel TR module, applied on payload-level and operating at X-band frequency, is illustrated. For all temperature states, requirements of output power for transmission on each channel is not smaller than 6 watts, and the noise figure of the module is not higher than <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{4. 2 d B}$</tex>. To mitigate temperature effects caused by high power, the module employs multi-layer embedded copper technology for uniform heat dissipation. Besides, the module adheres to lightweight design standards, weighing no more than 600 grams. A vertical insulator rear pin design on the backside of the PCB is considered for the convenience of facilitating integration with low-profile antennas in subsequent stages. The TR module integrates system-in-package (SIP) chips for high-density assembly, significantly reducing encapsulation time and enhancing consistency and reliability of the module indicators. Furthermore, an on-board calibration network is incorporated into the PCB board, located on the lower trace layer, and is designed for realtime amplitude and phase calibration for the RF circuit. Test results from prototype sample demonstrate that the module meets all design specifications.

title: Electricity in the Ottoman Empire
authors: Ahmet Oral
publish: 2025 IEEE History of Electrotechnology Conference (HISTELCON)
abstract: This paper summarizes the development of the electrotechnology and its transfer to the Ottoman Empire accordingly. While electric telegraph was considered useful to increase the power of central government on the regional authorities in terms of empire, telephony was deemed unsafe to use as it could not be controlled, and it was not initially permitted. Electric lighting was not also widespread in the country for a long time on the grounds that it would be dangerous. And first wireless stations were installed for point-to-point overseas connection instead of maritime communications as well. Fortunately, these products took their place in Ottoman daily life, albeit with a delay, and the remaining examples begun to be exposed in the museums.

title: Bodies, Knowledge, and Frequencies: A Feminist Reading of Hedy Lamarr's Contributions to Engineering
authors: Juana Esperanza Potes Romero, Julio Sebastián Díaz León
publish: 2025 IEEE History of Electrotechnology Conference (HISTELCON)
abstract: The main objective of this article is to critically re-examine the contributions of Hedy Lamarr—particularly her invention of Frequency-Hopping Spread Spectrum (FHSS) and her career as an actress—through the lens of feminist epistemology and science studies. The study seeks to highlight how her technical achievements were historically marginalized and to demonstrate the epistemic and institutional value of recovering these silenced contributions. Sandra Harding's Standpoint Theory and intersectionality [1] are employed to interrogate androcentric biases in scientific recognition, while Donna Haraway's cyborg [2] metaphor serves to question essentialist binaries (actress/inventor, beauty/intellect, culture/technology) and to situate Lamarr's hybrid identity as a legitimate site of technical knowledge production. The analysis shows that the lack of recognition accorded to Lamarr was not due solely to technical limitations, but to gendered exclusions and institutional mechanisms that controlled access to knowledge. From feminist frameworks, her story is re-signified both as a technological advance and as a political act of resistance against androcentrism. Feminist science and engineering, beyond simply adding women into history, demand a reconfiguration of knowledge production through intersectionality, critique of essentialisms, and visibility—opening the way toward more critical, inclusive, and socially responsible scientific practices.

title: Multi-Objective Competitive Co-Evolutionary Optimization for Two-Agent Land Battlefield Wargame Strategy
authors: Zekun Wang, Cheng Xing, Hongying Zhang, Ziheng Cheng
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Control, Robotics and Cybernetics (CRC)
abstract: Many challenges arise in two-agent wargame scenarios, as each agent seeks to optimize its own objectives, which can lead to conflicts. The complexity of the problem increases significantly when the optimization process involves multiple objectives. This paper focuses on decision-making optimization within a single decision step of land battlefield wargames. We introduce an improved multi-objective competitive co-evolutionary optimization framework for strategy optimization in two-agent land battlefield wargames. The framework employs the NSGA-II algorithm to obtain the Pareto front, and a high tradeoff value strategy is applied to select the final decision from the Pareto front. Experimental results demonstrate the effectiveness and validity of the proposed framework and algorithm.

title: Predicting Graduation Outcomes Using XGBoost: A Case Study of Engineering Undergraduates at KMUTNB
authors: Pimruthai Saikaow, Bundit Joybundit, Kitipoth Wasayangkool
publish: 2025 Research, Invention, and Innovation Congress: Innovative Electricals and Electronics (RI2C)
abstract: This study proposes a predictive model based on XGBoost to classify undergraduate engineering students into three distinct academic outcomes: on-time graduation, delayed graduation, and dropout. By incorporating structured preprocessing, including data filtering, feature correlation analysis, and the application of correlation-based feature weighting, the model achieved high accuracy and demonstrated robustness across all target classes. Early academic indicators such as cumulative GPA, credit accumulation in the first two years, and GPA trajectory were identified as critical predictors. The model achieved an overall accuracy of 85.4%, with balanced performance across all classes, especially in identifying at-risk students. These findings highlight the potential of machine learning as a tool for educational data analytics, supporting academic planning and early intervention systems.

title: Experimental Study and Efficiency Analysis of a Hybrid Wind Turbine (Savonius-Darrieus) at Varying Heights for Micro-Scale Wind Power Generation
authors: Ferry R A Bukit, Naemah Mubarakah, Anggi Maulana Hasibuan
publish: 2025 International Conference on Smart-Green Technology in Electrical and Information Systems (ICSGTEIS)
abstract: The ongoing energy crisis caused by the depletion of fossil fuel reserves has accelerated the development of sustainable and environmentally friendly alternative energy sources. This study presents the design, construction, and performance evaluation of a micro-scale wind power generation system utilizing a hybrid wind turbine that combines the Savonius and Darrieus types. The system is designed to harness local wind energy potential to meet street lighting demands in Sopotinjak Village. The methodology includes hybrid turbine design and fabrication, performance testing under both openand closed-circuit conditions, and efficiency analysis based on the Power Coefficient (CP) and Tip Speed Ratio (TSR). Experiments were conducted on three turbine types-Savonius, Darrieus, and Hybrid-with rotor height variations of 200 cm, 250 cm, and 300 cm. The results indicate that the hybrid turbine consistently outperforms the individual Savonius and Darrieus turbines. Under open-circuit testing, the hybrid turbine produced voltages 3.86% and 3.83% higher than the Savonius and Darrieus turbines, respectively. Under load conditions, the voltage and current generated by the hybrid turbine were 7.94% and 14.05% higher, respectively, than those of the Savonius turbine, and 3.82% and 6.15% higher than those of the Darrieus turbine. The hybrid turbine's power output increased significantly by <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{2 3. 1 \%}$</tex> compared to Savonius and 10.15% compared to Darrieus. The highest CP value of 0.232 and TSR of 0.58 were achieved at a rotor height of 300 cm. Although the Savonius turbine exhibited a more stable CP trend with increasing height, the hybrid turbine demonstrated superior aerodynamic performance and overall efficiency. These findings suggest that the hybrid turbine configuration is a highly effective solution for small-scale wind energy applications, particularly in rural areas with variable wind conditions.

title: Comprehensive Interface Adhesion Characterization for Advanced Semiconductor Packaging
authors: Dong Jun Kim, Sun Woo Lee, Won Choi, Ho Jun Chang, Inhwa Lee, Seungju Park, Jihyun Lee, Joong Jung Kim, Sumin Kang, Taek-Soo Kim
publish: 2025 20th International Microsystems, Packaging, Assembly and Circuits Technology Conference (IMPACT)
abstract: As the layer number of semiconductor devices continue to increase and structures become complex, the mechanical reliability of back-end-of-line (BEOL) interconnect structures becomes increasingly critical for device performance and manufacturing yield. This study presents a comprehensive investigation of interfacial adhesion energies in BEOL structures using the integrated measurement method, double cantilever beam (DCB) fracture mechanics testing to identify the weakest interface and optimize material selection and process parameters.We systematically characterized three critical interfaces: Cu–Cap (Capping layer), Cu–IMD (inter-metal dielectric), and IMD–Cap using unified measurement methods. For Cu–Cap interfaces, two different capping materials (Cap1 and Cap2) were evaluated under various surface treatment conditions. NH3 plasma treatment and H2 -NH3 plasma treatments were applied, with treatment effects analyzed through chemical bonding characterization. Results showed that the enhanced surface treatment increased Cu–Si bonding ratios at the Cu– Cap1 interface through the removal of copper oxide layers, thereby improving interfacial adhesion energy. For Cu–IMD interfaces, we compared two IMD materials with different dielectric constants (κ values). IMD1 with lower κ exhibited significantly lower adhesion energy (0.72 ± 0.03, normalized) compared to IMD2 with higher κ(1.47 ± 0.30), attributed to increased porosity and defect densities in low-κ materials that introduce nonuniform bonding characteristics and stress concentration points. The IMD–Cap interface demonstrated remarkable sensitivity to deposition sequence. Surface energy analysis revealed that the higher surface energy of Cap2 (49.01 mJ/m<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>) compared to IMD1 (32.54 mJ/m<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>) enhanced physical adsorption of CVD precursors, explaining the deposition sequence dependency.These findings provide critical insights for enhancing BEOL reliability through optimized material selection, surface treatment protocols, and control of deposition sequence. The quantitative adhesion energy database and mechanical analysis will contribute to the development of more robust and reliable interconnect structures for advanced semiconductor packaging applications.

title: Truck compartment point cloud segmentation method based on multi-scale geometric feature fusion and density analysis
authors: Jiong Yan, Liang Ye, Lei Zhu, Yi Li, KeYun Tian, ShiCan Shun
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Computer Information Technology (AICIT)
abstract: This paper proposes a method for truck cabin point cloud segmentation based on multi-scale geometric feature fusion and density analysis. First, the point cloud is subjected to a combined judgment of normal vector direction and local height difference to extract regions of geometric structure abrupt changes in the point cloud and obtain candidate feature points. Subsequently, feature points located at the cabin connection are screened based on their X-axis coordinates combined with the projected density histogram. These X-axis coordinates are then used to coarsely segment the truck point cloud into the front and cabin regions. For the cabin region, Fast Euclidean Clustering (FEC) is employed and the normal consistency of each cluster is calculated to eliminate non-cabin point clusters. Finally, RANSAC plane fitting is used to precisely extract the cabin point cloud, ensuring accurate segmentation. Experimental results demonstrate that this method outperforms the Difference of Normals (DON) and region growing algorithms in terms of segmentation accuracy, boundary preservation, and computational efficiency, achieving high-precision segmentation even in complex point cloud structures.

title: FMECA for Battery Energy Storage System to Load Backup with Integrated Photovoltaic Rooftop in Industry
authors: Papon Ngamprasert, Nawin Rodrueang, Natchapol Ruangsap, Nattachote Rugthaicharoencheep
publish: 2025 International Conference on Power, Energy and Innovations (ICPEI)
abstract: This paper presents FMECA for battery energy storage system to load backup with integrated photovoltaic rooftop in industry. Battery energy storage system requires annual maintenance, which results in this case study. The assessment is done by setting the criteria for performance, environment, safety and financial evaluation by collecting data into Excel program. The results indicate that the financial operation faces a high level of risk, falling within the orange zone. Due to the high maintenance costs, an annual assessment using the FMECA method is required to evaluate the batteries. This approach helps ensure performance, environmental compliance, and safety.

title: Good Reliability FOPLP with Digital Dynamic Correction for die shift compensation
authors: Terry Wang, Chien-Ming Tseng, Wade Chen, Bor-Chuan Chuang, Cheng-Yueh Chang, Yu-Jhen Yang, Pei-Pei Cheng, Hungyu Wu, Austin Cheng, Hsin-Yi Huang, Simon Zhong, Chi-Hua Huang, Kent Chen, Chun-Shan Tsui
publish: 2025 20th International Microsystems, Packaging, Assembly and Circuits Technology Conference (IMPACT)
abstract: This study addresses die shift issues in Chip-First Fan-Out Panel Level Packaging (FOPLP) using Digital Dynamic Connection technology for high-end IC applications. A 3-dielectric, 4-metal stack structure was developed, integrating epoxy molding compound (EMC) and photosensitive build-up film (PSBF) to achieve low warpage and high reliability. The proposed design demonstrates improved structural stability and electrical performance, supporting precise die alignment and interconnect integrity. These results highlight the potential of chip-first FOPLP for future panel-level interposer applications in multi-chip high-performance systems.

title: Optimizing Memory Performance: Analyzing Design Influencers on Eye Margin in Advanced Computing Systems (IMPACT 2025)
authors: Fabian Tan, Min Keen Tang, Alex Chiou
publish: 2025 20th International Microsystems, Packaging, Assembly and Circuits Technology Conference (IMPACT)
abstract: Server platform developers have expressed concerns with memory interface electrical healthiness. Server system design has grown more complex, leading to the need for stricter board design rules, more advanced circuit knobs tuning and increasing rigorous validation coverage. By integrating design-on-simulation technologies and utilizing advanced testing and measurement techniques, we have enhanced the data management framework for HSIO margin data, enabling efficient analysis and actionable insights. Our study systematically examines the impact of key design parameters including DRAM configuration, DIMM channel, pitch, Via-In-Pad routing, PCB material, routing layers, and trace lengths on memory electrical performance metrics such as voltage margin and delay margins.

title: Stochastic Co-Optimization of EV Charging Station Placement and Scheduling Considering System Load Profile
authors: Thanakorn Wasarum, Keerati Chayakulkheeree
publish: 2025 International Conference on Power, Energy and Innovations (ICPEI)
abstract: This study presents an approach to determine the optimal locations for EV charging stations within the IEEE 33-bus radial distribution system. The placement of these stations is crucial, as inappropriate siting can lead to system overloads and increased energy losses. These negative impacts can be mitigated through strategic planning and optimal siting of EVCS within the existing radial distribution network.The proposed research identifies optimal EVCS placement while analyzing system power loss and voltage profile. The study introduces three metaheuristic algorithms genetic algorithm (GA), grey wolf optimizer (GWO) and particle swarm optimization (PSO) with the primary objective of minimizing total power loss (Ploss) reducing the Voltage Deviation Index (VDI) and maintaining bus voltages within standard operating limits. Performance evaluations were conducted on the IEEE 33-bus distribution network under a 24-hour load profile, reflecting realistic load variations. Experimental results indicate that GWO and PSO outperform GA in terms of reducing power losses and enhancing voltage stability. Furthermore the optimal EVCS locations are generally found to be associated with structurally critical buses within the distribution system.The findings of this study demonstrate that the integration of EV charging stations supported by appropriate planning and optimization algorithms, can effectively address technical challenges in power distribution systems. The proposed methodology can serve as a practical guideline for future expansion of EVCS infrastructure in a sustainable manner.

title: Sparrow Search Algorithm for PMSM Parameter Identification
authors: Haoran Zhang, Quan Ran, Shiping Zhao
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Computer Information Technology (AICIT)
abstract: To improve convergence speed, avoid local optima, and enhance identification accuracy of PMSM parameters, this paper proposes an Improved Sparrow Search Algorithm (ISSA). The algorithm applies a golden sine strategy for discoverers and Levy flight for followers to enhance global and local search capabilities. Simulation results demonstrate that ISSA outperforms SSA and PSO in convergence speed, accuracy, and stability.

title: Exact Solutions of an Extended Benney-Luke Equations Using (G′/G, 1/G)-method
authors: Nguyen Minh Tuan, Phayung Meesad, Paiwan Wongsasinchai, Nguyen Hong Son
publish: 2025 Research, Invention, and Innovation Congress: Innovative Electricals and Electronics (RI2C)
abstract: This paper presents the application of the (G′/G, 1/G)-expansion method to solve the extended Benney-Luke equation. The method successfully produces exact solutions in various forms, including hyperbolic, trigonometric, and rational solutions. These solutions are graphically depicted in three dimensions and 1-D contour plots to investigate the wave behavior. The (G<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">′</sup>/G, 1/G)-method demonstrates its efficacy in solving the Benney-Luke equation by converting nonlinear evolution equations into ordinary differential equations. The approach offers new insights into the structure of wave propagation and surface tension dynamics.

title: Deep Q-Network Strategy for Personalized English Learning Path Optimization
authors: Ming Yang
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Computer Information Technology (AICIT)
abstract: A Deep Q-Network (DQN)-driven strategy is employed to optimize personalized English learning paths. Multi-dimensional capability modeling and deep feature extraction are applied to construct the state space, and the ε-greedy mechanism is integrated with the DQN to achieve adaptive task sequence recommendation. A language knowledge graph is incorporated into path management to establish semantic order, while an incremental learning mechanism based on user feedback supports real-time strategy adjustment. Experiments on real datasets show that the proposed approach significantly outperforms collaborative filtering and traditional classification models in recommendation accuracy, path completion rate, and user experience. The results demonstrate the effectiveness of reinforcement learning in enhancing intelligent recommendation for English learning and highlight the broad application potential of DQN-based strategies.

title: Optimizing Frequency Detuning in UHF RFID Tag Through Matching Network
authors: Mohamad Fakrie Mohamad Ali, Osman bin Ayop, Noor Asniza binti Murad, Mohamad Kamal A. Rahim, Farid bin Zubir, Nisaa Yasmin Nor Izuddin
publish: 2025 IEEE International RF and Microwave Conference (RFM)
abstract: This paper explores a comprehensive investigation into frequency detuning in passive Ultra-High Frequency (UHF) RFID tags through the implementation of tunable matching network. The impedance of RFID chips, being capacitive and frequency-dependent, often leads to reflection losses and reduced tag performance in varied operating conditions. To address this, a parametric study was conducted using CST simulation, focusing on the tunability of the UHF coil via rotational bridges. The design integrates mechanical tuning using Bridge 1 and Bridge 2 to modify the physical length and inductance of the coil, effectively adjusting the self-resonance frequency (SRF). Simulation results demonstrate a tunable frequency range from 874 MHz to 983 MHz. The optimized matching network achieved a target SRF at 920 MHz, with an <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$S_{11}$</tex> of −3.88 dB and a measured read range of 0.22 meters. This case provides a practical design methodology for enhancing UHF RFID tag performance in dynamic environment through structural impedance matching techniques.

title: Key Elements and Theoretical Logic of Blended Teaching from the Perspective of Total Quality Management: Integration of Computer Technology and Artificial Intelligence
authors: Li Lin, Hashima Binti Hamid
publish: 2025 International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, Digital Media Technology and Social Computing (ICAIDS)
abstract: This study constructs a key elements model of blended teaching from the perspective of Total Quality Management (TQM). Utilizing grounded theory analysis, the study conducts an in-depth analysis of literature reviews, expert interviews, and policy documents. In the research process, computer technology and artificial intelligence (AI) are employed to enhance data quality and analysis efficiency. Specifically, text mining tools preprocess large volumes of literature to improve data quality, machine learning algorithms classify initial data to identify potential themes and concepts related to blended teaching, and deep learning models (e.g., BERT and GPT) perform semantic analysis to accurately extract key concepts and themes. Through these technological means, the study identifies seven key elements of blended teaching: learning outcomes orientation, integrated curriculum design, dual-mode teaching implementation, technical platform support, teacher competence, teaching guarantee, and comprehensive evaluation. The model incorporates applications of computer technology and AI, such as learning analytics to predict student performance, adaptive learning systems to adjust teaching content based on student progress, and natural language processing to provide instant feedback, thereby enhancing teaching quality and learning effectiveness. These elements collectively improve teaching quality by clarifying goals, optimizing design, and strengthening support. The study provides a theoretical reference for blended teaching practice and a policy basis for educational management decision-making.

title: Development of a Dual-Band Double Spiral Antenna for Medical Hyperthermia Therapy
authors: Nitika Sharma, Rajesh Khanna, Mayank Kumar Rai, Kiran Kumari
publish: 2025 5th Asian Conference on Innovation in Technology (ASIANCON)
abstract: This study presents the design and performance evaluation of a compact dual-band double-spiral antenna developed for localized microwave hyperthermia in biomedical applications. The antenna is fabricated on an FR4 substrate and features a multilayer structure comprising a top-mounted spiral radiator, a slotted ground plane between substrates, and a bottom-layer microstrip feed line. The size of the antenna is 60 × 60 × 3.30 mm³. The antenna operates at 1.8 GHz and 2.45 GHz, allowing treatment flexibility for tumors of varying sizes and depths. The performance is evaluated within a heterogeneous tissue-mimicking phantom (skin, fat, muscle), placed 5 mm above the antenna to simulate realistic clinical conditions. The key performance metrics, such as specific absorption rate (SAR), penetration depth (PD), and effective field size (EFS), are analyzed at each frequency. Further, the thermal distribution is also studied in the presence of a phantom at different frequency bands. The results demonstrate that the antenna achieves frequency-dependent field localization and controlled thermal profiles, confirming its suitability for targeted and safe hyperthermia therapy in superficial and subcutaneous tumor regions.

title: AI Speaks, but does it Feel? Detecting Synthetic Voices with Emotional Cues
authors: Nipun Bhardwaj, Arun Sankar M. S.
publish: 2025 IEEE 15th International Conference on System Engineering and Technology (ICSET)
abstract: Speech is a popular biometric authenticator as it is convenient, non-invasive, and simple. The deepfake/spoofed or simply synthesized voices represent a considerable risk to voice authentication, as it allows unauthorized access to systems. With the rapid advancements in the quality of generated speech in recent years due to technological innovations, identifying effective detection techniques has become increasingly important and many countermeasures are developed. The synthesized voices, while increasingly realistic from a hearing perspective, may still struggle to accurately replicate other elements in human speech including the nuances of human emotional expression. In this study, we investigate the emotional characteristics of spoofed and bonafide speech of the ASVspoof 2019 and 2021 datasets using various Speech Emotion Recognition (SER) algorithms. Our findings reveal that spoofed speech often lacks the distinct emotional profiles of bonafide speech. This suggests that SER algorithms can be leveraged for detecting spoofed speech, providing an additional layer of security in speech processing systems to counter spoofing threats.

title: Windowed OFDM with Index Modulation
authors: Ahmed Waheed, Somayeh Mohammady
publish: 2025 IEEE International RF and Microwave Conference (RFM)
abstract: This paper presents a novel scheme called Windowed Orthogonal Frequency Division Multiplexing with Index Modulation (W-OFDM-IM), which integrates windowing techniques such as rectangular, Hamming, Hanning, Chebyshev, and Kaiser into OFDM-IM to mitigate out-of-band (OOB) radiation while preserving spectral efficiency. The proposed system is evaluated in both additive white Gaussian noise (AWGN) and multipath channels, with a focus on bit error rate (BER) performance and power spectral density (PSD) characteristics. The simulation results demonstrate that, among all windowing techniques, the rectangular and Kaiser window achieves moderate suppression of OOB (−15 dB) without significant degradation of BER. Compared to conventional OFDM and standard OFDM-IM, W-OFDM-IM exhibits enhanced spectral containment and comparable BER performance, making it a viable solution for next-generation wireless systems including 6G requiring stringent spectral efficiency and interference mitigation.

title: Prediction of Angiotensin-Converting-Enzyme (ACE) Inhibitor Bioactivity as an Antihypertensive Agent Using LSTM Modeling Optimized with Grey Wolf Optimization
authors: R. Adicondro Yusuf Hendratmo, Isman Kurniawan
publish: 2025 8th International Conference of Computer and Informatics Engineering (IC2IE)
abstract: Hypertension is a major global cardiovascular disease, with ACE inhibitors central to its treatment. Accurate prediction of compound bioactivity is essential to accelerate drug discovery. This study proposes a regression model using Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) networks optimized via Grey Wolf Optimization (GWO) to predict the inhibitory activity (pIC<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">50</inf>) of ACE-targeting compounds. The model utilizes SMILES-based molecular representations encoded into vector sequences, eliminating the need for handcrafted descriptors. Although the dataset contains only 255 bioactive compounds from ChEMBL, prior research shows that small datasets can yield meaningful insights with proper modeling. Sequential learning from SMILES enables the model to capture temporal patterns and mitigate data limitations. Several LSTM baselines were evaluated, followed by GWO-based hyperparameter tuning. The best model achieved a test (R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>) of 0.667 comparable to prior Random Forest (R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> ≈ 0.745) and SVM (R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> ≈ 0.74) results. Additionally, the model obtained a leave-one-out cross-validated coefficient of determination $\left( {Q_{LOO}^2} \right)$ of 0-696, indicating strong internal consistency. These results suggest that combining sequence-based modeling with metaheuristic optimization provides a robust and efficient method for predicting ACE inhibitor bioactivity.

title: 3D Lightning Mapping Using a Two-Station VHF Interferometer System: Preliminary Results
authors: Muhammad Zuhair Bolqiah Edris, Mohd Riduan Ahmad, Muhammad Haziq Mohammad Sabri, Yuji Takayanagi, Manabu Akita, Ahmad Rifhan Salman, Mohamad Zoinol Abidin Abd. Aziz, Mohd Khairy Zahari, Takeshi Morimoto, Mohd Zafri Baharudin, Farah Hani Nordin, Zen-Ichiro Kawasaki
publish: 2025 IEEE International RF and Microwave Conference (RFM)
abstract: This paper presents a preliminary result on the three-dimensional (3D) mapping of lightning using a two-station very high frequency (VHF) broadband interferometer (ITF) system. Two ITF stations were deployed at Universiti Teknikal Malaysia Melaka (UTeM) and Universiti Teknologi MARA (UiTM), Jasin, separated by 18.25 km, to capture the azimuth and elevation angles of VHF lightning signals. By combining the 2D mapping results from both stations, a 3D mapping method was applied to estimate the 3D positions of lightning flashes using the distance and height estimation of the intersection point. A total of four lightning flashes were successfully analyzed where 3 cloud-to-ground (CG) and 1 isolated breakdown (IBD) flashes. The results show that CG flashes generally followed a downward-to-upward propagation pattern along the same channel, while the isolated breakdown flash showed different patterns than CG.

title: To Enhance and Integrate Agriculture Food Supply Chain Transparency by using Smart Contract and Blockchain Technology
authors: Krisnanand Bendre, Shahjahan Shaikh, Pawan Kumar Singh, Pravin Yadav, Om Pal, Vivek Pandey
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Advances in Computing Research On Science Engineering and Technology (ACROSET)
abstract: Agriculture is the back bone of India, as around 58% of its population depends on agriculture for their livelihood. However, the agricultural supply chain is a complex and typically fragmented process with many intermediaries. The Kisan Bill, passed in September 2020, aimed to remove middlemen and give farmers direct market access but faced protests over price security and corporate control, leading to its repeal in November 2021. To address these concerns, our system uses blockchain and smart contracts to ensure fair pricing, transparency, and secure farmer-to-buyer transactions, eliminating reliance on intermediaries. Transparency is a major problem in the current system that leads to misinformation, poor communication, and consequently loss for the producers. We propose the system for a decentralized and transparent network that aids in sharing data. Here, information is accommodated in blocks and has a unique hash value, verified by multiple nodes spread over the chain. Smart contracts—self-executing proposals based on rules that the parties prescribe and upon specific events trigger consequences—allow trust and accountability. This strategy not only minimizes fraud and inefficiencies but also empowers farmers with fairer and more dependable transactions.

title: An Improvement of Energy-Aware Routing Protocol With Mobile Sink Optimization For Wireless Sensor Networks
authors: Kirandeep Kaur, Komal Sharma
publish: 2025 5th Asian Conference on Innovation in Technology (ASIANCON)
abstract: Environmental biology, healthcare, facility monitoring, and many more fields are among the many uses for wireless sensor networks (WSNs), one of the newest technologies in the Internet of Things (IoT) arena. These networks collect, process, and transmit environmental data by connecting a wireless network of small, resource-constrained sensors to other sensors. Managing the mobility of mobile sinks is one of the primary difficulties in operating wireless sensor networks. Mobile sinks can serve as data gathering sites inside a network because of their portability. However, this mobility has a number of disadvantages, such as frequent changes in energy and route. To tackle this problem, this research proposes a novel routing method that facilitates sink mobility. This approach uses a cluster-based model to execute the mobile sink routing protocol, and the sink moves based on the average energy in each cluster. Mobile sinks assist wireless sensor networks in balancing the load on the end nodes by distributing the load among several network nodes.

title: Superposed Transmission of IoT Low-Speed Signal over High-Speed Video Signal with Multilevel Modulations
authors: Sana Kagaya, Takatoshi Sugiyama
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Internet of Things and Intelligence Systems (IoTaIS)
abstract: In recent years, NTN (Non-Terrestrial Network), a concept beyond 5G/6G, has been attracting attention. Among them GEO (Geostationary Orbit) is superior in terms of wide coverage. Currently, IoT (Internet of Things) sensor data collection systems are receiving attention, and from the perspective of frequency utilization efficiency, it is desirable to transmit data using the same satellite as video transmission systems. As a transmission scheme for this system, we propose low-speed CDMA (Code Division Multiple Access) and high-speed OFDM (Orthogonal Frequency Multiple Access), and their performances have been clarified. In this paper, we apply multilevel modulations to high-speed OFDM signal and clarify the number of superposed low-speed CDMA signals.

title: MDNet: Multi-Scale Detail-aware Network for Low-Light Image Enhancement
authors: Aditya Bharadwaj, Inderjeet, J. S. Sahambi
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Internet of Things and Intelligence Systems (IoTaIS)
abstract: Low-light image enhancement remains a challenging problem due to the difficulty of restoring both global structures and fine-grained details under poor illumination. In this paper, we propose MD-Net (Multi-scale Detail-aware Network), a novel deep learning framework designed to address this challenge by leveraging a hierarchical encoder-decoder architecture. MD-Net processes input images at multiple spatial resolutions to extract and integrate features across scales, enabling the network to enhance images with improved clarity, contrast, and detail. The architecture incorporates two key modules: High-Level Information Awareness (HLIA), which captures global semantic and contextual cues, and Multi-Level Feature Aggregation (MLFA), which effectively fuses features from different receptive fields to preserve textures and fine details. Experimental results demonstrate that MDNet achieves superior performance over existing state-of-the-art methods, producing visually pleasing results and achieving competitive quantitative scores across standard low-light image enhancement benchmarks.

title: An Intelligent Autonomous Robot with Recognition, Depth-Aware Perception, and Manipulation
authors: Alex Eayrs, Chris Gerhardson, Trygve Eggen, Hyeun Jeong Min, Cheol-Hong Min, Hassan Salamy
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Internet of Things and Intelligence Systems (IoTaIS)
abstract: This paper presents the development of an autonomous indoor service robot that can navigate and interact with an unfamiliar environment. Equipped with a depth camera, IMU, drive motors, and a gripper arm, it uses object, text, and barcode recognition to identify and interact with specific items. The system is built on a Robotis TurtleBot3 with an OpenMANIPULATOR-X arm, running ROS, and an Intel RealSense D435i camera. The platform demonstrates autonomous recognition and task execution indoors, with potential for expansion to diverse applications. In addition, the robot estimates depth information and size information utilizing the depth camera information. Such information is important not only in object manipulation but also in assessing spatial characteristics for intelligent obstacle avoidance.

title: Real Time Video Segmentation for Object Tracking
authors: Snehal Arjun Dudhane, S. S. Redekar
publish: 2025 5th Asian Conference on Innovation in Technology (ASIANCON)
abstract: In computer vision, real-time video segmentation for object tracking is a crucial job with applications in robotics, augmented reality, autonomous driving, and surveillance. In order to precisely identify and track objects across video frames in real time, this research proposes an effective method that combines object tracking and video segmentation. The suggested approach combines a strong tracking algorithm with deep learning-based semantic segmentation to extract object boundaries and preserve identification across time, especially in the face of difficult circumstances such background clutter, motion blur, and occlusion. We optimize frame-wise processing with temporal coherence and use lightweight convolutional neural networks to attain real-time performance. Results from experiments on benchmark datasets show that our approach is appropriate for real-world applications since it maintains low latency while achieving excellent accuracy. The suggested framework offers a dependable and expandable way to comprehend dynamic scenes and make decisions in real time.

title: Decentralized Social Networking with Artificial Intelligence for Enhanced Connection and Updates
authors: S. Kanimozhi, Anuj S, Santheep W S, Hari Prasath S
publish: 2025 5th Asian Conference on Innovation in Technology (ASIANCON)
abstract: This paper introduces Decentralized Social Networking with Artificial Intelligence for Enhanced Connections and Updates, a platform that merges user-controlled data, AI-driven personalization, and Quantum inspired trust scores to redefine digital socialization. The proposed platform empowers users by storing profiles and content locally on their own devices, ensuring permanent ownership, while employing ephemeral caching servers to optimize data accessibility. The data is temporarily mirrored on the decentralized nodes during active interactions and automatically erased post-session. At its core, the system integrates the design of mainstream platforms like Instagram and WhatsApp with end-to-end encryption similar to Signal.It is further enhanced by AI features such as context-aware emoji generation using Stable Diffusion, in-chat decision-making agents that are fine-tuned to group dynamics, and "Time Capsule" messaging that auto unlocks based on AI-predicted real-world triggers or on certain dates. A quantum entanglement trust system is implemented to disrupt malicious behavior by using reputation scores across the network, which is pre-simulated by AI to deter misuse. By decentralizing control, personalizing via ethical AI, and prioritizing post-quantum security, this platform offers a scalable, user-centric alternative to exploitative centralized platforms, bridging the gaps between privacy, societal accountability, and creativity.

title: Comparisons Between Open-LLMs For Fake News Detection
authors: Rachel Ladouceur, Chaima Njeh, Haïfa Nakouri, Fehmi Jaafar
publish: 2025 9th Cyber Security in Networking Conference (CSNet)
abstract: The spread of fake news on social media is a growing concern with significant negative societal impacts. To address this challenge, researchers have proposed various methods and algorithms for fake news detection. Recently, large language models (LLMs) have emerged as promising tools for both detecting and explaining fake news. This paper presents results from classification and explanation of true and fake news using three LLMs—Mistral, LLaMA3, and LLaMA4—applied through zero-shot prompting via Together.ai. The models analyzed 1,228 claims from the Fin-Fact dataset, evenly divided between real and fake news. Our findings are threefold. First, none of the three LLMs achieved strong classification performance, with LLaMA4 recording F1-score of 0.59 for fake news and 0.51 for true news. Second, in terms of explanation quality, LLaMA4 outperformed the other models, achieving the highest METEOR score (0.072), also obtained the lowest negative COMET score (–0.260) demonstrating improvement over its predecessor, LLaMA3. Third, all models consistently performed better on fake news than on true news, a counterintuitive outcome, since fake news is generally considered more challenging to interpret. This consistency across metrics, METEOR, BERTScore F1 and COMET, reinforces the validity of this observation. The relatively high BERTScore F1 (0.6+) indicated that all models produced semantically consistent explanations. However, both METEOR and COMET scores were very low relative to their respective scales, suggesting that the LLMs’ justifications differed in wording and judgment from those in Fin-Fact. Those metrics are designed for short and precise texts and are unsuitable for evaluating the long narrative justifications present in the Fin-Fact dataset.

title: Overcoming Legal Barriers to the Safe Use of Agentic Artificial Intelligence in Mediation and Dispute Resolution
authors: Salissou Alio Sanda
publish: 2025 9th Cyber Security in Networking Conference (CSNet)
abstract: The agentic artificial intelligence, AI systems capable of acting autonomously to achieve a goal, promises a revolution in dispute resolution as a mediator. However, its integration into the legal system faces fundamental obstacles. This article aims to identify, analyze, and propose concrete solutions to these legal obstacles for the secure and ethical deployment of agentic AI in mediation and amicable dispute resolution. The methodology is based on an interdisciplinary approach, combining the analysis of positive law (civil liability, procedural law, European Regulation on AI) with a technical study of agentic systems and a comparative review of initiatives in European and French legislation. The results identify different major categories of obstacles and their associated solutions. This work thus demonstrates that while the legal obstacles are substantial, they are not insurmountable. They require a creative adaptation of the existing framework and innovative proposals to build an ecosystem where technology serves the fundamental values of law under the supervision and ultimate responsibility of humans. Such an approach represents a major opportunity to democratize access to justice through strict supervision of the use of mediating agentic artificial intelligence to guarantee its fairness, security and loyalty.

title: Cross-Study Comparability for IDS: A Call for Clarity
authors: Maximilian Ludwig, Stefan Machmeier, Vincent Heuveline
publish: 2025 9th Cyber Security in Networking Conference (CSNet)
abstract: Systems and networks connected to the Internet are dominant targets for attackers. Determining whether a communication is benign is a challenging task that Intrusion Detection Systems (IDS) aim to remediate. Researchers have developed new methods to combat the rapidly changing scenarios of attacks; however, evaluating these approaches requires similar hardware, operating systems, datasets, and time, which is limited in practice. In this paper, we address this and present BICEP, a framework that aims to fill this gap: making studies and IDS tools comparable. The framework is portable and extensible, enabling the setup, configuration, and benchmarking of arbitrary IDS. For a baseline comparison, we chose Suricata, Snort and Slips for evaluation. We benchmarked each system separately and in different combinations to determine the advantages and disadvantages of their detection capabilities using the CIC-IDS-2017, UNSW-NB15, and CTU-13 datasets. As a result, we found significant differences regarding resource consumption and detection capabilities between signature and anomaly-based solutions.

title: BIKES: A Moving Network Instrument for Music and Sound Art
authors: Orlando Kenny, Laura Call Gomez, Shirin Sathe, Henrik Von Coler
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th International Symposium on the Internet of Sounds (IS2)
abstract: BIKES s a moving network music instrument consisting of four electric bicycles, each equipped with an onboard computer, touch display, and a loudspeaker. The bicycles share control data and metadata over a local-area network, creating sonic interventions in arbitrary locations, either while moving or while stationary, as an installation. BIKES is an instrument in its own right and is intended to be programmed individually for different concepts and compositions, using tools such as SuperCollider, Python, and Ansible. This paper discusses the initial prototype, detailing the hardware, software, and network communication architectures used for musical interaction. BIKES has been used in public performances and installations in a variety of urban contexts, displaying the system’s novel ways of interacting with its environment. Future developments will focus on enhancing the system’s robustness by improving the hardware design and equipping each bike with a router to form a decentralized mesh network.

title: Pipeline for Data Collection and Real-Time Inference for Semantic Segmentation of 3D Point Clouds
authors: João Victor C. de Figueiredo, Rogério Albert M. P. Mozer, Victor M. Silva Souza, Analucia S. Morales, Iwens G. Sene, Lucas Araújo Pereira
publish: 2025 XV Symposium on Computing Systems Engineering (SBESC)
abstract: Semantic segmentation of 3D point clouds plays a fundamental role in applications such as autonomous vehicles, robotics, and 3D mapping, enabling the precise identification of objects and relevant classes. However, performing this task in real time presents challenges related to computational efficiency and model optimization. This work presents the development and performance analysis of a pipeline for real-time Light Detection and Ranging (LiDAR ) data acquisition and inference, integrating machine learning models based on Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs). The proposed approach combines Software-in-the-Loop techniques and the concept of a digital twin, covering the entire process from data capture and preprocessing to semantic segmentation, ensuring a continuous processing workflow. The experiments done with an adaptation of the RIU-Net architecture demonstrated the feasibility of the proposed solution, showing satisfactory results in terms of execution time, accuracy, and Intersection over Union (IoU), reinforcing its applicability to real-time 3D computer vision systems.

title: The Advanced Arithmetic of Oprema, the Relay Computer of Carl Zeiss Jena
authors: Jürgen F. H. Winkler
publish: 2025 IEEE History of Electrotechnology Conference (HISTELCON)
abstract: The Oprema was a relay computer, which was designed and built at Carl Zeiss Jena (CZJ)) in 1954/55. Its arithmetic was based on a floating-point number format. The number format allowed also the representation of the denormalized values zero, infinity and indeterminate. The paper describes the number format and the arithmetic operations and the different forms of rounding in detail.

title: Enhancing Freshwater Lobster Productivity with IoT-Enabled Web Interface for Water Quality Management
authors: Alfriska Oktarina Silalahi, Tantri Manalu, Joshua Silitonga, Christanti Siahaan, Good Fried Panggabean, Tulus Pardamean Simanjuntak
publish: 2025 8th International Conference of Computer and Informatics Engineering (IC2IE)
abstract: This study presents the design, implementation, and evaluation of an IoT-enabled, solar-powered web-based interface for real-time water quality management in freshwater lobster (Cherax Quadricarinatus) aquaculture. Existing monitoring approaches in small-scale aquaculture are typically manual, labor-intensive, and prone to delayed responses, which can result in water quality degradation and yield loss. To address these limitations, the proposed system integrates a multi-parameter sensor array (dissolved oxygen, pH, temperature, ammonia) and solar panel battery monitoring into a responsive web interface accessible via smartphones and computers. The novelty of this work lies in the combination of renewable-energy-powered IoT sensing with a mobile-friendly, real-time monitoring dashboard, enabling farmers to act promptly when water parameters deviate from optimal ranges. Field testing was conducted over a continuous 14-day period under varying environmental conditions (day/night cycles and weather fluctuations). Results show average data latency of 2–3 s, uptime >99%, and ammonia maintained below 5.0 ppm. Sensor calibration against reference instruments yielded an average accuracy of 98.7%, and data transmission stability remained above 99% uptime. Compared to manual monitoring, the system reduces labor requirements by over 60% and enables earlier detection of water quality anomalies. These results demonstrate that the system not only improves operational efficiency but also enhances sustainability in off-grid aquaculture environments. Future work will focus on integrating predictive analytics for automated water quality control.

title: Optimal Control Based on Reinforcement Learning for a Class of Nonlinear Singularly Perturbed Systems
authors: Mohammadsaleh Rouhi, Roya Amjadifard
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Control, Instrumentation and Automation (ICCIA)
abstract: Optimal control of nonlinear singularly perturbed systems presents a significant challenge in control engineering. This paper proposes a model-free, online reinforcement learning algorithm to find the optimal controller for this specific class of systems. The only required knowledge of the system is the stability of the fast sub-system. The proposed method is based on policy iteration and utilizes measured slow-states data to learn the solution for the Hamilton-Jacobi-Bellman equation without requiring the slow system dynamics. Specifically, the policy evaluation step is formulated using an integral form of the Bellman equation and is solved online via the RLS algorithm. To demonstrate its efficacy, the algorithm is implemented on a chaotic Lorenz system, which exhibits singularly perturbed characteristics. Simulation results confirm the convergence of the control gain to its optimal value and show the well-satisfied response of the proposed approach in comparison with the previous methods applied to this class of systems.

title: Accelerating High-Speed Interconnect Development with a Closed-Loop Design and Validation Framework
authors: Chiew Yee Ho, Jimmy Hsu, Brian Ho, Thonas Su, Ryan Chang, Vick Chuang, Colin Chen
publish: 2025 20th International Microsystems, Packaging, Assembly and Circuits Technology Conference (IMPACT)
abstract: As the datacenter industry rapidly grows and high-speed interconnect signal data rate increases to PCIe Gen7 with Pulse Amplitude Modulation (PAM4) encoding, the board design is crucial to ensure the quality of the high-speed signal data transmission. Conventionally, in platform design and qualification stage, System Design Verification (DV), Signal Integrity (SI) and Electrical Validation (EV) tests are conducted to ensure the quality of the high-speed signal data transmission on the specific platform design. However, due to the cost and time constraints, board manufacturers may decide to omit some of the testing which may result in late found issues after platform post-production launch, such as PCIe link stability or data integrity issues that could potentially cause an outage in the datacenter fleet services. In this paper, a closed loop design and validation methodology for datacenter platform design which includes feedback loop and correlation of test results and issues found in DV, SI and EV tests is proposed and detailed case studies with including design, SI and EV analysis and correlation will be provided.

title: Optimization of Dynamic Environment SLAM Algorithm Based on Multi-sensor Fusion
authors: Fan Yang, Yucheng Peng
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Computer Information Technology (AICIT)
abstract: This paper proposes an improved SLAM method for dynamic environments by fusing camera, LiDAR, and IMU data. It combines geometric constraints with deep learning to detect and filter dynamic objects, while adaptive weighting optimizes sensor fusion. Semantic segmentation and optical flow enhance dynamic feature removal, and a multi-scale mapping strategy improves consistency. Experiments demonstrate superior accuracy and robustness over traditional SLAM in both simulations and real-world tests.

title: X-Shield: Explainable Credit Card Fraud Detection Using XGBoost and SHAP for Analyst-Centric Triage
authors: Faris Danial Uda Harris, Norzilah Musa, Norzehan Sakamat, Haslizatul Fairuz Mohamed Hanum
publish: 2025 IEEE 15th International Conference on System Engineering and Technology (ICSET)
abstract: Credit card fraud remains a high-impact, low prevalence problem in financial infrastructures, and detection models that compromise high recall for strong analyst confidence are required. This paper introduces X-SHIELD, an explainable credit card fraud detection system that aligns the prediction capacity of XGBoost and the explainability of SHAP within an analyst-focused triage dashboard. Using a large-scale anonymized dataset of over <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{5 5 0, 0 0 0}$</tex> transactions, X-SHIELD is comprehensively tested under stratified hold-out, cross-validation, and threshold-tuned regimes and displays near-perfect performance (accuracy of 99.97%, precision of 99.94%, and recall of 99.0%). Beyond raw performance, the system delivers case-level SHAP explanations that report feature contributions and build calibrated narratives, therefore filling the gap between algorithm-driven detection and human decision-making. Comparative analysis demonstrates that X-SHIELD supersedes conventional baseline not only in prediction capacity but also in explainability, facilitating faster triage, improved analysts' confidence, and superior regulatory compliance. By aligning the best-of-class classification through transparent interpretability, X-SHIELD represents a significant step toward reliable and operationally tenable AI-driven fraud detection.

title: A Multi-Touch Web and Android-based E-Restaurant Management System using LabVIEW
authors: Sethuraman Rao G, Menaka K, Konduru Abhilash, Bolledu Kishore, Chilaka Sarath
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Innovative Data Communication Technologies and Application (ICIDCA)
abstract: Restaurants are under more and more pressure to offer their patrons individualized and effective services in the fast-paced world of today. In order to enable customizable online food ordering, this project intends to design and develop a comprehensive E-Restaurant Management System (ERMS) that incorporates multi-touch web and Android-based interfaces. LabVIEW serves as the main development platform for the suggested system, and Arduino is used for hardware integration. Customers can place orders online using the ERMS's user-friendly web interface or specialized Android application. Secure payment processing, customizable menu management, and real-time order tracking are all made possible by the system. Using a centralized dashboard, restaurant managers can keep an eye on orders, control inventory, and examine sales patterns. This project shows how LabVIEW, Android, and Firebase can be used to create creative, tech-driven solutions using real-time data bases.

title: Design and Implementation of a 2-DOF Manipulator Based on Inverse Kinematics for Agricultural Robotic Competition
authors: Muhamad Yusvin Mustar, Bintang Surya Tryatmojo, d Dian Ramadhan, Refi Febrian, Kunnu Purwanto, Rahmat Fauzi Siregar
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electronic and Electrical Engineering and Intelligent System (ICE3IS)
abstract: Inverse kinematics is a mathematical method used to calculate the required joint angles of a robotic arm to position its end-effector at a specific point in Cartesian space. This paper aims to propose a design and implement a 2-DOF robotic manipulator based on inverse kinematics for agricultural robotic competitions, particularly for Robot 1 in the ABU Robocon 2024. The main objective is to develop a lightweight and task-specific manipulator integrated with a mecanum-wheeled mobile robot platform, capable of accurately performing seedling picking and planting tasks on a planar surface within competition constraints. The manipulator system has two joint servo motors that drive each joint, and there is also a gripper as an end effector driven by one servo motor. The mechanical, hardware, and software designed for the manipulator system were successfully realized and implemented. Experimental results show that the system achieves acceptable positioning accuracy, and payload variations during operation tend to increase both positional error and execution time.

title: Adaptive Haar Wavelet Based Denoising for Noisy ECG Signal Restoration
authors: Vibhu Jangra, Himanshu Dhakad, Arpit Kumar Sharma
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Advances in Computing Research On Science Engineering and Technology (ACROSET)
abstract: This study provides a detailed approach for denoising physiological signals through wavelet transform techniques. We concentrate on essential attributes such as pre-RR intervals, post-RR intervals, r-peaks, and QT intervals, which are crucial for accurately analysing heart rate and variability. The methodology involves preprocessing the signals by normalizing them and addressing any missing values in the training data. Following this, the discrete wavelet transform is applied using Haar wavelets, and a soft thresholding technique is employed to effectively reduce noise while retaining significant signal features. We have evaluated the performance of the denoising process and have assessed it using the signal-to-noise ratio i.e the SNR as the evaluation parameter for the evaluation of this particular study. Then we have even plotted both the original signals and denoised signals that are provided for the illustration of the effectiveness of the proposed method that is used for this study. Our results demonstrate that wavelet-based denoising significantly improves the quality of physiological signals, facilitating more accurate analyses in clinical and research contexts. This particular study and the work will also highlight the potential use of the advanced signal processing techniques in order to enhance the interpretation of complex physiological data.

title: Enhancing Deep Learning to Identify Cardiac Hypertrophy in Patients with Diabetes: A Comprehensive Review
authors: Deepika Ryakala, P Balaji Srikaanth
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Innovative Data Communication Technologies and Application (ICIDCA)
abstract: Left ventricular hypertrophy (LVH) is a common condition in diabetics and is linked to an increased risk of heart disease. A timely and accurate diagnosis of LVH is essential for early intervention and better patient care. Advanced cardiac imaging methods such as computed tomography (CT) and magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the heart are used to more precisely assess the progression of LVH in conjunction with more traditional diagnostic methods such as electrocardiography (ECG) and echocardiography. Developing AI-driven models that study a variety of patient information, such as clinical, genetic, and lifestyle elements, can facilitate early identification of individuals at a higher risk of developing LVH. Additionally, these models can assist in predicting disease progression and help optimize personalized treatment strategies. In this review, we summarize literature in which deep learning models have been used for detection of LVH. For example, multiple researchers have reported the development of CNN models that classified LVH-positive / LVH-negative cases from our MRI images labelled. Our review moved beyond model classification of LVH and discussed the importance of model interpretability, specifically in medical imaging-related research. For instance, we reviewed methods including Grad-CAM and pixel-based heat maps that illustrate the features learned by CNN. We also summarized a number of datasets (imaging and ECG) and discussed model architectures (stating when CNNs were selected) and reported benchmark results of a number of recent studies. Preliminary results suggest accuracy and sensitivity in LVH diagnosis using deep learning to be high. To extend our review, we included discussion of late pre-clinical and clinical application of non-invasive AI tools in the context of being the first-line method for the early detection of LVH, in particular targeting patients with diabetes and other chronic diseases, plus challenges and potential avenues for future work, including the incorporation of multimodal patient data sources and model transparency.

title: Interactive HMI Visualization for a Real-Time Flow Control System Using Variable Speed Drive and Electromagnetic Flowmeter with HART-Based Calibration
authors: Safira Firdaus Mujiyanti, Ahmad Fauzan Adziimaa, Dafa Hasan Cramajaya, Tepy Lindia Nanta, Salwa Dzanur Royana, Ishmatu Aulia Rizky Kirana
publish: 2025 Eight International Conference on Vocational Education and Electrical Engineering (ICVEE)
abstract: Current industrial flow control systems face challenges in achieving both high precision and fast response. This research presents the development of an interactive human machine interface (HMI) for a real-time flow rate monitoring and control system. The system integrates an electromagnetic flowmeter and a variable speed drive (VSD) to adjust the pump speed based on input. The electromagnetic flowmeter, which has been calibrated using a HART communicator, ensured measurement reliability, and showed high measurement accuracy of 97.5% in measuring the system flow rate. The pump responded linearly to frequency inputs ranging from 0 to 50 Hz and successfully controlled flow rates in the range of 18 - 108 L/min. Real-time data on flow rate and motor frequency are effectively visualized through the HMI, allowing for precise manual adjustments. In addition, the HMI can store historical data and display trend visualization. This recorded data can be used to analyze system performance and identify errors.

title: Garbage Classification using Deep Learning: A Neural Network Approach for Automated Waste Sorting
authors: Sallauddin Mohmmad, Nagasri Pingili, Ravi Kumar Rachavaram, Gulab Singh Chauhan, Billakanti Srinivasa Rao
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Innovative Data Communication Technologies and Application (ICIDCA)
abstract: Effective waste management has become important for the world to protect the nurture from pollution. The automatic detection and classify of the garbage is essential for managing in separation of waste, control the increasing volume and complexity of household waste. This research focused on deep learning-based image classification system to automatically categorize waste into six classes: cupboard, paper, trash, metal, glass, and plastic. We evaluated and compared the performance of four Neural networks architectures: a custom-designed CNN, MobileNetV2, DenseNet121, and EfficientNetB0. All models trained using the Adam optimizer and categorical cross entropy loss. Among the tested architectures, EfficientNetB0 achieved the validation accuracy of 94.38% and a test accuracy of 94.66%, with the lowest validation loss of 0.1851. On the other hand, the MobileNetV2 gained the accuracy of 92.43% and custom CNN and DenseNet121 models yielded promising results with validation accuracies of 87.95% and 88.96%, respectively. Overall, the performance results demonstrated that deep learning models, particularly EfficientNetB0, could be effectively employed in automated garbage classification systems to support and more scalable waste sorting solutions.

title: Climate Feature Impact on Rainfall Prediction Using Recurrent Neural Networks: Comparative Analysis of AUSMI and ENSO Predictors in Central
authors: Hanifullah Hafidz Arrizal, Laila Ma’Rifatul Azizah, Marzuki Sinambela, Adi Widiatmoko Wastumirad, Nardi, Chayadi Oktomy Noto Susanto
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electronic and Electrical Engineering and Intelligent System (ICE3IS)
abstract: Understanding how climate indices affect rainfall prediction accuracy is key to improving forecasts in tropical monsoon areas. This study evaluates different combinations of climate features for dekadal rainfall prediction using three recurrent neural networks: GRU, BiLSTM, and hybrid BiLSTM-GRU. We used 33 years of dekadal rainfall data (1991-2023) from 34 stations across Central Java, Indonesia, and tested four predictor configurations: rainfall-only, rainfall+ENSO, rainfall+AUSMI, and rainfall+AUSMI+ENSO. Results show that rainfall-only predictors outperformed all other combinations, achieving the lowest MAE ($\mathbf{2 8. 5 5}$ mm) and highest $\mathbf{R}^{\mathbf{2}}$. Adding ENSO caused minimal change (MAE: 29.76 mm), while AUSMI significantly reduced accuracy (MAE: 32.09 mm).
