title: Severity Classification in Prostate Cancer using Exponential Revolution Optimization Algorithm Enabled Deep Quantum Neural Network
authors: Goddumarri Vijay Kumar, Mohammed Ismail Bellary, Thota Bhaskara Reddy
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Innovative Data Communication Technologies and Application (ICIDCA)
abstract: Prostate cancer continues to be a major cause of cancer-related mortality worldwide. Despite its often-slow progression and potential to remain asymptomatic for extended periods, it poses significant health risks, underscoring the importance of early detection and ongoing monitoring. Moreover, diverse existing approaches struggle to accurately distinguish between aggressive and indolent tumors. This lack of precision contributes to widespread issues of overdiagnosis and overtreatment, exposing patients to unnecessary interventions and associated health risks. Thus, this research proposes an Exponentially Revolution Optimization Algorithm enabled Deep Quantum Neural Network (EROA_QNN) for severity classification of prostate cancer. Firstly, MRI images are preprocessed using Hybrid Local and Non-Local Means (HLNLM) filtering. Then, Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) is used for segmentation. In feature extraction stage, various features, including Gradient Binary Patterns (GBP), statistical features, Local Gradient Patterns (LGP), and CNN-based features are extracted. Finally, severity classification is carried out using a Deep Quantum Neural Network (DQNN), and it is optimized using Exponentially Revolution Optimization Algorithm (EROA), which combines the Exponentially Weighted Moving Average (EWMA) with the Revolution Optimization Algorithm (ROA). Furthermore, EROA-QNN achieved an accuracy, sensitivity and specificity as 96.23%, 96.03%, and 95.81%.

title: Machine Learning-Based Smart Healthcare System for Diagnosis, Alerts, and Real Time Analytics
authors: Shivam Sharma, Shikhar Kumar, Shryansh Jaiswal, Sapna Bharti, Leeladhar Chourasiya, Sushma Khatri, Kamal Kumar Sethi
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Advances in Computing Research On Science Engineering and Technology (ACROSET)
abstract: The Machine Learning-Based Smart Healthcare System for Diagnosis, Alerts, and Real-Time Analytics is designed to enhance medical diagnostics and patient management using AI-driven technology. This system integrates machine learning models for X-ray and ECG analysis, allowing users to upload and analyze their medical reports to detect diseases like lung infections, tuberculosis, and heart abnormalities. Additionally, the platform provides an efficient doctor-patient interaction system, where doctors can upload prescriptions and medication schedules, enabling patients to track their treatment progress and receive real-time reminders. This feature helps in preventing missed medications and ensures adherence to prescribed treatment plans. The system is built as a cross-platform native application that runs on Android, iOS, Web, and Windows. The frontend is developed using Flutter (Dart, Material Design, XML, Java for Android), while the backend is powered by Express.js, MySQL, MariaDB, and Flask for API integration. The ML models utilize CNN (Convolutional Neural Networks) developed with Keras and TensorFlow, generating H5 and PKL model files for medical image analysis. Security is ensured through hashing techniques, while APIs are tested using Thunder Client. The system's goal is to improve early disease detection, automate diagnostics, and enhance healthcare accessibility while reducing the burden on hospitals. By leveraging AI, cloud storage, and real-time analytics, this project aims to revolutionize digital healthcare and provide a more efficient patient monitoring system.

title: Technical Analysis and Regulation of GSO Satellite Coordination on Ku-Band Frequency in Indonesia: Case Study of BRIsat and JSat-1C Satellites
authors: Michelle Octavia Yolanda Sari, Meiditomo Sutyarjoko, Nachwan Mufti Adriansyah
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electronic and Electrical Engineering and Intelligent System (ICE3IS)
abstract: The growing reliance on geostationary satellites (GSO) in Indonesia for telecommunications has introduced a range of technical and regulatory issues, especially within the Ku-band spectrum. This study focuses on BRIsat, a GSO satellite managed by PT Bank Rakyat Indonesia, assessing its operational capacity, strategies for interference reduction, and adherence to regulatory standards. A significant issue is the orbital proximity to JSat-1C, with a mere 0.5 -degree separation, which impacts BRIsat’s Carrier-to-Interference Ratio (C/I), notably in the downlink frequency (-1.43 dB), potentially leading to service quality issues. Compliance with ITU-R Articles 9, 11, and 21, along with Indonesia’s domestic regulations, is essential for ensuring sustainable satellite operations. The research suggests implementing advanced adaptive power control techniques and regulatory adjustments to reduce interference, enhance BRIsat’s operational efficiency, and secure its market presence in the long term.

title: Deep Learning-Enabled Detection of Dental Caries using Pre-Processed Mobile Intraoral Images
authors: Preethika R, Sakthivel D, Sanjai Kumar B, Mohanarathinam A
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Innovative Data Communication Technologies and Application (ICIDCA)
abstract: Dental caries is a widespread and long-term dis- ease that impacts billions of people across the globe, creates challenges to the overall well-being and health of the mouth. The proposed research paper discusses how deep learning and artificial intelligence (AI) can be used in dental diagnostics. It considers pre-processed images of mobile intraoral photographies as a novel approach to the early detection of carious lesions and application of treatment. The research will enhance the accuracy and reliability of caries detection by applying the existing convolutional neural network (CNN) architectures. This gives dental professionals an effective tool to find caries at an early stage. The research highlights the role of mobile technology in dentistry, allowing professionals in various settings to access powerful diagnostic features. The findings demonstrate the possibility of deep learning in clinical decision-making and patient outcomes. This leads to a future where dental caries could be detected early. In the long run, this study hopes to shift the approach in dental care, ensuring that people receive timely and quality treatment, which will improve oral health across the entire population.

title: A Systematic Approach to DC Bias Optimization for High Sensitivity Schottky Diode Detectors
authors: Yichen Liu, Xiong Chen, Han Yu, Yuhan Liu, Weikang Liu, Tianyu Zhuang
publish: 2025 18th IEEE United Conference on Millimeter Waves and Terahertz Technologies (UCMMT)
abstract: This paper presents the simulation and design of a 1.8 GHz Schottky diode detector with differential outputs. A comprehensive comparison was conducted on detector performance under different DC bias conditions, including forward current (I0), load resistance (RL), and bias voltage (Vb). The study primarily focuses on the trade-off between voltage sensitivity and square-law dynamic range. We propose using these performance variations as design criteria, enabling more strategic selection of detector DC operating points.

title: IFA-Based Antenna in LGA Package With Minimal Ground Clearance for BLE Module Applications
authors: Jiahui Zheng, Bo Yuan, Gaofeng Wang
publish: 2025 18th IEEE United Conference on Millimeter Waves and Terahertz Technologies (UCMMT)
abstract: This paper proposes a novel antenna with a very small clearance area in a Land Grid Array (LGA) package. The Antenna in Package (AiP) evolved from an inverted-F antenna (IFA) and is designed by considering the parasitic effects of the lands of LGA and the bonding wires. The parasitic effects are then neutralized by resistive loading and impedance matching technology for two different clearance areas of the Bluetooth Low Energy (BLE) Module, measuring <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$3 \times 8 ~\text{mm}^{2}$</tex> and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$4 \times 8 ~\text{mm}^{2}$</tex>, respectively. The antenna's bandwidth covers the entire Bluetooth band of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{2. 4 0 - 2. 4 8 ~ G H z}(|\mathbf{S 1 1}| \leq-\mathbf{1 0 ~ d B})$</tex>. Different sizes of Printed Circuit Boards (PCB) are utilized as the co-ground plane of the AiP. The simulated and measured results demonstrate that the efficiency of the AiP can reach 59.2 % and 74.1 % for ground clearances of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$3 \times 8 ~\text{mm}^{2}$</tex> and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$4 \times 8 ~\text{mm}^{2}$</tex>, respectively. This indicates that the AiP can be a promising candidate for BLE module applications.

title: Analysis of Electromagnetic Properties of Polymer Composites Doped with Shelled Particles
authors: Yisong Huang, Haidong Chen, Wenquan Che, Shizhao Yuan, Huawei Yu, Sheng Ding
publish: 2025 18th IEEE United Conference on Millimeter Waves and Terahertz Technologies (UCMMT)
abstract: This paper systematically examines the influence of particle shell structures on composite materials' effective electromagnetic properties over a wide frequency spectrum based on numerical calculation and simulation. The shell structure reduces the dielectric constants (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\varepsilon_{\mathrm{r}}$</tex>) and loss tangent <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(\tan \delta)$</tex> significantly due to the reduced dielectric strength between particles. Meanwhile, particles with and without shells exhibit a frequency-dependent decrease in the real part of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\varepsilon_{\mathrm{r}}$</tex> across the <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$10^{6} -10^{7} \text{Hz}$</tex> range and a frequency-independent decrease over the frequency range from MHz to THz. Based on the computational method, the study's results provide a solution for analysing interactions among micron-scale particles in composites to enhance various materials and applications in microwave and higher-frequency fields.s

title: A $\pm 45^{\circ}$ Dual-Polarized Millimeter-Wave Antenna Using Compressed High-order Mode Folded Dipoles
authors: Yu Luo, Zihan Zhou, Fei Xiao
publish: 2025 18th IEEE United Conference on Millimeter Waves and Terahertz Technologies (UCMMT)
abstract: This paper proposes a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\pm 45^{\circ}$</tex> dual-polarized antenna operating in the millimeter-wave band. The dual-polarized antenna employs a pair of non-uniform compressed third-order mode folded dipoles and a pair of basic-mode dipoles. By adjusting the magnitude and phase of the feed ports, the cross-polarization discrimination (XPD) is effectively improved. Simulation results indicate that the antenna operates within the <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$27.6-28.35 \text{GHz}$</tex> frequency range, achieving a maximum gain of 10.9 dBi. The axial XPD is 20.97 dB, and the XPD at <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\pm 60^{\circ}$</tex> is 9.04 dB.

title: A Microstrip Rat-Race Mixer Based on Spoof Surface Plasmon Polaritons Structure
authors: Tianyu Lu, Leilei Liu
publish: 2025 18th IEEE United Conference on Millimeter Waves and Terahertz Technologies (UCMMT)
abstract: This paper introduces the design process and simulation results of a microstrip rat-race mixer based on Spoof Surface Plasmon Polaritons (SSPP) structure. This single-balanced mixer is composed of a rat-race coupler and two SMS7621-079LF Schottky diodes. A comb-shaped SSPP structure is introduced to replace the microstrip transmission line. The operating frequency range is <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$23.5 \sim 24.5 \text{GHz}$</tex>, and the RF port is impedance matched within a 1 GHz bandwidth. When radio frequency (RF) signal at 24 GHz with the power of -30 dBm, and local oscillator (LO) signal at 24.01 GHz with the power of 8 dBm are injected, the mixer has minimum conversion loss of 7.3 dB. The structure proposed in this paper has no complex design and is easy to fabricate with PCB process.

title: Numerical Simulation of Macro-Electron Cyclotron Trajectories in a Gyrotron Electron Gun
authors: Ning Li, Efeng Wang, Chaojun Lei, Qixiang Zhao, Zihan Lei, Xu Zeng, Jinjun Feng
publish: 2025 18th IEEE United Conference on Millimeter Waves and Terahertz Technologies (UCMMT)
abstract: Taking the motion of a macro-electron in an electromagnetic field as an example, this paper utilizes a MATLAB visualization interface to derive the physical image of electron cyclotron motion in an electromagnetic field, explaining the formation process of large-orbit electron beams. The key to forming a large-orbit electron beam is that the electron's cyclotron direction changes as the axial magnetic field transitions from negative to positive. During this process, the positive axial magnetic field corrects the cyclotron center offset caused by the negative magnetic field, enabling the electron beam, after correction by the reversed magnetic field, to rotate around the central axis. Ultimately, a large-orbit electron beam with a guiding center radius (distance from the electron cyclotron center to the axis center) of zero is formed.

title: Design and Implementation of Hermetic Packaging for W-Band Low-Noise Amplifier MMIC
authors: Shihe Deng, Meng Zhang, Yunxi Guo, Xiaoyu Chen, Shujun Zhao, Yujie Yang
publish: 2025 18th IEEE United Conference on Millimeter Waves and Terahertz Technologies (UCMMT)
abstract: This paper presents the design and implementation of a low-insertion-loss, hermetic low-noise amplifier (LNA) module. To address the vulnerability of traditional E-plane waveguide probe packaging structures to moisture ingress during environmental testing, a hermetic vertical waveguide-tomicrostrip transition design is proposed. This design significantly enhances the module's robustness in harsh environments. Furthermore, by introducing a periodic gap waveguide structure around the waveguide short-circuit region, electromagnetic energy leakage and higher-order mode resonance within the quartz substrate are effectively suppressed. Simulation results demonstrate that the proposed waveguide-to-microstrip transition achieves a return loss better than -25 dB and an insertion loss below 0.3 dB across the <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$87.5-90.5 \text{GHz}$</tex> band. Measurements indicate that the LNA module exhibits a gain exceeding 20 dB, an input return loss below -20 dB, and a typical noise figure of 2.3 dB within the operational bandwidth. The loss attributed to the bilateral packaging is less than 1 dB. The overall performance shows excellent agreement with the chip datasheet, validating the effectiveness of the design.

title: A Fast Mutual Coupling Calculation Method for Multi-Antenna Systems
authors: Baoxuan Bian, Wu Ren, Dan Ding, Zhenghui Xue, Weiming Li
publish: 2025 18th IEEE United Conference on Millimeter Waves and Terahertz Technologies (UCMMT)
abstract: This paper proposes a fast calculation method for the mutual coupling characteristics of multi-antenna system. In this method, an excitation signal with different frequency components is set for each antenna, and all antennas are excited at the same time. For antennas working in the same frequency band, the orthogonal frequency division multiplexing (OFDM) signal with an orthogonal frequency component is used for excitation, and for antennas working in different frequency bands, a band signal with the corresponding center frequency is used for excitation. Taking the multi-antenna system of mobile phone as an example, the simulation results show that the calculation speed of the proposed method can be increased by about 34 % in the same frequency band and about 41 % in different frequency bands when the calculation results are in good agreement with the results of the conventional method.

title: A Wideband Circularly Polarized Microstrip Leaky-Wave Antenna Loaded With Rhombic Patch
authors: Wan-Hao Xu, Junbing Duan, You-Feng Cheng, Cheng Liao
publish: 2025 18th IEEE United Conference on Millimeter Waves and Terahertz Technologies (UCMMT)
abstract: This paper provides a wideband circularly polarized (CP) microstrip leaky-wave antenna (LWA) loaded with rhombic patch structure., The CP characteristic and open stopband (OSB) suppression are realized by asymmetrically loading shorting pins in the rhombic structure of the antenna. By constructing an 11-element series-fed antenna array, it shows that the antenna achieves an impedance bandwidth of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$55.65 \%(5.24 \text{GHz}-9.28 \text{GHz})$</tex> and a circular polarization (CP) bandwidth of 55.6 % (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$5.2 \text{GHz}-9.2 \text{GHz}$</tex>). The frequency-dependent beam angles can scan from <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$-39^{\circ}$</tex> to 26°, while the CP radiation coverages the same scanning range. Featuring broad bandwidth and wide-angle scanning capabilities, this antenna demonstrates strong potential for wireless communication and radar applications.

title: Evaluation of Data Rate Capabilities in Metallic Terahertz Waveguides for D-Band Applications
authors: Arslan Ahmed Sohoo, Fauziahanim Che Seman, Yee See Khee, Izhar Ahmed Sohu, Sajjad Ahmed Bhatti, Nurul Syafeeqa binti Ishak
publish: 2025 IEEE International RF and Microwave Conference (RFM)
abstract: There is a drive in the exploration of the high-frequency band, such as mm-waves and terahertz (THz) waves, with the increment in the demand for high-speed communication systems and applications. This study aims to explore the propagation characteristics of hollow circular waveguides (HCW) of different metallic materials for potential THz applications. The propagation characteristics of hollow-circular waveguides (HCWs) were analyzed using CST Studio Suite for the D-band range (110 to 180 GHz). Following this analysis, each waveguide's maximum achievable data rate per unit length is estimated using a channel model. The obtained results imply that hollow circular waveguides (HCWs) can achieve data rates in the terabits per second (Tbps). The work provides insightful data for improving terahertz high-bandwidth waveguide designs.

title: EARTH: Efficient Architecture for RISC-V Vector Memory Access
authors: Hongyi Guan, Yichuan Gao, Chenlu Miao, Haoyang Wu, Hang Zhu, Mingfeng Lin, Huayue Liang
publish: 2025 34th International Conference on Parallel Architectures and Compilation Techniques (PACT)
abstract: Vector processors frequently suffer from inefficient memory accesses, particularly for strided and segment memory access patterns. While coalescing strided accesses is a natural solution, effectively gathering or scattering elements at fixed strides remains a significant challenge. Naive approaches typically rely on high-overhead crossbars that remap any byte in memory or registers to any position in registers or memory, leading to physical design issues. Meanwhile, segment operations require row-column transpositions, which are often handled using either element-level in-place transposition (degrading performance) or large buffer-based bulk transposition (incurring high area overhead). Both options are undesirable, highlighting a need for more efficient solutions. In this paper, we present EARTH, a novel vector memory access architecture designed to overcome these challenges through shifting-based optimizations. For strided accesses, EARTH integrates specialized shift networks for gathering and scattering strided elements. After coalescing multiple accesses into one request within the same cache line, data can be routed between memory and registers through the shifting network with minimal overhead. For segment operations, EARTH employs a shifted register bank that enables direct column-wise access, eliminating the need for dedicated segment buffers while providing highperformance, in-place bulk transposition at acceptable overhead. We implemented the entire EARTH design on FPGA with Chisel HDL based on an open-source RISC-V vector unit Saturn. Our evaluation demonstrates that EARTH enhances performance for strided memory accesses proportionally to their prevalence in workloads, achieving $\mathbf{4 x}-\mathbf{8 x}$ speedups in benchmarks dominated by strided operations. The architecture also delivers area-efficient segment handling. Compared to conventional designs, EARTH reducing hardware area by 9% and power consumption by 41%. By optimizing these necessary memory access patterns, EARTH significantly advances both the performance and efficiency of vector processors.

title: Gain Enhancement of a Novel Circularly Polarized Dielectric Resonator Antenna Using a Metallic Superstrate for Millimeter Wave 5G Applications
authors: Abinash Gaya, Mohd Haizal Jamaluddin, Irene Kong Cheh Lin
publish: 2025 IEEE International RF and Microwave Conference (RFM)
abstract: A novel millimeter wave Dielectric Resonator Antenna (DRA) is proposed here resonating at 26 GHz for 5G applications. The novel DRA has achieved a bandwidth of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$5.7 \mathbf{G H z}$</tex> which is <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{2 1. 9 2 \%}$</tex> of the impedance bandwidth. The antenna is linearly polarized and has achieved a gain value of 5.8 dBi. A metallic patch has been used as a superstrate to enhance the gain here. 2.1 dBi gain value has been increased after using a metallic superstrate just above the antenna. The superstrate is situated 2 mm from the top edge of the antenna. The metallic superstrate has enhanced the gain of the DRA because of close loop coupling. The DRA has maximum radiation towards the broadside direction and is linearly polarized. The ultra-wide bandwidth and higher gain values has made this antenna more suitable for the millimeter wave frequency band applications.

title: Analysis of Perlis Riverine Water Quality Using Thermal Infrared and Microwave Sensing Method
authors: Kishaan Rao Subramaniam, Fwen Hoon Wee, Been Seok Yew
publish: 2025 IEEE International RF and Microwave Conference (RFM)
abstract: This study evaluates the dielectric constant of riverine water to determine its purity, with a focus on Perlis waters where pollution is a major concern. Common contaminants include toxic chemicals, oil, garbage, suspended particles, and sewage, often caused by untreated waste from human activities. Soil and sand also mix with river and seawater, further affecting its purity. Accurate analysis requires reliable measurement techniques. This paper uses dielectric measurement and infrared temperature sensing to assess water quality. A high-temperature coaxial probe is used to measure the dielectric constant, a key indicator of water purity. Infrared sensors detect thermal emissions to help identify and classify debris. The study compares clean water with water mixed with soil, observing changes in both dielectric and temperature values. These techniques provide a reliable method for analyzing the composition and quality of riverine water, supporting efforts to address water contamination problems in Perlis.

title: Discrete PID-Based Trajectory Tracking for Robotic Manipulators Using the Grasshopper Optimization Algorithm
authors: Morteza Harati, Nima Hanari, Amir A. Ghavifekr, Mina Salim
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Control, Instrumentation and Automation (ICCIA)
abstract: This paper provides a discrete PID-based trajectory tracking approach for robotic manipulators, where the parameters of the controller are optimally tuned utilizing the Grasshopper Optimization Algorithm (GOA). The PID controller is discretized using trapezoidal integration and backward differentiation and applied for a two-degree-offreedom (DOF) manipulator which is modeled by Lagrangian formulation. The performance index which is employed for optimization is the Integral of Time-weighted Absolute Error (ITAE). The GOA-based PID controller is compared with a Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO)-based PID under two scenarios: (i) nominal conditions without disturbances, and (ii) uncertain conditions with external disturbances. Simulation results demonstrate that the proposed GOA-tuned PID outperforms the PSO-tuned PID in terms of trajectory tracking accuracy, convergence speed, and robustness against disturbances. Specifically, the GOA-based controller achieves lower ITAE values and faster convergence, thereby providing superior performance in both nominal and uncertain environments.

title: A Control-Oriented Index for Monitoring Sleep Apnea Severity Progression Using Longitudinal Oxygen Desaturation Changes
authors: Elmira Aftabi, Shiva Naghsh, Ali Akbar Safavi, Amir Sharafkhaneh
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Control, Instrumentation and Automation (ICCIA)
abstract: Sleep apnea (SA) is a prevalent sleep disorder that can lead to serious health complications as its severity progresses. Detecting changes in severity through continuous monitoring is critical for timely intervention and prevention of adverse outcomes. This study proposes a minimalistic longitudinal approach to determine whether SA severity remains stable or worsens, using a single, easily measurable biomarker-blood oxygen desaturation (NDes3pH). Data from the Sleep Heart Health Study (SHHS), comprising two time points (SHHS1 and SHHS2) from the same individuals, were analyzed. NDes3pH values from SHHS1 and the change in NDes3pH between SHHS2 and SHHS1 were used as features. A multilayer perceptron classifier achieved <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{8 0. 0 \%}$</tex> accuracy, <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{8 2. 5 \%}$</tex> recall, <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{7 9. 7 \%}$</tex> precision, 81.1% F1-score, 0.811 and 79.6% AUC in distinguishing individuals with stable severity from those with worsening severity. The method requires only fingertip oximeter readings, enabling low-cost, scalable, and accessible monitoring. Findings highlight the potential of simple longitudinal metrics to support personalized care and digital health-based monitoring systems.

title: Hand Objects Classification for Personality Recognition Using YOLOV5
authors: Ni Kadek Dwi Rusjayanthi, I Ketut Gede Darma Putra, Made Sudarma, Anak Agung Kompiang Oka Sudana
publish: 2025 International Conference on Smart-Green Technology in Electrical and Information Systems (ICSGTEIS)
abstract: Palmistry is a science that studies personality or individual traits through reading hands, including palms. The premise that personality can be recognized from hand features forms the basis for this research. Hand objects studied in this research were Head Lines, Line Frequency, Saturn Lines, Mars Mount, and Little Finger. The classification of hand objects was performed using a Deep Learning approach, specifically leveraging the YOLOV5 architecture. This classification was carried out in several stages: Data Selection, Data Annotation, Data Spliting, Training, and Testing. The hand objects utilized are correlated with the Big Five Personality Theory, which consisted of five dimensions: Agreeableness, Conscientiousness, Extraversion, Neuroticism, and Openness. The results obtained were the highest value in the recognition of Line Frequency with a precision rate of 0.979, recall 0.897, mAP50 0.995, and mAP5095 0.723. The lowest results were obtained for the Saturn Line, Mars Mount, and Little Finger objects: precision 0.693, recall 0.623, mAP50 0.626, and mAP50-95 0.278. The highest class mAP, achieved by both the Many Lines Class and Few Lines Class, matched the overall mAP of the Line Frequency Object, which was 0.995. Conversely, the Long Little Finger Class recorded the lowest mAP at 0.358.

title: A Highly Sensitive Microfluidic T-Resonator for Detecting Aqueous Solutions
authors: Rammah A. Alahnomi, Z Zakaria, N. A. Rahman, N. A. Shairi, Syah Alam, A. A. M. Bahar
publish: 2025 IEEE International RF and Microwave Conference (RFM)
abstract: Microwave resonator-based sensors have emerged as powerful tools for precise, non-invasive material analysis. Their ability to provide real-time, label-free measurements makes them particularly attractive for chemical and biological applications. In this study, a compact microfluidic T-shaped resonator is proposed for accurate detection of aqueous solutions. The structure is carefully engineered to confine the electromagnetic field within the sensing region, enabling the detection of small variations in the dielectric properties of test liquids through measurable frequency shifts. A microfluidic channel is integrated to ensure controlled sample handling, consistency, and minimal losses. To further enhance performance, the resonator is combined with a blazed grating and operates at a resonant frequency of approximately 2.5 GHz. The sensor achieves a normalized sensitivity of about 0.51% and is capable of detecting a wide permittivity range from 1 to 78.54. Experimental results confirm that the proposed design provides higher sensitivity than conventional resonators, demonstrating strong potential for practical applications in liquid characterization and biochemical sensing.

title: Experimental Study of Screen-Printed Lab-on-a-Chip with Conductive Ink
authors: Thanakrit Thanacharoenchanaphas, Kessararat Ugsornrat, Wichayaporn Kamsong, Triwit Phurksasukkasem, Chanpen Karuwan, Adisorn Tuantranont
publish: 2025 Research, Invention, and Innovation Congress: Innovative Electricals and Electronics (RI2C)
abstract: In this work, a multifunctional lab-on-a-chip device was developed by integrating electrowetting-on-dielectric (EWOD) and electrochemical sensing on a single microfluidic platform. The device utilizes screen-printed electrodes fabricated with conductive ink on a flexible substrate. The microchannel design was modified from a traditional T-junction to an H-junction configuration, enabling the precise manipulation of up to four discrete droplets for complex reagent handling. The electrochemical sensing module utilizes a three-electrode configuration, comprising a carbon working electrode, carbon counter electrode, and a silver/silver chloride (Ag/AgCl) reference electrode. Electrochemical action was evaluated using cyclic voltammetry (CV) in 0.1 M phosphate-buffered saline (PBS) at pH 7.0. NADH was used as the target analyte due to its relevance in enzymatic lactate detection pathways. A distinct oxidation peak for NADH was observed at approximately +0.6 V (vs. Ag/AgCl), confirming the system’s capability for NADH detection and its potential as a platform for indirect lactate sensing via electrochemical methods.

title: Thermal Interface Material Validation Framework for Large-Scale Chip Packages
authors: Chris Lin, Sam Hsu, Edward Wu
publish: 2025 20th International Microsystems, Packaging, Assembly and Circuits Technology Conference (IMPACT)
abstract: With the continuous advancements in semiconductor technology, the power consumption and heat flux density of chips have increased significantly, creating an ever-growing demand for more efficient thermal management solutions. The heat dissipation pathway of a chip begins at the chip itself (junction-to-case), then flows through the thermal interface material (TIM) to the thermal cooling solution, and is further dissipated into the surrounding environment or other devices. The TIM acts as a critical bridge between the chip and the thermal solution. If its performance is under expectation, even the most effective thermal solution will fail to achieve its maximum potential.

title: Cloud-Based Personal e-Healthcare System for Medical Doctors in Compliance with National Regulations
authors: Altuğ Şimşek, İlke Bahçeci Şimşek, Günhan Dündar
publish: 2025 International Conference on Smart-Green Technology in Electrical and Information Systems (ICSGTEIS)
abstract: Rapid advances in information and communication technologies enabled widespread use of digital tools, devices and systems to deliver health-related services. From electronic health records (EHRs) and telemedicine to mobile health applications and wearable computing devices, e-healthcare represents a paradigm shift in medical care which creates a demand for scalable, cost-effective and highly available cloud infrastructures accessible by all parties in a modern healthcare ecosystem. In this paper we describe a complete cloud-based e-healthcare platform for medical doctors in compliance with the national regulations currently in force in Türkiye. Doctors can store health records, pictures, videos and documents of their patients on the cloud in an indexable and encrypted fashion with keys specific to every doctor. To comply with current regulations, consent of patients in accordance with the Personal Data Protection law is taken electronically for their medical data to be stored, encryption keys and encrypted data are never stored on the same system, a three-layer protection scheme is employed while accessing the data over the Internet by using doctor and patient frontends, patient medical data are directly synchronized with Ministry of Health Personal Health Services, and financial receipts are directly generated on behalf of the Ministry of Treasury Internal Revenue Service. The proposed system also has direct connections to authorized financial institutions for credit card processing and national and international messaging operators for SMS notifications. Independent from the institution they work for, the proposed system has all the tools for doctors required for practicing and is available in a monthly subscription-based software-as-a-service (SaaS) price model.

title: Data Processing and Fusion Technology based on The Transformer Architecture Large Model Technology
authors: Jia Zhao, Ming Cui, Haifeng Fang
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Computer Information Technology (AICIT)
abstract: With the rapid development of intelligent and connected vehicles, the scale and complexity of data are increasing rapidly. How to process and integrate massive, multi-source heterogeneous automotive data efficiently has become a key issue. Large model technology, with its powerful learning and representation capabilities, offers new solutions for data preprocessing and fusion. This paper presents a data processing and fusion framework based on the Transformer architecture large model, first obtaining multi-source heterogeneous data including digital and text through techniques such as web crawlers; Then, machine learning processes such as data cleaning, data transformation, PCA data dimensionality reduction, and feature extraction from large models are carried out on the data; Finally, conduct comparative analysis through experiments. The experiments showed that the framework performed well in terms of data fusion speed and data accuracy. The approach provides a theoretical approach and innovative model for data cross-border and data fusion in the automotive industry.

title: Model-Free Motion Control of Parallel Robots Based on a Fuzzy Adaptive Direct-Discrete Recurrent Neural Network
authors: Binbin Qiu, Zhenhan Zhang, Jinjin Guo
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Control, Robotics and Cybernetics (CRC)
abstract: This work proposes a fuzzy adaptive direct-discrete recurrent neural network (RNN) model to address the limitations of fixed time steps in traditional RNN models for the model-free motion control of parallel robots. First, kinematic equations are established through direct discretization, eliminating the dependence on continuous-time environments and continuous models inherent in indirect-discrete RNN methods. Second, a fuzzy control system (FCS) is designed to dynamically adjust time steps by generating fuzzy-power factors based on logarithmic error inputs. Third, an adaptive coefficient matrix estimation method is developed for scenarios with unknown robot parameters. Finally, simulative experimental results demonstrate that the fuzzy adaptive strategy achieves significant computational time reduction in complex trajectory tracking tasks. This study provides a novel framework for the control of parallel robots in highly dynamic scenarios.

title: A Physically Driven Off-Road Autonomous Driving Comfort Path Planning Method Based on Road Surface Vibration Response Prediction
authors: Xingyu Zhou, Yutong Jiang, Zhiqi Du, Fan Yang, Xingxin Li, Jiahe Tian
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Control, Robotics and Cybernetics (CRC)
abstract: In off-road autonomous driving, the decline in ride comfort caused by severe road surface vibrations is a key challenge. Existing methods primarily rely on terrain geometric features (such as elevation variance) for path decision-making, making it difficult to quantify the actual impact of vibrations on vehicle dynamics and lacking active optimization of comfort. To address this, this paper proposes a physics-based method for predicting road surface vibration responses and optimizing path planning. First, a digital elevation model is constructed using radar point clouds, and key geometric features (elevation standard deviation and slope) are extracted. An innovative simplified vehicle vibration physical model is introduced to establish a mapping relationship between terrain features and the predicted root mean square value of vertical body acceleration, with parameters obtained through real-vehicle calibration, enabling precise physical quantification of bump comfort. Subsequently, the root mean square value of vertical body acceleration is set as the core optimization objective, and a comfort-oriented path planner is designed: the cost function of the A* algorithm is improved to explicitly integrate comfort cost, path length cost, and obstacle distance cost, achieving a multi-objective balance between safety, efficiency, and comfort. Real-vehicle validation conducted in typical off-road environments demonstrates that the proposed model achieves high prediction accuracy. Compared to traditional obstacle avoidance and elevation variance optimization planners, this method significantly reduces body vertical acceleration values (with an average reduction exceeding 35percents) while only moderately increasing path length (less than 30 percents). This study provides a mechanistically clear solution for enhancing occupant comfort and component durability in off-road autonomous driving.

title: Odd Ones Out: Exploiting Prediction Mismatch for Universal Generated Image Detection
authors: Yi-Hong Yeh, Hau-Ching Chen, Jiann-Liang Chen
publish: 2025 9th Cyber Security in Networking Conference (CSNet)
abstract: Traditional detectors trained on both real and synthetic images tend to overfit to known generative artifacts and perform poorly on unseen generation models. To address this issue, we propose a pixel-prediction framework trained exclusively on real images to detect synthetic content without fake-image supervision. Experimental results on the GenImage benchmark have shown that the proposed approach achieves an average AUC of 0.829. To prevent pixel information leakage that existed in previous work without increasing computational complexity, we propose Zero-Leakage Linear-time Pixel Model (ZLPM), a model that employs hollow convolution and 2 × 2 grouping, stacked on top of a modified U-Net that predicts per-pixel value distributions, after which negative log-likelihood (NLL) and entropy are aggregated via linear regression to classify real versus synthetic images. Performance is further boosted by modeling the NLL–entropy relationship via least-squares fitting.

title: Shallow Buried Metal Detection Based on Millimeter-Wave Synthetic Aperture Radiometric Imaging
authors: Zhaoyang Fang, Guangfeng Zhang, Zhenhong Fan
publish: 2025 18th IEEE United Conference on Millimeter Waves and Terahertz Technologies (UCMMT)
abstract: This study investigates the simulation detection and imaging analysis of shallow-buried metal targets in nearfield scenarios using a synthetic aperture radiometer. The impact of baseline loss due to random antenna absence was simulated, and a more reliable antenna array was optimized using greedy and simulated annealing algorithms. After increasing antenna redundancy, simulations were repeated and compared. Results show that under near-field conditions, the low-redundancy array achieves excellent imaging after phase correction, with clear targets and sharp edges in the brightness temperature map, though performance declines with antenna loss. Comparing the two optimized arrays, the greedy algorithm's design yields better imaging under antenna absence and remains functional in loss scenarios, supporting practical applications for shallow-buried target detection.

title: A Broadband Linear-to-Linear Polarization Conversion Metasurface
authors: Jin Zhang, Ayesha Kosar, Lulu Han, Cunjun Ruan
publish: 2025 18th IEEE United Conference on Millimeter Waves and Terahertz Technologies (UCMMT)
abstract: In this paper, a broadband linear-to-linear polarization conversion reflective metasurface is proposed and investigated. The unit cell of the metasurface consists of three layers: a top resonant ring integrated with a bowtie structure, a dielectric substrate, and a bottom ground plane. It can complete linear-to-linear polarization conversion, achieving polarization conversion ratio exceeding 90% over the frequency band of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$36.67-43.14 \text{GHz}$</tex> (relative bandwidth: 32.3%). Furthermore, the polarization conversion performance remains stable for incident angles up to 30°. The proposed metasurface exhibits advantages of simple structures, wide operating frequency band and high conversion efficiency, showing significant application potential in advanced microwave communication systems.

title: Design of Terahertz Antenna with High Gain and Low Side Lobe
authors: Huan Yang, Yi-Fei Mu, Gui-Ping Fu, Long Yun, Xing-Fan Wu
publish: 2025 18th IEEE United Conference on Millimeter Waves and Terahertz Technologies (UCMMT)
abstract: As a Key converter of Communication, Terahertz antenna has been developed greatly in recent years. In view of the high gain and low side lobe requirements of terahertz band, a offset reflector antenna is designed. The operating bandwidth is about 7 %, and the feed adopts multimode horn, which is compact and easy to process. From simulation, the gain great than 36 dB, the 3 dB beamwidth is about 2.7 deg, which is in line with the design expectation.

title: Robust Null-Broadening Beamforming Algorithm in High-Dynamic Scenarios
authors: Haowei Dong, Jianyin Cao, Zhendong Ding, Hao Wang
publish: 2025 18th IEEE United Conference on Millimeter Waves and Terahertz Technologies (UCMMT)
abstract: A robust null-broadening beam-forming algorithm integrating double projection, adaptive diagonal loading, and covariance matrix tapering (CMT) is proposed in this paper. Traditional minimum variance distortionless response (MVDR) algorithm has the disadvantages of fixed nulls being unable to suppress dynamic interference and the main lobe being prone to deviation in high dynamic scenarios. By applying the proposed algorithm, nulls of interference are deepened through double projection of signals onto interference/noise subspaces. Besides, desired signal proportions are reduced by adaptive diagonal loading, and null width is broadened through CMT processing. Simulations are designed based on an array of 16 elements. The results demonstrate that stable null depth, width, and main lobe gain are maintained by the application of proposed algorithm. When the number of snapshots K is 200, the performance of this method is superior to that of the MVDR and MVDR-orthogonal subspace projection (MVDR-OSP) algorithms. The output signal-to-interference-plus-noise ratio (SINR) varying with signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) is kept consistent across the entire interval, indicating suitability for high-dynamic environments.

title: Dynamic Simulation Techniques of Grid Connected-Large Induction Machine
authors: P. Kumkratug
publish: 2025 International Conference on Power, Energy and Innovations (ICPEI)
abstract: This paper develops the method for dynamic analysis of large induction machine connected to a grid power system. The proposed method is based on the open source program offering advantages such as saving simulation cost and time. The equivalent circuit of induction motor consists of a transient voltage source and impedance. The proposed method was tested on a test system and also validated through the newest version SimPowerSystem/ MATLAB R2024b.

title: Rice Paddy Yield Prediction using Artificial Neural Network with Rice Growth Parameters in Thailand
authors: Hathaiwan Wichaidit, Parinya Srisattayakul
publish: 2025 International Conference on Power, Energy and Innovations (ICPEI)
abstract: This research aims to develop an artificial neural network (ANN) model for predicting rice yield in Thailand, due to rice is an important economic crop that plays an important role in national food security and economy. Although statistical analysis methods have been used to predict rice yield in the past, they still have limitations in handling complex data and non-linear relationships between variables. This research designs an appropriate ANN based on 10-year historical data covering 20 main variables of rice growth, economic factors, and climate. The ANN model is designed to compare the performance of three hidden layer structures, namely ANN-10, ANN-15 and ANN-20, using ReLU activation function, Adam algorithm and early stopping technique to control overfitting. The data is divided into training set and testing set in chronological order to evaluate the yield accuracy. The analysis results found that ANN-10 had the lowest average mean absolute percentage error (MAPE) value at 12.73%, which is within the standard criteria for predicting economic crop yields, while ANN-15 and ANN-20 had slightly higher MAPE values. These results reflect that determining the optimal number of nodes and structure significantly improves the learning potential, reduces the risk of overfitting, and improves the model accuracy.

title: Ontologies and Artificial Intelligence: Bridging Semantic Gaps in Machine Understanding
authors: Krithika M, Fathima Rumaiza SM, S. Prathi, M. Elavarasi
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Innovative Data Communication Technologies and Application (ICIDCA)
abstract: As artificial intelligence (AI) systems come decreasingly complex and integrated into real- world operations, the need for machines to understand and reason about data in a mortal- like, semantically rich manner has grown more critical. Ontologies are the formal representations of knowledge within a sphere which play a vital part in enabling this semantic understanding. This paper explores the crossroad of ontologies and AI, fastening on how onw ontological fabrics can bridge the semantic gap between raw data and machine cognition. We dissect the part of ontologies in enhancing knowledge representation, perfecting interoperability, and supporting logic and conclusion in AI systems. It is a structured survey and synthesis of published evidence in healthcare, Natural Language Processing (NLP), and Semantic Web domains. We position ontologies as conceptual frameworks that support semantic enrichment of AI systems and provide illustrative examples from existing literature rather than experimental validation. The main contributions are: (1) a structured literature synthesis with transparent selection criteria, (2) a conceptual three layer architecture for integrating ontologies with AI (Ontology Layer, AI Layer, Integration Layer), and (3) identification of open challenges including ontology alignment, scalability, and maintenance. Eventually, this paper argues that ontologies are not just support tools but foundational factors for erecting transparent, resolvable, and semantically able AI.

title: Personalized English Vocabulary Learning System using Reinforcement Learning and Cognitive Behavior Pattern Recognition Techniques
authors: Edgardo B. Sario, Sonny Boy V. Villegas, Melito D. Mayormente
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Innovative Data Communication Technologies and Application (ICIDCA)
abstract: The increasing global prominence of English has made vocabulary acquisition a critical component in language proficiency, especially for non-native speakers. Traditional vocabulary learning systems often lack dynamic personalization and fail to account for cognitive behavioral variations such as fatigue, confusion, or engagement, limiting their long-term effectiveness. To address these shortcomings, this study proposes a novel hybrid framework RL-CBPR-MAAN which integrates Reinforcement Learning (RL), Cognitive Behavior Pattern Recognition (CBPR), and a Memory-Augmented Attention Network (MAAN) to deliver personalized English vocabulary learning experiences. The primary objective is to adaptively recommend vocabulary learning paths by analyzing individual learner performance and cognitive states. Unlike conventional models, the proposed system dynamically adjusts difficulty and content delivery in real-time, enhancing learner engagement and retention. Tools such as NLTK, Transformers, and TensorFlow/Keras are used for data preprocessing, cognitive modeling, and training. Experimental results using the Duolingo English Learner Dataset demonstrate that the RL-CBPR-MAAN model achieves superior performance with 83.6% accuracy, 82.4% F1-score, 91.2% engagement, and a 28% retention gain, significantly outperforming baseline methods. The system’s ability to recognize cognitive states and adapt learning content accordingly represents a novel contribution to intelligent language tutoring, offering a scalable, data-driven solution for improving vocabulary acquisition efficiency.

title: Delay Index Modulation (DIM): a Low-Complexity Acoustic Communication Scheme for IoT Networks
authors: Raed Mesleh, Omar Hiari, Reem Asakreh
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Internet of Things and Intelligence Systems (IoTaIS)
abstract: This study presents delay index modulation (DIM), a novel approach to enhancing acoustic communication systems. DIM encodes data by selectively activating one of multiple available acoustic transmitters at each time instant, transmitting identical, unmodulated signals. Receivers decode information by analyzing propagation delays, eliminating the need for complex modulation schemes. A proof-of-concept implementation in free-space environments demonstrates DIM’s feasibility, achieving reliable data transmission with low computational complexity and robustness to channel variations. Analytical modeling and Monte Carlo simulations further validate its scalability and energy efficiency, reinforcing its potential for practical deployment. While this work focuses on free-space validation, future research aims to adapt DIM for underwater applications, addressing key challenges such as multipath fading and Doppler effects.

title: Multi-Class Cell Segmentation in H&E Images Using Deep Learning
authors: Dzaky Hanif Arjuna, Edy Kurniawan, Reza Fuad Rachmadi, I Ketut Eddy Purnama
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Internet of Things and Intelligence Systems (IoTaIS)
abstract: Manual analysis of positive and negative in H&E-stained histopathology images is critical yet remains subjective and time-consuming in breast cancer prognosis. This study proposes an automated multi-class segmentation approach using a U-Net architecture to distinguish between these cell types. We evaluated the method across six experimental scenarios, comparing two data preparation strategies (image resizing vs. image tiling) and multiple hyperparameter configurations, including learning rate and regularization techniques. Results show that image tiling, which preserves high-resolution details, significantly outperforms resizing. The model with the highest performance obtained a Mean Intersection over Union (IoU). 0.6619 and Dice Coefficient 0.8664 on the test set by combining image tiling with using reduced learning rate of 0.00005 and stronger regularization (Dropout 0.3 and L2). Despite limitations such as class imbalance and the absence of data augmentation, this study highlights the proposed method’s potential as a precise and efficient tool for automated Ki-67 analysis in clinical settings.

title: Intelligent Control Strategies for Precise AUV Depth Regulation
authors: Amirhossein Mashghdoust, Mohammad Reza Kamali Ardakani, Mahdi Pourgholi, Sajjad Rezvani Khaledi
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Control, Instrumentation and Automation (ICCIA)
abstract: The ocean holds untapped resources and critical infrastructure, yet its exploration demands precision in navigating dynamic underwater environments. This paper advances Autonomous Underwater Vehicle depth control, enabling reliable performance in missions like offshore energy inspections and deep-sea ecological surveys. We develop and evaluate three AI-enhanced controllers, integrating neural networks and chaos game optimization for real-time adaptation to ocean currents and disturbances. Simulations testing at a 57 m target depth show that our multilayer perceptron (MLP)-based controller achieves near-zero steady-state error and reduces movement fluctuations by 31.3 % compared to fuzzy-based alternatives, ensuring smoother and more energy-efficient motion. These advancements deliver millimeter-level precision, empowering AUVs to maintain subsea cables, map hydrothermal vents, and monitor marine ecosystems with unprecedented stability, even in turbulent waters.

title: Design and Realization of a Low-Cost $4 \times 4$ Butler Matrix Antenna Array for C-Band Beamforming
authors: Soumya Sundar Pattanayak, Naveen Kumar, Shwetha M
publish: 2025 IEEE International RF and Microwave Conference (RFM)
abstract: The article addresses the design and modelling of a beam-forming antenna array employing a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$4 \times 4$</tex> Butler Matrix Network (BMN) for C-band applications. The proposed lowcost antenna is designed and simulated using CST Microwave Studio Suite (V. 2024), and the prototype is fabricated using an in-house PCB manufacturing process. Simulated results demonstrate that the antenna can form beam patterns in four distinct directions <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\left (\pm 3^{0}, \pm 19^{0}\right)$</tex>. The design achieves a wide −10db bandwidth of 14.5% at 5.575 GHz, along with a narrow bandwidth of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$2.5 \%, 1.07 \%, 1 \%$</tex>, and 2.72% at <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$4.327,4.677,4.99$</tex>, and 6.6 GHz, respectively. Also, it exhibits very good gain and considerable radiation efficiency. Furthermore, excellent agreement between simulated and experimental results confirms the validity and effectiveness of the proposed design.

title: Comparative Study of BERT and ChatGPT for Multi-Label Cyberbullying Detection with Intensity Scoring
authors: Nathaniel Xin Rong Tay, Hui Na Chua, Muhammed Basheer Jasser, Bayan Issa, Ghassan Saleh Aldharhani
publish: 2025 IEEE 15th International Conference on System Engineering and Technology (ICSET)
abstract: Cyberbullying on social media often involves subtle, context-dependent language, posing challenges for automated detection. Traditional machine learning approaches, reliant on handcrafted features and shallow context, struggle to capture such nuances. Transformer-based Large Language Models (LLMs) like BERT and ChatGPT offer deeper semantic understanding and zero-shot learning capabilities, yet their comparative effectiveness in multi-label cyberbullying classification and severity estimation remains underexplored. This study evaluates BERT (zero-shot classification) and ChatGPT (prompt-based classification) against a reference-standard dataset of human-annotated online comments, covering overlapping categories of abuse. Performance was measured using BLEU, ROUGE, macro-F1, and weighted-F1 metrics, with an intensity scoring framework to quantify severity. Results show BERT aligns closely with human annotations across all metrics, detecting both common and rare categories, while ChatGPT performs well for high-frequency categories but struggles with nuanced cases. This study's contributions include: (i) a reproducible evaluation framework for LLM-based multi-label abuse detection, (ii) operationalization of intensity scoring for severity-aware moderation, and (iii) comparative evidence on strengths and limitations of discriminative versus generative LLMs in ethically sensitive Natural Language Processing (NLP) tasks.

title: Poster:Value-Aware Scheduler for Energy Reduction
authors: Haiyue Ma, Kaifeng Xu, David Wentzlaff
publish: 2025 34th International Conference on Parallel Architectures and Compilation Techniques (PACT)
abstract: Optimizing energy consumption for computing workloads is a critical challenge, especially as we push the limits of high-performance systems within resource constraints. An underexplored approach to reducing energy costs is exploiting value locality: the tendency of instructions to process similar operand values during execution. Instruction operand values have abundant similarities within the reachable instruction window, a factor that existing architectures currently ignore. This paper introduces the broad concept of instruction-level, value-aware scheduling, an approach that leverages value locality in the hardware scheduler. By redirecting instructions of similar operand values to move together down the pipeline, the scheduler can reduce switching activity and dynamic energy usage. Such valueaware design philosophy, capable of adapting to a diverse range of workloads and architectures, has potential to be applied in broader architectural improvements.

title: IS2 inside museums: the case of the "Adria" rattle’s interactive installation
authors: Giulio Pitteri, Andrea Franceschini, Nicolò Merendino, Antonio Rodà
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th International Symposium on the Internet of Sounds (IS2)
abstract: Many museums are increasingly employing interactive installations, such as virtual reality experiences and digital reconstructions, to enhance the presentation of their collections, particularly in relation to ancient musical instruments. However, these digital experiences often do not convey the physicality and tangible qualities of the instruments themselves. In addition, there is a growing demand among institutions for solutions that allow visitors to engage with the acoustic dimensions of these artifacts in a more immersive and accessible manner, including the ability to experience sounds from instruments held in other museums.The project centered on the rattle preserved at the Adria National Archaeological Museum was developed in response to these needs. It aimed to create an interactive installation within the museum, featuring an electronic replica of an Etruscan rattle dated to the third to fourth centuries BC. This replica was constructed using a microcontroller-based system housed within a 3D-printed shell, which was modeled from a scan of the original artifact. The device is capable of reproducing sampled sounds of the original instrument and is paired with an interactive touchscreen display that offers contextual information and a digital twin of the artifact. The replica communicates wirelessly with the display through Wi-Fi and has access to an online database of audio samples recorded from other musical instruments housed in museums across the region.Although not intended as a perfect visual reproduction, the outer shell was enhanced with tactile reliefs that replicate the original decorative motifs and equipped with haptic feedback features to ensure accessibility for visitors with visual or auditory impairments.

title: Digital Defense: Cybersecurity Awareness Platform for Qatar's Public Sector
authors: Asmaa Khalifa A M Al-Mohannadi, Afra Abdulla S Kh Alnuaimi, Fatima Mubarak S A Al-Buainain, Shafii M Abdulhamid, Nadim Rana, Abdullah Hussein Al-Ghushami
publish: 2025 9th Cyber Security in Networking Conference (CSNet)
abstract: Human error is the weakest link in any corporation, especially in government sectors. This work addresses the critical issue of human error in cybersecurity within government sectors. The study introduces "Wa3i," an Arabic term for "awareness," as an online cybersecurity training platform designed for ease of use by government employees in Qatar. The research involved surveying these employees' cybersecurity knowledge, followed by enrollment in "Wa3i's" tailored training, which spans four levels across various topics. Analysis of trainee responses showed a significant deficiency in cybersecurity awareness among Qatar's government workforce. This concern demands attention due to its rated severity and the subject's complexity and growing relevance. The platform is active, with ongoing enhancements supported by financial and moral investments, aiming for improved future outcomes in cybersecurity proficiency.

title: Zero-Delay Spatial Audio Rendering for Immersive Networked Music Performances
authors: Christian Schörkhuber, Markus Zaunschirm, Luca Turchet
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th International Symposium on the Internet of Sounds (IS2)
abstract: Low-latency spatial audio processing is essential to reduce the overall latency in immersive networked music performances (NMP). In spatial audio rendering chains, most components, including source filtering for directivity, occlusion, and environmental effects, can be implemented with negligible latency using minimum-phase IIR filters. However, Head-Related Impulse Responses (HRIRs), which are fundamental to binaural rendering, often introduce non-negligible latency when measured HRIRs are used. In this paper, we discuss the sources of latency and present a zero-delay implementation based on minimum-phase FIR filters and delay lines. Through a controlled listening experiment involving 14 expert musicians, we evaluated the perceptual transparency of the zero-delay rendering with respect to a reference implementation without latency optimization. The experiment comprised two zero-delay versions with different filter lengths and involved samples for five different source directions and four different signal types. The results showed that participants could not distinguish the reference from a zero-delay version with 64 filter taps at 48 kHz sampling rate, indicating that this configuration is suitable for spatial audio rendering in NMP systems.

title: A Dual-Polarized Broadband Antenna in the X-Band
authors: Zhiwei Wang, Zhenyi Niu
publish: 2025 18th IEEE United Conference on Millimeter Waves and Terahertz Technologies (UCMMT)
abstract: This paper proposes an X-band broadband dualpolarized patch antenna. With slot-coupled feeding, the antenna achieves a relative bandwidth of 20 % (VSWR <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$<2$</tex>) for both polarizations. The hybrid feeding method and air layer simplify the structure and reduce port coupling. By conducting simulations, it is verified that both port-to-port and crosspolarization isolation exceed 30dB. Moreover, the antenna exhibits highly consistent gain across both polarizations. This design offers an outstanding solution for applications involving polarization synthesis and array formation.

title: 5G Networks Coverage Extension Using Passive Intelligent Reflective Surface at mmWave
authors: Xin-Yu Liu, Mustafa K. Taher Al-Nuaimi, Zhuo Huang, Guan-Long Huang
publish: 2025 18th IEEE United Conference on Millimeter Waves and Terahertz Technologies (UCMMT)
abstract: Current 5G communications face significant challenges in dense urban environments, where building obstructions often disrupt the line-of-sight link between 5G base stations (BS) and mobile users, particularly at millimeter-wave (mmWave) frequencies. To address this issue, this paper proposes a passive intelligent reflective surface (IRS) designed to restore connectivity between users and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{5 G}$</tex> base station. The proposed IRS features a single-layer design and operates without external power consumption. It effectively redirects signals from a 5 G BS located 13 meters away, with an incident angle of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\theta_{i}=-18^{\circ}$</tex> and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\varphi_{i}=0^{\circ}$</tex>, toward user reception directions within <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\boldsymbol{\theta}_{r}=35^{\circ} \pm 3^{\circ}$</tex> and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\varphi_{r}=0^{\circ}$</tex>. The device functions across both the <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{n 2 5 8}(\mathbf{2 4. 2 5}-\mathbf{2 7. 5 ~ G H z})$</tex> and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{n} 257(26.5-29.5 \text{GHz})$</tex> bands. The proposed IRS is fabricated using PCB technology and the results verify that the proposed IRS can reliably re-establish communication links obstructed by urban structures.

title: A $10-40 \text{GHz}$ Wideband LNA in 0.15um GaAs pHEMT Technology
authors: Xi Chen, Wenlong He
publish: 2025 18th IEEE United Conference on Millimeter Waves and Terahertz Technologies (UCMMT)
abstract: To address broadband requirements in millimeter-wave radar systems, this paper presents a 10-40 GHz low-noise amplifier (LNA) employing transmission-line-based Wideband matching techniques. The four-stage common-source architecture incorporates source degeneration and transmission-line matching. Fabricated in <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$0.15-\boldsymbol{\mu} \mathrm{m}$</tex> GaAs pHEMT technology, FEM simulations demonstrate a minimum noise figure of 2.5dB and peak gain of 18dB at 5V drain bias within a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$2.1 \text{mm} \times 1.6 \text{mm}$</tex> die. This MMIC is suitable for integration into phased array radar RF front-ends.

title: Improving EEG Emotion Recognition with Projection Layer and Output-Gated GRU Network
authors: Wenzhang Du, Suchada Sitjongsatapom, Pipat Sakarin
publish: 2025 International Conference on Power, Energy and Innovations (ICPEI)
abstract: EEG-based emotion recognition enables intuitive human-computer interaction but remains challenging due to limited data and noisy signals. In this paper, we propose an Attention-Output-Gated Gated Recurrent Unit (AOG-GRU) architecture that fuses a low-rank recurrent projection, temporal self-attention, and an output gate to improve emotion classification oil the DREAMER dataset. We compare AOG-GRU against a standard LSTM, a standard GRU, a GRU with attention (AttnGRU), and a convolution-augmented GRU (ConVGRU). Using 5 x 5 nested cross-validation on DREAMER’S 23-subject EEG corpus, AOG-GRU attains 88.9% accuracy and a macro-FI of 0.891, outperforming the next-best model (ConvGRU, 81.5%) by 7.4 percentage points. The added output gate and projection boost performance over the attention-only GRU while increasing per-fold runtime by only 1.8 s (increase about 9.6%). A detailed analysis—including cross-fold performance curves and confusion matrices—illustrates AOG-GRU’s consistent gains. These results show that the proposed AOG-GRU effectively mitigates the noisy, low-sample nature of EEG emotion data and sets a new state-of-the-art on DREAMER.

title: Design and Numerical Study of Solar-Driven Photo-electrochemical Cell Using Nanostructured Group-III Nitrides for Green Hydrogen Production
authors: G. Chandra Mohan, Nikhil Deep Gupta
publish: 2025 5th Asian Conference on Innovation in Technology (ASIANCON)
abstract: The growing global energy demand and escalating environmental challenges necessitate the development of clean, renewable, and sustainable energy sources. Hydrogen, as a zero-emission and high energy density fuel, presents a viable alternative to fossil fuels. Still generating green hydrogen efficiently possesses a stiff challenge. This work introduces a solar-driven, self-sustained photoelectrochemical (PEC) system designed for green hydrogen production. The proposed system leverages the unique properties of InGaN/GaN nanowire-based photoelectrodes, integrated with a Nafion-212 proton exchange membrane (PEM), that powered by a high-flux solar dish concentrator for improved system performance. Two PEC configurations were evaluated—one using a traditional TiO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf> photoanode and the other employing an advanced InGaN/GaN nanowire photoelectrode. The nanowire-based system exhibited significantly enhanced light absorption, superior photocurrent density, and greater operational stability under concentrated solar illumination. A custom-designed 4.97 m diameter solar dish provides a power concentration ratio of ~24,000×, delivering over 67.87 W of optical power at the photoelectrode surface. This hybrid design offers a scalable, efficient, and ecofriendly solution for decentralized hydrogen generation in remote and off-grid areas, contributing to the advancement of sustainable energy technologies.

title: Experimental Study of Screen Printed Lab on a Chip for Depressive Substance Analysis
authors: Warisara Boonsiri, Kessararat Ugsornrat, Wichayaporn Kamsong, Chanpen Karuwan, Assawapong Sappat, Adisorn Tuantranont
publish: 2025 Research, Invention, and Innovation Congress: Innovative Electricals and Electronics (RI2C)
abstract: This study presents the development and evaluation of a screen-printed electrowetting-on-dielectric (EWOD) microchip for the electrochemical analysis of depressive substances. The device consists of two integrated components: a T-junction EWOD structure and an electrochemical detection zone. The EWOD module comprises two primary layers a silver electrode and a polydimethylsiloxane (PDMS) dielectric layer fabricated via screen-printing and spin-coating techniques, respectively. At the end of the T-junction, an electrochemical sensor was embedded, consisting of a screen-printed electrode system including a carbon working electrode, a carbon counter electrode, and a silver/silver chloride (Ag/AgCl) reference electrode. All electrodes were fabricated using a layer-by-layer screen-printing method. Cyclic voltammetry was employed to assess the sensor's performance in detecting substances associated with depression. Reverse testing with dopamine a key neurotransmitter linked to depressive disorders yielded voltammograms closely matching a previously established calibration curve. These results highlight the potential of the proposed EWOD-based microchip as a promising platform for portable and reliable depressive substance analysis.

title: A Comparative Investigation of Fractional Order PID and TID Controllers Optimized via NSGA-II for Load Frequency Control in a Two-Area System
authors: Sina Molaei, Ali Doustmohammadi
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Control, Instrumentation and Automation (ICCIA)
abstract: In the evolving landscape of modern power systems, Load Frequency Control (LFC) plays a critical role in maintaining stability and reliability, particularly in restructured environments where generation, transmission, and distribution are handled by independent entities rather than unified utilities. This study aims to design, optimize, and compare Fractional Order Proportional-Integral-Derivative and Tilt-Integral-Derivative controllers for LFC in a restructured two-area power system comprising thermal and hydro plants, with the goal of achieving superior frequency regulation under load disturbances. The research employs a simulation-based approach, modeling the two-area system based on established deregulated frameworks. Controller parameters are tuned using the Non-dominated Sorting Genetic Algorithm-II for multi-objective optimization, balancing criteria like settling time and overshoot.
