title: A Comparative Analysis of Machine Learning Approaches for Electricity Consumption Forecasting: Performance Evaluation, Failure Analysis, and Hybrid Model Development
authors: Beheshte Sadeghi Sabzevari
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Control, Instrumentation and Automation (ICCIA)
abstract: This study presents a comparative evaluation of nine forecasting models—Linear Regression, ARIMA, Prophet, XGBoost, CatBoost, LSTM, GRU, ConvLSTM, and LSTM+XGBoos—applied to Spain Electric Power Generation and Consumption dataset, spanning different geographical regions and time periods. The dataset was preprocessed to address missing values. Then systematic failure case analysis was conducted to identify limitations under various consumption patterns. Results demonstrate that the CatBoost model achieves superior performance <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\left(\text{R M S E}=\text{3 8 6. 4 0}, \mathrm{R}^{\mathrm{2}}=\text{0. 9 9 2 7}\right)$</tex>. Detailed computational efficiency analysis reveals trade-offs between accuracy and execution time in different models. We identify specific scenarios where deep learning models fail, including sudden consumption changes and low-variability periods, and propose targeted improvements. This work provides actionable guidance for practitioners in smart grid applications, highlighting model selection criteria based on deployment constraints, data characteristics, and performance requirements.

title: The Pulse Compression Concept for Radar Signals a Technology Designed Ahead of Its Time
authors: Carolin Meyer-Schwalm
publish: 2025 IEEE History of Electrotechnology Conference (HISTELCON)
abstract: Driven by military demands in World War II, several individuals contributed to the development of the radar technique known as pulse compression. Although not a factor to the outcome of the war and often kept under classification until the 1950s, the concept later entered the public domain and laid the foundation for the ongoing research on radar pulse compression techniques and waveform design. The aim of this paper is to give an overview of how these scientists from different countries discovered this method to significantly boost radar performance.

title: PreComp-VFL: Enhancing Embedding Representation in Vertical Federated Learning for Medical Data
authors: Bashair Alrashed, Priyadarsi Nanda, Dinh Thai Hoang, Saleh Alqahtani, Raddad Faqihi, Osama Dighriri, Ethar Alzaid, Amani Aldahiri
publish: 2025 9th Cyber Security in Networking Conference (CSNet)
abstract: Vertical federated learning (VFL) in healthcare enables institutions holding different features of the same patients to collaboratively train machine learning models without exposing raw data. However, most existing VFL approaches focus on secure aggregation and privacy-preserving computation, while overlooking client-side preprocessing. This limitation can result in less informative embedding representations and increased communication overhead. To address this, we propose PreComp-VFL, a client-level preprocessing method that integrates unsupervised feature selection with dimensionality reduction techniques. PreComp-VFL allows clients to transmit compressed, informative, and privacy-preserving embeddings without requiring label access. We used four real-world medical datasets in a number of experiments demonstrating our proposed scheme and achieved improved model accuracy and F1 Score compared to standard VFL. We also show that our proposed scheme achieves significant reductions in communication costs relative to server-side feature selection scheme.

title: Hooked on Convenience: The Loyalty Effect on Customers of E-Marketplace as Super Apps
authors: Cut Felicia Zyvaristin, Lea Sulaiman Saputra, Cecep Hidayat
publish: 2025 8th International Conference of Computer and Informatics Engineering (IC2IE)
abstract: The increasing integration of various services in e-marketplace platforms has led to the emergence of super apps in Indonesia. This study examines how customer loyalty is influenced by the multifunctional convenience offered by these platforms. Specifically, it investigates the roles of perceived usefulness, ease of use, customer satisfaction, trust, and habit in fostering continued usage and loyalty. In comparison with other research that focuses on either single-function or general e-commerce apps, this study aims to bring a focused discussion of loyalty drivers in multifunctional e-marketplace super apps. The sampling method was purposive, targeting consumers who directly encountered the claims. A quantitative survey was conducted with 442 active users of major Indonesian e-marketplaces, and data were collected in May 2025. The questionnaire has been distributed throughout Indonesia. Using Structural Equation Modeling (SEM) via SmartPLS, the analysis reveals that habit and trust significantly mediate the relationship between perceived service quality and customer loyalty. Moreover, ease of use and satisfaction strongly influence loyalty intention, while perceived usefulness plays a secondary role. These findings highlight the importance of emotional attachment and behavioral habit in sustaining user engagement within super apps. The study offers valuable insights for e-marketplace developers and digital strategists aiming to enhance user retention through integrated service design and trust-building mechanisms.

title: Notes on the Hypercyclicity of Discrete Time-varying Linear Dynamical systems
authors: Xin Liu, Shengnan He
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Control, Robotics and Cybernetics (CRC)
abstract: This paper establishes a sufficient condition for the hypercyclicity of discrete time-varying linear systems on finite-dimensional Euclidean spaces ${{\mathbb{R}}^m}$ under vanishing perturbations. We show that if the Lyapunov exponents along a subsequence vanish for all vectors, then arbitrarily small perturbations exist that render the system hypercyclic. The proof utilizes the Baire Category Theorem, and the structure of the hypercyclic vector set is analyzed for both commuting and noncommuting sequences.

title: Deep Learning Embeddings for Zero-Day Cyber Threat Detection: A Multi-Modal Framework for Network Flow and SIEM Data Analysis
authors: Shiva Kumar Ramavath, Akshay Mittal, Vaishnavi Gudur
publish: 2025 9th Cyber Security in Networking Conference (CSNet)
abstract: Zero-day cyber attacks cause billions in damages annually, with traditional signature-based detection systems failing to identify 67% of advanced persistent threats. This paper presents a novel multi-modal deep learning framework that leverages unsupervised embeddings to detect unknown cyber threats in real-time across network flow data and Security Information and Event Management (SIEM) logs. Our approach employs Variational Autoencoders (VAE) for network flow embedding generation and Graph Neural Networks (GraphSAGE) for modeling complex entity relationships in SIEM data. The framework transforms high-dimensional, heterogeneous cybersecurity data into semantically rich, low-dimensional vector representations that capture intricate behavioral patterns without requiring labeled attack data. Extensive evaluation on the CSE-CIC-DS2018 dataset and synthetic SIEM logs demonstrates significant performance improvements: 91% AUC-ROC for network anomaly detection (19% improvement over traditional methods), 93% AUC-ROC for SIEM anomaly detection, and 67% reduction in false positive rates. The system maintains sub-millisecond detection latency, enabling real-time deployment in enterprise environments.

title: Evaluating Foreign Exchange Fluctuations: Utilizing Bagging and Grid Search Algorithm
authors: Jasmin D. Niguidula, Arlene R. Caballero, Wellani M. Molino, Fernando L. Renegado, Darwin C. Vargas, Ariel L. Tomagan
publish: 2025 8th International Conference of Computer and Informatics Engineering (IC2IE)
abstract: Currency exchange rates show a country's currency's value. International commerce, tourism, and consumer pricing depend on exchange rates. It fluctuates according to inflation, interest rates, political stability, and economic policy. Despite economic and political obstacles, the exchange rate between the US Dollar (USD) and the Philippine Peso (PHP) has shown resiliency, although projecting its future is difficult. Understanding the complex link between inflation and exchange rate swings is vital, particularly when currency depreciation may cause inflation. Two time series algorithms, Bagging and Grid Search, are tested to predict the PHP-USD exchange rate. Given the importance of exchange rate variations on inflation, commerce, and economic policy, this paper uses machine learning to describe and quantify a dataset from July 2022 to March 2025. WEKA processed investing.com data, training models on 70% and testing them on 30%. The Bagging method predicted a five-day USD-PHP appreciation with high accuracy. Despite growing mistakes over longer forecasting periods (MAE rising from 0.1201 to 0.3019 on the training data), Bagging's performance was close to real values for shorter-term forecasts. Grid Search predicted higher exchange rates with more aggressive rises during the same five-day period. Although it performed well throughout training, its test data estimates tended to overestimate, especially during turbulent times from December 2024 to February 2025. Both algorithms lost accuracy with time, although Grid Search had a greater error rate. The research found that machine learning algorithms, namely the Bagging approach, can accurately anticipate the PHP to USD exchange rate in the near run. By helping firms and financial institutions identify currency movements and reduce losses, these predictive insights may improve risk management. The models may also enable automated trading systems by providing reliable data-driven indications for quick buy or sell decisions. Forecasting tools in financial operations help stakeholders make more proactive, strategic, and informed decisions in a dynamic, data-centric economy.

title: Design of a DC-Biased Cavity Diplexer
authors: Jian Ma, Jie Chen, Zheng-Bin Wang
publish: 2025 18th IEEE United Conference on Millimeter Waves and Terahertz Technologies (UCMMT)
abstract: To address the issue of increased complexity in some diplexer systems due to the need for Direct Current (DC) power feeding, the paper designs a cavity diplexer with an integrated DC bias function. A DC path is set between port resonant cavities, combining DC power supply with RF transmission. Simulation and physical testing results demonstrate the diplexer has the insertion loss of less than 0.41 dB, the return loss of more than 10 dB, and the isolation of more than 75 dB in the two passbands of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$800-960 \text{MHz}$</tex> and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$1710-2160 \text{MHz}$</tex>, providing a useful reference for future research on the integration of cavity diplexers with other circuit functions.

title: A Circularly Polarized Phased Array Antenna Design for Satellite Communications
authors: Ping Yuan, Zhongrui He, Zhongqian Niu, Bo Zhang
publish: 2025 18th IEEE United Conference on Millimeter Waves and Terahertz Technologies (UCMMT)
abstract: A wideband, circularly-polarized phased-array antenna operating in the Ku-band is presented for satellite communications. Bandwidth enhancement at the element level is achieved by stacking a parasitic patch above the driven patch with an optimized air cavity in between. By using a dual-feed point with a microstrip line, the antenna element achieves circular polarization. An <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$8 \times 8$</tex> array with 11 mm element spacing is designed and analyzed in HFSS. The simulation results show that the antenna array can achieve beam scanning of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\pm 45^{\circ}$</tex>, the relative bandwidth (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$S 11<-10 \text{dB}$</tex>) is 22.9%, the axial ratio for circular polarization remains below 3 dB.

title: Study the Effect of Resistance on Absorptive Structure Based on Effect of Electromagnetically Induced Transparency
authors: Cheng-Ji Zhao, Ji-Dong Liu, Gang Zhang, Yan-Qun Liu, Wan-Chun Tang
publish: 2025 18th IEEE United Conference on Millimeter Waves and Terahertz Technologies (UCMMT)
abstract: The present paper investigates the effect of different value resistances on the absorption of electromagnetic energy using a structure based on electromagnetic-induced transparency (EIT)-like phenomena. A lump resistor is loaded on the horizontal strip of the <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\pi$</tex>–shape EIT-like structure. In circumstances where the resistance value is less than 470Ω, the traditional EIT phenomenon occurs. Increasing the resistance value to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$4.7 k \Omega$</tex> has been shown to induce a novel phenomenon, wherein the initial transparent state transitions to an absorbing state. The simulation results indicate that the absorptivity can reach up to 44 %, which is a promising finding for the potential application of the structure as metamaterial sensor.

title: Broadband Planar Filtering Dipole Antenna Design for Phased and Retrodirective Array Systems
authors: Lanjun Sun, Xiang Wang, Zhi-Yuan Zong, Song-Song Qian, Huangyan Li, Boyu Sima, Jin-Dong Zhang, Wen Wu
publish: 2025 18th IEEE United Conference on Millimeter Waves and Terahertz Technologies (UCMMT)
abstract: This paper proposes a planar filtering dipole antenna, which is employed as a basic element to construct a wideband phased array and a van atta retrodirective array. The proposed filtering antenna adopts magnetoelectric (ME) dipole. It operates in the frequency range of 6.5 GHz to 10.3 GHz, achieving a peak in-band gain of 4.16 dB and an out-of-band radiation suppression of more than 30 dB. The developed phased array demonstrates decent in-band beam-scanning performance, while the van atta retrodirective array exhibits great RCS enhancement characteristics.

title: A Conceptual Data Management Maturity Assessment Model
authors: Busarin Visitsilp, Nalinpat Bhumpenpein
publish: 2025 Research, Invention, and Innovation Congress: Innovative Electricals and Electronics (RI2C)
abstract: This study aims to analyze factors affecting data quality improvement and propose a conceptual model for assessing data management maturity in an organization. It is integrated the Data Management Maturity (DMM) model with key themes identified through Semi-structured interviews with eight data quality experts. Six key themes comprising of data quality literacy, intra-organizational collaboration, policies and standards, data management processes, data quality assessment, and data quality challenges, are synthesized and mapped across the five levels of the DMM model to create comprehensive guidelines. The proposed model is designed to support organizations in systematically assessing and improving their data quality management maturity. A mapping matrix illustrates the interaction between these dimensions and DMM levels. Although the proposed model has not been validated in real practice, it provides a solid foundation for future empirical studies and practical applications, with the conceptual model

title: Predictive Modeling of Term Deposit Subscriptions Using Machine Learning and Bagging Ensemble Methods on Imbalanced Data
authors: Ratih Nur Esti Anggraini, Stefanie Quinevera, Ricky Mardianto, Radityo Anggoro, Ary Mazharuddin Shiddiqi, Anny Yuniarti
publish: 2025 International Conference on Smart-Green Technology in Electrical and Information Systems (ICSGTEIS)
abstract: The traditional method of offering fixed-term deposits to customers through telephone communication often proves ineffective due to limited timeframes and insufficient understanding of customer preferences. This leads to disturbances caused by unwanted product offerings and low success rates in telemarketing campaigns, wasting resources. Customer behavioral learning is essential for understanding customer behavior and improving telemarketing effectiveness. However, class imbalance in datasets poses challenges for accurate machine learning predictions. To address this, a hybrid model with data balancing approach, namely SMOTE-ENN and SMOTE-Tomek techniques, is proposed. The results show that the bagging model with XGBoost achieves the highest accuracy of 91,12 %, especially with SMOTE-Tomek balancing. Conversely, logistic regression (LR) and naive bayes (NB) models exhibit lower accuracy. In conclusion, the bagging method with XGBoost effectively predicts customers likely to accept long-term deposit offers. Employing a hybrid approach improves model performance, with SMOTE-Tomek balancing yielding the highest accuracy and enhancing data balance. This enhances model accuracy and stability.

title: Dynamic Switching Characterization of GaN Power Transistors Using Double Pulse Test (DPT) in a Fly-Buck Converter
authors: Susmita Mistri, Hao Chung Kuo, Ching-Chang Tu, Surya Elangovan
publish: 2025 20th International Microsystems, Packaging, Assembly and Circuits Technology Conference (IMPACT)
abstract: This work presents a simulation-based analysis of GaN HEMTs switching performance using the Double Pulse Test (DPT) in a Fly-Buck DC-DC converter topology. Two gate return configurations Kelvin-source and common-source (non-Kelvin) were compared using LTspice under typical conditions, with a gate-source voltage (VGS) from –3.8V to 6V and a drain-source voltage (VDS) of 50V. Key switching parameters, including voltage overshoot, ringing, current rise time, and diode reverse recovery, were extracted from the simulated waveforms. The results show that the Kelvin-source connection enables faster switching and significantly reduces switching losses due to better gate control. However, the sharper transitions also lead to increased voltage overshoot and stronger ringing caused by excited parasitic resonances. On the other hand, the common-source (SS) setup results in slower transitions and reduced overshoots, ringing and higher energy losses. The Fly-Buck topology, modeled with realistic parasitic elements, offers a practical context to assess these effects. The study highlights the importance of Kelvin-source routing for high-efficiency, high-frequency designs, while also emphasizing the need for careful layout and snubber design to manage overshoot and EMI.

title: A Fast and Semi-Automatic Video Annotation Method Using Image Tracking for Deep Learning Training
authors: Mahdi Pourkerman, Seyed Vahab Shojaedini
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Control, Instrumentation and Automation (ICCIA)
abstract: Accurate annotation of moving objects in videos is a critical yet time-consuming task in many computer vision projects. Traditional frame-by-frame methods demand extensive effort and high user precision. This paper proposes a semi-automatic and efficient approach for annotating moving objects by leveraging image-based tracking techniques. Users annotate only keyframes, while intermediate frames are automatically inferred. Animation tools such as interpolation allow for rapid correction of tracking errors. The method produces output compatible with standard formats like YOLOv8 (aligned with YOLOv5 and above), and can be adapted to COCO and other formats, making it suitable for both online and offline applications. Implementation is done via a custom script developed in Adobe After Effects [11], enabling automated extraction of object positions and generation of annotations. Experimental evaluations were conducted on a dataset tracking cattle movement in videos, demonstrating both time efficiency and spatial consistency improvements over traditional methods.

title: Driver Drowsiness Detection Via a Hybrid Deep Learning Model Based on YOLO and Mobilenet
authors: Majed Hamdi, Alireza Akoushideh, Asadollah Shahbahrami
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Control, Instrumentation and Automation (ICCIA)
abstract: This study presents a hybrid deep learning framework for real-time driver drowsiness detection, integrating YOLOv8 for facial feature localization with MobileNetV2 for lightweight classification. Two training strategies-balanced and unbalanced datasets-were evaluated to assess their impact on model performance. The balanced approach achieved superior results, eliminating false negatives and reducing false positives, with an <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{F 1}$</tex>-score of 0.9998 and 100 % recall. Comparative analysis using ROC and Precision-Recall curves confirmed the balanced model's advantage in safety-critical contexts. The proposed system demonstrates high accuracy (99.98 %) and real-time capability, making it suitable for deployment in embedded automotive environments. These findings highlight the importance of data distribution in optimizing detection reliability and minimizing risk.

title: Developing a Visual Novel Game for Bullying Prevention in Adolescents
authors: Noorlela Marcheta, Malisa Huzaifa, Alifa Salsabila Deshendra, Ariawan Andi Suhandana, Asep Kurniawan, Muhammad Yusuf Bagus Rasyiidin
publish: 2025 8th International Conference of Computer and Informatics Engineering (IC2IE)
abstract: Bullying has long-term impacts on students’ mental health, social well-being, and academic performance. Data from the Indonesian Ministry of Health recorded 2,621 reports from 2024 to 2025, of which 620 were identified as bullying cases. This study aims to develop an educational game based on a Visual Novel as a learning medium to prevent bullying. The research employed an Animation Production Pipeline approach involving validation by a content expert, a media expert, and a trial with 62 students. Evaluation instruments consisted of content validity and effectiveness questionnaires, with data analyzed using percentage scores of feasibilities. The results indicate that the game achieved an average score of 89.98% in design and interactivity, and 88.30% in learning effectiveness. These findings suggest that Visual Novel–based games hold strong potential as effective educational tools for raising students’ social awareness of bullying. This study contributes to the literature on technology-based educational interventions and provides an alternative interactive learning medium to address social issues in Indonesia.

title: Sounding Canvas: An Embedded, Networked, Interactive Audio Artwork
authors: Luciano Ciamarone, Dora Motèque, Marco Giordano
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th International Symposium on the Internet of Sounds (IS2)
abstract: The "Sounding Canvas" is an interactive art installation that transforms a traditional canvas into a dynamic, sound-producing interface. Users interact by touching different areas of the canvas, triggering a variety of sounds that appear to emanate directly from the artwork. This experience is facilitated by an embedded system comprising of capacitive sensors connected to an Arduino, a Raspberry Pi 4 for processing and sound generation logic, and a HiFi Berry Amplifier for audio output. The system employs a machine learning decisional algorithm in Python, ensuring that touch interactions result in evolving and varied auditory responses. Furthermore, each canvas can connect to a remote server, allowing multiple installations to share "touch events" in real-time, creating the potential for networked, participatory experiences. This paper details the architecture, implementation, and interactive qualities of the Sounding Canvas, highlighting its relevance as a responsive sound installation and a platform for sonifying touch-based sensor data.

title: Design of a Wideband High Rectangular Coefficient FSS with Lumped Capacitor Loading
authors: Yi-Fei Mu, Huan Yang, Bing Bai, Cun-Long Li, Hai-Qiang Liu, Xing-Fan Wu
publish: 2025 18th IEEE United Conference on Millimeter Waves and Terahertz Technologies (UCMMT)
abstract: This paper presents the design of a broadband frequency selective surface (FSS) with a high rectangular coefficient based on lumped capacitance loading. The proposed structure comprises two layers of double square loops patch elements with lumped capacitors and one layer of square loop aperture elements. The effects of electromagnetic wave incident angles and polarization modes on its electromagnetic characteristics are analyzed through full-wave simulations. It is found that loading lumped capacitors onto the double square loops patch not only broadens the relative bandwidth to 30% but also introduces transmission zeros at both the low- and highfrequency edges of the passband, thereby enhancing the steep roll-off characteristics at the passband edges and achieving a high rectangular coefficient. The proposed FSS structure can be applied to the design of stealth radomes.
