Through extensive software analysis and mechanical simulation, we demonstrate the device’s superior performance in terms of operational efficiency, safety monitoring, and environmental adaptability. The system integrates real-time temperature and current monitoring with automated debris removal, providing a significant advancement in power system maintenance and operation. Experimental validation shows 360x faster adjustment time compared to traditional systems (i.e., 15-minute manual adjustment), with $\mathbf{9 5 \%}$ debris removal efficiency and real-time monitoring capabilities that enable predictive maintenance strategies.

title: MediVault: Smart Expiry Alerts Full Store Solution
authors: Anshika Lunia, Atul Sharma, Akshit Bhandari, Vandana Kate, Chanchal Bansal, Ifrah Qureshi
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Advances in Computing Research On Science Engineering and Technology (ACROSET)
abstract: The pharmaceutical industry faces significant challenges related to medicine wastage, inefficient stock management, and shortages of essential drugs. This research paper presents MediVault, an AI-driven pharmacy management system designed to address these issues through automated expiry date tracking, dynamic pricing adjustments, and intelligent medicine substitution. By leveraging advanced analytics and real-time monitoring, MediVault enhances inventory control, minimizes financial losses, and ensures timely availability of critical medications. This paper explores the system’s architecture, implementation, and potential impact on optimizing stock levels, reducing waste, and improving overall healthcare accessibility. The pharmaceutical industry faces significant challenges related to medicine wastage, inefficient stock management, and shortages of essential drugs. This research paper presents MediVault, an AI-driven pharmacy management system designed to address these issues through automated expiry date tracking, dynamic pricing adjustments, and intelligent medicine substitution. By leveraging advanced analytics and real-time monitoring, MediVault enhances inventory control, minimizes financial losses, and ensures timely availability of critical medications. This paper explores the system’s architecture, implementation, and potential impact on optimizing stock levels, reducing waste, and improving overall healthcare accessibility.

title: Plastic Detection in Water Using Computer Vision
authors: Hemlata Parmar, Pranshu Bhargava, Utsav Krishan Murari
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Advances in Computing Research On Science Engineering and Technology (ACROSET)
abstract: Plastic pollution in aquatic environments is a pressing environmental issue, adversely impacting ecosystems, economies, and public health. Effective detection of macroplastic debris (plastic items >5 mm) in water bodies is critical to quantifying pollution, identifying sources, and designing targeted mitigation strategies [1]. Recent research has highlighted the potential of computer vision (CV) and deep learning (DL) approaches to automate macroplastic detection in diverse aquatic settings. It is a growing environmental issue in water bodies with severe ecological, economic, and health impacts. Large plastic debris, macroplastics, can persist for decades in aquatic ecosystems, harming marine life, disrupting habitats, and entering the food chain. Accurate macroplastic detection is essential for understanding pollution sources, assessing accumulation patterns, and implementing effective mitigation strategies. Recent advances in computer vision and deep learning offer promising solutions for automating the detection and monitoring of plastic waste in water. These technologies can facilitate large-scale, real-time tracking of macroplastic debris across rivers, lakes, and coastal areas, providing critical insights into the extent of pollution and aiding in global efforts to protect aquatic environments [7] [10].

title: Cloud-Native AI: Optimizing Machine Learning Workloads for Scalability and Performance
authors: Anurag Shrivastava, R V S Praveen, Heba Abdul-Jaleel Al-Asady, Kanchan Yadav, Ravi Kalra, Akhilesh Kumar Khan
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Advances in Computing Research On Science Engineering and Technology (ACROSET)
abstract: Cloud-native AI is a mechanism in which an enterprise can leverage the power of cloud infrastructure to transform its machine learning (ML) landscape to achieve scale, flexibility, and performance. That is, containerization, microservices, orchestration, and serverless computing enabled cloud-native environments provide new ways of optimizing ML workloads. It puts forward shows how leveraging Kubernetes, distributed training frameworks, and AI-specific cloud services are positive to better utilization of resources and accelerated model deployment. In addition, it explores how autoscaling, model parallelism and cost optimization work together for seamless ML operations. The results emphasise the need for combining AI with cloud-native architectures to enable new scaled innovations to deliver better decisioning capabilities in real times across market sectors.

title: Efficient MRI Brain Tumor Classification using an Optimized Hierarchical Deep CNN
authors: D. Raghava Kumari, Ch. Rajendra Prasad
publish: 2025 5th Asian Conference on Innovation in Technology (ASIANCON)
abstract: It is also difficult to extract and classify the type of a tumor in the MRI images and may even be difficult to detect without the help of an expert, since the ordinary imaging methods cannot differentiate between the deformation of the brain structures effectively. In this research paper a customized deep Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) architecture is proposed for classification of brain tumors into multiple classes using Magnetic Resonance Imaging MRI images. This architecture incorporates a series of convolutional blocks with increasing filters (32–256), and each followed by batch normalization, max pooling, and dropout to extract hierarchical features and improve generalization and stability. The architecture extracts hierarchical structures at the level of textures up to tumor patterns and also minimizes the spatial dimensions to make it efficient. Flattened features are processed by Dense layers and classified via a SoftMax output into four tumor types -glioma, meningioma, pituitary, and no tumor. The developed CNN model has an accuracy of 0.929 percentage and a loss of 0.071, which is higher compared with the traditional methods of classification both in precision and performance. The model is developed with clinical applicability in mind as it will enable healthcare providers to have accurate diagnosis of the type of cancerous tumors, as well as allow them to make better plans in the treatment that would consume less time.

title: Combining Object Detection and Geometric Analysis for Egg Dimension Estimation in Smart Farming
authors: Hasan Zidni, Karisma Trinanda Putra, Nor Salwa Damanhuri, Sarwo Pranoto, Deri Aditya Romadhon, Rustam Asnawi
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electronic and Electrical Engineering and Intelligent System (ICE3IS)
abstract: Accurate measurement of egg dimensions is essential in modern poultry farming for effective grading, sorting, and quality control. However, traditional manual methods are time-consuming and susceptible to inconsistency, limiting their scalability in large-scale operations. This study presents a hybrid approach that combines YOLOv8-based object detection with geometric analysis to automatically estimate egg lengths from digital images. A custom YOLOv8n model was trained on annotated egg datasets and evaluated for detection performance, achieving 0.87 mAP @ 0.5, 0.75 $\mathrm{mAP} \text{@} 0.5: 0.95,0.88$ precision, and 0.86 recall. Detected bounding boxes were converted from pixels to centimetres using a calibrated pixel-to-length ratio. The estimated dimensions were compared with ground-truth measurements taken manually using callipers. Across multiple test samples, the proposed method achieved a mean absolute error (MAE) of 0.056 cm and an average relative error of 1.29%, demonstrating high estimation accuracy. These results demonstrate both high estimation accuracy and the system’s potential to reduce measurement time and human subjectivity, supporting scalable and contactless egg size classification in smart farming.

title: AI-Powered Summarization of Legal Documents: A Solution for Enhancing Legal Research Efficiency
authors: Vedant Rajekar, Nidhi Mangtani, Yash Parate, Pratik K Agrawal
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Advances in Computing Research On Science Engineering and Technology (ACROSET)
abstract: Legal professionals face significant challenges in processing voluminous court verdicts and legal documents due to their complex structure and technical vocabulary. This paper presents a comprehensive AI-based legal document summarization system that leverages the nsi319/legal-pegasus model, specifically fine-tuned for legal domain applications. Our system incorporates a novel hybrid approach combining transformer-based abstractive summarization with domain-specific post-processing rules to preserve critical legal information. The solution features customizable summary lengths and maintains legal integrity through automated checks for appeals, sentencing, and statutory references. Preliminary evaluation through manual assessment demonstrates superior performance over baseline models, achieving 85-90% accuracy on documents up to 800 words. The system significantly reduces manual processing time while maintaining factual and legal accuracy, making it a practical tool for legal professionals.

title: Optimizing Mental Health Detection: A Performance Study of Support RideNN Forward Harmonic Network with Adaptive Giant Trevally Algorithm
authors: Amit Dnyaneshwar Narote, Uttam Dnyanu Kolekar, Vijaykumar Nageshrao Pawar
publish: 2025 5th Asian Conference on Innovation in Technology (ASIANCON)
abstract: Mental health disorders affect individuals across all age groups, cultures, and socioeconomic backgrounds. Traditional methods suffer from several critical limitations, like insufficient data integration and limited accessibility. Hence, this paper devises a Support RideNN Forward Harmonic Network with Adaptive Giant Trevally Optimizer (SRideNN-FHNet_Adap-Gto), enhancing mental health detection. At first, input data is collected from the OSMI Mental Health dataset, and these data are extracted into three-level attributes, like personal-level, medical-level, and query-level attributes. After extraction, feature selection is performed using Recursive Feature Elimination (RFE). Next, selected features undergo data augmentation using the Synthetic Minority Over-Sampling Technique (SMOTE). Subsequently, mental health detection is carried out using SRideNN-FHNet_Adap-Gto, which combines Support Vector Machine (SVM), RideNN, harmonic analysis and these networks are trained using Adaptive Giant Trevally Optimizer (Adap-Gto). Adap-Gto combines Giant Trevally Optimizer (GTO) with an Adaptive mechanism. Finally, the effectiveness of SRideNN-FHNet_Adap-Gto is evaluated using Support RideNN Forward Harmonic Network (SRideNN-FHNet) and Support Vector Machine with Adaptive Giant Trevally Optimizer (SVM_Adap-Gto) with respect to without optimization, with optimization, and swarm size. With swarm size 40, SRideNN-FHNet_Adap-Gto acquired an accuracy of 97.765%, True Positive Rate (TPR) of 98.868%, and True Negative Rate (TNR) of 96.979%.

title: Machine Learning-Enhanced Flexible Metamaterial Biosensor for Pesticide Qualitative and Quantitative Analysis
authors: Chun Li, Jing Yang, Ling Jiang
publish: 2025 18th IEEE United Conference on Millimeter Waves and Terahertz Technologies (UCMMT)
abstract: Here, we proposed a flexible umbrella-shaped metamaterial (USM) biosensor and conducted modeling analysis for six pesticides simultaneously. To improve the contrast of the sensor, we introduced triple-resonance sensing based on highorder modes, taking into account both the resonance depth and the Q-factor. During the model-building process, we adopted a twostage cascade ensemble learning framework, which significantly improved the accuracy, scalability, and convenience of qualitative and quantitative sensing results. The qualitative accuracy of the six pesticides reached up to 100%. For the quantitative analysis, the root mean square error (RMSE) was only <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$2.21 \mu \mathrm{g}$</tex>, and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$R^{2}$</tex> reached 0.9952, showing excellent sensing performance.

title: A 21–29GHz Low-Power LNA with High-Linearity Achieved Using a Novel Post-Distortion Method with Triple-Coupled Transformer
authors: Jingfeng Du, Yijing Zhong, Jiaxuan Li, Jionghua Zheng, Congwei Liao, Yinggang Li
publish: 2025 18th IEEE United Conference on Millimeter Waves and Terahertz Technologies (UCMMT)
abstract: This paper focuses on the design of a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$22.4-29.8\ \text{GHz}$</tex> LNA for automotive radar and 5G-Adv/6G communication applications, requiring high linearity, low power and low noise. To achieve high linearity with low power consumption, a novel postdistortion technique utilizing a triple-coupled transformer is proposed, where the auxiliary transistor generates the opposite nonlinear terms while simultaneously providing gain, in difference from the conventional post-distortion design. An 8-shaped inductor is used to save chip area. Operating at a 1.1 V supply voltage, the two-stage common-source LNA achieves a gain of 15.2 dB, 3.2dB NF, an IP1dB of −5.2 dBm, and consumes 30.2 mW at 25° C under the TT corner. Under worst-case PVT conditions, it maintains a gain of 12.1 dB and an IP1dB of −6.8 dBm, demonstrating good robustness against PVT variations.

title: A 2D ADMM High-Resolution Imaging Algorithm Incorporating Reweighted Sparse and Total Variation Regularization
authors: Haolei Qi, Boguang Yang, Tao Hong, Wen Jiang
publish: 2025 18th IEEE United Conference on Millimeter Waves and Terahertz Technologies (UCMMT)
abstract: In inverse synthetic aperture radar (ISAR) imaging, in order to improve the imaging accuracy at under-sampled conditions, this paper proposes a 2 D reweighted <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\ell_{1}$</tex> norm and Total Variation regularized alternating direction method of multipliers sparse imaging method (2D-RWTV-ADMM). By introducing sparse prior and structure prior, the imaging noise and sidelobes are effectively suppressed, and the target edge information is maintained. The ADMM is adopted to achieve efficient solution, and the dynamic reweighting strategy is combined to enhance the sparse constraint ability. Simulation experimental results show that the proposed method can still maintain good imaging resolution and robustness under undersampled rate and low signal-to-noise ratio conditions, effectively improves the main target focusing ability, suppresses false scattering points, and improves the image edge blurring problem.

title: Fast Iterative Method for Millimeter-Wave Waveguide Antenna Array
authors: Tong Li, Sai Guo, Yue-Long Lyu, Zhao Li
publish: 2025 18th IEEE United Conference on Millimeter Waves and Terahertz Technologies (UCMMT)
abstract: Based on one-dimensional Taylor synthesis method, a fast magnitude distribution trimming method for one dimensional wire antenna radiation pattern with low side lobe level is proposed in this paper. Firstly the parameters of travelling wave one dimensional wire array and simulation model are calculated according to the mathematical formula. Then radiation pattern and the near-field magnitude distribution are obtained. On the basis of this, a new set of array excitations and parameters of antenna are retrieved by flipping magnitude distribution. Repeat the whole process until the pattern and magnitude distribution satisfies the requirements. Finally, good agreement is achieved between Taylor distribution and simulation magnitude distribution, thus validating the -30dB low side lobe level performance of the array.

title: A New Near-Field Probe with Parasitic Element for High Sensitivity
authors: Lei Wang, Quan Huang, Chengyang Luo, Guoguang Lu
publish: 2025 18th IEEE United Conference on Millimeter Waves and Terahertz Technologies (UCMMT)
abstract: Herein, a new differential near-field probe with high sensitivity is presented. The near-field probe consists of a pair of differential loops as a driven element, an inner U-shaped loop with two connected vias, and two strip-lines terminated with two <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$2.92 \text{m m}$</tex> radio-frequency SMAs with <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$5 0 \Omega$</tex>. Note that these differential loops and inner U-shaped loop are connected in series to obtain high detection sensitivity. In the near-field probe, these non-grounded differential loops are applied to simultaneously receiving double electric and magnetic-fields, and non-grounded U-shaped loop as parasitic element is also utilized to sense more electromagnetic-fields. Finally, in order to prove the design effectiveness, the probe prototype is simulated by electromagnetic simulation software, etched on a five-layer PCB, and characterized by a near-field simulation system with a standard microstrip line. The simulated and measured results reveal that the proposed near-field probe can not only achieve the simultaneous measurement of electric- and magnetic-fields, but also has a higher detection sensitivity.

title: Compact 5G N77 Band Filter with Upper Out-of-Band Suppression
authors: Haonan Wang, Yingxuan Peng, Xiaohan Wang, Bowei Liu, Xingyan Yang, Rui Wan, Zihuan Cao, Chunqin Xia, Po Chow, Shanwen Hu, Gang Shi
publish: 2025 18th IEEE United Conference on Millimeter Waves and Terahertz Technologies (UCMMT)
abstract: A fifth-generation (5G) N77 bandpass filter (BPF) with wide upper out-of-band suppression is proposed. The proposed BPF exhibits symmetric hook shaped folded feeding lines (HSFFLs) and a M-shaped resonator. The HSFFLs are proposed with stepped-impedance variation line with extra coupling, which strength the wide stopband characteristic. And the M-shaped resonator is proposed to enhance the coupling with HSFFLs, thus wider bandwidth and smaller insertion loss are obtained. The designed BPF is constructed using a two-layer lowtemperature co-fired ceramic (LTCC) substrate, resulting in a compact footprint of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{2 5} \boldsymbol{\times} \mathbf{1 2} \boldsymbol{\times} \mathbf{0. 2} \mathbf{~ m m}^{\mathbf{3}}$</tex>, equivalent to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{0. 7 8} \boldsymbol{\times} \mathbf{0. 3 6} \times 0.006 \lambda ~\mathrm{g}^{3}$</tex>. Full-wave electromagnetic (EM) simulation results demonstrate an in-band insertion loss (IL) of less than 0.1 dB and a wide upper stopband reaching frequency up to 12.5 GHz, with a suppression level exceeding <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1 9} \mathbf{~ d B}$</tex>.

title: Design Method for Severs of Sub-Millimeter Wave Multi-Section Traveling Wave Tube
authors: Fei Li, Liu Xiao, Jiandong Zhao, Zicheng Wang, Hongxia Yi, Zhiliang Chen, Xinwen Shang, Yanwei Li, Weixing Li, Can Li
publish: 2025 18th IEEE United Conference on Millimeter Waves and Terahertz Technologies (UCMMT)
abstract: The use of multi-section slow wave circuits is an effective method to improve output power and efficiency of traveling wave tubes(TWTs). This article discusses the selection for the positions and widths of severs in sub-millimeter wave three-section TWTs by numerical simulation. Based on the existing E-band two-section TWT, a three-section interaction circuit was designed and simulated output powers and electronic efficiencies of the two were compared while maintaining the same operating voltage, operating current and total interaction length. The general methods for severs of sub-millimeter wave multi-stage TWTs are summarized.

title: 2-D SVPF for Wavefront Curvature Compensation in PFA for FMCW SAR Imaging
authors: Zhongyu Liu, Junnan Liu, Aoran Qin, Xinhua Mao
publish: 2025 18th IEEE United Conference on Millimeter Waves and Terahertz Technologies (UCMMT)
abstract: The polar format algorithm (PFA) is limited in nearfield UAV-synthetic aperture radar (SAR) imaging due to wavefront curvature errors caused by its planar wavefront assumption. This paper proposes an improved wavefront curvature compensation method based on space-variant postfiltering (SVPF). By analyzing the mathematical principles of polar coordinate format conversion, we derive a filter expression in the 2-D spatial frequency domain under squint conditions. Additionally, we formulate a reverse expression for geometric distortion to enhance the precision of calculating the true coordinates of subimage center points. Experimental results validate the effectiveness and reliability of the proposed method, which achieves higher accuracy compared to traditional methods.

title: Design of a Down-Conversion Module Based on HTCC Integrated Packaging
authors: Xuan Bin
publish: 2025 18th IEEE United Conference on Millimeter Waves and Terahertz Technologies (UCMMT)
abstract: Based on the HTCC alumina multi-layer ceramic technology, an X-band multifunctional down-conversion module with integrated packaging has been designed. Through simulation design, the module integrates multiple functions such as radio frequency (RF) amplification, local oscillator (LO) amplification, frequency conversion and filtering, amplitude adjustment, local oscillator path switching, and power supply control within the size of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$13 \text{mm} \times 10 \text{mm} \times 2.55 \text{mm}$</tex>. The module has a receiving gain greater than 16 dB within the operating frequency band, a gain flatness of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\leqslant \mathbf{0. 7 d B}$</tex>, and an RF return loss of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\leqslant-\mathbf{2 7 d B}$</tex>. This paper analyzes and summarizes the main technologies related to the design.

title: Hybrid Method of Deep Residual Learning and Particle Swarm Optimization Applied to Slotted Patch Antenna Design
authors: Yu Xia, Lei Zhu, Mingli Sun
publish: 2025 18th IEEE United Conference on Millimeter Waves and Terahertz Technologies (UCMMT)
abstract: In this paper, a hybrid method combining a deep residual neural network (ResNet) with particle swarm optimization (PSO) is proposed for slotted patch antenna design. The deep ResNet describes the nonlinear relationship between slot parameters and antenna <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$S$</tex>-parameters. It handles abrupt resonant behavior changes caused by small parameter variations of slots through skip connections, ensuring stable training. After training, the PSO calls the deep ResNet to optimize the bandwidth of the antenna. A slotted patch antenna is used as a design example to validate the proposed method. The predicted, simulated, and measured results align closely, and the optimized bandwidth meets the desired range. Furthermore, compared to the traditional design method, this hybrid method demonstrates both high efficiency and accuracy in slotted patch antenna design.

title: Investigation of Double-Corrugated Waveguide with Grating Slow-Wave Structure for Low-Voltage Terahertz TWT
authors: Weilong Wang, Zhaowei Qu, Wenxin Liu, Fang Zhu, Zhaochuan Zhang
publish: 2025 18th IEEE United Conference on Millimeter Waves and Terahertz Technologies (UCMMT)
abstract: In this paper, we propose a novel double-corrugated waveguide with grating (DCWG) slow-wave structure (SWS) designed for low-voltage terahertz traveling-wave tubes (TWTs). This structure offers several advantages: it is compatible with cylindrical electron beams, operates at low voltage, provides a wide bandwidth, minimizes reflections, and is easy to manufacture. Beam-wave interaction simulations demonstrate that, when using a cylindrical electron beam with a voltage of 9.8 kV and a current of 200 mA, a TWT based on this structure can achieve an output power exceeding 60 W in the <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$200-240 \text{GHz}$</tex> frequency range, with a maximum output power of 143 W and a peak gain of 30 dB.

title: Evaluate Hybrid Classical-Quantum Architecture in Deep Image Processing
authors: Niranjala S. H., M. Kazem Chamran, Mustafa Mowafak Alobaedy
publish: 2025 IEEE 15th International Conference on System Engineering and Technology (ICSET)
abstract: This research focuses on the architectural design and the performance difference of hybrid quantum and classical machine learning in the context of image processing using Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs). As we are in the digital era, it's crucial to deal with complex datasets due to the scalability and performance issues. In this research, researchers experienced the use of classical CNNs integration with the quantum computing paradigms. Based on the research findings, we outline the architecture of such hybrid models, highlighting the integration of standard CNN layers with Variational Quantum Circuits (VQCs) and the prominence of the ReLU activation function. The study investigates comparative performance metrics and observations using standard CNNs and adding extra layers in contrast to those of quantum CNNs run on classical hardware, highlighting such metrics as accuracy and computational performance. The findings highlight the feasibility and comparative advantage of hybrid models, suggesting the prospects of improved sophisticated deep image processing methods.

title: Indoor Smart Cultivation Monitoring System (SCMS) while Measuring Energy Consumption
authors: Areeha Javaid, Muhammad Umair Iftikhar, Hifza Mustafa, Muhammad Yousif, Ghulam E Mustafa Abro, Komal Hussain Amina
publish: 2025 IEEE 15th International Conference on System Engineering and Technology (ICSET)
abstract: Precision agriculture, also known as Smart Cultivation, seeks to enhance plant development while reducing resource consumption. This study introduces a novel indoor smart agriculture monitoring system that incorporates environmental sensors to track essential factors including temperature, humidity, air quality, light intensity, electrical conductivity, and soil wetness. Real-time data is conveyed to a cloud platform (ThingSpeak) for analysis. Machine learning models, such as Random Forest, Support Vector Regressor, Decision Tree, Gradient Boosting, and Feedforward Neural Network, are employed to forecast plant growth, with performance assessed by MAE, MSE, RMSE, and R-squared metrics. The system facilitates data-informed decision-making, including the generation of warnings for soil moisture levels, and enhances sustainability by monitoring energy and water usage. A 120 W solar system with battery backup is advised based on daily energy consumption, illustrating the system's capacity to improve output and resource efficiency while facilitating the adoption of renewable energy.

title: LibraPIM: Dynamic Load Rebalancing to Maximize Utilization in PIM-Assisted LLM Inference Systems
authors: Hyeongjun Cho, Yoonho Jang, Hyungi Kim, Seongwook Kim, Keewon Kwon, Gwangsun Kim, Seokin Hong
publish: 2025 34th International Conference on Parallel Architectures and Compilation Techniques (PACT)
abstract: Large language models (LLMs) require inference systems that can handle both compute- and memory-intensive workloads. GPUs and NPUs (referred to as xPUs) efficiently process compute-intensive layers, while Processing-In-Memory (PIM) architectures are well suited for memory-bound stages. To exploit this complementary relationship, recent LLM inference systems have adopted heterogeneous architectures integrating xPUs with PIM units. However, this integration poses several challenges. Tight execution dependencies between the two devices limit concurrency, as PIM often must wait for data produced by the xPUs. Moreover, batch size and sequence length affect the computational load on PIM and the accelerator differently, leading to execution imbalance across devices and degrading their utilization. To address these challenges, we propose LibraPIM, a novel PIM framework that orchestrates workload rebalancing and concurrent execution between compute accelerators and in-memory compute units, enabling efficient and scalable LLM inference. LibraPIM addresses the above challenges through two key techniques: Dynamic Batch Offloading (DBO), which adaptively redirects portions of the workload to the underutilized device based on runtime profiling, and Dual-Path Execution (DEX), which enables concurrent PIM operations and memory accesses through sub-bank partitioning with minimal hardware overhead. Together, these techniques improve resource utilization across heterogeneous devices, thereby increasing system throughput in LLM inference. Our experimental results demonstrate that LibraPIM achieves $6.2 \times$ average speedup over the baseline PIM-enabled system and delivers a $2.1 \times$ average speedup compared to a state-of-the-art approach.

title: Receipt Information Extraction Through YOLOv8 and OCR Space Enhanced with Grad-Cam Explainability
authors: Rizki Elisa Nalawati, Hata Maulana, Risna Sari, Fitri Sagita, Muhammad Dzaky Nashshar, Iwan Sonjaya
publish: 2025 8th International Conference of Computer and Informatics Engineering (IC2IE)
abstract: The implementation of a receipt extraction system combines YOLOv8 for object detection, OCR Space for robust text recognition, and Grad-Cam as an explainable AI technique. OCR Space is particularly effective in accurately handling discount formats and structured financial data. The system achieves strong performance with a recall of 99.8%, precision of 91.5%, F1-score of 95.5%, and mean average precision (mAP) of 98.7%. Key information such as item names, prices, and quantities is accurately extracted through a combination of bounding box-based cropping and targeted OCR processing. Grad-Cam visualizations confirm that the model focuses on semantically important regions within receipts and invoices, enhancing interpretability. This hybrid approach offers a scalable and efficient solution for automating the extraction of transactional data from receipts and invoices. It also opens opportunities for integration into broader business workflows, enabling real-time processing and analytics.

title: CT-HS: Cross-Translation Hate Speech Detection with Co-Attention Network for Cross-Lingual Generalization
authors: Bagus Tri Yulianto Darmawan, Bassamtiano Renaufalgi Irnawan, Rizky Adi
publish: 2025 8th International Conference of Computer and Informatics Engineering (IC2IE)
abstract: The widespread use of hate speech on digital platforms poses real-world consequences, including psychological harm such as depression, anxiety, and in extreme cases, incitement to violence. The multilingual nature of online communication increases the difficulty of effective hate speech detection across diverse languages and scripts. Although several attempts have been made to automate the hate speech detection process, current methods tend to fail to generalize decently across multiple languages. In this paper, we propose Cross-Translation Hate Speech (CT-HS), a novel method that employs translation of the hate speech sentence as a pair of original hate speech inputs. Specifically, CT-HS translates each input sentence into the target language, constructing a parallel sentence pair, and feeds them to the model, capturing semantics across languages. We employ a publicly accessible Southeast Asia hate speech dataset to evaluate the performance of our method against current, already established baseline methods, which include Small Language Model and Large Language Model. CT-HS achieves F1-macro improvements over XLM-RoBERTa up to +37% and up to +229% over Mistral 7B in non-alphabetical languages such as Vietnamese, Tamil, and Mandarin. These findings demonstrate that our method helps the model to generalize complex languages for hate speech detection in multilingual settings.

title: A Flying Boom Aerial Refueling Docking Control Strategy Based on Model Free Adaptive Control
authors: Xinxin Wang, Bao Guo, Yidi Lei, Haoang Tang, Pengyuan Qi, Zhicong Shao, Xi Huang
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Control, Robotics and Cybernetics (CRC)
abstract: To address the limitations in current research on Automatic Boom Air-to-Air Refueling (A3R), specifically including the prevalent assumption that the tanker maintains steady level flight, the neglect of the inner boom’s telescopic motion, and the lack of a comprehensive full-process unmanned control strategy, this study employs the Kane method to construct the multi-body dynamic and kinematic models of the telescoping boom aerial refueling system, proposes a control strategy based on Proportional-Derivative Model-Free Adaptive Control (PD-MFAC), and clearly defines the control logic and envelope range of A3R. Validation through MATLAB/SIMULINK simulations indicates that the designed controller exhibits excellent performance, the envelope is reasonably set, and successful docking can be achieved in both undisturbed and turbulent environments. Notably, under turbulent conditions, successful contact can be accomplished with a maximum of two attempts. These results confirm the effectiveness of the proposed model and control strategy.

title: Effects of Instructional Modality on Performance Anxiety and Stress in Sight-Singing
authors: Michael Oehler, Leonard Bruns, Benedict Saurbier, Tray Minh Voong
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th International Symposium on the Internet of Sounds (IS2)
abstract: Extended reality (XR) environments offer novel opportunities for music education, yet their impacts on student stress and anxiety remain underexplored. In a fully counter-balanced within-subjects study, we compared three vocal lesson modalities — mixed reality (MR) with near-photorealistic Persona avatars on Apple Vision Pro, tablet-based FaceTime video conferencing, and traditional in-person instruction — during structured sight-singing tasks. Participants completed two sight-singing performances per condition (pre- and post-feedback), while physiological (electrodermal activity, heart rate variability) and psychological (questionnaire on music performance anxiety, self-evaluation) measures were recorded. Across all modalities, pedagogical feedback led to a significant reduction in electro-dermal activity (EDA) and improvements in functional coping, self-efficacy, and composite self-evaluation scores. No significant differences emerged between MR, tablet, and in-person lessons in either physiological arousal or self-reported anxiety, though MR exhibited non-significant trends toward larger EDA decreases and self-efficacy gains. These results suggest that avatar-based MR telepresence can approximate the stress-modulating benefits of face-to-face teaching, while tablet video conferencing remains a viable, less immersive alternative.

title: Design of Wall-Climbing Mobile Robot System for Crack Detection in Buildings
authors: Jacob Panangian Lumbanbatu, Winda Astuti, Zener Sukra Lie, Muhammad Nurul Puji, Norashikin M. Thamrin, Megat Syahirul Amin Megat Ali
publish: 2025 8th International Conference of Computer and Informatics Engineering (IC2IE)
abstract: Maintaining buildings is essential to ensure their functionality, longevity, and safety. Conventional inspection techniques are usually expensive, time-consuming, and dangerous for human workers. This study suggests creating a Wall-Climbing Robot (WCR) system for automatic building crack detection to overcome these difficulties. The objective of this project is to develop a robotic system that can move across vertical surfaces for maintenance and inspection duties. To make it possible, WCR uses an Electric Ducted Fan (EDF) as the adhesive method and Tracked Wheels as the locomotive mode. The Wall-Climbing Robot system consists of two main parts: Tracked Wheels locomotion and EDF control. The process for each system begins with Circuit Design. For the Tracked Wheels Robot, this involves designing the electronic connections between two DC motors, L298N Motor Driver, Arduino Nano, and FS-iA6B Receiver, ensuring proper power supply and signal flow. Similarly, for the EDF control system, the circuit design focuses on connecting the EDF to the Electronic Speed Controller (ESC) and linking the ESC's control input to the Arduino, along with the appropriate battery connections. The testing result showed that WCR was able to remain statically on the wall, since the friction force exceeded the gravitational force with 87% throttle.

title: Three-Dimensional Vortex Electromagnetic Wave Radar Imaging in the Large Squint Sight
authors: Ping Xu, Kang Liu, Hongyan Liu, Yuxin Chen
publish: 2025 18th IEEE United Conference on Millimeter Waves and Terahertz Technologies (UCMMT)
abstract: Due to the unique phase wavefront structure modulated by orbital angular momentum (OAM), vortex electromagnetic wave (VEMW) radar offers enhanced capabilities for target information acquisition and imaging performance improvement. In this paper, based on the uniform circular array (UCA), the VEMW radar is proposed to reconstruct the three-dimensional target information by exploiting the signal bandwidth, virtual array observation, and OAM degree of freedom. Firstly, an imaging model is established for a large squint observation scenario, and the corresponding echo signal characteristics are analyzed. Subsequently, the threedimensional imaging algorithms are developed to recognize the target's position in the range, elevation, and azimuth dimensions. Simulation results show good agreement with the theoretical analysis, providing robust three-dimensional imaging performance for multiple targets at different elevation angles.

title: On-Chip W-Band Power Divider Based on Spoof Surface Plasmon Polaritons
authors: Yi Wei Lu, Kai Lu, Jie Min Wu, Ming Jiang Wang, Di Bao
publish: 2025 18th IEEE United Conference on Millimeter Waves and Terahertz Technologies (UCMMT)
abstract: Corrugated metals with periodic grooves support spoof surface plasmon polaritons (SSPPs) waves in the microwave and terahertz ranges. In this paper, a spindle-type spoof surface plasmon polaritons (STSSPPs) unit structure is proposed, which can significantly reduce the cutoff frequency by increasing the groove depth of the branch lines through dispersion characterization. In this work, a W-band power divider is designed using three STSSPP transmission lines and a Cshaped microstrip matching network. In order to improve the isolation between the output ports of the power divider and reduce reflections, a 100Ω isolation resistor bridges symmetric branches. Results show that this STSSPP power divider has good performance in the W-band with a center frequency of 108 GHz, a 3 dB relative bandwidth of more than 90 %, low insertion loss, low reflection coefficient, and high isolation. Meanwhile, the STSSPP power divider proposed in this paper is designed using gallium arsenide (GaAs) process, and has a compact size of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$0.885 * 0.46 ~\text{mm}$</tex> with GSG (Ground-Signal-Ground) pad. This work may open new doors for the development of various millimeter-wave devices.

title: Research on Semi-Blind Channel Estimation Algorithm Based on CFDP in NB-IoT
authors: Lu Yingkang, Fang Chengzhi, Zhao Zechao
publish: 2025 18th IEEE United Conference on Millimeter Waves and Terahertz Technologies (UCMMT)
abstract: Millimeter-wave and terahertz communication technologies, as high-frequency communication technologies, can achieve high-speed response and low-latency communication and have broad application prospects in the Internet of Things (IoT) systems. The narrowband IoT (NB-IoT) system is based on OFDM technology and the channel estimation is the key to achieve lowlatency and fast-response data transmission. The common channel estimation algorithms usually have high pilot overhead. Considering the channel correlation in the two-dimensional time-frequency scheme of OFDM, this paper proposes an adaptive semi-blind channel estimation algorithm based on CFDP clustering and data reuse. This clustering algorithm can adaptively adjust its parameters to improve accuracy following the variation of the signal-to-noise ratio (SNR). Simulation shows that the new algorithm has the same performance as the traditional algorithms with less pilot overhead and computational complexity.

title: Design of a Field-Enhanced Terahertz Biosensor Based on an SSPP—CPS—SRR Structure
authors: Xia Kexin, Chen Kanglong, Han Lulu, Ruan Cunjun
publish: 2025 18th IEEE United Conference on Millimeter Waves and Terahertz Technologies (UCMMT)
abstract: This paper presents a terahertz biosensor that integrates split-ring resonators (SRRs) into coplanar stripline (CPS)-spoof surface plasmon polaritons (SSPPs). By replacing traditional rectangular SSPP stubs with SRR structures, the biosensor exhibits a cutoff frequency of 0.13 THz in dispersion simulation, while transmission simulations reveal a pronounced stop-band at 0.133 THz with a maximum attenuation of −41 dB. Electric field intensity simulations indicate an extreme enhancement of up to 79,720 times relative to the input port at the SRR gaps. Biosensing sensitivity simulations reveal an excellent response to changes in the refractive index, with a sensitivity of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{S} =38.3 \text{GHz} /$</tex> RIU (Refractive Index Unit). This design provides an innovative solution for high-sensitivity terahertz biosensing, showing potential applications in biomolecule detection, disease diagnosis, and other fields.

title: Ka-Band Twisted Ridge Circularly Polarized Horn Antenna with Wideband Waveguide Transition Using Additive Manufacturing Technology
authors: Run-Xian Cai, Jun Xu, Wei Hong
publish: 2025 18th IEEE United Conference on Millimeter Waves and Terahertz Technologies (UCMMT)
abstract: An ultra-wideband circularly polarized (CP) twisted-ridged horn antenna, fabricated using metal 3D printing and fed via a WR28 waveguide structure, is presented. The antenna incorporates a wideband waveguide transition designed to convert transmission of guided wave from the fundamental rectangular waveguide WR28 to a circular double-ridge waveguide for efficient excitation of CP radiation. While simulations predict an exceptional operating bandwidth of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$122.1 \%(14.5-60 \text{GHz})$</tex> for <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\left\vert \mathrm{S}_{11}\right\vert<-10 \text{dB}$</tex> and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$110.7 \%(14.5-50.5$</tex> GHz) for axial ratio (AR) <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$<3 \text{dB}$</tex>, practical measurements, constrained by the cutoff frequency of the WR28 waveguide, demonstrate operation within the entire Ka-band (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$26-40 \text{GHz}$</tex>). Within this measured band, the antenna achieves entire Ka-band coverage considering both impedance (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\left\vert \mathbf{S}_{11}\right\vert<-\mathbf{1 0} \mathbf{ d B}$</tex>) and axial ratio (AR <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$<3 \text{dB}$</tex>) bandwidths, along with a peak gain of 16.9 dBic. This work demonstrates a viable approach to realizing high-performance mm-Wave CP antennas using additive manufacturing technology, albeit with practical bandwidth limitations imposed by standard waveguide interfaces.

title: Message from the Executive Chairs & TPC Chairs
authors: N/A
publish: 2025 18th IEEE United Conference on Millimeter Waves and Terahertz Technologies (UCMMT)
abstract: On behalf of the Technical Program Committee (TPC), we warmly welcome all of you to the 18th IEEE United Conference on Millimeter Waves and Terahertz Technologies (UCMMT2025) in Nanjing.

title: Consensus-based Full-process Formation Control Strategy for Multi-UAV System
authors: Huixin Liu, Zongwei Chai, Pengyuan Qi, Xiaoxiong Liu
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Control, Robotics and Cybernetics (CRC)
abstract: This paper presents an integrated framework for full-process multi-UAV (Unmanned Aerial Vehicles) formation control, utilizing a 6-DOF F-16 aircraft model. The framework is founded on the inner-loop PID controllers for attitude stabilization and outer-loop guidance laws for trajectory tracking, combined with double-loop three-channel consensus control law that regulates inter-aircraft dynamics. It systematically manages the entire mission lifecycle: formation assembly is executed using Dubins curves for path planning, aiming at the path intersection problem in the process of UAV formation generation; formation keep and switching is achieved through a novel optimal assignment method that combines 3D spatial mapping with the Hungarian algorithm within a leader-follower strategy; and finally, aircraft departure and formation dissolution are managed by adjusting the communication topology, considering the actual formation flying mission. Full-process simulations validate the framework's effectiveness and engineering feasibility for complex, multi-phase missions.

title: Adaptive Model Switching for Dynamic Inference Serving in the IoT-edge-cloud Continuum
authors: Tiago Knorst, Michael G. Jordan, Guilherme Korol, Mateus Beck Rutzig, Antonio Carlos Schneider Beck
publish: 2025 XV Symposium on Computing Systems Engineering (SBESC)
abstract: Although Internet of Things (IoT) devices have enabled Deep Learning (DL) applications to operate closer to end-users, they struggle to scale with modern, computationally heavy DL algorithms due to their limited processing power. A promising solution is to offload computation to remote edge and cloud servers throughout the IoT-edge-cloud continuum. However, inconsistent network conditions, variable latency, and the distinct accuracy and precision requirements of different DL applications hinder the ability to uphold necessary performance standards. To address these issues, we propose AdaptSwitch, a dynamic framework that selects both the DL model and the most suitable execution location across the IoT-edge-cloud continuum, based on the application’s model accuracy and latency needs according to network conditions at a given moment. We evaluated AdaptSwitch using real IoT, edge, and cloud devices running state-of-the-art DL models for image classification while considering network delay data from real-world 5G/Edge/Cloud traffic datasets. Experimental results demonstrate that our approach improves Quality of Experience (QoE) by reducing inference latency while ensuring accuracy requirements are met through adaptive model switching.

title: A Dynamic AI-Powered Honeypot Framework for Adaptive Cyber Threat Diversion
authors: Iqra Hussain, Monther Aldwairi, Azka Wani
publish: 2025 9th Cyber Security in Networking Conference (CSNet)
abstract: The conventional honeypots, those digital decoys meant to lure in attackers, are too rigid and predictable. Once hackers recognize the same old banners or behaviors, they disengage almost immediately, leaving us empty logs and missed learning opportunities. This paper introduces a dynamic, reinforcement learning driven honeypot framework designed to counteract evolving cyber threats through real-time adaptive deception. We deployed the framework in a virtualized environment and integrated an AI-driven deception layer, a real-time threat intelligence engine, and automated response mechanisms. The framework achieves 97% detection accuracy and reduces false positives to 3.8%, outperforming traditional solutions like Cowrie and T-Pot.

title: Hybrid LSTM-BiLSTM Approach for DDoS Attack Forecasting
authors: Yahya Yakhlaf, Roumaissa Bekkouche, Hadhami Garbouge, Mohamed Belaoued, Samir Dawaliby
publish: 2025 9th Cyber Security in Networking Conference (CSNet)
abstract: Distributed Denial of Service (DDoS) attacks remain a critical threat to the stability and security of networked systems. To address the challenge of predicting such attacks in advance, we propose a hybrid deep learning approach that combines Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) and Bidirectional LSTM (BiLSTM) architectures. This model is designed to better capture temporal patterns in network traffic data while minimizing overfitting during training. We evaluated the model’s forecasting performance over multiple horizons (1, 5, 10, and 20 seconds). Experimental results demonstrate that our hybrid approach consistently outperforms traditional models, including standalone LSTM, GRU, RNN, and BiLSTM, in terms of forecasting accuracy. These findings highlight the potential of hybrid architectures for proactive DDoS attack mitigation.

title: Research on Trajectory Tracking Control of Ship Barnacle Cleaning Robot
authors: Chang Sheng Yang, Xiaochang Shi, Yuwen Chen, Wenbin Ma
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Control, Robotics and Cybernetics (CRC)
abstract: The surface of ships is often covered with a large number of organisms such as barnacles, which not only increases the energy consumption of ship navigation but also significantly reduces the navigation efficiency. Therefore, the removal of surface attachments is extremely important. This paper focuses on the trajectory tracking control research of the barnacle cleaning robot on the ship surface. To more realistically simulate the actual ship conditions, the main part of the ship body - the hull - was simulated by referring to the international ship standard KCS model. During the cleaning process, to ensure that the entire target area is covered to complete the cleaning work, the Boustrophedon path is adopted as the reference trajectory. This method has a path coverage rate as high as 97%. However, this method involves many turns, and the frequent turns pose a challenge to the response speed of the control algorithm, and may even lead to severe tracking deviations. This places higher demands on the accuracy and robustness of the control algorithm. To solve the above problems, a double-ring super-torque sliding mode controller is designed, which is controlled by double-ring control through decoupling position and speed control, combined with the robustness and anti-vibration characteristics of AST. To verify the performance of this controller, it is compared with the PID-FTSMC algorithm. The results show that the double-ring super-torque sliding mode controller performs better in terms of accuracy and anti-interference ability, and can stably refer to trajectory tracking even under strong interference.

title: Analysis of Terahertz Doppler Radar Based on High Temperature Superconductors
authors: Pei Wang, Mingyan He, Diya Su, Yalei Yin
publish: 2025 18th IEEE United Conference on Millimeter Waves and Terahertz Technologies (UCMMT)
abstract: A terahertz (THz) Doppler radar based on high temperature superconducting THz emitter and mixer is proposed. It theoretically shows that with emitting power of 0.55 mW at 0.5 THz and a mixing noise figure of 12 dB, the radar's detectable range is up to 4.1 m, indicating the radar could work in a shortrange. The Doppler frequency detection performance with different carrier frequencies of radar is presented by modelling breathing and heartbeat signals of adult. It proves that the proposed THz Doppler radar has advantages of flexibly tunable THz frequency and higher sensitivity than the millimeter band in detecting micro motion.

title: AI-Powered Predictive Maintenance for Field Equipment Optimization and Failure Risk Reduction
authors: R.C. Ilambirai, Jash Makhija, Kavish Shah, M. Moorthy, Sangeetha A, M. Muthulekshmi
publish: 2025 5th Asian Conference on Innovation in Technology (ASIANCON)
abstract: Failures of field equipment often result in expensive downtime and reduced production in industrial and agricultural operations. This research introduces an AI-driven predictive maintenance system using a Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) neural network to enhance equipment efficiency and mitigate failure risks. IoT-enabled sensors constantly monitor critical characteristics like temperature, vibration, and pressure. The LSTM model analyses the gathered time-series data, which is trained on past maintenance and failure records. The method was implemented on a dataset of equipment operating cycles, with a prediction accuracy of 94.7% for possible failures. The LSTM-based method decreased unscheduled downtime by 38% and maintenance expenses by 27% compared to traditional scheduled maintenance. Moreover, the lifespan of equipment improved by 15% due to prompt intervention. The model had a precision of 93.82% and a recall of 95.37%, indicating dependable early failure identification. The findings validate the efficacy of LSTM in predictive maintenance, facilitating data-driven decision-making and operational resilience in field settings with minimum human involvement.

title: LegalAssist: Empowering Legal Insights with LLM
authors: Dhruv Karia, Deep Parekh, Jhenil Parihar, Richa Sharma
publish: 2025 5th Asian Conference on Innovation in Technology (ASIANCON)
abstract: This study delves into how generative artificial intelligence—specifically sophisticated natural language processing models such as Transformers—can transform the manner in which legal work is conducted. Through the application of state-of-the-art AI techniques, the work aims to automate important legal tasks such as clause identification, document summarization, support for legal queries, and translation of legal content into various languages. The results identify the ways in which generative AI can enhance the accuracy, speed, and accessibility of legal processes and decrease the requirement for human effort. One of the main contributions of the study is demonstrating how AI can facilitate bridging the language gap between legal documents and the legal system, making it more accessible. With in-depth experimentation and practical application, this research provides a better insight into how generative AI can be utilized to benefit legal analysis and operations.

title: Future-Proofing Your Power Skills for 2030
authors: Rhonda Farrell
publish: 2024 IEEE Women in Engineering (WIE) Forum USA East
abstract: As we look toward 2030, professionals must go beyond technical expertise to cultivate the power skills, adaptive mindsets, and innovation-oriented strategies required to thrive in a rapidly evolving global workforce. This white paper explores how mastering foundational human capabilities, such as leadership, communication, emotional intelligence, and interdisciplinary collaboration, can future-proof careers in the face of AI disruption, digital transformation, and complex societal challenges. It presents a roadmap for growth from awareness to mastery, emphasizing mentorship, collaborative ecosystems, and continuous learning. The work also examines the pivotal role of technology as a career accelerator, urging professionals to integrate AI, digital collaboration tools, and ethical innovation into their leadership and decision-making. Through frameworks like career portfolios, personalized development plans, and inclusive innovation initiatives (e.g., IEEE's Tech4Good), individuals can align their professional path with purpose-driven impact. The paper encourages a proactive, growth-oriented mindset that empowers professionals not only to stay relevant but to drive positive transformation across industries and communities. Whether you're an emerging leader, experienced practitioner, or technical innovator, this guide provides strategies to elevate power skills, lead with integrity, and build a resilient, value-centered career that meets the challenges and opportunities of the next decade.

title: Improving Board-Level Reliability of Large BGA Packages via Edgebond Placement
authors: Meng-Kai Shih, Si-Wei Lin, Yuan-Hong Ding, Chin-Ju Hsieh, Simon Chang
publish: 2025 20th International Microsystems, Packaging, Assembly and Circuits Technology Conference (IMPACT)
abstract: With the rapid advancement of high-performance computing (HPC) and artificial intelligence (AI), large-area electronic packages—often exceeding 100 × 100 mm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>—are becoming increasingly prevalent. These packages offer improved power delivery and integration density but also introduce substantial reliability challenges, particularly related to solder-joint durability. A key concern is solder-joint degradation during thermal cycling testing (TCT), which simulates the mechanical and thermomechanical stresses encountered during actual operation and environmental exposure. In such large-format assemblies, package warpage and coefficient of thermal expansion (CTE) mismatches among constituent materials lead to localized stress concentrations, especially at the outermost corner solder joints. This study investigates the effect of edgebonds and their interaction with solder joints under TCT conditions. Three edgebond configurations were analyzed: (1) No Edgebond, (2) Edgebond not contacting solder joints, and (3) Edgebond contacting solder joints. Finite element analysis was used to simulate thermo-mechanical stress distributions and to identify high-risk failure zones across the three designs.The results show that the No Edgebond configuration produces the highest strain-energy accumulation at the outermost solder joints, indicating the highest early-failure risk. In contrast, the Edgebond not contacting solder joints configuration functions as an effective mechanical buffer—redistributing warpage-induced stress, shifting the critical energy concentration inward, and resulting in the lowest energy accumulation. The Edgebond contacting solder joints configuration offers partial mechanical support but remains less effective due to direct stress transmission into the joints. In summary, the No Edgebond case presents the worst condition, while the non-contact edgebond configuration provides the most favorable improvement in solder-joint reliability. These findings demonstrate that edgebonds can significantly mitigate CTE-induced stresses and delay crack initiation—provided that direct mechanical coupling to solder joints is avoided. Strategically designed edgebond configurations that maintain clearance from solder joints can therefore enhance both solder-joint and overall package reliability in large-area HPC and AI applications.

title: Dual-Model Framework for Alzheimer's Detection in CT Imaging: A Comparative Study of EfficientNetV2-B0 and ResNet50V2
authors: Shehu Mohammed, Neha Malhotra, Sourabh Kumar
publish: 2025 5th Asian Conference on Innovation in Technology (ASIANCON)
abstract: AD is a neurodegenerative disease that gradually impairs memory and cognitive function, requiring prompt and accurate recognition for effective management. Traditional radiological methods are effective but limited by subjective interpretation and time-consuming analysis, especially when examining large quantities of brain CT scans. This paper introduces a two-model deep learning framework that includes EfficientNetV2-B0 and ResNet50V2 to automate Alzheimer’s Disease classification based on CT images, outperforming previous methods. Both models are trained on a carefully curated dataset of labeled brain CT images and utilize advanced transfer learning with preprocessing and data augmentation to ensure robust learning. The EfficientNetV2-B0 model is adapted with compound scaling to optimize accuracy and computational efficiency, while ResNet50V2 uses deep residual learning to detect subtle pathology patterns in the CT data. Visual interpretability is enhanced through Grad-CAM heatmaps, allowing medical practitioners to identify and verify decision regions and gain insights into each classification. Experimental results demonstrate that these models outperform other stateof-the-art approaches such as MobileNetV2, VGG16, and DenseNet121 across metrics like classification accuracy, precision, recall, F1-score, and AUC. Furthermore, these models are suitable for clinical and resource-limited settings due to their fast and stable inference speeds. The findings confirm that the hybrid deep learning approach utilizing EfficientNetV2-B0 and ResNet50V2 can serve as an effective and interpretable method for detecting Alzheimer’s disease via CT imaging.

title: FL-KAN: A Federated Learning Framework with Kolmogorov-Arnold Networks and Confused Modulo Projection Homomorphic Encryption
authors: Yimeng Dou, Lin Yang, Yutang Han, Xiaodong Li, Ruoyun Zhao, Xingyu An, Li Guan, Xin Li
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Networks, Communications and Information Technology (CNCIT)
abstract: With the growing adoption of federated learning (FL) in privacy-sensitive applications, current methods continue to face critical challenges of suboptimal model efficiency and potential privacy leakage. Conventional neural architectures such as multilayer perceptrons (MLPs) often suffer from low parameter efficiency and limited interpretability. Meanwhile, privacy-preserving schemes based on homomorphic encryption, while theoretically sound, are frequently hindered by prohibitive computational overheads, impeding practical deployment. To address these limitations, we propose FL-KAN, a novel federated learning framework that integrates the Kolmogorov-Arnold Networks (KAN) with confused modulo projection homomorphic encryption. By replacing traditional MLPs with KANs, which leverage learnable univariate functions, the proposed method significantly reduces model complexity while enhancing accuracy in image classification tasks. Furthermore, we propose a privacy-preserving aggregation mechanism based on confused modulo projection homomorphic encryption, which enables secure model aggregation in the ciphertext domain. This strategy effectively mitigates inference attacks and achieves markedly higher computational efficiency compared to conventional Paillier-based approaches. Empirical results on the MNIST dataset demonstrate that FL-KAN achieves over a 2% improvement in classification accuracy relative to standard MLPs, with faster convergence rates. Additionally, in horizontal federated learning scenarios, FL-KAN outperforms the FedAvg algorithm, while introducing only a tolerable latency during the encryption phase. Overall, this work provides a promising solution for achieving a high-performance, privacy-preserving federated learning paradigm, contributing novel insights into secure and efficient distributed model optimization.

title: In-House Recovery of Palladium Catalysts from PCB Wastewater for Reuse in Electroless Plating
authors: Yi-Ting Wu, Vidya Kattoor, Tzu Chien Wei
publish: 2025 20th International Microsystems, Packaging, Assembly and Circuits Technology Conference (IMPACT)
abstract: This study develops a cost-effective approach for recovering and reusing palladium-containing waste solution from printed circuit board production lines. The process employs simple chemical treatments—introducing a reducing agent in combination with polymer stabilization—to convert deactivated Pd-containing waste into a novel Pd nanoparticle catalyst. Specifically, sodium borohydride was used to reduce metal ions in the waste solution, while poly(vinyl alcohol) (PVA) served as a stabilizer to form nanoscale metallic Pd particles (R–PVA–Pd). Experimental results show that a PVA-to-Pd mass ratio of 11.4:1 yields catalysts with uniform particle size distribution and excellent catalytic performance. Structural and compositional analyses further confirmed that the R–PVA–Pd is a Pd– Cu bimetallic system, attributable to the ~10% copper ion content in the original waste solution. Induction-time monitoring revealed that the R–PVA–Pd exhibit electroless copper plating activity comparable to PVA–Pd made from pure, fresh Pd salts, and significantly outperform commercial Sn–Pd colloids and ionic Pd catalysts. Stability tests demonstrated that low-temperature storage effectively suppresses nanoparticle growth and mitigates activity decay, extending the operational lifetime of R–PVA–Pd to at least two months. Owing to its simplicity, reproducibility, and economic advantages, this process offers a viable route for Pd recovery and reuse in the PCB industry and other Pd-utilizing industries.

title: A Gated Recurrent Unit-Based Model for Detecting Emergency Words in Indonesian Speech
authors: Candra Bella Vista, Mohammad Izamul Fikri Fahmi, Muhammad Dzaka Murran Rusid, Vivi Nur Wijayaningrum
publish: 2025 International Conference on Smart-Green Technology in Electrical and Information Systems (ICSGTEIS)
abstract: This study presents a deep learning approach for detecting emergency-related speech in the Indonesian language. The main issue addressed is the lack of an automated system capable of accurately recognizing emergency words such as “tolong” (help), “jangan” (don't), “kecelakaan” (accident), “maling” (thief), and “kebakaran” (fire) in real-world environments. A dataset consists of 1,100 audio recordings was developed and preprocessed, including silence removal and normalization. Each recording was manually labeled as either emergency or non-emergency based on its content. Acoustic features were extracted using Mel-Frequency Cepstral Coefficients (MFCC), along with delta and delta-delta coefficients to better capture dynamic temporal information. A Gated Reccurent Unit (GRU) based acoustic model was trained and evaluated using both 10-fold cross-validation and a holdout test set. The results suggest that GRU-based models are wellsuited for real-time emergency keyword detection in lowresource languages. The evaluation results show that the best performing GRU model achieved 97% accuracy and 100% recall on emergency-class samples in the external test set.

title: CAFE-Net: Context-Aware Facial Expression Network
authors: Changhui Hou, Cong Zhang, Zhongtao Fu, Xiang Rui, Lianying Zou, Kaile Dong
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Computer Information Technology (AICIT)
abstract: This paper proposes Context-Aware Facial Expression Network (CAFE-Net), a deep learning framework for facial expression recognition. It integrates a Context Enhancement module (CEM) to extract multi-scale semantic features via dilated convolutions and wavelet transforms, and a Key Region Modulation (KRM) module to enhance expression-relevant regions using spatial attention. Experiments on RAF-DB and FERPlus demonstrate that CAFE-Net achieves state-of-the-art accuracies of 89.00% and 88.78%, respectively, showing superior generalization and robustness across diverse expression scenarios.

title: Single to Dual Band Reconfigurable and Switchable Reflective Metasurface for 5G Millimeter Wave
authors: Sunusi Garba Mohammed, Noor Asmawati Binti Samsuri, Mohamad Kamal B. A. Rahim, Nabilah Binti Ripin
publish: 2025 IEEE International RF and Microwave Conference (RFM)
abstract: Reconfigurable Intelligent Surfaces (RISs) are among the most promising technologies for redirecting electromagnetic signals around obstacles in wireless communication. However, challenges in RIS related to limited bandwidth remain a key area for further improvement. This paper presents a method for improving the RIS bandwidth by integrating a PIN diode into a metasurface unit cell to adjust its reflection response dynamically. The unit cell operates in a single band mode at 28 GHz when the integrated PIN diode is OFF and transitions to a dual band response at 26 GHz and 28 GHz when the diode is ON. Simulation results show that the unit cell maintains a phase difference of 180° ± 20° and a reflection magnitude of − 1.389 dB over a frequency range of 27.661 GHz to 28.130 GHz, corresponding to a 1.71% bandwidth at 28 GHz when the diode is OFF. When the diode is ON, the unit cell maintains a dual-band response, corresponding to 2.39% bandwidth at 26 GHz and 1.38% bandwidth at 28 GHz. The reconfigurable dual-band behaviour demonstrates the potential for dynamic beams in RIS-based millimeter wave (mmWave) communication systems.

title: Agentic Auto-Scheduling: An Experimental Study of LLM-Guided Loop Optimization
authors: Massinissa Merouani, Islem Kara Bernou, Riyadh Baghdadi
publish: 2025 34th International Conference on Parallel Architectures and Compilation Techniques (PACT)
abstract: Automatic code optimization remains a difficult challenge, particularly for complex loop nests on modern hardware. This paper investigates a novel approach to code optimization where Large Language Models (LLMs) guide the process through a closed-loop interaction with a compiler. We present Compilot, an experimental framework that leverages off-theshelf LLMs, without any task-specific fine-tuning, as interactive optimization agents. ComPilot establishes a feedback loop where an LLM proposes transformations for a given loop nest to a compiler. The compiler attempts the transformations, reporting back legality status and measured speedup or slowdown. The LLM utilizes this concrete feedback to iteratively refine its optimization strategy. Our extensive evaluation across the PolyBench benchmark suite demonstrates the effectiveness of this zero-shot approach. ComPilot achieves geometric mean speedups of $2.66 x$ (single run) and $3.54 x$ (best-of- 5 runs) over the original code. Furthermore, ComPilot demonstrates competitive performance against the state-of-the-art Pluto polyhedral optimizer, outperforming it in many cases. This experimental study demonstrates that general-purpose LLMs can effectively guide the code optimization process when grounded by compiler feedback, opening promising research directions for agentic AI in code optimization.

title: Ultra-Wideband Ground Open Slot Fed Millimeter Wave Dielectric Resonator Antenna for 5G Applications
authors: Abinash Gaya, Mohd Haizal Jamaluddin, Irene Kong Cheh Lin
publish: 2025 IEEE International RF and Microwave Conference (RFM)
abstract: A novel ground open slot fed ultra-wideband Dielectric Resonator Antenna (DRA) with a resonant frequency of 26 GHz is proposed. Using a single isolated dielectric resonator, a simulated impedance bandwidth of 60% has been achieved in the millimeter wave 5G frequency bands from 24.08 GHz to 39.8 GHz, with a wide bandwidth of 15.72 GHz. There is a 6.91 dBi simulated gain. The ultrawide bandwidth and high gain characteristics of this antenna make it the best option for use in millimeter wave 5G frequency bands.

title: A Comparative Evaluation of Outlier Handling Techniques in Photovoltaic Power
authors: Nana Sutarna, Muhammad Imam Rafi, Prihatin Oktivasari, Murie Dwiyaniti, Christianto Tjahyadi, Tohazen Tohazen
publish: 2025 8th International Conference of Computer and Informatics Engineering (IC2IE)
abstract: R Renewable energy has become an urgent necessity, with photovoltaic (PV) power forecasting playing a key role in ensuring its reliability. Accurate prediction, however, is often challenged by the presence of outliers in sensor data, which can significantly affect model performance. This study aims to evaluate the impact of five different outlier handling techniques on the predictive accuracy of two deep learning models, Bidirectional Long Short-Term Memory (BiLSTM) and Gated Recurrent Unit (GRU), in estimating PV power output. Multivariate sensor data collected over a two-month period were preprocessed using various outlier treatments before training the models. Performance was assessed using MAE, RMSE, and R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> metrics. Results indicate that both models achieved strong predictive performance, with GRU consistently outperforming BiLSTM across all scenarios. Interestingly, the best results were obtained without applying any outlier handling, which yielded the lowest error and the most stable validation loss curve. Conversely, forest tagging and isolation techniques led to higher errors and occasional instability during training. The novelty of this work lies in its systematic comparison of multiple outlier handling strategies within the context of deep learning-based PV forecasting, a gap not comprehensively addressed in prior studies. These findings offer practical insights for designing robust preprocessing strategies, ultimately supporting more reliable renewable energy operations in real-world applications.

title: Poster: HeteroSched: Co-Optimizing Scheduling and Parallelization for Deep Learning Workloads
authors: Bahram Afsharmanesh, Md Musfiqur Rahman Sanim, AmirAli Mirian, Gagan Agrawal
publish: 2025 34th International Conference on Parallel Architectures and Compilation Techniques (PACT)
abstract: As Deep Learning (DL) training has emerged as a dominant workload on clusters in recent years, there has been significant interest in parallelizing individual models and scheduling them efficiently. However, to date, no prior work has taken an integrated approach to addressing both problems while simultaneously accounting for heterogeneity in the execution environment. This paper introduces, demonstrating that the integrated optimization of parallelization and scheduling is both feasible and highly effective. The main insight of our work is to generate a set of possible target resources for each job and to develop corresponding parallelization strategies for each. Each jobstrategy pair is then treated as a scheduling candidate. Scheduling decisions are made by extending prior Linear Programming (LP)based formulations and incorporating new heuristics to reduce decision overhead.

title: BrailleVox: A Refreshable Voice Driven Braille Converter
authors: Divya K S, Raghi R Menon, Parvathy Nair, Gouri J Shenoi, Hiba Fathima M N, Arya Nandha
publish: 2025 5th Asian Conference on Innovation in Technology (ASIANCON)
abstract: This paper presents BrailleVox, a two-output assistive solution that integrates voice recognition with a refreshable Braille display in order to enhance digital accessibility for blind users. Contrary to traditional approaches that make use of audio feedback (screen readers) or fixed Braille devices, BrailleVox provides real-time feedback in both visual and tactile modes by combining conversational AI with dynamic Braille hardware. The system allows users to pose verbal questions and receive synchronized answers on a display and in a refreshable Braille module, providing flexible access based on user choice. Extensive usability testing exhibited strong voice-to-Braille accuracy, minimal latency, and excellent performance in diverse environments. By overcoming the constraints of single-mode systems, BrailleVox improves accessible technology for independent information access in education, work, and life situations

title: Research on the Sub-synchronous Oscillation Problem of New Energy Inverters Connected to the Power Grid
authors: Xiangyang Duan, Zhiqiang Wang, Haibo Zhou, Chunguang Wang, Anjie Wang, Shengjie Liu
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Mechatronics Technology (ICEEMT)
abstract: As the penetration level of renewable energy generation units increases in modern power grids, the stability of power systems faces new challenges, particularly the growing risk of sub-synchronous oscillations (SSO), which threaten overall system security. This paper investigates sub-synchronous oscillation phenomena in grid-connected converters for renewable energy systems using the impedance-based analytical method. The impedance-frequency characteristics of a three-phase grid-connected converter are modeled, and system stability is assessed based on the Nyquist stability criterion. The influence of control parameters and other factors on SSO is analyzed. Finally, simulation studies are conducted, demonstrating that appropriate tuning of the phase-locked loop (PLL) and current control loop coefficients effectively mitigates the risk of sub-synchronous oscillation.

title: Impact of Market Forecasting Analysis using Deep Learning Models
authors: Neetu Mittal, Kunal Gaurav, Mayank Rawat, Mohd Abu, Ayush Ayush
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Advances in Computing Research On Science Engineering and Technology (ACROSET)
abstract: The market forecasting task has always been a challenging task due to dynamic and unpredictable behavior of financial markets. Reliable predictors are necessary for informed decision making by investors, business, and policymakers. Conventional methods such as ARIMA and GARCH have dominated the field but face many limitations, mainly in modelling non-linear relationships and long-term reliance. Current advancements in the deep learning have introduced innovative models, Like Recurrent Neural Networks (RNNs) and Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) networks, which outdo in processing sequential data. RNNs recognize the patterns I time series data, ensure them suitable for short-term forecasting. However, there are some difficulties which decrease their performance when dealing with long term dependencies. On the other hand, LSTM networks, which is advancement of RNNs, that handle these difficulties by incorporating memory cells that keep data for a longer period of time, by ensuring for more accurate predictions in financial forecasting. This study analyses the design, implementation and comparative performance of RNN and LSTM models in market forecasting. Using the previous data of stock prices, the ability to predict future market trends has been analyzed. This research shows that LSTM networks outperform RNNs in accuracy, reliability and their ability to capture long term reliance, though their computational prices are much higher. These insights have a way of adopting highly advanced deep learning techniques in financial forecasting applications.

title: CNN-based Demolition Waste Classification for Sustainable Construction Resource Recovery
authors: Murugesan G, R. Meenakshi, E. Sivanantham, Bhanumathi M, A. Senthil Murugan, S Sujatha
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Innovative Data Communication Technologies and Application (ICIDCA)
