title: Reflections on the IEEE Milestone Program
authors: David G Michelson
publish: 2025 IEEE History of Electrotechnology Conference (HISTELCON)
abstract: In 1979, the first IEEE Milestone was dedicated in collaboration with the American Society for Civil Engineers and the American Society for Mechanical Engineers. Four years later, on the eve of the IEEE centenary celebrations, the IEEE Milestones program was officially launched with a mandate to draw the attention of both the public and the profession to significant events and accomplishments in electrical and computer engineering and related fields that occurred at least 25 years in the past. Although the Milestones program started slowly, it rapidly gained momentum. More than 20 Milestone proposals are now being submitted each year. As of September 2025, 276 Milestone plaques have been dedicated with many more approved and awaiting dedication. With the 300th Milestone dedication looming and 50th anniversary of the first Milestone dedication just a few years away, the IEEE History Committee has initiated a review of the Milestones program with an aim to refining its procedures and processes to reflect current approaches to public history and address operational challenges. Here, we reflect on the history, accomplishments, and challenges of the Milestones program to date and propose ways in which the program can be enhanced to ensure its relevance and efficacy in the decades to come.

title: A Data Archive about History of Informatics in Hungary
authors: Pál Breuer, Bálint Dömölki, Miklós Havass
publish: 2025 IEEE History of Electrotechnology Conference (HISTELCON)
abstract: History of computer science, information technology (IT) and telecommunication are definitely part of our cultural heritage. Collection and distribution of factual data about history of these fields should be regarded as important part of preservation of cultural heritage of a given geographic area and time period. This is more necessary and adequate in case of rarely documented facts, moreover if achievements were created beyond objects might have physically been preserved, like intellectual activities and especially productions of pre-internet times. Computer research, developments, software and like of early periods are among those which are not accessible on web archives (but by documents and in human memories only). Under the frame of the John von Neumann Computer Society, Hungary (NJSZT) there has been set up a Section for History of Information Technology and it has come to the resolution to build up a data archive covering a wide range of computing heritage, i.e.: persons' professional careers and activities on computer R&D; products (SW, HW); institutions and companies involved; papers, reports, further written documents; list of events, conferences etc.; photo documents scanned, and finally, video portraits of elderly prestigious professionals, on other word, witnesses of the past. Collecting data is dedicated specially to IT history in Hungary as well as to impacts throughout the world by Hungarian origin professionals, and is emphasized on time period from the very beginning till around the '90ties. This project has been started by volunteer activities of mostly retired noted professionals since 2009. The Archive is ready now for opening to public research, experts and science historians. The paper describes as the model of the digital archive in details as the research opportunities among its historically valued data and also the intellectual significance of the more than 5200 items in the Archive. There is given some remarks about a unique collection and exhibition of computer history in Hungary located in Szeged, Hungary maintained also by NJSZT. The aggregation of this collection together with the Archive form jointly a hybrid, i.e. real + virtual, museum. The paper also describes our latest action for preserving the Archive for long time, we call “eternity”, not to be dependent of limits of temporal and changing storage options in digital sites and forms of the present.

title: How Digital Literacy, Information Quality, and Travel Experience Affect Tourism Information Systems
authors: Dicky Hida Syahchari, Engkos Achmad Kuncoro, Teguh Amor Patria, Antonius Atosokhi Gea, Murty Magda Pane, Siriporn Khetjenkarn
publish: 2025 8th International Conference of Computer and Informatics Engineering (IC2IE)
abstract: This study aims to examine the impacts of digital literacy, information quality, and travel experience on the effectiveness of Tourism Information Systems (TIS) technology in Bali. Gaps already identified within the literature suggest: no comprehensive studies that incorporate digital literacy, information quality, and the travel experience within TIS; no adequate consideration of the digital competencies of both tourists and service providers within the tourism ecosystem; and no consideration of the impact information quality, as well as emerging technologies, have on the tourist experience in Bali as a culturally rich destination. As the tourism industry continues to expand, the practical and timely integration of TIS for disseminating information to tourists and other stakeholders is becoming increasingly critical. A quantitative approach was used for the study. Participants included 117 tourists in Bali, all of whom completed the questionnaires. Three primary hypotheses on the relations between digital literacy, information quality, travel experience, and the effectiveness of TIS were tested. Results showed that all three independent variables had a significant and positive influence on TIS effectiveness. Of all three, travel experience had the most substantial impact, followed by digital literacy, and then information quality. The results demonstrated that enhanced digital competencies for TIS in tourism and hospitality, as well as the quality of information provision and travel experience management, need to be optimised through the use of advanced technology. This study aimed to fill the existing literature gap by adopting a holistic approach to addressing the gaps in the literature and these relationships. For the case of Bali, the results of this research can assist decision-makers and tourism sector stakeholders in improving the management of tourist information, increasing tourist satisfaction, and promoting the cultural and environmental sustainability of tourist destinations.

title: Optimizing the Management of Islamic Places of Worship in Pekanbaru Using K-Prototypes Clustering and Multi-Validation Approaches
authors: Akbarizan, Rahmad Kurniawan, Sri Murhayati Nurcahaya, Mashadi, Mohd Zakree Ahmad Nazri, Nurrahmi Hayani
publish: 2025 8th International Conference of Computer and Informatics Engineering (IC2IE)
abstract: The Forum for Religious Harmony (FKUB) in Pekanbaru is responsible for ensuring fair management and support for worship places across religious communities. A major challenge lies in resource allocation because of the lack of reliable data on facility conditions, congregation sizes, and spatial distribution. This gap increases the risk of unequal support, inefficiency, and social tension. This study applies unsupervised learning, focusing on the K-Prototypes algorithm to address this issue. K-Prototypes is suitable for this dataset because it combines numerical and categorical attributes including worship type, subdistrict, district, building condition, and the number of regular congregants. A total of 990 records provided by the Indonesian Council of Ulama (MUI) and FKUB Pekanbaru were cleaned and analyzed, each with six key features. Several validation methods were applied to determine the optimal number of clusters, including the Elbow Method, Silhouette Score, Davies-Bouldin Index, and Calinski-Harabasz Index. The analysis identified seven meaningful clusters, supported by the highest Calinski-Harabasz Index of 201.46. Significant differences in congregation sizes were also confirmed through ANOVA. The results provide actionable insights that enable FKUB and policymakers to design fairer resource allocation and targeted support. This study demonstrates how clustering of mixed-type data can advance the management of worship facilities. The approach offers a practical model for multi-faith urban settings facing similar challenges. This study is limited to Islamic worship facilities in Pekanbaru, and future work should extend the analysis to other faiths and cities to enhance generalizability.

title: An Ultra-Wideband Multilayer Energy Selective Surface Based on Coupled Resonator Filter
authors: Jiaqun Yang, Jun Xu, Bo Hu, Hui Zhang, Xutao Yu
publish: 2025 18th IEEE United Conference on Millimeter Waves and Terahertz Technologies (UCMMT)
abstract: In this letter, an ultra-wideband multilayer energy selective surface (ESS) based on the coupled resonator filter topology is proposed. The ESS is composed of three layers, of which the top and bottom is comprised with meander-line metallic patches integrated with diodes and the middle layer is a square metallic loop structure. In contrast to conventional ESS designs based on LC resonance, the ESS operates through interlayer resonance between the equivalent capacitance (C) generated by the top/bottom metallic patches and the equivalent inductance (L) produced by the middle layer square metallic loop. When in the transmitting state, the structure obtains an 1dB bandwidth covering 7.3 to 12.5 GHz. When in the shielding state, the structure transforms into a shielding plate, with shielding effectiveness (SE) above 45dB within the frequency range of 5 to 15GHz. Meanwhile, the ESS exhibits excellent angel stability with IL less than 1dB when the incident angle changes within the range of 0 to 50 degrees.

title: Design of Folded Dipole Antenna Based on Shortcircuit of Overhanging Terminal
authors: Pengcheng Li, Peng Hui Jian, Yuan Li, Xi Chen, Kai Wang, Tao Dong
publish: 2025 18th IEEE United Conference on Millimeter Waves and Terahertz Technologies (UCMMT)
abstract: In the paper, a C-frequency band dipole antenna, implied for coaxial feeding high-power transmission, is designed. With the structure of the bent arms, the size of antenna is reduced effectively. Simultaneously, overhanging terminal shortcircuit of coaxial transmission design is applied for improving of anti-vibration ability. Besides, impedance matching is also achieved by the structure. The entire antenna model is simulated by Ansys HFSS. The measured results indicate that the good performance of VSWR (Voltage Standing Wave Ratio) is achieved between the frequency range of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{5 - 5. 5 ~ G H z}$</tex>. Furthermore, with the input power rating up to 47 dBm, the antenna can be proved to keep working normally more than 15 minutes.

title: An Amplifying Phase-Amplitude Reconfigurable Metasurface for Flexible Beam Control
authors: Lijie Wu, Zheng Xing Wang, Hui Dong Li, Jun Yan Dai, Qiang Cheng
publish: 2025 18th IEEE United Conference on Millimeter Waves and Terahertz Technologies (UCMMT)
abstract: Phase-amplitude reconfigurable metasurfaces (PARMs) have garnered significant attention in recent years for their powerful manipulation and real-time control of electromagnetic (EM) waves. However, existing PARMs often suffer from low energy efficiency, limited amplitude tuning range, and inadequate phase control precision. To solve these problems, we propose an amplifying phase-amplitude reconfigurable metasurface (APARM) capable of simultaneous wide-range, high-precision amplitude and phase modulation. Specifically, it is embedded with gain-tunable amplifier chips and can realize over 5 dB EM energy amplification and about 30 dB amplitude tuning range. Meanwhile, it possesses stable 1-bit phase modulation and thus can achieve accurate phase control at harmonic frequencies through time coding strategies. Crucially, unlike conventional amplitude-control method that relies on energy absorption, the integration of amplifier chips significantly enhances energy efficiency. Furthermore, it greatly simplifies control circuits and reduces system complexity by decoupling amplitude and phase control. To validate the performance of the proposed APARM, a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$6 \times 6$</tex> prototype was carefully constructed, fabricated and measured. The results demonstrate that it can realize energy amplification, wide-range amplitude control, and accurate phase tuning. Moreover, through diverse time coding strategies, the APARM array can realize flexible harmonic beam control. Owing to its great performance, we believe that the proposed APARM will find potential applications in wireless communications and radar systems.

title: Reinforcement Learning-Based Design of Sparse Arrays for Imaging Applications
authors: Yuke He, Kuiwen Xu
publish: 2025 18th IEEE United Conference on Millimeter Waves and Terahertz Technologies (UCMMT)
abstract: In this letter, a general design method for multi-input multi-output (MIMO) antenna arrays based on deep reinforcement learning (DRL) is proposed, which is suitable for short-range ultra-wideband (UWB) imaging applications. The proposed method achieves better uniformity within the effective aperture and exhibits low element shadowing characteristics. It is applicable to arrays with arbitrary numbers of elements and any aperture size. In comparison with the curved and rectangular array configurations, the proposed array design exhibits significantly better focusing performance, highlighting its effectiveness in achieving higher imaging resolution and reduced sidelobe artifacts.

title: Quantifying AI Impact in Post-Compromise Incident Response
authors: Muntathar Abid, Priyadarsi Nanda
publish: 2025 9th Cyber Security in Networking Conference (CSNet)
abstract: This paper presents metrics for measuring the operational impact of artificial intelligence in cybersecurity incidents. It introduces five practical metrics that assess how AI influences the speed, scale, and visibility of post-compromise activity. The metrics are evaluated through two simulated scenarios representing different levels of organisational maturity and security capability. Results show that artificial intelligence can accelerate attacker actions and challenge traditional detection and response workflows. This highlights the need for measurable indicators of AI's impact in cyber-attacks. The metrics support readiness assessments in enterprise environments with increasing integration of AI systems.

title: Perspectives on Practical Implementations in the Web-based Musical Metaverse
authors: Damian Dziwis, Alberto Boem, Matthias Nowakowski, Luca Turchet
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th International Symposium on the Internet of Sounds (IS2)
abstract: The technical advances that immersive environments are experiencing through virtual and augmented reality, combined with the global networking possibilities offered by the internet, are making shared virtual environments increasingly attractive as a platform for musical practice in the so-called Musical Metaverse (MM). The growth of dedicated tools and systems, especially for web-based metaverse environments, has made the web-based MM particularly relevant in recent years. Browsers and web technologies have particular advantages for live performances and sound installations in the MM. They are platform-independent and can be experienced on a wide range of devices, including PCs, smartphones, and standalone head-mounted displays. Users do not need to install additional software; a link is sufficient to participate in the next metaverse performance. However, all the advantages of web-based MM applications also come with various challenges and limitations, such as incompatibilities and inefficiencies. Drawing on extensive experience in development, research, and artistic practice in the realm of the web-based MM, the authors of this paper address the challenges encountered in the development of web-based MM applications and explore avenues for future advancement to bridge the identified gaps.

title: A Wideband Reconfigurable Feeding Network for Multi-Polarization Reconfigurable Antennas
authors: Xin-Hao Zhu, Yun-Peng Lyu, Lei Zhu
publish: 2025 18th IEEE United Conference on Millimeter Waves and Terahertz Technologies (UCMMT)
abstract: This paper presents a new miniaturized wideband reconfigurable feeding networking, composed of the Wilkinson power divider and compact wideband differential phase shifter. By optimally configuring and biasing the PIN diodes to control their ON/OFF states, the proposed feeding network can switch among three operational modes: one circularly polarized (CP) mode and two linearly polarized (LP) modes. The proposed feeding network is suitable for polarization reconfigurable antenna applications. To verify the proposed design concept, a prototype of the proposed feeding network has been designed, fabricated, and tested. Experimental results validate the proposed feeding network's good performance, with measured return loss (RL) > 10 dB, insertion loss (IL) <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$<1.8 \text{dB}$</tex>, port isolation (ISO) <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$>18 \text{dB}$</tex>, and phase error (PE) <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$< \pm 5^{\circ}$</tex> with the fractional bandwidth (FBW <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$=69 \%$</tex>) over the frequency range of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$1.9-3.9 \text{GHz}$</tex>.

title: Proactive Cybersecurity through Cyber Crime Triangle Framework: A Mathematical Approach with AI/ML Integration and Game-Theoretic Optimization
authors: Naughtakid Phromchan, Pongsarun Boonyopakorn
publish: 2025 Research, Invention, and Innovation Congress: Innovative Electricals and Electronics (RI2C)
abstract: Cybersecurity threats are evolving faster than conventional defenses can adapt. To address this growing asymmetry, we propose the Cyber Crime Triangle Framework (CCTF)—a proactive, mathematically grounded approach that unifies criminological theory, partial differential equation (PDE) modeling, AI/ML-driven detection, and game-theoretic optimization. Rooted in Crime Triangle Theory, CCTF formulates the dynamic interplay among attackers, targets, and defenders as a system of coupled PDEs. These equations capture spatiotemporal threat behavior, while embedded AI modules adaptively assess offender motivation, target vulnerability, and defense readiness. A game-theoretic layer models adversarial interactions as a Stackelberg game, enabling the derivation of optimal defense strategies under uncertainty. Formal verification ensures safety, stability, and recoverability of the system. Experimental validation across five major attack scenarios—including APTs, ransomware, insider threats, IoT-based attacks, and supply chain compromises—demonstrates 94.7% detection accuracy, a 2.1% false positive rate, and a 76.8% reduction in potential damage. These results confirm CCTF’s capability to anticipate and counter complex cyber threats in real-world environments.

title: Economic Mathematics Question Bank Development System Based on Artificial Intelligence Algorithm
authors: Yuhui Zhu, Changsheng Bao
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Computer Information Technology (AICIT)
abstract: This study planned and implemented a system for developing economic mathematics test bank with the help of artificial intelligence algorithms. The goal is to eliminate the shortcomings of traditional test bank platforms, such as slow question composition efficiency, excessive content duplication, and inaccurate difficulty matching. The overall structure of the system architecture includes four core modules: front-end display, back-end service, AI model engine, and database. It relies on BERT semantic encoding combined with constraint optimization algorithm to achieve the effect of intelligent question composition and question recommendation. The system is trained and evaluated based on the UCI public data set. The experimental results show that compared with the traditional methods, this system has made significant progress in the dimensions of question composition coverage, difficulty balance, and recommendation relevance. It can be seen from user test feedback that the system has shown good status in interface interactivity and recommendation accuracy. The platform can be used more in the online homework and teaching assistance of higher education mathematics courses, giving technological impetus to intelligent education.

title: Decoding the Stones: Vision-based Recognition of 8th-Century Tamil Vattezhuthu Inscriptions: A Systematic Review
authors: Tanusree D, Vidhyalakshmi B, B. M Arunesai, Priya.J, N.Prabhavathi
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Innovative Data Communication Technologies and Application (ICIDCA)
abstract: Vattezhuthu, one of the earliest Tamil scripts, dating from the 6th to 12th centuries A.D., is of high historical and linguistic importance. However, many inscriptions remain undeciphered, partly due to erosion, partly because the glyph structures are complex and partly because there isn't even a basic annotated datasets available. The traditional image-based recognition methods tend to not work well even when the characters are degraded or stylistically variant. Recent works have explored various convolutional neural networks (CNNs), in particular VGG16, MobileNet, and Siamese CNN-RNNs, with several preprocessing methods (binarization, median filtering, contour-based segmentation, etc.) to improve the recognition of the heavily degraded inscriptions. The paper reviews, in general, the currently employed strategies, architectures and preprocessing pipelines in Tamil inscription digitization, while recognizing significant limitations. Future directions in data augmentation, few-shot learning and generalization of any scripts will be considered in the context of some of the tools and techniques relevant to South Indian cultural heritage preservation.

title: The Octagonal Slot Antenna Improvement with A Circular Stub on A Textile Substrate for 4G/5G and UWB Communication Systems
authors: Chayapol Sangmook, Norakamon Wongsin, Thinnawat Jangjing, Nipont Tangthong, Nonchanutt Chudpooti, Chawalit Rakluea, Wanchalerm Chanwattanapong, Chatree Mahatthanajatuphat
publish: 2025 International Conference on Power, Energy and Innovations (ICPEI)
abstract: This paper presents the improvement of a octagonal slot antenna integrated with a circular stub on a flexible textile substrate for modern wireless communication systems, including 3G, 4G, 5G, and Ultra-Wideband (UWB) applications. The antenna design was methodically refined via parametric analysis and constructed from laser-cut copper conductive fabric on a textile substrate with a relative permittivity (εr) of 2.2 and dimensions of 40 × 46 × 1.06 mm. Measurement results validate an extensive operational spectrum ranging from 1.55 GHz to over 12 GHz, encompassing critical frequency bands for 3G–5G (1.71–2.6 GHz) and UWB (3.1–10.6 GHz). The antenna has consistent bidirectional radiation patterns, achieving a peak gain of 3 dBi in the 3G–5G spectrum and 4.2 dBi in the UWB spectrum. The proposed antenna, characterized by its compact dimensions, mechanical flexibility, and broad frequency performance, is exceptionally appropriate for wearable electronics and integrated wireless systems.

title: Implementation of Multifunctional Smart Desk Lamp using ESP32 Microcontroller Board
authors: Li Fei, Suchada Sitjongsataporn
publish: 2025 International Conference on Power, Energy and Innovations (ICPEI)
abstract: With the rapid development of Internet of Things (IoT) technology, the smart home industry, particularly smart desk lamp is experiencing rapid growth. This multi-functional smart lamp using ESP32 microcontroller board can automatically sense the ambient light and human activity, enabling intelligent switching to address the inconveniences and safety hazards associated with traditional lamps. Therefore, designing a smart desk lamp that integrates voice control, wireless charging, adaptive brightness adjustment, and other functions is particularly important. The smart desk lamp introduces the features of wireless charging and intelligent brightness adjustment via light sensors. Equipped with these functions, the smart desk lamp can display time, date, and weather forecasts, monitor ambient temperature and humidity, and includes a 3.5-inch touchscreen for intuitive brightness adjustment, providing users with comprehensive information and convenience.

title: Warpage Optimization of Manufacturing Process for Fan-out Chip on Substrate-Bridge
authors: Chung-Hang Lai, Wei-Jie Yin, Wei-Hong Lai, Chin-Li Kao, Chen-Chao Wang, C P Hung
publish: 2025 20th International Microsystems, Packaging, Assembly and Circuits Technology Conference (IMPACT)
abstract: Driven by the rapid progress in high-performance computing and heterogeneous integration, advanced packaging technologies are evolving to fulfill growing demands for high I/O density and enhanced electrical performance. ASE’s Fan-Out Chip on Substrate-Bridge (FOCoS-B) is a promising solution. This structure integrates multiple chiplets through an embedded bridge within a fan-out module, which is then mounted onto a high-density organic substrate. The architecture enables fine-pitch interconnects while offering excellent signal integrity and design flexibility.Due to the complex material stack and multi-layer assembly process, mechanical reliability especially warpage control has become a critical challenge in FOCoS-B packaging. This study investigates warpage behavior during two critical manufacturing stages: wafer-level processing and post-dicing fan-out module assembly. Finite Element Analysis (FEA) is used to simulate thermal-mechanical deformation and assess key contributing factors including structural and material conditions. In this study, the structural factors considered include the carrier thickness and the top epoxy molding compound (EMC) thickness, while the material factors involve the top and bottom EMC, wafer underfill (WUF), and the wafer carrier. A design of experiments (DOE) approach is applied to systematically analyze the impact and interaction of these variables.During the wafer process, the properties of the EMC and carrier are crucial and expectedly have a significant impact on warpage. After singulation into individual modules, the combination of the top and bottom EMC becomes even more important. Improper combinations of materials and structural parameters can result in significant warpage and stress concentrations, especially near the embedded bridge, thus threatening device reliability.This study provides key insights into warpage control and mechanical behavior in FOCoS-B structures and serves as a design guideline for improving process yield and long-term reliability in next-generation fan-out packaging.

title: Advanced synchrotron and electron microscopy techniques for the development of Pb-free solder alloys and intermetallics: Case studies
authors: Kazuhiro Nogita
publish: 2025 20th International Microsystems, Packaging, Assembly and Circuits Technology Conference (IMPACT)
abstract: This paper provides an overview of research activities at the Nihon Superior Centre for the Manufacture of Electronic Materials (NS CMEM), The University of Queensland, including how advanced materials characterisation using Synchrotron and state-of-the-art electron microscopy techniques, can be used to optimise and develop Pb-free solder alloys and the associated intermetallics that form between the solder alloys and substrates of electronic interconnects. The following two practical/experimental advanced approaches will be discussed, along with their use in international collaborative projects, (i) Synchrotron X-ray imaging at the SPring-8 synchrotron [1] - [5], and (ii) State-of-the-art electron microscopy at The University of Queensland and Kyushu University [6] - [8].

title: Breakdown Voltage and Electric Field Behavior in Three Types of Electrodes
authors: K. Kitwattana, P. Jitjing, A. Thongma, C. Plaengpraphan
publish: 2025 International Conference on Power, Energy and Innovations (ICPEI)
abstract: Studying breakdown voltage and electric field behavior in three-electrode systems is an important issue to understand how electrode geometry and spacing influence insulation performance and its failure mechanisms. This work develops three prototype electrode sets: plane-plane electrodes, sphere-plane electrodes, and point-plane electrodes, enables controlled experiments that simulate real-world high-voltage conditions, helping to enhance performance of insulation. In addition, it can optimize the insulation design and predict breakdown behavior more accurately.The investigation into high-intensity electric fields generally reveals that electrical breakdown occurs when the field strength reaches the dielectric's maximum withstand capability. Experimental results indicate that, in air-insulated systems, the electric field intensity at the point of breakdown varies depending on the electrode geometry and spacing. Notably, each breakdown occurrence has a maximum electric field intensity (Emax) that slightly decreases as the distance increases.During the breakdown voltage testing, a voltage ramp rate of 1 kV/s was applied across the electrodes. Experimental results from the three different electrode configurations demonstrated that the breakdown voltage increased proportionally with the electrode gap (U∝d).Finite element simulations were then conducted at the breakdown points corresponding to each distance, revealing that the average electric field intensity (E<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">avg</inf>) decreased as the distance increased, while the maximum electric field intensity (E<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">max</inf>) showed only a slight decline. Notably, the point-to-plane configuration consistently exhibited a high electric field intensity across all distances.By calculating the electric field factor (η) using Eavg and Emax, it was observed that η* significantly decreased with greater electrode spacing, particularly in sharp-edged geometries. These findings suggest that E<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">avg</inf> alone is not a reliable indicator of breakdown thresholds. The development of this test apparatus and corresponding educational modules serves to support undergraduate instruction materials and future research into electric field dynamics.

title: Pattern Shapes Prediction in Cross-sectional Images and Proposing Processes with Neural Network
authors: Kohei Motojima, Hayato Sugiyama, Kaede Ameyama, Chiho Ueta
publish: 2025 20th International Microsystems, Packaging, Assembly and Circuits Technology Conference (IMPACT)
abstract: Recently, with the development of artificial intelligence (AI) and Big Data, semiconductor packages are required to have high computation capability. To meet this demand, semiconductors are miniaturized, and the semiconductor packages are rapidly becoming denser and larger due to the development of chiplet technology and heterogeneous technology. The connection method between the chip and the substrate changes based on the number of I/Os on the chip. Accordingly, the materials used for package substrates must offer functionality and processing accuracy to ensure reliable bonding with various materials. The pattern shapes of the functional materials need to be controlled because it is known that pattern shapes significantly impact the long-term reliability of semiconductor packages. To control the pattern shape, it is important to design materials and process technology, and this accuracy requirement is becoming stricter every year [1] . Therefore, whenever a new semiconductor package is developed, many substrate prototypes are fabricated and then subjected to destructive cross-section observations. This process is crucial for the material design and establishing process technology [2] . Additionally, small-diameter vias can be opened due to the evolution of lithography equipment and laser equipment. As a result, there are increasing demands for pattern shape control, such as residuals and taper angles at the bottom of the vias. Interlayer insulations and solder resist (SR) applied high-density designs for a wide variety of semiconductor packages with especially demanding pattern shapes. Because they require different film thicknesses, pattern shapes, and via sizes. To meet these demands, the cross-sections must be polished so that the center of the via diameter can be observed about the combination of film thickness and via size for each condition. Observations of the center cross-section of a via of several to several ten micrometers require advanced polishing techniques and significant experimental costs. Currently, no equipment can efficiently observe, so it can take several days to several weeks to complete a task that doesn’t require a human resource. Therefore, it is a problem that not enough time can be allocated to creative work in these days of manpower shortages. For the future evolution of semiconductor packaging, new technologies are needed to efficiently and quickly achieve the development of revolutionary functional materials and the establishment of mass production process technologies, along with advances in equipment.

title: A Paillier-based k-out-of-n oblivious transfer protocol
authors: Li Guan, Xiaodong Li, Ruoyun Zhao, Jianyi Zhang, Yimeng Dou, Xingyu An, Yuan Cui, Xin Li
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Networks, Communications and Information Technology (CNCIT)
abstract: Oblivious Transfer (OT), a fundamental primitive in cryptography and a cornerstone of Secure Multi-Party Computation (SMPC), is widely applied in privacy-preserving domains. Constructing efficient and secure OT protocols remains an active research area. To address the limitations of existing OT protocols, such as high time complexity and poor scalability, this paper proposes a secure and efficient k-out-of-n oblivious transfer protocol based on the Paillier homomorphic encryption algorithm . The protocol employs a system of multivariate equations to enable the receiver to select k messages from n messages held by the sender. By integrating multi-threaded parallel processing, the computational speed of ciphertext matrix-vector operations is significantly improved. Additionally, plaintext-ciphertext computation replaces traditional encryption methods to optimize the Paillier algorithm’s efficiency for batch data encryption. Experimental results demonstrate that, compared to recent k-out-of-n OT schemes: when n exceeds 30,000 with k=1, the protocol achieves a 200% performance improvement; when n=512 and k=256, it outperforms existing protocols by approximately 100% in overall efficiency.

title: An Application Study on a Novel SFT-PTS PAPR Suppression Scheme
authors: Zhao Chen, Yifan Zhou, Xin Guo, Mengshuang Zhu, Qunqun Zhou
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Networks, Communications and Information Technology (CNCIT)
abstract: The Filter Bank Multicarrier with Offset Quadrature Amplitude Modulation (FBMC-OQAM) system has attracted significant attention in recent years due to its advantages such as high data rates and robustness against multipath fading. However, FBMC-OQAM systems suffer from high Peak-to-Average Power Ratio (PAPR). To address this issue, an improved PAPR suppression scheme, named Segmented Fourier Transform-Partial Transmission Sequence (SFT-PTS), is proposed. Unlike traditional PTS methods that optimize each data block independently, SFT-PTS segments the overlapped signal of the data blocks, applies a Fourier transform, and then performs PTS. The approach significantly reduces computational complexity while still achieving good PAPR suppression performance. Specifically, under the simulation parameters described in Section V, when the Complementary Cumulative Distribution Function (CCDF) is 10<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">−3</sup>, the proposed scheme improves the PAPR suppression by 0.2 dB compared to the MBJO-PTS-Suc. Furthermore, when the number of subblocks V=8, the scheme reduces the number of real additions by 72.6% and the number of real multiplications by 69.9%. Additionally, cascading the SFT-PTS with μ-law compression-expansion further enhances PAPR suppression at the cost of a slight BER performance degradation.

title: Exploring the Effects of Adaptive Testing Innovations on Distance STEM Education for Adult Learners: A Systematic Review
authors: Anwar Al-Abbass, Georgy Loriya, Jason Stidd, Thomas Trask, Nicholas Lytle
publish: 2025 IEEE Digital Education and MOOCS Conference (DEMOcon)
abstract: This systematic review examines the impact of recent advances in adaptive testing on distance learning in STEM (Science, Technology, Engineering, Mathematics) education for adult learners. Through an analysis of 20 relevant papers published between 2014 and 2024, selected from an initial pool of 297 studies, the research reveals how modern adaptive testing systems, enhanced by machine learning algorithms and artificial intelligence, are transforming distance STEM education. The findings demonstrate that technologies such as Computerized Adaptive Testing (CAT) and reinforcement learning algorithms significantly improve learning outcomes through personalized assessment paths and real-time feedback mechanisms. These systems have been shown to reduce test time while maintaining assessment accuracy and can effectively accommodate learners from diverse educational backgrounds. Adaptive testing shows strong results in large-scale online courses, where traditional assessments often fail. However, challenges persist in areas such as question bank development, algorithm optimization, and ensuring demographic fairness. This review synthesizes current research directions and identifies opportunities for future development, particularly emphasizing the need for more comprehensive studies on long-term learning outcomes across various STEM disciplines.

title: Blockchain-Based Online Voting System: Enhancing Security and Transparency in Elections Through Advanced Cryptographic Integration
authors: Manoj Patil, Adarsh Mote, Diksha Patil, Pratik Patil, Rutvi Patil
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Advances in Computing Research On Science Engineering and Technology (ACROSET)
abstract: Blockchain technology presents a transformative solution to the vulnerabilities inherent in traditional electoral processes by ensuring security, transparency, and scalability. By leveraging a decentralized and immutable ledger, blockchain provides vote integrity, voter anonymity, and end-to-end verifiability. This paper details the design, implementation, and evaluation of a blockchain-based online voting system using Ethereum smart contracts. The system integrates sophisticated cryptographic techniques, including zero-knowledge proofs and homomorphic encryption, alongside a distributed architecture to enhance election integrity. Our implementation demonstrates several key advantages: tamper-proof voting records, real-time verifiability of election progress, and scalability for large electorates. Performance analysis reveals an 85% reduction in vote counting time compared to traditional methods, with 99.99% accuracy and zero security breaches during testing. The system achieves cost efficiency through automated vote tallying while maintaining voter privacy. While challenges such as regulatory compliance and user adoption persist, this work demonstrates that blockchain technology holds the potential to revolutionize democratic processes by offering a secure, transparent, and accessible voting solution for the digital age.

title: Personalized Meta Reinforcement Learning for Adaptive Shared Control in Semi Autonomous Vehicles
authors: Kodeeswari K, Amsaveni Manigandan, Narmatha P, Nandini N, S.S. Ananthan, J. Noor Ahamed
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Innovative Data Communication Technologies and Application (ICIDCA)
abstract: Semi autonomous vehicles use shared control strategies to balance decision-making between human drivers and automated systems, aiming to enhance safety, comfort, and adaptability. Traditional arbitration methods are largely static and struggle to adapt to varying driver traits such as aggressiveness, caution, and reaction time. To address this, the paper proposes the Personalized Meta Reinforcement Learning for Adaptive Shared Control (PM-RL-SC) framework, which models human vehicle interaction as a meta reinforcement learning problem over diverse driver styles. The approach uses a latent driver behaviour encoder to generate real-time personalized embeddings from steering patterns, gaze direction, and other sensor data, enabling calculation of a dynamic blending coefficient to merge human and autonomous commands. Leveraging Model Agnostic Meta Learning (MAML), the system rapidly adapts to new drivers with minimal data, greatly reducing calibration time. Evaluated in the CARLA simulation environment across various road layouts and driver profiles, PM-RL-SC achieved higher safety scores, better style matching, and improved comfort compared to baseline reinforcement learning, rule-based arbitration, and contextual bandit methods, reaching optimal performance in under five episodes. These results highlight its potential for next generation semi autonomous vehicle systems.

title: Assessment of Various Machine Learning Approaches for Predicting Water Quality with Unbalanced Data
authors: Shilpa Agnihotri Pandey, Prajeet Sharma
publish: 2025 5th Asian Conference on Innovation in Technology (ASIANCON)
abstract: The integration of Water Quality is essential for keeping the good human health. This paper has validated various machine learning (ML) based models for water quality prediction (WQP) of the drinking water potability. this research has validated the machine learning (ML) and deep learning (DL) models for the categorization and prediction of water quality. A significant contribution of study is to focuses on implementing 3 times Synthetic Minority Over-sampling Technique (SMOTE). This technique is used to address class imbalance by generating synthetic samples for the minority class, which can greatly improve model performance on imbalanced datasets. The DL-based classifier achieved the highest accuracy of 82.67% in this study, while cross-validation prediction-based SVM also showed good performance with nearly 80.33% accuracy for WQP.

title: DDoS Protection Using a Honeynet Implementation with Offensive Capabilities
authors: Sonali Patil, Nikhil Pattewar, Swarnim Bhadale, Ramiz Shaikh, Bhargav Mule
publish: 2025 5th Asian Conference on Innovation in Technology (ASIANCON)
abstract: Distributed Denial of Service (DDoS) attacks represent a persistent and evolving threat to online services, aiming to exhaust resources and disrupt availability. This research paper proposes a novel approach to DDoS protection through the strategic implementation of a honeynet. By deploying a network of decoy systems designed to attract and capture malicious traffic, a honeynet provides a controlled environment for the in-depth analysis of DDoS attack methodologies and attacker behavior. This capability allows for the real-time collection of threat intelligence regarding emerging attack vectors, tools, and techniques. Beyond traditional honeynet functionalities of detection and mitigation through traffic diversion and blacklisting, this paper explores the integration of 'offensive capabilities'. These capabilities leverage the insights gained from analyzing attacks within the honeynet to inform proactive defense strategies, potentially disrupting attacker infrastructure or preemptively neutralizing threats. This research contributes to advancing the field of DDoS defense by presenting an enhanced honeynet-based security framework that moves beyond reactive measures towards a more dynamic and intelligent response to the evolving DDoS threat landscape.

title: Design of FinFET Based Compressors
authors: Nithin Kumar S, Dinesha P, Apeksha U, Chithrashree G S, Naveen Kumar Y
publish: 2025 5th Asian Conference on Innovation in Technology (ASIANCON)
abstract: Compressor architectures are pivotal in arithmetic datapaths, enabling optimized partial product accumulation in multipliers and accelerating multi-operand addition. With conventional CMOS facing scaling constraints at advanced technology nodes, FinFET-based implementations offer enhanced electrostatic control, reduced leakage, and superior energy efficiency. This work presents the schematic design and post-layout simulation of 3:2, 4:2, 5:2, 6:2, and 9:2 compressors utilizing a FinFET process node in Cadence Virtuoso. Each topology is characterized for dynamic power and propagation delay. Benchmarking is performed against equivalent CMOS-based realizations. Furthermore, the proposed compressor topologies are integrated into representative arithmetic blocks such as carry-skip adders, carry-save adders, and multiplier units, among others, to evaluate their impact on overall system performance. The study substantiates the viability of FinFET-centric compressor designs for low-power, high-speed digital signal processing applications.

title: Design of Embedded Vehicle Speed Monitoring and Early Warning System for 51 Single-Chip Microcomputer
authors: Fan Yang, Zhuoyan Du
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Computer Information Technology (AICIT)
abstract: In response to the urgent need for real-time speed monitoring and overspeed warning in the field of bicycle safety in road traffic, this paper designs and implements an embedded speed monitoring and Bluetooth multi-terminal warning system based on 51 microcontroller. The system takes the low-power 51 microcontroller as the core controller, the YH13S Hall sensor for real-time speed collection, and uses the CH9140 Bluetooth module to build a wireless communication link between the on-board terminal and the mobile device, enabling display on the LCD and real-time monitoring of riding speed and overspeed alarm through the mobile phone APP.

title: YOLO-SVC: Small Vehicle Detection in Complex Environments with Star Backbone and Attention
authors: Shubin Yang, Qiqing Chan, Yunchuan Yang
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Computer Information Technology (AICIT)
abstract: To address the problem of poor vehicle detection performance under UAV perspectives—primarily caused by small object sizes and occlusions in complex environments—this paper proposes a small object vehicle detection algorithm for complex scenarios, named YOLO-SVC, based on the YOLOv11n framework. First, the backbone network is replaced with the Star backbone, which leverages implicit high-dimensional space mapping operations to capture finer-grained detail features in the image, thereby enhancing the detection accuracy for small targets. Second, a CAA attention mechanism is introduced into the backbone, which suppresses irrelevant background regions via anchor-aware attention weights, effectively reducing interference from complex backgrounds. Finally, an Auxiliary Detection Head (Aux Head) is incorporated to mitigate semantic drift in intermediate layer features through a multi-level supervision strategy, ultimately improving the robustness of the main detection head in challenging scenes. Experimental results show that, compared to the baseline model, the proposed algorithm achieves improvements of 3.2% in mAP@0.5 and 1.7% in mAP@0.5:0.95 on the VisDrone2019 dataset, significantly enhancing detection accuracy while reducing both false positives and missed detections.

title: Novel Encoding and Crossover Methods for Hybrid Multi-Stage Scheduling Problems with Multi-Assembly Precedence Constraints
authors: Naritsak Tuntitippawan, Teeradej Wuttipornpun, Vichai Rungruenganan, Sukanya Cherdchoongam, Tanyanunch Chatrakamolthas, Watcharapan Sukkerd
publish: 2025 Research, Invention, and Innovation Congress: Innovative Electricals and Electronics (RI2C)
abstract: This study presents novel encoding and crossover methods specifically designed for use with both evolutionary and non-evolutionary algorithms to address hybrid multi-stage scheduling problems with multi-assembly precedence constraints. The proposed encoding employs a unified chromosome structure that represents order, operation, and machine within a single gene, offering a more structured and intuitive representation of precedence. Building on this structure, the crossover first selects genes from the chosen parents and extracts only the order information to form a partial chromosome, which is then completed by incorporating the corresponding operations and machines from the respective parents. A detailed demonstration shows that the proposed methods improve gene arrangement, effectively preserve precedence constraints, and ensure solution feasibility without requiring repair processes commonly needed in existing approaches.

title: Quantum-Enhanced Detection of False Base Stations in Beyond 5G Networks Using Quanvolutional Neural Network
authors: I Wayan Adi Juliawan Pawana, Hoseok Kwon, Linawati, Ilsun You
publish: 2025 International Conference on Smart-Green Technology in Electrical and Information Systems (ICSGTEIS)
abstract: The emergence of Beyond 5G (B5G) and 6G networks introduces advanced capabilities in speed, latency, and connectivity, while also amplifying the risk of sophisticated security threats such as False Base Stations (FBS). These rogue entities imitate legitimate base stations to intercept data, perform man-in-the-middle attacks, or disrupt services. Researchers have explored conventional machine learning methods for FBS detection, but these methods often struggle to address the high-dimensional and dynamic nature of next-generation networks. This paper proposes a Quanvolutional Neural Network (QNN) framework as a quantum-enhanced solution for FBS detection. QNN utilizes quantum phenomena such as superposition and entanglement to perform complex feature transformations, enabling more expressive data representations than classical models. We evaluate the proposed QNN against a traditional Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) using a classification task designed to simulate the detection of FBS. Results demonstrate that although the QNN exhibits slower convergence during early training, it ultimately outperforms the CNN across all key evaluation metrics. The QNN achieves higher accuracy (90.65%), improved recall, lower false positive rate, and a superior F1 score, while also attaining a lower final training loss. These findings suggest that QNNs have strong potential for real-time, localized threat detection in AInative 6G architectures. Future work will explore deployment on Noisy Intermediate-Scale Quantum (NISQ) hardware and evaluate model performance under realistic noise conditions. This study contributes to ongoing research on integrating quantum machine learning into secure and intelligent wireless communication systems

title: A novel PV Power Fusion Prediction with CEEMDAN and Bayesian optimized LSTM
authors: Di Wu, Yi Zong, Wenjing Su
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Computer Information Technology (AICIT)
abstract: In the context of renewable energy systems, accurate prediction of solar energy output is crucial for mitigating the challenges posed by intermittency and volatility inherent in photovoltaic (PV) power generation. This study introduces a novel PV power forecasting model leveraging the Complete Ensemble Empirical Mode Decomposition with Adaptive Noise (CEEMDAN) technique. The model integrates multi-dimensional feature sets—including historical PV power data length, climatic variables, and solar irradiance—to decompose the original time series into multiple intrinsic mode functions (IMFs). Subsequently, Pearson correlation analysis is employed to evaluate the relationships among these components, guiding their grouping and aggregation. The resulting Co-IMFs are individually input into a Bayesian-optimized Long Short-Term Memory (BO_LSTM) network for component-level PV power prediction. The individual prediction outcomes are then re-incorporated as distinct features within the BO_LSTM framework to achieve a fused, comprehensive forecast of PV power output. Experimental evaluations demonstrate that the proposed approach effectively captures detailed prediction dynamics for each IMF component, with the fused predictions exhibiting robust performance and high accuracy over a forecast horizon of up to four days.

title: Deep Reinforcement Learning-based Research on Electric Vehicle Charging and Discharging Scheduling
authors: Xiaoli Liu, Hongwu Qin, Wang Lei
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Mechatronics Technology (ICEEMT)
abstract: With the continuous development of new energy technology, the scale of EV (Electric Vehicle) users is growing. Maximizing the charging and discharging benefits while meeting the charging needs of EV users has become a challenge. In response, this thesis constructs an EV charging and discharging scheduling model and proposes the DDPG (Deep Deterministic Policy Gradient) algorithm based on it. By adjusting the charging and discharging conditions of different vehicles under different electricity pricing conditions, the economic benefits of the charging station are maximized while minimizing the degradation of the energy storage unit lifespan.

title: Optimization Method for Monocular Vision Ranging Based on Parallel Element Rectification
authors: Jingwen Qian, Jin Zhang, Cheng Wu, Kangwei Wang, Jie Sheng
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Intelligent Perception and Computer Vision (CIPCV)
abstract: This paper proposes a monocular vision ranging optimization method aimed at addressing the issue of inaccurate distance measurement due to perspective distortion in long-range imaging. The proposed method, namely Parallel Element Rectification for Monocular Vision Ranging (PER-MVR), enhances ranging accuracy by utilizing the features of parallel elements to rectify distance measurement parameters. The optimized YOLOv5 object detection model is employed for target localization and size estimation. Analyzing the geometric characteristics of parallel elements, which decrease in size with distance due to perspective effects, allows for the extraction of key information to adjust the monocular ranging model’s parameters. Experimental results demonstrate that the PER-MVR method achieves an average ranging error of less than 5% within the 30-200 meter range, whereas typical ranging methods widely used in the transportation field exhibit errors exceeding 15% within 100 meters. The proposed method not only significantly reduces ranging errors but also substantially extends the measuring range, demonstrating considerable practical value.

title: Adder Circuits are Designed using 18 nm FinFET Technology
authors: Suraj Shukla, Vibhor Sharma, Ravi Ranjan Kumar, Sivangi Ravikanth, Manish Kumar Singla, Gaurav Sharma
publish: 2025 5th Asian Conference on Innovation in Technology (ASIANCON)
abstract: Implantable electronic systems demand ultra-low-power circuit techniques, particularly at nanometer-scale technologies. Due to the limitations of conventional CMOS, there is a need for innovative logic designs that leverage emerging device architectures. This work presents the design of one-bit adder circuits using 18 nm FinFET technology, implemented with the Complementary FinFET Technique (CFT) and Complementary Pass Transistor Logic (CPTL). Simulation results reveal that the CFT-based adder achieves a Power Delay Product (PDP) of 6905.130 × 10<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">-15</sup> and an Energy Delay Product (EDP) of 6981.565 × 10<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">-22</sup>. In comparison, the CPTL-based adder outperforms CFT, delivering a PDP of 6460 × 10<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">-15</sup> and an EDP of 6137 × 10<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">-22</sup>. Owing to its superior power and energy efficiency, the FinFET-based CPTL adder proposed in this study is highly suitable for integration into low-power, portable, and implantable biomedical devices.

title: Deep Learning-Based Framework for Automated Detection and Classification of Rice Leaf Diseases
authors: Santosh Varshney, Amit Vajpayee, Poonam Kukana, Bhupinder Kaur
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Advances in Computing Research On Science Engineering and Technology (ACROSET)
abstract: It is impossible to overstate the importance of rice production in providing food for India's enormous population. Rice production is hampered by issues such as bacterial leaf blight, brown spot, and smut. The time-consuming nature of manually checking for diseases necessitates the development of automated methods. In this study, a Deep Learning model has been developed to handle the illness detection and classification of several common rice diseases using machine learning techniques. The three disease classes—Bacterial Leaf Blight, Brown Spot, and Leaf Smut—are represented in the dataset's 119 photos. We conducted exploratory data analysis in an effort to comprehend the distribution and character of the photos. Next, we employed the Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) architecture to create the classification model. We now introduce the suggested model architecture: Fundamental Functional Elements Pooling layers and Convolutional layers. The Layers that are dense Grouping Image’s spatial features are down-sampled by pooling layers after being processed by convolutional layers. In the current study, we employed a variety of techniques, such as picture augmentation, to improve the model's capacity to effectively categorize unknown data. The partitioned training, validation, and test datasets were used to construct and evaluate this model. According to the experiments, the suggested method performs well in classifying rice diseases with an emphasis on minimal loss and high accuracy. Therefore, the work contributes to the development of automated early diagnosis and maturity of rice illnesses, which would help safeguard potential yield and national food security.

title: Binary Classification of Epileptic Seizures from EEG Signals Using Ensemble Machine Learning
authors: Aarna Pareek, Chirag Joshi
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Advances in Computing Research On Science Engineering and Technology (ACROSET)
abstract: The identification of epileptic seizures using electroencephalogram (EEG) signals plays a crucial role in the early diagnosis and treatment of epilepsy. However, manual analysis of EEG recordings is often time-consuming and prone to interpretation errors. This study presents a machine learning ensemble model that combines Random Forest, XGBoost, and Multi-Layer Perceptron classifiers to distinguish between seizure and non-seizure brain activity. Feature selection techniques are employed to extract the most relevant features, while the Synthetic Minority Over-Sampling Technique (SMOTE) is applied to address class imbalance. The proposed model is evaluated on a benchmark dataset and achieves a classification accuracy of 96.43%. Experimental results indicate that the approach is both efficient and practical, making it suitable for real-life clinical applications.

title: QoS-Aware Digital Twin Extension for Fusion-Based Routing in IoMT Networks
authors: Ambuja Kulshreshtha, Uma Meena
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Internet of Things and Intelligence Systems (IoTaIS)
abstract: The Internet of Medical Things (IoMT) relies heavily on energy-constrained wireless sensor networks (WSNs) that have stringent quality-of-service (QoS) criteria for latency, reliability, and jitter. Although clustering, metaheuristics, and reinforcement learning (RL) have enhanced energy-eﬃcient routing, the majority of existing methodologies do not monitor or ensure Quality of Service (QoS) amongst fluctuating traﬃc conditions. This paper illustrates QDFR, a QoS-aware Digital Twin fusion routing framework. QDFR integrates fuzzy clustering, Beluga Whale Optimization (BWO) for energy-eﬃcient cluster-head selection, RL-based routing for adaptive next-hop decisions, a lightweight QoS monitoring layer, and a predictive Digital Twin (DT) that forecasts congestion and node failures for proactive rerouting.In a 250-node, 800-round IoMT testbed with authentic healthcare data, QDFR consistently surpasses LEACH, PSO-CH, RL+Clus, and its ablated variations in terms of residual energy, end-to-end latency, and packet delivery ratio (PDR). IIt achieves mean PDR of 0.9646, delay of 160.63 ms, and reduces SLA violations to only 0.05%, compared with > 90% for baseline comparisons. These gains stem from the synergy of BWO (energy balance), RL (congestion adaptation), and DT (proactive forecasting). Although QDFR implicitly reconciles energy and QoS, further research will investigate explicit mmulti-objective optimization, deep RL variants, and validation across diverse IoMT datasets. The findings further demonstrate QDFR as a reliable and energy-eﬃcient framework for latency-sensitive healthcare communication.

title: Blockchain-Powered Secure Data Sharing in AI-Driven Smart Cities
authors: Kiruthiga. R, Anurag Shrivastava, Ananth Krishna Rambhatla, RaviTeja Aida, Montater MuhsnHasan, Saloni Bansal
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Advances in Computing Research On Science Engineering and Technology (ACROSET)
abstract: With the rapid evolution of artificial intelligence (AI) in smart cities, secure and efficient data-sharing mechanisms to encode privacy, integrity, and accessibility are required. As a natural result of a centralized data-sharing framework, they remain vulnerable to security issues, unauthorized access, and most importantly, single-point-of-failure. Data confidentiality does not concern the layer blockchain technology; it offers better trust and security among stakeholders due to its decentralized and tamper-proof data manager. The outline of how block chain can resolve AI-based smart city data coming from diverse citizen-based sensors is discussed; consensus mechanisms, urgent access, multi-signature encryption is explored. Blockchain improves data transparency, reduces fraud, and ensures compliance with data privacy regulations by leveraging smart contracts and distributed ledger technology. In addition, the study addresses challenges related to the scalability which is a computational overhead issue and regulatory constraints that blockchain can face, and some solutions that could help the adoption of multiple stakeholders in urban infrastructures such as blockchain. The results show how a secure sharing of information via blockchain can drastically improve smart cities powered by AI ensuring their resiliency and efficiency toward sustainable intelligent urban environments.

title: Deep Learning-Based Beamforming and Resource Allocation Techniques: Enhancing Massive MIMO Performance in 5G Networks
authors: S. Varalakshmi, R. Ruth Shobitha, B. Shamreen Ahamed, Nisha M, Khaled Alqawasmi, P. Nishitha
publish: 2025 5th Asian Conference on Innovation in Technology (ASIANCON)
abstract: The development of wireless communication networks has led to the introduction of 5G communication technology that aims to achieve ultra-reliable low-latency communication (URLLC), enhanced mobile broadband (eMBB), and massive machine-type communications (mMTC). The key to realizing these objectives is Massive MIMO, the use of very large antenna arrays to achieve dramatic spectral efficiency and throughput gains. On the other hand, beamforming and resource allocation for massive MIMO systems is intrinsically difficult due to the high-dimensional signal processing and time-varying wireless environments. Classical optimization methodologies often lack in coping with dynamic situations in real-time and they do not scale well when the system dimension increases. Against these challenges, in this work, we study how to tap the potential of deep learning-based frameworks for the design improvement of the beamforming and resource allocation in massive MIMO systems. To address this problem, in this paper, we propose a deep learning-based framework of joint beamforming and dynamic resource allocation to learn the optimal solution from data-driven patterns other than pure mathematical models. Using CNNs and DRL algorithms help to forecast the optimal beamforming vectors and resources allocation efficiently in dynamic user densities, channel states and quality-of-service constraints. Through training with large realistic datasets based on 5G scenarios, the model is able to react to wireless changes, reduce interference, and improve spectral efficiency. The proposed network is deployed at physical and medium access control (MAC) layers of the architecture, achieving nearly real-time decisions with low computational complexity in inference. Simulation results show that the deep learning model has substantial performance gains compared to traditional optimization approaches, such as throughput, latency, energy efficiency and fairness. Furthermore, it shows strong generalization to different network topologies and user mobility patterns, which offers robust and scalable operation in large-scale 5G deployments. The research shows the promise of using AI for wireless and for intelligent self-optimizing networks. Learning-based approaches integrated in the 5G network core can ensure optimal network operation and improve QoS and QoE, fulfilling them providing a way to meet the requirements of various users. The results clear the way for deep learning to be embedded in 6G networks, where smart resource management will be of greater importance. This paper paves the way for a new breed of AI-powered wireless systems, in which deep learning is less an add-on enhancement but more of a core of communication design.

title: A Comparative Study of Feature Engineering and Machine Learning Pipelines for Detecting Phishing URLs with High Accuracy in Cybersecurity
authors: Chaitanya Appani
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Advances in Computing Research On Science Engineering and Technology (ACROSET)
abstract: One of the most prevalent ways that malware and ransomware are distributed, as well as how phishing attacks are launched, spam is sent, and websites are defaced, is via malicious URLs. A malicious URL may be included on a genuine website, sent over email, or shown in an advertising. Attackers target unsuspecting people who click on malicious URLs. Malicious URL detection is a crucial component of cybersecurity as it may stop certain attacks by identifying them and warning the user. This study suggests a new way to find phishing URLs by using a Bidirectional Long Short-Term Memory (Bi-Lstm) model. This model works well with sequential data to find complex patterns in URLs. The Bi-Lstm has demonstrated an almost flawless performance in testing, obtaining a 99.99% F1score, 99.96% precision, 99.94% recall, and 99.99% accuracy. The Bi-Lstm model performs better than Random Forest (94.42%), Convolutional Neural Networks (96.56%) and Gradient Recurrent Units (92.95%), when all evaluation measures are considered. Detecting malicious websites with the proposed method improves cybersecurity by giving reliable protection against phishing and various web attacks.

title: Facial Recognition-Enhanced User Profiling for Personalized Recommendation Systems
authors: Mubeen Ahmed Khan, Tanvir Habib Sardar, Devi Priya V S, P Naresh, Nivetha R, Shreyas Rajendra Hole
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Advances in Computing Research On Science Engineering and Technology (ACROSET)
abstract: A recommendation system with integrated user profiling is presented, leveraging facial recognition for seamless user identification. Existing profiles are accessed for personalized recommendations based on past preferences. New user profiles are created, and recommendations are tailored based on initial choices, adapting as interaction data accumulates. This approach bridges the gap between traditional recommendation systems and user identification, offering a personalized experience for diverse users. This version emphasizes the real-time aspect, which is often a key feature in such systems, and utilizes "engines" to convey a more technical, system-focused feel and Innovative. It also highlights "leveraging" to suggest an active application of technology for innovations. From the analysis, it is observed that MMOD GPU performs 453% better than Haar, 559% better than that DNN, 292% better than HoG and 6788% % better than MMOD(GPU).

title: Real-Time Airbag Deployment System Using FreeRTOS with Runtime Metrics
authors: B. Yashaswini, Surekha Paneerselvam
publish: 2025 5th Asian Conference on Innovation in Technology (ASIANCON)
abstract: Two-wheeler crashes account for a disproportionate share of road fatalities because motorcycles lack the passive safety features common in cars. This paper presents a real-time airbag deployment system that runs on an ESP32 dual-core microcontroller under FreeRTOS. A two-stage verification combines an MPU6050 inertial sensor with an infrared proximity sensor to suppress false triggers, while an interrupt-driven panic button provides manual override. Tasks are organised with priority-based scheduling, binary semaphores, and a mutex-protected alert device to guarantee deterministic behaviour under concurrent loads. We instrument FreeRTOS and report four key runtime metrics: task execution time, context-switch latency, end-to-end event latency, and jitter. In the worst case, context switches complete in 160 μs and end-to-end latency does not exceed 18 μs, validating the platform for time-critical actuation. A prototype guardian attached to a test bike deployed the airbag within 7 ms of a simulated collision without spurious firings. These results demonstrate that low-cost microcontrollers, when paired with a carefully profiled RTOS, can deliver automotive-grade safety features for resource-constrained two-wheelers.

title: Design and Analysis of Triangular Patch UWB Antenna with Band Notch
authors: Muhammad Azmi, Kartika Praty Dena Zaam, Harfan Hian Ryanu, Muhammad Rendra Perdana, Aminah Indahsari Marsuki
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electronic and Electrical Engineering and Intelligent System (ICE3IS)
abstract: Ultra-Wideband (UWB) antenna is a radio technology that is widely used in modern communication systems. The simultaneous use of various services in the UWB frequency range can cause interference. This research proposes a modification of UWB antenna with notch band technique by adding slots to the antenna patch to overcome interference at WLAN frequency (5.15-5.85 GHz). Simulation results show that the addition of slots successfully produces dual band characteristics with return losses at low frequencies of 3.1 GHz and 4.7 GHz of -12.21 dB and -10.63 dB, respectively, and at high frequencies of 5.6 GHz and 7.4 GHz of -10.36 dB and 10.39 dB, respectively. The VSWR values obtained at low frequencies of 3.1 GHz and 4.7 GHz are 1.58 and 1.77, respectively, while at high frequencies of 5.6 GHz and 7.4 GHz they reach 1.83 and 1.74, respectively. These results show that the proposed modification successfully maintains the performance of the UWB antenna while minimizing interference from WLAN systems.

title: LoRaWAN-Based Smart Meter for Enhancing Energy Audits: Technical Recommendation
authors: Erika Lety Istikhomah Puspita Sari, Muhammad Ary Murti, Suryo Adhi Wibowo, I Ketut Agung Enriko, Widyasmoro
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electronic and Electrical Engineering and Intelligent System (ICE3IS)
abstract: This paper provides technical recommendations for implementing a LoRaWAN-based smart meter system aimed at enhancing energy audits in buildings. Focusing on the OPMC Telkom Witel Building in South Jakarta, the study underscores the importance of accurately monitoring electricity usage through various distribution panels, specifically Sub Distribution Panels (SDPs). The proposed system integrates Internet of Things (IoT) technology to facilitate real-time energy management, featuring Automated Meter Reading (AMR) devices that capture energy consumption data, alongside LoRa Smart Meters equipped with Current Transformers (CT) for precise monitoring of critical devices such as Air Handling Units, elevators, and chillers. The data collected by these smart meters is transmitted to an IoT Gateway via a LoRaWAN network, ensuring efficient data relay to cloud servers. Once processed by the LoRa Network Server, the information is analyzed through the Telkom IoT Platform, providing building managers with a user-friendly dashboard that visualizes real-time energy usage and historical trends. This innovative architecture not only promotes efficient energy distribution with minimal infrastructure but also enhances decision-making capabilities regarding energy consumption. Additionally, the user application offers comprehensive functionalities, presenting essential electrical parameters and various data types for effective energy auditing. By employing this LoRaWAN-based smart meter system, building managers can optimize energy usage, reduce waste, and ultimately drive sustainability and cost efficiency in energy management practices.

title: PPoS-EHR: Attribute-based Access to Encrypted Health Records via Blockchain
authors: Leela V, Kanishka K, Kaviyasri S, Guru Dharshan K, Harnish R, Murugalakshmi V
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Innovative Data Communication Technologies and Application (ICIDCA)
abstract: Protecting privacy, availability, and security of Electronic Health Records (EHRs) is of utmost importance in the modern digital health industry. Traditional centralized storage system has been under increasing security threats like illegal access, data tampering, cyber-attack and single point of failure. To address these problems, we present in this work a new blockchain-based system which combines Token-Based Authentication and Permissioned Pure Proof-of-Stake (PPoS) consensus model. The architecture authenticates the identity of participants using Decentralized Identifiers (DIDs) and generates cryptographic tokens providing limited access to EHRs that expire over time. These tokens, together with encrypted metadata and access logs are written on a permissioned block chain to provide transparency, traceability and finegrained access control. For data privacy concern, the real health record is off-chained saved with encryption by the ChaCha20-Poly1305 algorithm. The PPoS enforced on Algorand blockchain, provides an efficient, green consensus for the authorized healthcare nodes. It is compliant with HIPAA and GDPR, has excellent audit features and provides a highly available, emergency override access.

title: Reducing The Search Space For Efficient Wrapper Feature Selection
authors: B Venkatesh, S Annapoorna, Alapati Nithika, Valike Sreenithya, Mopuri Kumudvini, Balmoori Shriya
publish: 2025 5th Asian Conference on Innovation in Technology (ASIANCON)
abstract: The explosive growth of high-dimensional data in several fields, such as healthcare, finance, and cybersecurity, offer serious issues for feature selection. Irrelevant and redundant features can degrade machine learning model performance by adding complexity to computation and decreasing classification accuracy. Wrapper-based feature selectors,though extremely efficient, typically feature excessive computational complexity because their search processes are exhaustive.This study offers a more improved feature selection model that blends nature-based metaheuristic optimization techniques, such as Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO), with wrapper-methodological approaches. The goal is to reduce the search space, thus improving processing speed as well as maintain high model accuracy and precision. Employing PSO’s superior searching capabilities within it, the model optimally selects the most informative features efficiently, thereby reducing the dimensionality of big datasets without compromising predictive efficiency.The proposed methodology is tried on different datasets, like genetic and biomedical data sets, and demonstrated to be capable of reducing computational load and the findings show that the architecture’s structure enables scalability, resilience and also performs better than the traditional feature selection techniques. The applicability of this method allows numerous predictive tasks facilitating effective and precise model development throughout industries.

title: MSLinear: A Multi-Scale Linear Model for Efficient Time Series Forecasting
authors: Tiandong Li, Chen Wang, Guanghong Yang, Zepeng Wen
publish: 2025 10th International Seminar on Computer Technology, Mechanical and Electrical Engineering (ISCME)
abstract: Contemporary methods for time series forecasting frequently face two major constraints: they typically model temporal data from a singular perspective, failing to encapsulate the variety of temporal resolutions present, and their considerable model complexity and high computational requirements make them ill suited for environments with limited resources, such as embedded platforms or rapid stock trading. To overcome these issues, we introduce MSLinear, a linear framework operating across multiple scales, designed for efficient temporal prediction. Our method constructs multiscale temporal representations by computing moving averages over diverse window lengths on the input data. These representations are then independently handled by dedicated, streamlined linear layers to yield predictions specific to each scale, which are subsequently combined to form the ultimate forecast. Through comprehensive experimental evaluations across eight real-world datasets, MSLinear delivers performance that is competitive with, and occasionally surpasses, current leading benchmarks, while simultaneously maintaining the minimal computational footprint, thereby proving exceptionally well suited for applications where performance is critical.
