title: A Switchable Frequency Selective Rasorber with Wide Passband Based on Crossed Helical Structure
authors: Xinkun Liu, Xinchang Su, Weiwei Men
publish: 2025 18th IEEE United Conference on Millimeter Waves and Terahertz Technologies (UCMMT)
abstract: In this work, a switchable broadband frequency selective rasorber (FSR) is proposed, in which the broadband transmission performance is attributed to the spiral structure in the lossy layer. The spiral design increases the equivalent inductance, thereby enhancing the transmission bandwidth. A PIN diode is embedded in the lossless layer, enabling the switching between transmission and reflection modes within the passband by controlling its state. When the PIN diode is in the OFF state, the -3 dB transmission bandwidth of the FSR extends from 3.4 GHz to 6.0 GHz, corresponding to a relative bandwidth of 55%. The absorption bands on either side cover <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{2. 2 - 3. 0 G H z}$</tex> and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{6. 4 - 9. 5 G H z}$</tex>, with absorption rates exceeding 80%. When the PIN diode is turned ON, electromagnetic waves within the transmission band are reflected, further enhancing absorption in the adjacent bands. This design is advantageous for reducing the radar cross section (RCS) in dual-site radar antenna systems and improving stealth performance.

title: Rainfall Rate Estimation Using Terahertz Channel Performance and Deep Neural Networks
authors: Wanzhu Chang, Yuheng Song, Wenbo Liu, Mingxia Zhang, Jiabiao Zhao, Peian Li, Jianjun Ma, Houjun Sun
publish: 2025 18th IEEE United Conference on Millimeter Waves and Terahertz Technologies (UCMMT)
abstract: This work investigates rainfall intensity estimation using terahertz (THz) channel performance and deep neural networks. A THz time-domain spectroscopy system captured channel measurement data under controlled rain at multiple frequencies. Four architectures-CNN, RNN, LSTM, and BiGRU—were trained and evaluated. Results show that model performance varies with frequency, CNN performs well across most bands, while BiGRU excels at the mid-high frequency of 220 GHz.

title: Design and Performance Simulation of High-Q High-Sensitivity Terahertz Metasurface Sensors
authors: Weilin Shi, LingYu Liu, Liqi Cui, Jiangkun Tian, Guozhong Zhao
publish: 2025 18th IEEE United Conference on Millimeter Waves and Terahertz Technologies (UCMMT)
abstract: This paper presents the design of a terahertz metasurface sensor based on a symmetrically arranged <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\Omega$</tex>-shaped metallic structure. The sensor consists of a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$50 \mu \mathrm{m}$</tex> cyclo-olefin copolymer (COC) substrate coated with a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$0.2 \mu \mathrm{m}$</tex> gold layer patterned into the proposed structure. Numerical simulations were performed using CST Studio Suite, revealing a sharp transmission peak flanked by two distinct transmission dips in the spectral response. Analysis of the electric field distribution and surface currents indicates that the two transmission dips arise from electric dipole resonances in the upper and lower structures, while the central peak corresponds to an electric quadrupole resonance mode. Further simulations compared the performance of metasurfaces with identical structural parameters but different substrates-COC, quartz, and silicon. The results demonstrate that the COC-based metasurface exhibits a higher quality factor (Q-factor) and greater contrast compared to conventional quartz and silicon substrates, attributable to the ultra-low dielectric loss of COC, which is critical for enhancing sensing performance. By optimising geometric parameters such as the radius and gap spacing of the <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\Omega$</tex>-shaped structures, the sensor achieves a resonant frequency of 1.6969 THz with a Qfactor of 132. Additionally, the transmission spectra were simulated for analytes with varying refractive indices <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(50 \mu \mathrm{m}$</tex> thickness), yielding a refractive index sensitivity of 442.7 <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{GHz} / \text{RIU}$</tex> through linear fitting. This work provides a novel approach to realising high-performance terahertz sensors using symmetric resonator designs.

title: Conductor Losses in Metallic Monopole Antennas: A MoM-Based Analysis from 1 kHz to 200 GHz
authors: H. L. Zhou, J. F. Li
publish: 2025 18th IEEE United Conference on Millimeter Waves and Terahertz Technologies (UCMMT)
abstract: In metallic-only antennas (i.e., those free of dielectric materials), the conductor properties and geometric designparticularly the cross-sectional and axial configurationscritically influence the antenna's radiation efficiency and realized gain in practical applications. These factors are fundamentally tied to the frequency-dependent skin effect, which governs current distribution and conductive losses. In this work, we numerically investigate these effects using MATLAB-based method-of-moments (MoM) simulations, analyzing vertical quarter-wavelength monopole antennas with finite conductivity (copper) and non-zero cross-sectional dimensions (square-rod geometry), as opposed to idealized perfect electric conductor (PEC) approximations. Our study critically evaluates various monopole designs across a broad frequency range (1 kHz to 200 GHz), assessing their performance in terms of metallic losses.

title: Novel NbN-Based Beam-Splitting Metamaterial
authors: Yan Teng, Ling Jiang
publish: 2025 18th IEEE United Conference on Millimeter Waves and Terahertz Technologies (UCMMT)
abstract: This paper introduces superconducting materials into traditional metamaterials for far-field beam manipulation. First, a beam-splitting metamaterial capable of operating across multiple temperature zones was investigated, maintaining comparable performance under both 4.2 K and 14 K conditions. Second, a composite gold-superconducting beam-splitting metamaterial with tunable properties was studied, enabling the number of far-field split beams to switch with temperature variations.

title: Forest Height Estimation with Sentinel-1 Dual-Polarization and Interferometric Features Using Random Forest
authors: Fangyi Li, Chuhan Zhang, Yiheng Jiang, Yumei Long, Wenmei Li
publish: 2025 18th IEEE United Conference on Millimeter Waves and Terahertz Technologies (UCMMT)
abstract: Forest height is a key structural parameter closely linked to aboveground biomass and ecosystem dynamics. This study evaluates the contribution of Sentinel-1 SAR-derived features, particularly dual polarization and interferometric SAR (InSAR) parameters, in forest height estimation, using Global Ecosystem Dynamics Investigation (GEDI) Light Detection and Ranging (LiDAR) observations as reference. Dual-polarization backscattering coefficients and InSAR coherence and phase features, with or without canopy height models (CHM) derived from GEDI, were used as inputs to a Random Forest regression model. Results show that InSAR features significantly enhance prediction accuracy. The combination of InSAR and CHM achieved a validation <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{R}^{\mathbf{2}}$</tex> of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{0. 6 1 1}(\mathbf{R M S E}=\mathbf{3. 1 1 8 ~ m})$</tex>, significantly outperforming the PolSAR + CHM combination, and highlighting the greater predictive power of interferometric features. The full feature set (InSAR + PolSAR + CHM) further improved the performance, yielding the highest accuracy with a validation <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{R}^{\mathbf{2}}$</tex> of 0.644 and RMSE of 2.884 m. These findings highlight the critical role of InSAR data in improving forest height inversion and underscore its value for integration into large-scale forest monitoring workflows, particularly in the context of advancing remote sensing methodologies for ecological assessment and Earth observation.

title: Liquid Metal-Enabled Reconfigurable Metasurface Using Waveguide Excitation
authors: Rasoul Fakhteh, Yi Wang
publish: 2025 18th IEEE United Conference on Millimeter Waves and Terahertz Technologies (UCMMT)
abstract: This work presents a liquid metal-enabled reconfigurable metasurface based on a substrate-integrated waveguide (SIW). This metasurface antenna consists of 16 complementary electric-LC (CELC) unit cells placed on top of the waveguide. Each unit cell integrates a liquid metal (LM) switch, enabling dynamic control of its electromagnetic response. The switching mechanism is actuated through vertical channels that extend from the ground plane to the surface of the SIW, allowing precise manipulation of LM injection and removal within the LM switch. By adjusting the state of the LM switches, the phase distribution across the metasurface can be actively tuned, enabling reconfigurable radiation patterns. This approach minimizes the negative effects of conventional tuning components, such as diodes, varactors, and mechanical actuation mechanisms, on metasurface performance. Simulation results demonstrate the metasurface ability to produce beams at <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1 2}^{\boldsymbol{\circ}}, \mathbf{- 3 0}^{\boldsymbol{\circ}}$</tex>, and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{6 6}^{\boldsymbol{\circ}}$</tex> at 11.6 GHz.

title: Detection of Hand Bone Fractures in X-Ray Images Using Two-Stage Deep Learning Methodology
authors: Vidya, Sriraksha, Shlaghana, Shreya Rajendra Gaonkar, Ayeshatul Hafeeza
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Innovative Data Communication Technologies and Application (ICIDCA)
abstract: Bone fracture is among the most common of all medical conditions, and it needs to be detected early to allow for complete cure and healing. Radiologists’ manual X-ray image interpretation is most often time-consuming, subjective, and error-prone, especially in high-volume emergency situations. Bone anatomical variations, superimposition of structures, and poor image quality make detection even more difficult. In this paper, we propose a two-stage deep learning-based approach for automatic detection of fractures and hand bone fracture classification from X-ray images. YOLOv5 and Faster R-CNN models are utilized in the first stage to identify the areas of fracture from the X-ray. ResNet50 and DenseNet121 models are utilized in the second stage to classify the fractures into transverse, oblique, or comminuted. Contrast Limited Adaptive Histogram Equalization (CLAHE) and normalization are utilized as preprocessing methods to enhance model performance and image quality. Experimental results show that the two-stage approach yields more reliable outcomes than conventional single-stage CNNs, with classification accuracy in Faster R-CNN + DenseNet121. The system shows promise for real-time clinical use, offloading the workload of radiologists and facilitating rapid, reliable medical decision-making. Future work will include larger data sets, 3D imaging, and deployment of mobile healthcare applications.

title: Development of Cloud-Based Structured Query Language Injection (SQLi) Detection using Deep Learning and FastAPI
authors: Carlo Jude P. Abuda, Ariel Roy L. Reyes
publish: 2025 Eight International Conference on Vocational Education and Electrical Engineering (ICVEE)
abstract: Structured Query Language Injection (SQLi) attacks continue to pose a serious threat to web applications, especially those hosted in cloud-based environments. Traditional detection methods, such as signature-based and rule-based systems, often fail to detect obfuscated or evolving injection patterns. Despite the increasing use of deep learning techniques for SQLi detection, which are particularly effective in recognizing complex, obfuscated, and evolving SQL injection patterns. However, most studies remain limited to offline experiments without real-time system deployment. This research addresses that gap by developing and operationalizing a deep learning-based SQLi detection model integrated with FastAPI. The study aimed to design a classification model capable of distinguishing malicious from safe SQL queries using numerically encoded inputs. Following the Evolutionary Prototyping Model, the system was developed through data preprocessing, model training using TensorFlow-Keras, and deployment as an API. A total of 30,919 SQL queries were used, and the model achieved 97% training accuracy and 94.5% validation accuracy, supported by strong precision, recall, and F1-scores above 93%. Findings confirm the model’s high reliability and real-time responsiveness, with an average detection response under 50 milliseconds. The research demonstrates that integrating deep learning with lightweight API frameworks can result in a scalable and accurate solution suitable for web security systems. These results suggest practical implications for deploying intelligent cybersecurity tools in real-world cloud applications.

title: Analyzing Investor Behavior Shifts Under AI Influence: A Deep Learning Perspective
authors: S. Pravin, S Jegadeesan, R. Santhana Krishnan, M. Saravana Karthikeyan, J. Relin Francis Raj, M. Arun Kumar
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Innovative Data Communication Technologies and Application (ICIDCA)
abstract: This study investigates the behavioral impacts of artificial intelligence (AI) on the investment decision-making patterns of Indian investors, with a focus on AI-driven tools such as stock market chatbots, robo-advisors, and sentiment-based trading bots. The research framework employs multiple deep learning architectures to capture and analyze different dimensions of investor behavior. Deep Neural Networks (DNN) are utilized for classification to determine whether exposure to AI influences portfolio allocation towards higher-risk assets. Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) networks are applied to model time-dependent changes in risky asset allocation, while Deep Factorization Machines (DeepFM) are used to rank investors by their likelihood of following AI-generated recommendations without verification. Additionally, transformer-based models like BERT process investor communications from platforms such as WhatsApp, Telegram, and online forums to extract sentiment features. Data preprocessing includes Min-Max normalization, median-based imputation, sliding-window segmentation for time-series analysis, and sentiment integration. Decision thresholds—0.75 for DNN classification, +5% allocation change for LSTM regression, and top 30% ranking cutoff for DeepFM—are implemented to balance predictive accuracy with responsible financial guidance. A T-learner framework is incorporated for causal inference, isolating the behavioral effect attributable specifically to AI exposure. The evaluation employs precision, recall, ROC-AUC, RMSE, MAE, NDCG, and SHAP-based explainability measures. The system is deployed on cloud infrastructure with real-time monitoring to ensure stability, interpretability, and regulatory compliance. Findings aim to inform policy, enhance investor education, and ensure ethical AI integration in India’s financial sector while safeguarding against potential risks of overreliance on AI-generated investment advice.

title: Synergistic Hybrid Segmentation for Handwritten Kannada Word Recognition Addressing Deep Learning Challenges
authors: Malini. M, Hemanth K S
publish: 2025 5th Asian Conference on Innovation in Technology (ASIANCON)
abstract: The handwritten Kannada script has an intricate aksharas that are formed by combining consonants, vowels, and ottus. These complex combinations pose significant hurdles for automated text segmentation. The inherent diversity in handwriting styles, coupled with prevalent character overlap, multi-touch connections, varied curve structures such as upper open curve(OC), upper closed curve (CC), and the highly condensed nature of Ottaksharas, routinely blurs character boundaries, leading to severe segmentation errors that propagate and compromise overall recognition accuracy. A hybrid approach that customizes adaptive traditional methods like vertical pixel count, to identify true character gaps in handwritten Kannada characters could effectively manage character overlap, or segment multi-touch characters or Ottaksharas. This pre-processing stage can allow subsequent deep learning models to recognize this segmented character. This will avoid significant hurdles: immense data requirements for pixel-level annotations, high computational costs for dense prediction, and significant architectural complexities for precise boundary delineation and handling connectivity. Given these constraints, particularly with less-resource language like Kannada, scaling deep learning models will lead to ever erroneous recognition. This paper argues that modified traditional approaches, by directly embedding customized knowledge and leveraging targeted feature engineering, can offer a computationally efficient and data-lean alternative. This strategy enables more robust segmentation for complex Kannada characters, providing a practical pathway for automated handwritten text processing in such linguistic domains.

title: Medicinal Plant Recognition and Information System Using MobileNetV2: A Comprehensive Mobile Solution
authors: Sharika T R, Akshaya Jayaraj, Raghi R Menon, Parvathy Nair, Chinnu Mariya Varghese, Anila S
publish: 2025 5th Asian Conference on Innovation in Technology (ASIANCON)
abstract: With the growing popularity of natural health remedies, there is growing demand for accessible and accurate means of medicinal plant identification. In this work, we are proposing SMARTMEDGROW which is a system for precise plant identification and management of medicinal plants based on deep learning algorithms. Our system permits identification of plants through the capture or upload of leaf images, using deep learning models for identification. The InceptionV3, MobileNetV2, and ResNet50 three convolutional neural network models were compared regarding the precision of plant identification. Among these, MobileNetV2 had the maximum precision of 89%, hence the best model due to the balance between performance and computational complexity. This system also provides comprehensive medicinal plant information, including identification, biological nomenclature, medicinal uses, benefits, potential side effects, safety precautions, and allergic reactions, all supported by multilingual capabilities, plant growth monitoring based on soil type, and an AI-powered database of natural home remedies for skin, hair, and general wellness, fostering natural health practices and community learning for researchers, practitioners, and the public.

title: TinyML-Based Object Detection on Smart Blind Stick for Visually Impaired Person
authors: Parama Diptya Widayaka, Pradini Puspitaningayu, Sayyidul Aulia Alamsyah, Endryansyah Endryansyah, Lusia Rakhmawati, Paramitha Nerisafitra, Rifqi Abdillah, Akbar Wildhanata, Haikal Alif Eyrlangga
publish: 2025 Eight International Conference on Vocational Education and Electrical Engineering (ICVEE)
abstract: In our daily life, we often find people with certain disabilities or certain physical limitations, such as visually impaired people. People with visual impairment often require assistance from others to perform daily activities. We have seen people with visual impairment using walking sticks to help them walk on the street or pedestrian. With the development of technologies, many studies have been conducted to create disability aids or assistive technology for people with disabilities, especially smart blind sticks with function to detect objects in front of people with limited vision, where the smart blind stick is equipped with a sensor to detect the presence of an obstacle in front of them. However, these aids are still limited to detect the presence of an object by identifying the type of the object. In this study, a smart blind stick system was created by implementing artificial intelligence to detect objects in front of people with visual impairment, where this system applies Tiny-ML that can be implemented on edge devices such as microcontrollers. In the results of this study, the system works well to recognize objects such as cars, motorcycles, road separators, and tactile guides in front of people with visual impairment by an F1 score of 78.1 percent. This object detection also gives a good result from hardware implementation with inferencing time 1368ms, 119.4K peak ram usage, and 90.2K flash usage.

title: Federated Feature Stores: Real-Time Learning Without Centralized Data Movement
authors: Satya Manesh Veerapaneni, Prateek Sharma, Siva Sankar Das, Jayakanth Tivari, Uttam Kumar
publish: 2025 5th Asian Conference on Innovation in Technology (ASIANCON)
abstract: The fact that data generated in distributed sources grows exponentially poses great hurdles on the centralized machine learning workflow, especially regarding data privacy, latency and bandwidth overhead. Federated Feature Stores (FFS)Constitute a new paradigm that perpetrates real-time learning in which data is not aggregated. In this paper, one such architecture is provided in which feature engineering, storage and access, are decentralized and co-located with data sources taking advantage of the principles of federated learning. To satisfy the need to maintain data locality but guarantee consistency, low latency inference and privacy regulations, FFS uses a combination of on-device feature computation combined with updating global models. We are working on federated feature synchronization, version control and optimal caching for heterogeneous environments. The experimental analysis over edge clusters and cloud back ends reveals significant bumps in the end-to-end training throughput, inference latency, and privacy preservation over conventional centralized feature pipelines. The given FFS framework provides a scalable, privacy-sensitive, and efficient replacement of older data engineering pipes in the fields of healthcare, finance and the Internet of Things.

title: A Terahertz Metamaterial Biosensor for Label-Free Detection of Pain-Related Compounds
authors: Lulu Han, Kanglong Chen, Cunjun Ruan, Qinggang Ge, Jun Yang
publish: 2025 18th IEEE United Conference on Millimeter Waves and Terahertz Technologies (UCMMT)
abstract: In this study, a terahertz metamaterial biosensor was proposed for the label-free detection of pain-related compounds. The sensor was employed to identify two representative pain-related compounds, Protopine and ML190, which induced distinct and measurable resonance frequency shifts upon interaction with the sensing surface. The measured frequency shifts were approximately 14 GHz and 24 GHz, respectively, demonstrating the sensor's high sensitivity and its capability for analyte differentiation. This low-cost, real-time biosensing platform enables rapid and sensitive detection of painrelated compounds, with broad potential in biomedical and pharmaceutical fields.

title: On-Chip Wideband Bandpass Filter Using Capacitor Coupled Resonator
authors: Yu Zhang, Xin Guo, Wen Wu
publish: 2025 18th IEEE United Conference on Millimeter Waves and Terahertz Technologies (UCMMT)
abstract: In this paper, an on-chip bandpass filter based on 180 nm CMOS technology is proposed. A filter circuit model implemented using the capacitor coupled LC resonator is proposed. Then, the circuit model is transformed into the physical layout to further verify the feasibility of this design method. In the procedure, the design of on-chip inductors and capacitors is investigated. A third-order bandpass filter at 20 GHz is designed and simulated. Full-wave simulation results show that this bandpass filter can achieve fractional bandwidth (FBW) of 40% with minimum insertion loss (IL) of about <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1. 6 d B}$</tex>, with single and compact structure.

title: Handheld Device for Rapid on-Site Detection of Escherichia Coli O157: H7
authors: Junting Zhou, Weibin Zhou, Xinwu Xie, Manman Du, Tianteng Hao, Zhi Cheng, Jisheng Li
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Biomedical Signal and Image Processing (ICBIP)
abstract: Traditional detection instruments for Escherichia coli O157: H7 in water samples have disadvantages such as elaborate sample processing, long detection time and large instrument volume, which cannot meet the requirements of timely on-site detection in outdoor environments. In this work, we constructed a portable electrochemical detector based on a paper-based electrochemical sensor modified by electrospun cellulose acetate nanofibers (CA NF) and a detection circuit for analyzing bacteria in environmental water samples. The developed detector can perform different detection functions such as potentiostatic method and cyclic voltammetry, and can display the detection results in real time through its LCD screen, a mobile phone, or a personal computer. The feasibility of the detector was verified by potassium ferrocyanide and potassium ferrocyanide mixed solutions using potentiostatic method, with a high accuracy (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{R}^{\mathbf{2}}=\mathbf{0. 9 9 7 6}$</tex>) prediction curve, which is comparable to a commercial electrochemical workstation. The cyclic voltammetry function of the detector shows similar performance to the commercial workstation, too. In addition, the content of Escherichia coli O157: H7 in real environmental water samples was detected in 5 min in total and the results consistent with the culture method. This portable electrochemical detector has high integration, small size, and can quickly and on-site detect Escherichia coli O157:H7 in water samples, making it a promising tool for environmental monitoring and public health protection.

title: Customizing VGGNet Layers for Balinese Script Lontar Character Recognition
authors: Ida Ayu Putu Febri Imawati, Made Sudarma, I Ketut Gede Darma Putra, I Putu Agung Bayupati, Minho Jo
publish: 2025 International Conference on Smart-Green Technology in Electrical and Information Systems (ICSGTEIS)
abstract: This research trains variants of the VGGNet model for recognizing the AMADI Lontar Set script. The training process compares VGG16A, a deep network with 22 layers, and VGG16B, a shallow network with 16 layers. The aim is to identify the optimal configuration of the VGGNet model architecture, training setup, and dataset arrangement for Balinese script recognition. The novelty lies in systematically testing deep versus shallow VGGNet variants on the AMADI LontarSet dataset, with a focus on isolated character recognition. The research follows five stages: preparing the AMADI Lontar Set dataset, preprocessing, defining VGG16A and VGG16B architectures, training each model, and evaluating the results by plotting accuracy and loss. Due to architectural, training, and input resolution differences, VGG16B achieved its final epoch at 6, with training accuracy of 91.01%, testing accuracy of 85.3%, validation accuracy of 83.93%, and a final loss of 0.02. The shallower VGGNet variant outperformed the deeper model, especially for isolated character recognition.

title: Deadbeat Predictive Direct Power Control for Vienna Rectifier Without Grid Voltage Sensors
authors: Yuntao Pan, Jingyu Yan, Zhen Wang
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Computer Information Technology (AICIT)
abstract: Grid voltage information is critical for three-phase Vienna rectifiers, significantly impacting system stability. To overcome the shortcomings of conventional control approaches, including weak anti-interference ability and delayed dynamic response, this paper presents a deadbeat predictive direct power control (DBP-DPC) scheme that operates without grid voltage sensors. Firstly, the mathematical modeling of the three-phase Vienna rectifier is developed in the α-β coordinate system. By analyzing the grid voltage calculation expressions, an enhanced second-order generalized integrator (SOGI) technique is utilized to achieve fast and accurate estimation of the grid voltage. Using the instantaneous power theory, the voltage equations at the frontend of the switching network are derived, discretized, and incorporated into the predictive control framework. Finally, switching signals are produced through space vector pulse width modulation (SVPWM). Simulation results demonstrate that the proposed control strategy, which replaces physical voltage sensors with computational estimation, achieves smaller DC-link voltage overshoot during startup and faster voltage regulation under sudden load changes compared to traditional PI controllers. During startup, the overshoot of the DC bus is reduced by 8.76%, and the time required to reach the set voltage is decreased by 28.18%. This validates the effectiveness and robustness of the sensorless DBP-DPC approach for Vienna rectifiers.

title: Construction of a Global Automotive Industry Data Fusion Platform based on Reinforcement Learning
authors: Qian Ding, Zhehui Guo, Fan Zhang
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Computer Information Technology (AICIT)
abstract: With the rapid development of the global automotive industry, the data of the automotive industry has formed a multi-source heterogeneous data collection including supply chain data, vehicle operation data, etc. Traditional data fusion methods are difficult to meet the demand for efficient collaboration at this moment. Reinforcement learning, a machine learning paradigm that learns optimal strategies through interaction with the environment, offers new ideas for the dynamic optimization of global automotive industry data fusion platforms. This paper presents a global automotive industry data fusion platform architecture based on reinforcement learning, builds a five-layer platform architecture including data acquisition layer, data preprocessing layer, data fusion layer, reinforcement learning layer and model application layer, and presents a mathematical model based on Markov decision process; Finally, the effectiveness of the platform in decision optimization and supply chain collaborative scheduling was verified through simulation experiments. The research shows that the platform can achieve dynamic adaptive optimization of global automotive industry data fusion, with data processing efficiency increased by more than 10%.

title: An Improved Lightweight EfficientNetV2-EMA Network for ECG Atrial Fibrillation Detection
authors: Songyang An, Yongkang Zhou, Zizhao Meng, Xiao Li
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Biomedical Signal and Image Processing (ICBIP)
abstract: Arrhythmia is a common cardiovascular disease with high mortality, especially atrial fibrillation (AF), and its early diagnosis is very important for preventing complications such as stroke and heart failure. The traditional deep learning model has been trained by single or multi-lead ECG signals, and has made remarkable progress in atrial fibrillation detection. However, these models often face the balance between feature extraction and computational complexity, which limits their application in resource-constrained devices. Therefore, this paper proposes an improved EfficientNetV2 arrhythmia classification model based on Efficient Multi-Attention (EMA) module, aiming at improving the performance of single lead electrocardiogram (ECG) in atrial fibrillation detection, and meeting the needs of wearable devices for lightweight models. EMA module integrates global and local features through efficient multi-scale attention mechanism, which significantly improves the characterization ability of ECG features, and maintains low parameter quantity and high computational efficiency. The experimental results on MIT-BIH public data sets show that EfficientNetV2-EMA model has achieved excellent results in accuracy, sensitivity and specificity. Compared with many baseline methods, it only uses <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{1 8 K}$</tex> parameters to show significant advantages. This model is especially suitable for real-time ECG monitoring of wearable devices, which can detect potential atrial fibrillation in time and reduce the risk of complications such as stroke and heart failure, and has significant clinical application potential.

title: Monocular 3D Posture Detection for Freely Moving Rats
authors: Qixuan Sun, Kedi Xu
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Biomedical Signal and Image Processing (ICBIP)
abstract: Accurate three-dimensional (3D) posture estimation of experimental animals is critical for behavioral neuroscience research. Traditional approaches typically require complex setups involving multiple synchronized cameras and controlled environments, which can be costly and impractical for long-term studies. To overcome these limitations, we propose a monocular 3D posture prediction system for rats based on deep learning. Our system employs RTMDet and RTMPose for robust 2D keypoint detection, PoseFormerV2 for temporal 3D pose reconstruction, and MonoDepth2 to estimate depth information from monocular images. The system enables 3D posture and spatial position estimation of freely moving rats using a single conventional camera, significantly reducing hardware demands and operational costs. We trained and evaluated the model on the publicly available Rat-7M dataset, achieving 17.86 mm in Procrustes Aligned Mean Per Joint Position Error (PA-MPJPE) and 47.87 mm in Mean Per Joint Position Error (MPJPE) on the test set. This approach provides a cost-effective, scalable, and noninvasive solution for continuous monitoring of rodent behavior in naturalistic settings, thereby supporting extended behavioral and neurological investigations.

title: Polarization-Reconfigurable C-Band Circularly Polarized Microstrip Antenna
authors: Zhilin Liu, Shiang Li, Peng Chen, Xiaoyan Yuan, Xutao Yu
publish: 2025 18th IEEE United Conference on Millimeter Waves and Terahertz Technologies (UCMMT)
abstract: This paper targets the low earth orbit (LEO) satellite communication scenario and addresses the issues of insufficient polarization switching flexibility in traditional circularly polarized antennas. A polarization-reconfigurable microstrip antenna design in the C-band is proposed. The study focuses on the co-optimization of a dual-layer microstrip patch structure and a reconfigurable feeding network. The impedance bandwidth of the antenna is extended through near-field magnetic coupling effects, while dynamic polarization switching is achieved via an orthogonal dual-feed network. The design adopts a dual-layer dielectric stacked layout, leveraging the electromagnetic coupling between parasitic and driven patches to enhance frequency response. The feeding system incorporates Single Pole Double Throw (SPDT) switches and phase control structures, enabling electrically controlled switching of orthogonal signal phase relationships to support seamless LHCP/RHCP transitions. This solution maintains sufficient bandwidth while improving the antenna's polarization purity, aiming to provide a compact and efficient polarization-adaptive solution for satellite onboard terminals to meet the demands of spectrum reuse and anti-interference in dynamic communication environments.

title: Optimized Neural Network Hardware Accelerator for Object Detection Based on Zynq
authors: Chenyao Luo, Jiale Li, Kexue Sun
publish: 2025 18th IEEE United Conference on Millimeter Waves and Terahertz Technologies (UCMMT)
abstract: To address the high-power consumption of traditional neural network accelerators, this paper proposes a hardware accelerator based on the ZYNQ chip, a platform designed by Xilinx that integrates an ARM processor with FPGA logic to enable efficient hardwaresoftware co-design. Targeting the characteristics of YOLOv3-tiny algorithm, the accelerator adopts a hardware-software co-design approach that partitions the algorithm on ZYNQ's heterogeneous platform. The PS side handles tasks suitable for CPU serial scheduling, while the PL side manages complex parallel computations, fully leveraging their respective advantages. We optimize the use of multipliers and adders by implementing two 8bit multiplications with one DSP and replacing binary adder trees with ternary structures, further reducing resource consumption and improving timing. Experimental results on ZYNQ platform show the system uses only 18.15% BRAM and 14.65% DSP resources with 2.144 W power consumption, achieving 12.66 GOPS/W energy efficiency—significantly outperforming GPU and CPU platforms. This proves our system can achieve high-performance object detection with low power consumption, making it ideal for embedded mobile deployment.

title: Collaborative Spectrum Sensing Method Based on HHO-CNN
authors: Qi Ding, Yuxuan Zan, Quanquan Wang
publish: 2025 18th IEEE United Conference on Millimeter Waves and Terahertz Technologies (UCMMT)
abstract: This paper proposes a novel method to enhance the classification performance of collaborative spectrum sensing. The method involves the Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) parameter optimization method based on the Harris Hawks Optimization (HHO) algorithm. The method employs the HHO algorithm to automatically optimize key CNN parameters, including learning rate, number of neurons and convolutional kernel dimensions. During the optimization process, a loss function is used to quantitatively evaluate prediction errors. Then backpropagation mechanisms are used to minimize these errors. Simulation results demonstrate that the HHO-CNN algorithm displays significant advantages in both classification accuracy and spectrum sensing performance. Its performance is notably superior to that of non-optimized CNN models and K-Nearest Neighbors (KNN) algorithms.

title: Unraveling the Role of Performance, Effort and Satisfaction in Social Media Acceptance
authors: Adele B L Mailangkay, Yulia Ery Kurniawati, Sudiana, Hendry Hartono, Muhammad Shabir Shaharudin, Sasmoko
publish: 2025 IEEE 15th International Conference on System Engineering and Technology (ICSET)
abstract: This study explores the determinants of social media acceptance by examining how performance expectancy and effort expectancy influence user's continuance intention and perceived enjoyment. User satisfaction is introduced as a moderating variable to assess its role in shaping these relationships. Drawing upon the Unified Theory of Acceptance and Use of Technology (UTAUT) and the Technology Acceptance Model (TAM), this research employs a quantative methodology through an online survey of 250 active social media users in Indonesia aged 17 and above. Using SPSS 26, analyses included reliability testing, correlation, mutiple regression, and moderation analysis. Findings reveal that performance expectancy, effort expectancy, and user satisfaction significantly impact continuance intention, while only user satisfaction significantly affects perceived enjoyment. Interestingly, user satisfaction does not significantly moderate the relationships between expectancy constructs and the outcome variables. This study offers a nuanced understandig of how cognitive and affective factors interact to shape continued social media usage, emphasizing the unique role of satisfaction in driving emotional engagement. Practical implications highlight the importance of prioritizing user-centric platform design to enhance satisfaction and foster long-term engagement.

title: Salient Store: Enabling Smart Storage for Continuous Learning Edge Servers
authors: Cyan Subhra Mishra, Deeksha Chaudhary, Mahmut Taylan Kandemir, Chita R. Das
publish: 2025 34th International Conference on Parallel Architectures and Compilation Techniques (PACT)
abstract: Global IP-video traffic is projected to exceed 4.8 Zettabytes annually by 2025, driven largely by edge applications like autonomous driving and urban mobility that generate hundreds of terabytes per device. While significant research has optimized edge inference and training architectures, the critical challenges of data archival and storage have been largely overlooked. Our analysis reveals that archival operations, not inference, dominate system resources, consuming up to 80% of memory bandwidth and one-third of CPU cycles in edge servers. We present Salient Store, a novel computational storage architecture that transforms passive storage devices into active participants in the video analytics pipeline. Salient Store integrates motion-aware layered neural compression directly within storage FPGAs, reusing feature maps from inference to eliminate redundant computation while employing anchor-delta temporal encoding to maximize compression efficiency. By executing these operations entirely within the storage plane through peer-to-peer communication, our system bypasses host memory bottlenecks that plague traditional architectures. Comprehensive evaluation across five real-world datasets demonstrates that Salient Store reduces end-to-end archival latency by $6.18 \times$, decreases host-side data movement by $5.63 \times$, and maintains up to 47 dB PSNR while reducing system power consumption by 65%. This work fundamentally re-imagines storage for continuous learning systems, transforming it from a passive bottleneck into an acceleration layer that operates symbiotically with neural inference and training.

title: Dual Band L Shape and Dual Mode Ring Resonator Matched Bandstop Filter
authors: Muhammad Imran Bin Saharudin, Muhammad Nurazlan Shah Bin Nazar Shah, Badrul Hisham Bin Ahmad, Mohd Khairy Zahari
publish: 2025 IEEE International RF and Microwave Conference (RFM)
abstract: This paper proposes a multiband matched bandstop filter. Two types of design implemented in this filter which is L -shape (parallel connected) resonator and dual-mode ring resonator. The L-shape design filter is based on the half wavelength (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\lambda/2$</tex>) and quarter wavelength (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\lambda/4$</tex>) with gap coupling, which parallel with an all-pass nominally 90 degree phase shift element that can be optimized to achieve high Qfactor. The dual-mode ring filter design operates by supporting two degenerate modes, or equivalently, by producing split resonant frequencies through the introduction of a perturbing stub. Both of this filter design is cascaded to achieve multiband isolation. Frequency center of 1 GHz and 1.5 GHz chosen to demonstrate this experiment.

title: Generative AI in Education: Risks, Acceptance, Trust, And Usage Among Selected Students in The Philippines
authors: Angelito Bautista, Lalaine Josefa Carrao
publish: 2025 8th International Conference of Computer and Informatics Engineering (IC2IE)
abstract: The introduction of generative artificial intelligence (AI) in education has been so rapid that debates around its ethics, prevalence, reliability, and best practices continue to arise. The purpose of this study is to analyze perceptions of selected Filipino students towards generative AI in five major aspects: perceived risks and ethical issues, prevalence and acceptance, level of trust, current and intended use, and need for restriction. Building on the Technology Acceptance Model (TAM), this study investigates the influence of perceived usefulness, ethical implications, and trust on students' acceptance and use of generative AI within the context of their studies. Data were collected from 717 Filipino students using a quantitative, descriptive-correlational research design. The findings indicate that 95% of respondents use generative AI tools, with ChatGPT being the most frequently used. These students see the relevance and value of AI in improving tasks related to academic work, but they also express apprehensions in terms of academic integrity, misuse, and ethical risks. The researchers performed correlation analyses that showed perceived risk is significantly associated with perceived need for restrictions, perceived trust is significantly related to the acceptance of AI, and acceptance of AI is significantly associated with usage. The strong correlation between trust and the need for restrictions indicates that even those who trust AI recognize that ethical safeguards are needed. This study highlights the importance of AI literacy, ethical regulations, and clearly defined institutional policies in promoting AI advantages and maintaining academic integrity. Of particular interest are the implications of the findings for anyone who directly or indirectly contributes to shaping the integration of responsible AI in education systems, including teachers, policymakers, and institutions. Future studies could investigate AI use in the present and how regulations of AI will affect students and educators in the long term in academia.

title: Domain-Agnostic Causal-Aware Audio Transformer for Infant Cry Classification
authors: Geofrey Owino, Bernard Shibwabo Kasamani, Ahmed M. Abdelmoniem, Edem Wornyo
publish: 2025 8th International Conference of Computer and Informatics Engineering (IC2IE)
abstract: Accurate and interpretable classification of infant cry paralinguistics is vital for early diagnosis of neonatal distress and clinical decision support. However, most existing deep learning approaches rely heavily on correlation-driven signal representations, making them vulnerable to acoustic perturbations and domain shifts across recording environments. In this work, we present DACH-TIC, a novel Domain-Agnostic Causal-Aware Hierarchical Audio Transformer that integrates causal reasoning, multi-task modeling, and adversarial domain generalization for robust infant cry classification. DACH-TIC introduces a structured transformer backbone composed of local token-level and global semantic encoders, augmented by causal attention masking and a controlled perturbation training approach that simulates counterfactual acoustic perturbations. A domain adversarial head further enables invariance across recording environments, while multi-task supervision improves representation robustness by jointly optimizing cry type, distress intensity, and causal relevance. We evaluate DACH-TIC on cry recordings from the Baby Chillanto and Donate-a-Cry datasets, with ESC-50 noise overlays for domain augmentation. Compared to existing state-of-the-art models such as Hierarchical Token-Semantic Audio Transformer (HTS-AT) and Squeeze-and-Excitation Residual Network Transformer (SE-ResNet Transformer), DACH-TIC achieves significant improvements in accuracy (2.6%), macroF1 (2.2%), and causal fidelity metrics. It also generalizes well to unseen environments with minimal performance degradation (domain gap: 2.4%). These results establish DACH-TIC as a causally grounded, domain-resilient model for real-world deployment in neonatal acoustic monitoring systems.

title: Distributed Optimization and Adaptive Fuzzy Control of Cyber-Physical Vehicle Systems with Communication Delays
authors: Mahdieh Samadi, Farshad Rahimi
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Control, Instrumentation and Automation (ICCIA)
abstract: This work presents a framework for distributed collaborative optimization in cyber-physical vehicle systems (CPVSs) operating under communication delays, dynamic uncertainties, and unknown nonlinear disturbances. A new distributed optimization approach is introduced that allows individual vehicles to minimize their local objective functions while maintaining coordination with adjacent vehicles through a communication network experiencing constant time delays. For reliable pursuit of optimal trajectories, an adaptive fuzzy backstepping control strategy is developed to handle unknown nonlinearities and dynamic uncertainties inherent in vehicle dynamics. The integration between the cyber-layer optimization and physical-layer control guarantees precise tracking of optimal reference trajectories produced by the distributed optimization scheme. Simulations validate the performance and resilience of the proposed approach in realizing distributed optimization and control objectives for CPVSs.

title: Enhancing EFL Pronunciation and Dubbing Skills through Sequential Digital Storytelling and Animation Dubbing: A Mixed-Methods Study
authors: Fitria Nugrahani, Ade Rahma Yuly, Ratna Widyaiswara, Dinda Kadarwati
publish: 2025 8th International Conference of Computer and Informatics Engineering (IC2IE)
abstract: This mixed-methods research examines the efficacy of a novel pedagogical model that strategically integrates Digital Storytelling (DST) with animation dubbing to enhance pronunciation accuracy and dubbing synchronization skills among English as a Foreign Language (EFL) learners. Grounded in sociocultural theory, emphasizing collaborative learning and scaffolding, and cognitive load principles, aiming to manage mental effort, the study involved 30 Indonesian undergraduates in a structured 10-week intervention. The model deliberately sequenced tasks to scaffold complexity: participants began with low-stakes DST activities (Weeks 1-5), focusing on scriptwriting and voice recording for personal narratives. This foundational phase then transitioned to high-stakes animation dubbing practice (Weeks 6-10), requiring detailed clip analysis and precise lip-synchronization under performance pressure. Quantitative analysis revealed statistically significant improvements across key metrics. Segmental pronunciation errors (individual sounds) decreased substantially by 65%. Suprasegmental features, including intonation and stress patterns, showed considerable enhancement, evidenced by a large effect size (Cohen's d = 1.28). Crucially for dubbing proficiency, timing synchronization improved markedly, with 73% of lip-sync offsets falling below the demanding industry standard of 150 milliseconds. Qualitative data, taken from interviews and journal reflections, provided deeper insight, indicating that the initial DST phase effectively lowered learner anxiety and fostered expressive confidence, thereby facilitating a smoother transition to the more complex demands of dubbing. Overall, this study presents a robust and reproducible instructional framework that successfully bridges the development of core linguistic competence (pronunciation) with specialized dubbing skills (synchronization, expressivity).

title: A Magnetic Multi-Modal Wall-Climbing Robot with Configurable Switching
authors: Zhuohao Li, Chen Yao, Youli Chen, Peichen Wang
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Control, Robotics and Cybernetics (CRC)
abstract: With the widespread application of steel structures such as oil storage tanks, metal bridges, and ships, the demand for metal surface health inspection and maintenance continues to grow. Wall-climbing robots are crucial for performing inspection and maintenance tasks on metal structures. However, traditional fixed-configuration robots like wheeled and tracked wall climbing robots struggle to simultaneously maintain posture adjustment capabilities and stable adhesion when overcoming typical obstacles such as traversing 90° right-angle edges and spanning wide gaps due to their rigid configurations. To overcome these limitations in wall climbing robots, we propose a multi-modal magnetic adhesion wall-climbing robot with autonomous reconfiguration capabilities. This robot employs a modular joint design, including pitch joints, swing arm joints, and steering joints, integrated with magnetic wheel units featuring built-in hub motors. This enables dynamic switching between Configuration 1 and Configuration 2. Through prototype fabrication and experimentation, the robot demonstrated stable motion performance on vertical and horizontal surfaces within our simulated industrial environment. It successfully navigated internal 90-degree corners and traversed gaps at equal heights across different modes. Experimental results confirm that our multi-modal design significantly enhances the robot’s adaptability and traversal capability in complex wall environments, providing an effective solution for reliable operation of wall-climbing robots in unstructured industrial settings.

title: Vector Network Analyzer: Historical Milestones and Evolution
authors: Elena Bernardi, Gabriele Marasca
publish: 2025 IEEE History of Electrotechnology Conference (HISTELCON)
abstract: In this paper, a historical overview of the evolution of the Vector Network Analyzer is presented, highlighting the most significant milestones. The instrument's improvements have been analyzed based on data extracted from datasheets and application notes of commercial products developed over the years by various companies. An analysis of the most significant figures of merit is provided to evaluate the instrument's enhancement over time, with a particular focus on dynamic range and operational bandwidth. Finally, a brief summary of the calibration methods is presented.

title: 175 Years of German Submarine Technology: From the “Brandtaucher” to the Class 212CD
authors: Peter Hauschildt
publish: 2025 IEEE History of Electrotechnology Conference (HISTELCON)
abstract: Submarines have 175 years of history in Germany. The paper describes the technical development from the first, simple submarine “Brandtaucher” to the latest modern design 212CD which includes fuel cell based air independent propulsion and a new stealth design

title: Warpage Evaluation of Double-Stacked 3D Structure Using a Waffle Wafer
authors: Wataru Doi, Yoshiaki Satake, Tatsuya Funaki, Tadashi Fukuda, Takayuki Ohba
publish: 2025 20th International Microsystems, Packaging, Assembly and Circuits Technology Conference (IMPACT)
abstract: We studied warpage behavior in a double-stacked 3D structure in the Chip-on-Wafer (COW) process. By using a waffle wafer and bumpless COW, we demonstrated, for the first time, a thinner double-stacked 3D structure, and the ability to predict wafer warpage in multi-layer COW stacking applications. This approach enabled FEM analysis to estimate wafer warpage with approximately 5% accuracy during stacking. These results show that warpage can be predicted in advance, facilitating process design for multi-layer COW stacking. In conventional molding processes employing single-layer wafers with relatively simple structures, numerous studies have demonstrated the accuracy of warpage prediction models through direct comparison between simulation results and empirical measurements. However, in the case of more complex multilayer wafer structures, most existing research has been limited to simulation-based analyses, with few studies providing experimental validation of predictive accuracy. In this study, we successfully achieved high-precision warpage prediction for multilayer COW configurations. This outcome indicates the feasibility of constructing reliable predictive models for general Wafer-Level Package (WLP) processes, even under structurally complex conditions.

title: Dual Token Localization Network for Weakly Supervised Object Localization
authors: Hongbo Wen, Ziqian Liu, Weiyu Wang, Haoxuan Chen, Chengliang Jiang
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Computer Information Technology (AICIT)
abstract: Weakly supervised object localization (WSOL) aims to localize objects with by only image-level supervision. Recent studies show the significant success of applying visual transformer to WSOL, which is benefited from the long-range feature dependency of self-attention mechanism. However, existing transformer-based methods of using classification models to locate objects can lead to optimization conflicts between classification and localization tasks. In addition, the transformer-based methods lack exploration of local details due to their excessive focus on global features. To alleviate above issues, we propose a dual token localization network (DTLN) for weakly supervised object localization. Specifically, we propose a dual token localization transformer to decouple classification and localization tasks for alleviating optimization conflicts between them. Moreover, we propose a location query attention to obtain different localization maps by introducing different location tokens to query each patch tokens for generating better localization maps. Finally, we propose a differential loss to prevent different localization maps from converging in order to drive different localization maps to learn different local details. Experiments demonstrate that the proposed DTLN achieves superior performance on CUB-200-2011 with 98.79%.

title: AI-A-thon Learning Ecosystem
authors: Panita Chobtamkit, Prachyanun Nilsook, Panita Wannapiroon
publish: 2025 Research, Invention, and Innovation Congress: Innovative Electricals and Electronics (RI2C)
abstract: This research aims to analyze studies related to the implementation of AI-A-thon activities within the learning ecosystem, highlighting the shift from traditional learning models to practice-based learning that emphasizes collaboration and real-world applications of AI. A systematic literature review was conducted, and the data were analyzed using VOSviewer and Bibliometrix tools. The findings reveal that the Co-Keywords analysis identified six clusters comprising 40 items. The study also examined Most Relevant Sources and generated a WordCloud reflecting global research trends. The results indicate a growing international interest in this field and emphasize the potential of learners in promoting key 21st-century skills—namely creativity, problem-solving, and teamwork. Moreover, the findings suggest strategic directions for developing adaptive and sustainable learning ecosystems in response to the evolving digital era.

title: CRAFT-Net: Contour-Refining Attention and Fusion Network for Concrete Crack Segmentation
authors: Xiao Yang, Bin Shen, LongJie Liu, ZhiQi Zhang
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Computer Information Technology (AICIT)
abstract: Concrete crack segmentation remains challenging due to the thin, irregular nature of cracks, complex background textures, and variable lighting conditions that often lead to fragmented segmentation results with poor edge precision. We propose CRAFT-Net, a novel Contour-Refining Attention and Fusion Network that systematically addresses these limitations through a comprehensive feature enhancement pipeline. Our approach integrates EdgeAwareConv modules for high-resolution contour preservation, C2f_Attention blocks for focused crack feature extraction while suppressing background noise, and Concat_BiFPN layers for intelligent multi-scale feature fusion with learnable weights. Additionally, we introduce a lightweight Mask Refinement Network that combines low-resolution segmentation outputs with shallow high-resolution features to generate precise full-resolution masks. Extensive experiments on concrete crack datasets demonstrate that CRAFT-Net achieves superior performance in both segmentation accuracy and edge fidelity compared to existing methods, while maintaining computational efficiency suitable for practical deployment in structural health monitoring applications.

title: Clothing Segmentation using HSV Features and Morphological Algorithms
authors: Bhupendra Fataniya, Diya Shah, Roshni Jariwala
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Innovative Data Communication Technologies and Application (ICIDCA)
abstract: This paper presents an automatic clothing segmentation method in images using MATLAB-based image processing techniques. the implementation utilized techniques such as HSV color space conversion, morphological operations, edge detection, thresholding, and binary masking, to isolate clothing regions from the background. The system was evaluated on a dataset of 50 images, comparing the outputs with manually annotated ground truth masks (via CVAT). Metrics such as Intersection over Union (IoU), Dice coefficient, Precision, Recall, Mean Squared Error (MSE), and Peak Signal-to-Noise Ratio (PSNR) were calculated and results were inferred from the same. The method achieved a mean IoU of 0.6203, Dice score of 0.7342, Precision of 0.9276, Recall of 0.6597, MSE of 0.1058, and PSNR of 10.96 dB, demonstrating reliable segmentation accuracy in clean-background scenarios. However, performance drops for occlusions, overlapping garments, and dark-colored clothes due to the limitations of basic image processing techniques, suggesting that future improvements could involve deep learning approaches, such as Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs), to enhance segmentation under these challenging conditions.

title: Intelligent Waste Sorting System Based on YOLO-Enhanced Deep Learning Models
authors: Claire Guo, Ivy Zan, Isabel Ye
publish: 2025 International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, Digital Media Technology and Social Computing (ICAIDS)
abstract: This research proposes an intelligent waste management system integrating YOLOv11, a state-of-the-art object detection algorithm, with Large Language Models for automated waste classification and reporting. Our system addresses the challenges of urban waste management by combining visual recognition capabilities with textual analysis for comprehensive waste categorization. Experimental results demonstrate that YOLOv11 outperforms previous YOLO variants, achieving 0.931 precision and 0.971 recall in bounding box mode, with mAP@50-95 reaching 0.874. In mask mode, YOLOv11 attains even higher performance with 0.933 precision and 0.978 recall, surpassing both YOLOv5 and YOLOv8 variants. The multimodal approach enables accurate detection and classification while generating detailed disposal recommendations, significantly enhancing waste management efficiency.

title: AI-Enhanced Learning Assistant Platform with QA Generation, Evaluation, Learning Assessment to Discover Weaknesses and Improve Skills with Recursive Testing
authors: Suresh K, Satyam Kumar, S. Siddik, R. M. Dilip Charaan, S. P. Santhoshkumar, M. Sasikumar
publish: 2025 5th Asian Conference on Innovation in Technology (ASIANCON)
abstract: Through automated question generation, answer evaluation, weakness identification, recursive testing, a query forum, and professional chat support, this project offers an AI-powered educational system intended to improve learning. The system uses Natural Language Processing (NLP) to create questions from user-provided content that range in complexity. Latent Dirichlet Allocation (LDA) and Non-Negative Matrix Factorization (NMF) are two examples of machine learning algorithms that evaluate responses and offer immediate feedback with tailored insights. The system monitors student performance, pinpoints areas of weakness, and modifies study schedules appropriately. This architecture prioritizes efficiency and uses less training data than reinforcement learning (RL) techniques, which are beset by issues such as the “curse of dimensionality.” Additionally, the platform offers real-time expert support and a collaborative forum. It can be integrated with current LMS platforms and is made to be scalable and interoperable. This system, which prioritizes usability, accessibility, and inclusivity, outperformed current models and achieved 86% accuracy, providing a revolutionary approach to individualized and adaptive education.

title: Closed-Loop IIoT Control for Sustainable and Intelligent PCB Manufacturing: A Data-Driven Approach Integrating Domain Expertise (IMPACT 2025)
authors: Mickey Huang
publish: 2025 20th International Microsystems, Packaging, Assembly and Circuits Technology Conference (IMPACT)
abstract: The increasing demand for environmentally responsible, highly adaptive manufacturing processes, increased technical complexity, higher pressure on labor costs, energy costs, productivity and regulations has driven the electronics industry toward digitalization. title: FEA-based Neural Networks Estimation for Solder Lifetime in MLCC of PCB Layout Design
authors: Zi-An Huang, Chih-Hsun Lin, Shih-An Kuo, Chien-An Chou, Chu-Cheng Tsai, Wen-Hsiung Chen, Chang-Chun Lee, Jui-Chang Chuang, Yan-Yu Liou
publish: 2025 20th International Microsystems, Packaging, Assembly and Circuits Technology Conference (IMPACT)
abstract: Based on the recent huge demand in artificial intelligence and big data applications, recent research has increasingly focused on improving the efficacy and reliability of data center design. In this study, mechanical estimation is utilized to assist the engineering development of MLCC placement in PCB layout design. Enhancing the lifetime and reliability of power supplies also plays a critical role. One persistent challenge in power supply, is the mismatch in thermal expansion coefficients (CTE) between different materials, particularly under high temperature operating environments. Moreover, plastic deformation associated with creep progressively accumulates, eventually causing mechanical issues such as solder cracking or delamination, which in turn may accelerate electrical degradation or even result in complete breakdowns. To solve these challenges, this study proposes an integrated framework that combines physics based reliability modeling with machine learning approaches. In study also aim to develop a practical framework that integrates Coffin–Manson lifetime modeling through nonlinear finite element analysis (FEA) with multilayer perceptron neural networks, in order to achieve a more accurate assessment of reliability and to explore novel approaches for extending product life. Solder materials are considered using the Anand model. After validation of the FEA with experimental data, the deviation was found to be less than 20%. The mechanical simulation database comprises 250 sets of data, of which 80% were used for training the neural networks and 10% data for testing, 10% for validation data. This strategy provides multiple robust design options for engineers, bridging mechanical and electrical domains in MLCC placement within PCB layout design.

title: Depression Detection Based on Recursive Joint Specific Cross-Modal Fusion Enhanced by Multi-Modal Features
authors: Jiaxin Wang, Zhuochang Xu, Lei Jin, Xiaojia Wang, Chunfeng Yang, Regine Le Bouquin Jeannes
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Biomedical Signal and Image Processing (ICBIP)
abstract: Depression is a widespread mental health disorder that affects millions of people around the world. Compared to other forms of expression, text modality more authentically conveys human thoughts, making it valuable to explore its potential for multimodal depression detection. However, combining audio and text modalities for automatic depression detection presents challenges due to the redundancy of information and the differences between the two. This paper proposes a new approach to address these challenges by introducing a multimodal feature enhancement-based cross-modal feature fusion framework for depression detection. Our method focuses on extracting relevant features from both the audio and text modalities, with an emphasis on semantic information. Temporal convolutional networks are used to model the time-based features of each modality. Additionally, a bidirectional cross-attention modality expert module is designed to enhance and better understand the features of each modality. To effectively capture both the internal relationships within each modality and the connections between audio and text, we introduce a recursive joint-specific cross-modal attention feature fusion technique. This approach ensures that each modality's unique information is preserved during the fusion process, preventing the loss of important features. The proposed model is evaluated extensively on the DAIC-WoZ public dataset, and the results demonstrate its competitive performance compared to other methods.

title: Interactive Audio Sculpting: Plugin Customization and UI Affordances in Immersive Environments
authors: Michel Buffa, Marco Winckler, Quentin Escobar, Samuel Demont, Ayoub Hofr, Adam Mir-Sadjadi
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th International Symposium on the Internet of Sounds (IS2)
abstract: WAM Jam Party is a collaborative WebXR platform for creating 3D musical installations using Web Audio Modules (WAM) plugins. Expanding on earlier work, this paper introduces major improvements focused on usability, expressiveness, and interaction design. A new 3D GUI editor allows users to attach interactive, custom graphical interfaces to existing WAM plugins without modifying their source code, enabling representations such as synths with distinctive textures, labels, 3D knobs etc. or physics-based instruments like a guitar with a body shaped like a real acoustic guitar. The design offers a "3D Plugin Shop" and floating menus with preview thumbnail images as alternative means to select and assemble audio components. The system allows dynamic code injection for advanced behaviors, including animated parameter modulators, piano roll sequencers or an animated drum kit. User studies report higher engagement, faster onboarding, and creative workflows. This study also gives some practical insights for building collaborative audio tools in immersive web-based environments.
