title: A Machine Learning Framework for Personalized Employee Health and Productivity Optimization
authors: Atul Kumar, Jena P. Joshi, Aditi Aljapurkar, Akash Agarwal, Vinaydeep Brar, Manjiri Joshi, Amol Gawande, Kiran Singh
publish: 2025 5th Asian Conference on Innovation in Technology (ASIANCON)
abstract: The integration of artificial intelligence (AI) and machine learning (ML) technologies in workplace environments presents unprecedented opportunities for enhancing employee wellbeing and work-life balance. This paper presents a comprehensive framework for AI-driven employee wellbeing enhancement, incorporating personalized stress detection, productivity optimization, and adaptive work environment management. Our proposed system utilizes multimodal data fusion, combining physiological sensors, behavioral analytics, and environmental monitoring to create personalized wellbeing profiles. We evaluate our framework using real-world datasets from healthcare professionals and corporate environments, demonstrating significant improvements in stress reduction (34%), work-life balance satisfaction (28%), and overall productivity metrics (22%). The system incorporates four key mathematical models for stress prediction, workload optimization, empathy assessment, and well-being scoring. Results indicate that personalized AI interventions can effectively address the dual impact of technology on employee welfare while maintaining organizational efficiency. Our findings contribute to the growing field of positive AI design and provide practical insights for implementing wellbeing-focused AI systems in modern workplaces.

title: Green Cart: A Comprehensive E-Commerce Framework for Selling Plants and Gardening Services Online
authors: Pratik Brahmbhatt, Shreyaskumar Patel, Mukesh Patidar, Daxa Vekariya, Rashid Sheikh
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Advances in Computing Research On Science Engineering and Technology (ACROSET)
abstract: As home gardening and eco-friendly living becomes more popular, the need for easy-to-use plant shopping applications rises. This document describes the design and implementation of an e-commerce plant selling website developed with full-stack web technologies. The system permits users to view and purchase various classes of plants, which include indoor and outdoor plants, succulents, herbs, and flowering plants. Customers are able to filter plants by size, species, level of care, and suitability to the environment. The system combines a dynamic front-end interface with a solid back-end which monitors stock, user accounts, and orders. This design fulfills the requirements of the users while promoting urban sustainable gardening.

title: Deep Learning-Based Short-Term Load Forecasting: A Case Study on Residential and Commercial Load
authors: Phorprapa Chotipintu, Kedsara Palachai, Prachuab Peerapong, Terapong Boonraksa, Nopprut Seali, Boonruang Marungsri, Promphak Boonraksa
publish: 2025 International Conference on Power, Energy and Innovations (ICPEI)
abstract: Electrical load forecasting is an essential tool for effective energy management in the industrial and household sectors. This paper focuses on load forecasting, using a case study of commercial and residential load data. Three types of Deep Learning techniques —LSTM, BiLSTM, and ConvLSTM —are applied, and their forecasting performance is compared. The models are trained with hourly load data collected from real data sources, and the statistical accuracy and learning efficiency of each technique are compared. The simulation results show that the three techniques can provide accurate results. The BiLSTM technique has better learning stability than the LSTM and ConvLSTM techniques. The commercial load forecasting results using the BiLSTM technique can obtain an RMSE value of 1.8713, an MAPE of 6.8125%, and an R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> of 0.9948. The residential load forecasting results obtained using the BiLSTM technique have an RMSE value of 1.0941, an MAPE of 13.3502%, and an R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> value of 0.9511. The case study of both load types shows that commercial loads are more prone to error than residential loads due to the higher data volatility. This paper demonstrates the potential of DRL in load forecasting for future energy planning and management.

title: Early Warning and Prevention of High-Frequency Emergencies Based on Trusted Data Spaces
authors: Guian Feng, Yamei Zhou, Xiaojing Zhao, Tian Xia, Lili Jia Shanghai, Chenchen Xiong
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Networks, Communications and Information Technology (CNCIT)
abstract: As the frequency and scope of major diseases continue to rise, the need for an efficient early warning and prevention system in public health has become increasingly urgent. This paper addresses the challenges of preventing and predicting high-frequency and sudden-onset diseases, and proposes a blockchain-based solution to construct a trusted data space. The solution integrates blockchain technology with trusted data space construction, effectively addressing the challenges of data sharing and utilization across regions, departments, and business domains for disease warning and prevention. The experiment showed that the solution on-chain TPS(Transactions Per Second) for spatial data is 1318.7, and the single-node QPS(Queries Per Second) is 1999.2. It meets the requirements for handling high-frequency and sudden public health events, and offers certain advantages in data security, sharing efficiency, and privacy protection. Future research will continue to explore the deep integration and extended applications of cross - chain technology, zero - knowledge proof, and other privacy -preserving computing technologies.

title: A Global-Local Finite Element Simulation Approach for Early Failure Detection in Chiplet Packaging
authors: C.A. Yang, W.F. Wang, K.N. Chiang
publish: 2025 20th International Microsystems, Packaging, Assembly and Circuits Technology Conference (IMPACT)
abstract: With the progressive limitations of Moore's Law, the semiconductor industry is increasingly transitioning toward advanced packaging technologies. Among these, chiplet-based architectures have emerged as a promising paradigm for improving system-level performance through enhanced integration density, design flexibility, and improved manufacturing yield. However, the adoption of heterogeneous integration also introduces significant reliability challenges, such as thermomechanical stress accumulation, mismatches in coefficients of thermal expansion (CTE), mechanical warpage, and solder joint fatigue.This study proposes a simulation framework that integrates the Global-Local Finite Element Method (FEM) with Equivalent Beam Theory to accurately and efficiently assess the reliability of chiplet packages. Multi-point constraints (MPC) and refined meshing strategies are employed to enhance simulation precision while maintaining computational efficiency. SAC305 solder material is modeled under JEDEC's thermal cycling conditions ( -40 °C to 125 °C), and thermal-mechanical coupled analyses are performed using ANSYS APDL to identify high-stress regions and potential failure locations.Validation with empirical data confirms that the proposed FEM framework accurately predicts failure mechanisms in chiplet-based packages. This approach can shorten development cycles, reduce trial-and-error costs, and enhance design robustness, enabling early-stage risk evaluation and optimization to meet the growing demand for reliable, high-performance semiconductor packaging in next-generation computing.

title: Enhancing Security in DAWN-MANET for Disaster Management: Challenges and Solutions
authors: Khanista Namee, Pitpimon Choorod, Karn Na Sritha, Areej Meny, Rudsada Kaewsaeng-On, Jantima Polpinij
publish: 2025 Research, Invention, and Innovation Congress: Innovative Electricals and Electronics (RI2C)
abstract: The deployment of Disaster Area Wireless Networks (DAWNs) based on MANET technologies provides critical communication support in emergency situations. Nonetheless, they are decentralized and highly dynamic, which exposes them to security threats such as the Man-in-the-Middle (MitM) attacks, jamming, and eavesdropping. This paper presents a lightweight encryption incorporated routing protocol and simulates it under attacks in NS-2. The results show that the suggested secure routing scheme can not only improve PDR of the packets, decrease packet loss, and maintain an acceptable delay, but also enhance the resiliency and confidentiality of DAWN-MANET communications. For example, Secure-AODV was able to demonstrate a PDR of 93% and a decreasing packet loss of 6.8% under simulated attacks versus 85% and 14.2% respectively for normal AODV.

title: A Mathematical Model for PM2.5 Prediction based on Vehicle Density and Wind Speed in Samphanthawong district, Bangkok
authors: Waraporn Hiran, Nopparat Pochai
publish: 2025 Research, Invention, and Innovation Congress: Innovative Electricals and Electronics (RI2C)
abstract: Bangkok frequently experiences concerning levels of air pollution, particularly during its dry season. This pollution is primarily driven by emissions from vehicles, agricultural burning in nearby regions, industrial activities, and construction dust, all exacerbated by unfavorable weather conditions that trap pollutants. Samphanthawong District, especially Yaowarat, consistently grapples with severe PM2.5 pollution during this period. Our research emphasizes the critical role of meteorological factors, such as wind speed and natural ventilation, in dispersing urban pollutants. While the simulation model proved stable and its computational results were not significantly affected by the chosen time step, it highlighted a major issue: PM2.5 concentrations in Samphanthawong decrease very slowly due to light winds and inadequate airflow. Therefore, to effectively manage air pollution in this area, additional measures are needed to improve ventilation or directly reduce PM2.5 sources, as natural factors alone cannot achieve rapid pollutant reduction.

title: The Repetitive Deviance Nullification Groundwork Built on ASWMF Deviance Detection Routine and MF Enhancement Routine For Impulse Outlier
authors: Vorapoj Patanavijit, Darun Kesrarat, Wilaiporn Lee, Kanabadee Srisomboon, Kornkamol Thakulsukanant
publish: 2025 Research, Invention, and Innovation Congress: Innovative Electricals and Electronics (RI2C)
abstract: In the area of deviance nullification of programed photocopies, remarkably the rigidify tension impulsive outlier (RTIO), the last contemporary outlier nullification groundwork, which are systematically dispatched into the deviance detection routine and the deviance enhancement routine, is an ineluctable former photocopy groundwork ahead of other intricate groundwork. One of the last contemporary and feasible outlier nullification groundworks is ASWMF (Adaptive Sequentially Weighted Median Filter), which was originated in 2020 for the RTIO (rigidify tension impulsive outlier). Thereupon, this article originates the repetitive deviance nullification groundwork built on ASWMF deviance detection routine and MF enhancement routine for RTIO. The computer exploration tests the functioning of the proposed repetitive deviance nullification groundwork, in discrimination with other former outlier nullification groundworks such as MF, SMF, and AMF on the plenteous deviance photocopies, which are dispatched of Girl and Pepper in all proportion outlier dispersion of nullifying the RTIO.

title: Research on Method for Eliminating Noise and Trend Terms from Explosion Vibration Signals
authors: Zhang Long, Shi Yongxiang, Song Shiqian, Zhang Geng, Jiao Xuejie
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Networks, Communications and Information Technology (CNCIT)
abstract: Based on CEEMDAN and wavelet threshold, a method to eliminate the noise and trend terms of explosion vibration signals was constructed in our study. We used vibration velocity signals of a certain explosion experiment as an example. Firstly, the CEEMDAN method was used to decompose the signal into a series of IMF components; Secondly, the mean ratio method and correlation coefficient method were separately used to distinguish the low-frequency trend terms and high-frequency noise components, and the signal was then reconstructed based on the pure IMF components; Finally, the time-frequency characteristics and energy distribution laws of the signal were studied by Hilbert spectrum analysis. The results showed that this method could accurately distinguish and remove the low-frequency trend terms and high-frequency noise from original signal, which made the waveform of reconstructed signal return to the baseline center. Compared with other methods, this method acquired the highest signal-to-noise ratio and the smallest root mean square error, showing the best denoising effect. Moreover, Hilbert spectrum analysis showed that this method eliminated the low-frequency trend terms at 0-10Hz and the high-frequency noise components above 150Hz. In addition, the high-energy signal components in the middle frequency range could be preserved completely. The reconstructed signal energy was mainly concentrated in the 20-150Hz frequency range and 50-200ms time range. The Hilbert spectrum analysis based on reconstructed signal could reflect the time-frequency characteristics and energy distribution laws of explosion vibration signal more accurately.

title: Improvement of Lithium Battery SOH Estimation Algorithm Based on Attention Mechanism
authors: Kaixiang Liu, Xianjun Yi, Shichao Yan
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Computer Information Technology (AICIT)
abstract: The State of Health (SOH) of batteries is one of the core parameters for managing lithium-ion batteries in drones, and it is a key indicator for evaluating the performance of lithium-ion batteries in drones. For predict the soh of lithium battery more accurately, this paper proposes a CNN-LSTM lithium battery SOH estimation model based on multi-head self-attention mechanism (MHSA). Firstly, a SOH estimation model combining Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) and Long Short Term Memory Neural Network (LSTM) is constructed. CNN is good at extracting local features, while LSTM excels in capturing temporal dependencies. Afterwards, MHSA mechanism was introduced based on this model, this model can focus on short-term and long-term changes, which is conducive to solving the gradient vanishing problem in the circulation structure of ultra long series LSTM.. The experiment shows that the mean absolute error (MAE) does not exceed 0.012, the root mean square error (RMSE) is less than 0.02, and the coefficient of determination (R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>) exceeds 0.97. Compared with the LSTM model and CNN-LSTM network model, it has better estimation results.

title: To Implement and Enhance EEG Disease Classification with Customized Mixed Attention Mechanism Using Deep CNN-Bi-LSTM
authors: Abhit Bangar, Vivek Pandey, Harshal Bhagwat, Sandip Rasal, Tejas Shirke, Vasant P. Nikam
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Advances in Computing Research On Science Engineering and Technology (ACROSET)
abstract: The automation of disease recognition with Electroencephalography (EEG) signals is important for medical diagnostics since it reveals brain activities. The analysis procedures of EEG are still done manually and are therefore time consuming, highly susceptible to human error, and need deep knowledge which results in deviation from systematic analysis. This study aims to develop an effective EEG disease classification technique using deep learning models based on Deep CNN-BiLSTM architecture together with an Customized Mixed Attention Mechanism. In order to maximize comprehension of data by the model, Customized Mixed Attention Mechanism is employed so that the model focuses on EEG parameters of primary interest while minimizing focus on irrelevant information. The newly created method is tested on images of EEG data and shows satisfactory results in classifying several neurological disorders. Data and insight collected from the experiment suggest this model far outperforms the EEG classification techniques by achieving remarkable results of 99.45% accuracy, 96.67% F1-Score, 96.98% precision, 96.97% recall, and 97.47% Sensitivity.

title: Coffee Plant Disease Detection for Coffea Liberica Using ResNet50
authors: Gabriel Cesar M. Balan, Albert Lanze A. Vaquilar, Jessie Jaye R. Balbin
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Internet of Things and Intelligence Systems (IoTaIS)
abstract: Coffea liberica or Kapeng Barako is one of the well-known coffee varieties in the Philippines. Being among the top consumers of coffee in the world, the ever-growing demand and popularity of coffee has deemed the importance of sustainable farming. The study has developed a handheld device that utilizes the ResNet50 algorithm to develop a model for coffee plant disease detection. The handheld device utilizes Raspberry Pi 5, Raspberry Pi Camera Module V2, and HC-SR04 ultrasonic sensor. The model was trained using captured images of Coffea liberica plants in Lipa, Batangas, Philippines. The model is designed to identify leaf rust, leaf spot, coffee berry disease (CBD), and stem canker that affect Coffea liberica plants. The results show the disease detection accuracy for leaves to be 90%, the accuracy for berries is 86%, and the trunk is 83%. The overall coffee plant disease was able to achieve 91.7% accuracy in diagnosing coffee trees.

title: Cloud-Integrated IoT System for Real-Time Health Monitoring of Industrial Induction Motor
authors: Kishor Kanaparthi, Deepak. Ch
publish: 2025 5th Asian Conference on Innovation in Technology (ASIANCON)
abstract: The rapid progression of technology nowadays is largely focused on the Internet of Things (IoT). A multiple number of devices are seamlessly interconnected, particularly in industrial automation, enabling condition and control monitoring to enhance productivity. The condition monitoring of rotating machines for critical applications plays an important role in reducing downtime. with Industry 4.0, the role of IoT in online condition monitoring of electrical machines has gained considerable significance. The primary objective of this work is to utilize IoT for real-time monitoring of motor parameters such as voltage, current, temperature, and speed, while tracking their trends online via a web server. The data can be accessed through graphs and widgets by visiting the web page. The benefits of this approach include constant equipment monitoring and having data readily available for predictive maintenance.

title: Predictive Modeling of Sleep Disorders using Lifestyle and Physiological Indicators: A Machine Learning Approach
authors: R. Susmitha
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Innovative Data Communication Technologies and Application (ICIDCA)
abstract: Sleep disorders have large concern on the society, they being frequently associated with tractable lifestyle and physiological interventions. The present research employed a selected list of 374 participants, integrating 12 behavioral and biometric factors, such as sleeping time, exercise, stress, BMI, heart rate, and blood pressure. The Random Forest model was trained to find out who has sleep disorders, which resulted in 91.2% accuracy, 89.7% precision, 90.3% recall, and F1-score of 90.0 %. Exploratory data analysis exposed that the level of stress, physical activity, and the body mass index were highly related with sleep duration and quality. Remarkably, the prevalence of sleep apnea was observed in individuals whose stress level scored 8 and above and individuals with sleep time being less than 6 hours. The model found stress level, quality of sleep and BMI category to be leading predictive features. These results were indicative of the promise of machine learning in the early screening of sleep disorders with noninvasive markers in lifestyle, which led to its use in digital health tracking and prevention.

title: A Multi-Stage Preprocessing Pipeline for Landsat 8 Optical and Thermal Imagery in Flood Monitoring
authors: Sathiyamoorthy M, Subramanian P
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Advances in Computing Research On Science Engineering and Technology (ACROSET)
abstract: Accurate flood detection and monitoring rely heavily on high-quality satellite imagery. However, raw satellite images from NASA’s Landsat 8 suffer from atmospheric distortions, cloud cover, radiometric inconsistencies, and noise, which can impact the reliability of flood mapping. This paper proposes L8-FloodPrep, a multi-stage preprocessing pipeline designed to enhance Landsat 8 optical and thermal imagery for flood detection applications. The pipeline consists of five key stages: (1) Radiometric and Atmospheric Correction, which converts raw Digital Numbers (DN) into Top-of-Atmosphere (TOA) reflectance while removing haze; (2) Cloud and Shadow Removal, employing the Fmask algorithm and Normalized Difference Snow Index (NDSI) to filter cloud-covered regions; (3) Water Body Segmentation, utilizing the Normalized Difference Water Index (NDWI) and Otsu’s thresholding for precise floodwater extraction; (4) Thermal Band Analysis, incorporating Brightness Temperature (BT) calculations from the Thermal Infrared Sensor (TIRS) for flood extent validation; and (5) Geometric Correction and Data Formatting, ensuring georeferencing consistency and optimized data storage in GIS-compatible formats. The proposed preprocessing framework improves the accuracy and usability of Landsat 8 imagery for flood monitoring applications, providing a reliable dataset for hydrological studies, disaster management, and remote sensing analysis. The model achieves high accuracy (95.6%) and is deployable using open-source data and GIS-compatible outputs, making it suitable for real-time flood monitoring applications.

title: Enhanced Motor Shaft Design for Extended Life under Radial Bending Load Using Integrated Mechanical-Electrical Optimization
authors: Wanwinit Wijittemee, Boonyang Plangklang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Power, Energy and Innovations (ICPEI)
abstract: This study proposed a hybrid mechanical-electrical optimization to enhance the fatigue life of motor shafts under high radial bending loads in multi-yarn textile winding operations. The baseline S45C steel shaft in a 4-pole motor at 1500 rpm suffered high bending stresses from four yarn rolls, leading to short fatigue life. In the proposed design, the shaft was upgraded to hardened S50C and the motor replaced with a 6-pole type running at 1000 rpm. This lowers rotational speed, reduced centrifugal forces, raises the endurance limit, and improved the safety factor without reducing operational torque. Experimental measurements confirmed that the improved design maintained operational torque under typical working conditions. Finite element analysis revealed the S45C shaft had a maximum von Mises stress of ~255 MPa. These results demonstrated that combining material upgraded with pole-number adjustment significantly enhanced shaft durability in continuous textile winding operations.

title: Enabling Ultra-Low Latency AI Applications with 5G and Edge Computing Integration
authors: Anurag Shrivastava, Sheela Hundekari, Montater MuhsnHasan, Yogendra Kumar, Ashish Parmar, Smitha K
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Advances in Computing Research On Science Engineering and Technology (ACROSET)
abstract: 5G networks, and edge computing application and The combination of these networks and edge computing is giving birth to ultra-low latency artificial intelligence (AI) applications, which will greatly reduce processing delays, improve the ability to make decisions in real time, and give full play to the optimal allocation of resources. This synergy facilitates AI-powered innovations in the fields of autonomous vehicles, smart cities, telemedicine and industrial automation. By minimizing the reliance on centralized cloud infrastructure, 5G’s high-speed, low-latency connectivity, and edge computing’s localized processing capabilities promise faster response times and improved security. The integration of 5G-edge AI in 5G-edge-cloud is thus aimed to transform next-generation intelligent systems, and this paper identifies core enablers, challenges, and future directions of this integration.

title: Thermo-oxidation Effect on the Tensile Mechanical Properties of the Epoxy Molding Compounds at Elevated Temperature
authors: Ayumi Saito, Masaya Ukita, Keisuke Wakamoto, Ken Nakahara
publish: 2025 20th International Microsystems, Packaging, Assembly and Circuits Technology Conference (IMPACT)
abstract: Power modulus (PMs) are structured from materials with different coefficients of expansion (CTE). For example, these include a joint material for bonding semiconductor dies to a base plate, and an epoxy molding compounds (EMCs) that encapsulates a PMs to protect its inner structure. The reliability of PMs is commonly assessed by temperature cycling testing (TCT), which involves swinging the ambient temperature repeatedly between high and low [1] . This structural feature inevitably causes repeated thermal-mechanical stress in PMs during TCT, thereby posing cohesive cracking in the die attachment and/or interface delamination at the EMCs and metal [1] . In addition to these mechanical destructions, EMCs themselves are generally oxidized by exposure to high temperatures in the air atmosphere [2] .

title: DeepSkinGuard: A CNN-based Preventive System for Melanoma Identification
authors: A. Sankar Reddy, Shaik Farha Begum, P.Sai Krishna, E.Shanmukha Lalith, Ch.Vinay
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Innovative Data Communication Technologies and Application (ICIDCA)
abstract: Effective treatment for skin cancer requires its earlier, accurate detection, especially in cases of aggressive melanoma. Due to the wide spectrum of visual appearances of skin lesions, diagnosing them can be difficult since dermatologists rely so heavily on visual characteristics. This research introduces DeepSkinGuard, a specifically designed Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) model aimed at overcoming the limitations of the range of visual appearances of skin lesions. The model was constructed from the ground up using TensorFlow and Keras based on a fine-tuned dataset of 10,015 dermoscopic images collected from the Kaggle HAM10000 dataset. Importantly, as opposed to many state-of-the-art methods, DeepSkinGuard was trained from scratch on this dataset and therefore did not rely on transfer learning or pretrained networks. To mitigate overfitting and increase generalization, DeepSkinGuard included dropout layers, and utilized data augmentation, to appropriate define the image variations taking place in the real world environment, such as rotation, zooming, and flipping. The resulting classification was achieved by passing gathered features through fully connected layers, and resulting in an output consisting of a confidence score. We evaluated DeepSkinGuard using a K-fold cross-validation methodology, with DeepSkinGuard resulting in very impressive accuracy of 98.18%. Notably, this improved accuracy represented a nearly 3.0% improvement compared to the previously recorded baseline methods developed for classifying the same dermoscopic images without extensive pre-trained networks, or augmentation pipelines. With this degree of accuracy, we believed this model would represent a strong clinical decision support tool in dermatology.

title: Efficient Combinatorial Search for Personalized Keto, Vegan, and Gluten-Free Diets via Hybrid Backtracking-Branch and Bound
authors: Rafael Julio Suseno, Nurwahyu Alamsyah, Jap Robertus Kurniawan Setiabudi, Kevin Matthew Siregar, Adri Gabriel Sooai, Benedictus Erlangga, Minarni Wartiningsih, Agustinus Bimo Gumelar, Paul L Tahalele
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electronic and Electrical Engineering and Intelligent System (ICE3IS)
abstract: Meal planning for special diets (such as keto, vegan, and gluten-free) and food allergies require an efficient computational approach due to the complexity of food combinations that meet nutritional requirements, individual preferences, and ingredient availability. This research proposes a hybrid backtracking-branch and bound algorithm-based framework to dynamically optimize food combination search. The backtracking algorithm explores the solution space with a pruned state-space search, while branch and bound ensures optimal solutions through evaluation functions based on calorie targets, macronutrient ratios (protein: fat: carbohydrate), and user preferences. The system implementation includes a graphical interface (GUI) that allows setting food preferences, allergies, and dietary restrictions. Evaluation on 100 user scenarios showed that the algorithm generated meal plans with an average deviation of $2.2 \%$ from the calorie target and $97 \%$ adherence to dietary restrictions. A case study of a keto diet user with a nut allergy achieved a nutritional composition of $\mathbf{5 4 \%}$ fat, $44 \%$ protein and $2 \%$ carbohydrate. Participant testing ($n=50$) showed an $\mathbf{8 8 \%}$ satisfaction rate in terms of personalization and ease of use. This system contributes to precision nutrition by integrating combinatorial optimization techniques and public health needs. Future developments could include the integration of machine learning for dynamic preference adaptation and expansion of the global food database.

title: Harvesting Intelligence through Artificial Intelligence Applications for Precision and Productivity in Agriculture
authors: Rachna Shah, Gaurav Jeet, Ritesh Janga
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Innovative Data Communication Technologies and Application (ICIDCA)
abstract: The introduction of Artificial Intelligence (AI) in agriculture has provided advanced methods to mitigate longstanding problems in crop management, resource utilization and environmental protection. This paper investigates the deployment of AI-based solutions in core agricultural tasks in particular focusing on two machine learning techniques i.e., convolutional neural networks (CNNs) for image based crop disease detection and support vector machines (SVMs) for yield prediction. CNNs are also employed to classify and localise plant diseases in drone and field camera based high resolution images with minimal human intervention. Meanwhile, multivariable environmental and phenotypic data are also trained for SVM predictions of crop yields under different climate. Both methods are evaluated with reference to accuracy, generality and time of application based on controlled and open-field trials. It is observed that AI models can lead to fast decision-making, consumption reduction, encourage precision farming approach and resource conservation. The study demonstrates the importance of scaling up data-driven approaches for transforming agricultural systems and strengthening food security in the face of a changing climate.

title: Machine Learning-Assisted Design and Optimization of a Mirrored U-Slot Patch Antenna for Millimeter-Wave Applications
authors: Tejaswari Palisetti, Nikhitha Pasupuleti, Jothilakshmi P
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Advances in Computing Research On Science Engineering and Technology (ACROSET)
abstract: Designing antennas that can perform at high levels for modern wireless communication is something tedious and demanding. Traditional methods rely on iterative simulations, requiring lots of processing engines and expert fine-tuning. These normal processes run a number of electromagnetic simulations while trying out different configurations of the design-an inefficient yet cost-heavy process. For these challenges, the work is machine-learning based for the design and optimization of microstrip patch antennas within the MATLAB site. The proposed method will very much improve the existing traditional simulation-heavy antenna design and optimization-through advanced machine learning mechanisms like Random Forest Regression and Bayesian optimization, predicting performance parameters like return loss (S11), gain, bandwidth, and efficiency of the antennas without much simulation. The approach is easily adaptable to all frequency bands, thus making it highly practical for next-generation wireless technologies, such as IoT, 5G, and satellite communication. With reduced iterative counts and computational expense, the proposed machine-learning driven framework can emerge as an efficient, scalable, and cost-effective solution for the rapid advancement of high-performance antennas in increasingly dynamic wireless communication spheres.

title: Deep Reinforcement Learning to Enhance the Robustness of Electric Vehicle Fast Charging
authors: Kevin Renatus, Wilhelm Biehl, Bernard Baeker
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Mechatronics Technology (ICEEMT)
abstract: Electric vehicles are a critical component of environmentally sustainable mobility solutions. In addition to the extensive provision of charging infrastructure, ensuring reliable charging processes is crucial to achieving widespread public acceptance. This is challenging, because the underlying processes are more complex than those involved in refueling a conventional car. A variety of charging technologies and infrastructures are available around the world. However, implementing all systems at a single charging station is not economically viable. Moreover, deviations from standards and implementation errors can result in incompatibilities between vehicles and charging infrastructure. This work builds upon an existing Matlab/Simulink based model of electric charging, in order to simulate communication and energy transfer. Our model incorporates realistic fault scenarios, such as message timeouts, which can occur randomly. Secondly, we employ deep reinforcement learning (DRL) agents to adapt adjustable calibration parameters, thereby achieving fault correction. The simulation results of both DRL approaches, one model-free and one model-based, prove the concept of their ability in fault recovery. Our future efforts will concentrate on improving the DRL algorithms, and expanding the approach to optimize the electric charging duration while maintaining the health of the involved hardware, particularly the battery. Our long-term objective is to deploy this technology in a real world setting as part of an automated remote repair application.

title: Aggregation characterization and robust optimization method for schedulable uncertainty boundary of distribution network based on internally contracted collocated ellipsoid projection
authors: Daiyu Xie, Boyao Wei, Xin Wei, Zhicheng Zhou, Jianming Su
publish: 2025 10th International Seminar on Computer Technology, Mechanical and Electrical Engineering (ISCME)
abstract: The access of high proportion of distributed renewable energy and diversified adjustable resources makes the distribution network scheduling face profound uncertainty challenges. Although stochastic optimization can deal with this problem, its dimension disaster problem restricts its application in real-time scheduling. This paper proposes a novel uncertainty boundary aggregation representation framework. Firstly, the response confidence space of various adjustable resources is quantified based on historical data. Furthermore, in order to solve the computational complexity problem caused by the feasible region of high-dimensional flexible resources, the internally contracted collocated ellipsoid projection method is introduced to map the high-dimensional electric-heat-gas multi-energy feasible region approximation to the low-dimensional aggregation space to form a concise ‘ schedulable box ‘. On this basis, combined with the idea of robust optimization, a two-stage robust optimization scheduling model is constructed to minimize the operating cost in the worst scenario. The simulation results of the actual low-voltage distribution station area show that the proposed method can significantly improve the maximum open capacity of distributed photovoltaic by more than 15 %. Compared with the traditional stochastic programming method, the computational efficiency is improved by more than 70 %, and the economy and robustness of the system are guaranteed.

title: Smart Animal Collar for Prevention of Road-Accidents using Location Mapping and Machine Learning
authors: Aditya Saini, Mohan Kshirsagar
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Advances in Computing Research On Science Engineering and Technology (ACROSET)
abstract: The abundance of stray animals in urban India leads to many fatalities of both animals and humans due to a multitude of reasons. This paper proposes a solar-powered neck band equipped with GPS and GPRS functionality to track the real time location of strays and an integrated AI model to deter the animals from entering traffic zones and expressways. An XGBoost regressor was trained on road attribute data to predict road safety priority levels, achieving an accuracy of ~87% on the first dataset and ~84% on the second. The algorithm will use location data to detect when an animal is near a busy road, highway or expressway (marked locations) and trigger loud sounds, LED lights on the band and controlled shocks to repel the animal away high-risk areas. Real time tracking enables timely treat or vaccination in case of collision or injury. This study involves the development of an AI algorithm and the design of a collar using CAD software, ensuring the design is suitable for resistance to water and dust. The electrical components used for designing the collar have been included, and the results and proposed technology can be used to fabricate a physical prototype in the future.

title: Efficient Data Augmentation for Bioacoustics: A Noise-Enriched Bird Sound Dataset
authors: Adrien Deverin, Valentin Gies, Hervé Glotin
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Internet of Things and Intelligence Systems (IoTaIS)
abstract: In artificial intelligence (AI), the quality of training data is a key determinant of model performance. However, acquiring well-labeled and context-relevant datasets remains a challenge, particularly in the field of acoustic recognition, where labeled data is often scarce and environmental conditions vary significantly. While data augmentation is a common remedy, not all augmentation methods are equally effective or suitable for specific applications.This study introduces a methodology for constructing robust and context-relevant datasets that support high model performance, even in data-limited scenarios and across different signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) conditions. The proposed approach involves filtering and statistically enriching environmental noise specifically for the task of bird sound recognition. We present a curated dataset comprising ten European bird species, annotated both temporally and spectrally, along with the corresponding codebase and noise resources used in the augmentation process. The dataset contains 20 hours of audio, including 7 hours and 45 minutes of active bird vocalizations.Experimental results show that although models trained on the augmented data exhibit a slight performance drop on clean audio, they significantly outperform baseline models under real-world noisy conditions. This demonstrates the importance of environmentally grounded data augmentation in building resilient acoustic recognition systems.

title: Edge Intelligence for Fire Disaster Mitigation Using IoT and TinyML
authors: Henry Eric Kapalamula, Ipyana Issah Mwaisekwa, Arthur Nathaniel Mwang’onda, Nomsa Florence Ndhlozi
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Internet of Things and Intelligence Systems (IoTaIS)
abstract: Fire incidents are a major problem around the world. Every year, there are more than 1.3 million fires, which kill more than 3,000 people and cause more than $25 billion in property damage. Traditional fire detection systems don’t work very well in places where resources are limited or far away because they have high false alarm rates, slow response times, and rely on centralized processing. This work presents the development of an autonomous IoT and TinyML-based fire detection system that addresses these limitations through edge-based machine learning and multi-sensor fusion. The proposed system combines an Arduino Nano 33 BLE Sense microcontroller with MQ-2 carbon monoxide, MH-Z19B carbon dioxide, AHT21B temperature, and GPS sensors to get complete fire signatures. The created TinyML Model got 94.71% accuracy on validation and 93.35% accuracy on deployment after Int8 quantization. The TinyML implementation allows for real-time inference with a latency of 1ms and low power use, making it ideal for solar-powered autonomous operation. The performance analysis shows that the quantized model still works well for classification while using less processing power for edge deployment. The system has multiple ways to send alerts, such as local buzzers, integration with a cloud platform, and mobile notifications. This makes sure that emergencies are handled quickly.

title: Diffusion Model–based Data Augmentation for Low-Resource Speech Emotion Recognition
authors: E. Vimal Raj, Rollapati Sailaja, Bommireddy Harshitha, M Pardhiv Praneeth, Bijinepalli Karthik
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Innovative Data Communication Technologies and Application (ICIDCA)
abstract: Speech Emotion Recognition (SER) is an important human-computer interaction subsystem but its accuracy cannot be achieved in low-resource conditions when labeled emotional speech examples are limited. Traditional methods of augmentation (pitch shift or noise injection) cannot reflect the features of temporal-spectral changes of emotional speech. To solve this problem, a diffusion model-based data augmentation model is proposed to produce high-fidel synthetic emotional speech samples, which do not alter emotion-specific acoustic patterns. The method presented uses the denoising diffusion probabilistic model to refine synthesized waveforms by iteration, thus augmenting training datasets with a wide range of, but realistic, samples. The datasets of the IEMOCAP and RAVDESS were treated experimentally with low-resource settings (25% labelled data). Findings show that when diffusion-generated samples are combined with the baseline dataset, the accuracy of the classification rises by 83.2 and 85.7 on IEMOCAP and RAVDESS, respectively, which is more than 15 points higher than with conventional augmentation. Moreover, there was an average improvement of 12.3 percent in F1-score and model robustness to speaker variability was also more pronounced. The results of these studies verify that diffusion-based augmentation is an effective attempt to overcome the lack of data, which can be utilized in low-resource settings to scale up the SER.

title: CampusVision: A Deep Learning-based Framework for Enrollment Forecasting of US Higher Education via IPEDS
authors: Abdur Rahman, Aimina Ali Eli, Naresh Kshetri
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Innovative Data Communication Technologies and Application (ICIDCA)
abstract: The ability to forecasting student enrollment accurately is becoming increasingly crucial for universities and colleges because of the demographic changes, the changing educational policies, and the impacts of global events. Nonlinear, dynamic trends of contemporary education data are not adequately captured often by traditional statistical methods, which calls for the need of more advanced data-driven forecasting techniques. The paper discusses CampusVision, a unique deep learning-based forecasting tool that predicts the enrollment trends in U.S. postsecondary institutions short term with the help of IPEDS institutional-level data from the year 2019 to 2023. State-of-the-art sequence modeling methods, especially mechanic LSTM networks, were traversed in depth across numerous configurations, different features of the demographic, and length of time-series input. The models trained using the largest number of demographic features (e.g., race/ethnicity, gender, and residency status) combined with longer input sequences significantly outperformed other tested configurations. The experimental evaluations proved that the CampusVision proposal delivered the most superior outcome performance with the early stages of least prediction errors when deploying a five-year historical window and expanded demographic features MAE: 0.25, RMSE: 0.74 standardized units. The in-depth error analyses strengthened the outstanding performance of the model in the case of diverse and large-enrollment institutions. CampusVision is an accessible, easily replicated, and scalable forecasting pipeline for resource allocation, policy responsiveness, and institutional planning, which institutional researchers and policymakers will be looking into. The initiative will proceed with the integration of additional predictive analytics.

title: DAF-Net: A Data-Analytics-Driven Adaptive Framework for Deepfake Detection Using Hybrid Deep Learning Models
authors: R. PushpaLakshmi
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Advances in Computing Research On Science Engineering and Technology (ACROSET)
abstract: The emergence of deepfake technology, which is driven by sophisticated Generative Adversarial Networks (GANs), has presented a significant cybersecurity threat. Cybercrimes including identity theft, social engineering, and disinformation now use deepfakes, which are artificially modified videos, pictures, or sounds. Because these synthetic dangers are constantly changing, traditional detection techniques sometimes fall short. The unique multi-modal system DAF-Net (Data-Analytics-Driven Adaptive Framework for Deepfake Detection), which integrates contextual data analytics and deep learning, is proposed in this research. DAF-Net combines a Transformer encoder for temporal inconsistencies, a Convolutional Neural Network (EfficientNet) for spatial features, and Wav2Vec 2.0 for audio-based manipulation detection. Together, these models provide highly accurate deepfake detection across modalities. One of DAF-Net's unique features is its Data Analytics and Visualisation Module, which assigns a Contextual Risk Score and identifies spreading trends using metadata. Tested on datasets like FaceForensics++, DFDC, and ASVspoof 2021, DAF-Net outperformed current techniques with an accuracy of 93.6% for video and 91.2% for audio deepfakes. 87% of high-impact threats have their priorities accurately determined by risk scoring. DAF-Net provides a scalable, intelligent defence solution for practical cybersecurity applications by fusing data analytics and adaptive deep learning.

title: Transforming Urban Mobility with Integration of Blockchain and Machine Learning
authors: Khaja Mannanuddin, Yerram Sneha, Munthu Raju, Velugori Sathish, Ranganath Kanakam
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Advances in Computing Research On Science Engineering and Technology (ACROSET)
abstract: Call-In Cab is the most sought-after means of transportation used the commuters in the metropolitan cities of India. Call-In Cab services is generated through an application in on-line mode that helps the commuters and cab drivers to communicate with ease. At times, there is possibility of ride rejection either by the cab driver or commuter depending upon the distance from source location of cab driver to destination which is the origin place of commuter to start travelling. So, the decision of cab driver need to be taken into consideration for the ride request received. The most important aspect in the proposed model is the storage of transaction keeping in view the well-being of the commuter as well the cab-drivers. In our article, we have consider the distance of journey by calculating the length between the starting and ending point of planned trip. These journeys are captured through a google map or Waaze maps and the extracted information data is preserved in blockchain framework and utilized in hyper ledger fabric platform as well analysed by a decision tree and XGBoost model algorithms. The outcomes of this article depicts the characteristics of socio-economic system that brings forth a fruitful utility that minimize the distance, time and raises the level of commuters’ well-being even during the late night hours.

title: Develop a Performance based Right-To-Recall e-Voting System in India using Blockchain Technology
authors: Vivek Pandey, Sahil Ambekar, Ravi Varma, Kunal Nandiwadekar, Aditya Pol, Poonam Patole
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Advances in Computing Research On Science Engineering and Technology (ACROSET)
abstract: India’s democracy allows citizens to make representatives accountable during elections, but no immediate mechanism enables them to remove representatives prior to a particular term ending if representatives are seriously underperforming or categorized as nonrepresentative. The Right to Recall (RTR) E-Voting System utilizing Blockchain Technology addresses this lack of an immediate mechanism, providing a safe, transparent, and performance-based recall mechanism that decades of political science literature have deemed necessary. Recalling representatives for statutory reasons is often a slow bureaucratic process that is influenced by political bias when it is allowed at all. Blockchain’s decentralized, immutable, and secure nature helps guarantee that votes are tamper-proof, verifiable, and transparent. The system employs smart contracts to automate much of the recall processes while reducing human intervention and our potential for manipulation. Existing cryptographic techniques such as Elliptic Curve Cryptography (ECC) and Zero-Knowledge Proofs (ZKP) guarantee a high level of security and voter anonymity in our proposed system. This paper describes the design, architecture, implementation challenges, and the impact of a blockchain technology-enabled RTR voting platform in the context of India.

title: AGRIConnect: Bridging Crop Price Prediction, Guidance and Market Access
authors: Saranya S, Arivuselvam S, Gugan I, Boobesh A, Harini R
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Innovative Data Communication Technologies and Application (ICIDCA)
abstract: The volatility of crop prices paired with an ineffective market for agricultural products also contributes to the cash flow of farmers, which ultimately leads to a loss of revenue for farmers in the industry. To address the issues outlined above, in this paper, we propose AgriConnect, an integrated system that combines crop price prediction, an area crop advisor, and an online auction system. For efficient prediction of future prices of crops, the system proposed in this paper implements Random Forest as the feature selection algorithm and Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) as the time series-based price forecasting engine. In addition, geo-spatial clustering algorithms such as K-means and DBSCAN are used to cluster the farming locations based on the environmental conditions in order to provide region-based crop recommendations. The Index integrates agronomic principles for practices that are applicable to the agricultural practices of that region, and for transparency purposes to minimize the use of intermediaries, a Farm Hub is included for direct market access. Consequently, the hybrid model offers farmers a fully explainable decision support system that is also accompanied by a set of optimized sustainable practices to improve their understanding and management of agricultural markets.

title: Spectral Analysis of Rakshastal and Manasarovar Lake using Hyperspectral Image Processing
authors: Ranjana Gore, Abhilasha Mishra, Pramod Bhalerao, Shweta Yadav, Abhishek Das
publish: 2025 5th Asian Conference on Innovation in Technology (ASIANCON)
abstract: The hyperspectral data has emerged as significant technology for mineral mapping and mineral identification. This study presents the first comprehensive analysis of Rakshastal Lake, highlighting its distinct mineralogical characteristics in comparison to the nearby Manasarovar Lake. No prior scientific work has examined this diversity till today, despite their geographical proximity.The proposed work utilizes hyperspectral imaging performing spectral classification using support vector machine technique and gave the accuracy of 84%. It uncovers the presence of toxic minerals at Rakshastal Lake, including sepiolite (93%), arsenopyrite (97.2%), and galena (94%). Additionally, hazardous minerals such as ammonium chlorite (92.2%), cassiterite (92.8%), and Mascagnite (93%) were identified which are having potential threats to human health and ecological systems. It uses modified atmospheric correction with adaptive technique for handling bad columns. The results improved much more with endmember stability assessment.In contrast, the mineral composition of Manasarovar Lake features sphalerite, diaspore, microcline, anorthite, wollastonite, samarium, and olivine and microcline amazonstone. The amazonstone is a potassium-rich mineral playing a critical role in maintaining Earth's ecological balance. The findings of this study provide a scientific basis for understanding the mineral diversity between the two lakes, offering insights into their environmental and health implications.

title: Knowledge Graph Construction Technology for Vehicle-Grid Collaborative Planning Based on Context-Aware Prompt Engineering
authors: Ming Gao, Lixiao Wang, Longming Xu, Ling Yuan, Yuanfa Cen, Hui Wu, Xiaorou Huo
publish: 2025 10th International Seminar on Computer Technology, Mechanical and Electrical Engineering (ISCME)
abstract: To address limitations in knowledge organization and reasoning in vehicle-grid collaborative planning, this paper proposes a knowledge graph construction method based on context-aware prompt engineering. Leveraging large language models (LLMs) and an optimized prompt strategy, the method enables effective knowledge extraction and structured storage within the vehicle-grid collaboration domain. The method supports structured knowledge storage, querying, and analysis, offering intelligent support for charging infrastructure deployment, power supply optimization, and safety management [1].

title: Data-Driven Optimization Algorithm for Unsaturated Soil Strength Models with Real-Time Sensor Communication in Slope Stability Assessment
authors: Chenghu Yin, Chuanyi Sui
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Innovative Data Communication Technologies and Application (ICIDCA)
abstract: This study presents a data-driven optimization algorithm (SCDA) based on real-time sensor communication to overcome the issues of inadequate dynamic parameter acquisition and communication uncertainty in unsaturated soil slope stability prediction. This method creates a sensor-enhanced unsaturated soil strength model (SE-USSM) by applying effective stress theory. Through an optimized suction effect function, this model incorporates multidimensional sensor information—which incorporates displacement, pore water pressure, matrix suction, and water content—into the shear strength formula. Additionally, this study presents a communication reliability correction mechanism to remedy delay, packet loss, and noise in sensor data. The legitimacy and stability of the input data are guaranteed by this novel mechanism. Additionally, the researchers created an adaptive optimization framework that combines evolutionary techniques with information entropy weighting. This allows for dynamic, iterative updating of strength parameters and slope safety factors. The experiment was carried out using continuous sampling data spanning 720 hours. From four perspectives, the findings revealed the following: (1) Compared to the previous method, the RMSE (FS) of SCDA was decreased by approximately 21.4% in the full-time safety factor estimation. This result is more than 40% lower than the error of the static model; (2) SCDA can achieve 1-2 hours of delayed recognition in unstable event detection; (3) SCDA's MAE was reduced by approximately 17.8% in the 24-hour advance prediction when compared to the GA method; and (4) SCDA maintained RMSE (FS) better than the Raw method in the communication packet loss rate sensitivity test when the packet loss rate was 15%.

title: Research on Grid-Connection Locations for Distributed PV Power Sources Considering Distribution Network State Analysis
authors: Bingbiao Shi, Zhigao Chen
publish: 2025 10th International Seminar on Computer Technology, Mechanical and Electrical Engineering (ISCME)
abstract: Distributed photovoltaic power generation has become a key research area in future renewable energy generation, alleviating regional power supply shortages. However, connecting a large number of distributed PV sources to the grid can significantly impact grid conditions. To address this issue, this paper proposes a method for determining the optimal grid connection location of distributed PV sources that incorporates distribution network state analysis. This approach aims to enhance system voltage stability and reduce distribution network losses. Through case studies analyzing different PV connection points, this research investigates the impact of distributed PV sources on network losses and voltage levels in chain-type distribution networks. MATLAB-based calculations and simulations confirm that optimal PV connection points effectively elevate system voltage, stabilize it near rated levels, significantly reduce losses, and improve distribution network operational conditions.
