title: PIMF-GNBO based Optimization for CNC Integral Impellers under Smart Electronic Communication Framework
authors: Ze Wang, Hong Chang
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Innovative Data Communication Technologies and Application (ICIDCA)
abstract: As a complex free-form surface part, the CNC machining process of the integral impeller puts forward higher and more complex requirements on path planning, machine tool stiffness and real-time optimization. With the target of solving the issues that general performance of traditional optimization methods degrades under communication delay, packet loss and noise interference. This study proposes an integral impeller CNC machining optimization algorithm based on the PIMF-GNBO (Probabilistic Information Maximization Fusion-Gaussian Neural Bayesian Optimization) algorithm. As an electronic optimization, the model is embedded in the intelligent electronic communication framework (SECF). This method realizes the joint optimization of machining accuracy, machining efficiency, energy consumption, tool wear and communication robustness through the probabilistic fusion of multi-source observation data and Gaussian neural Bayesian modeling. At the same time, in response to the problems of delay and packet loss. This model constructs a delay compensation prediction model and a weighted fusion mechanism. The experimental results of standard scenarios on the five-axis CNC machine tool DMU 75 monoBLOCK platform show designed model vs. traditional process and single GNBO optimization be better in different scenarios. The average cutting force is decreased from 186.4 N to 168.2 N, the maximum tool wear (VBmax) is decreased from 0.192 mm to 0.128 mm, and the total processing time is decreased from 162.3 min to 132.4 min. At the same time, under high feed rate conditions (600 mm/min), the surface roughness remains at 0.78 μm. However, the traditional process increases to 1.12 μm. Under severe communication interference conditions, the processing time only increases by 9.1%, and the surface roughness increases by about 20%.

title: Healthy and Alzheimer’s Disease Brain MRI Slices Classification using Deep Transfer Learning
authors: Feras N. Hasson, Suresh Manic K, Asiya Najeeb, Gnanaprakasam. C. N, S. Prabha
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Innovative Data Communication Technologies and Application (ICIDCA)
abstract: The incidence of the disease is higher in the elderly than in adults. Alzheimer's disease (AD) is an age-related condition that adversely affects memory and behaviour in older individuals. MRI serves as a standard imaging technique for the clinical identification of Alzheimer' disease (AD). Given the importance of identifying and treating AD, the use of computer algorithms for detection is widely regarded. This study introduces a deep-learning approach aimed at identifying Alzheimer's disease in axial-plane MRI slices. The various stages of this work encompass MRI-slice collection and resizing, feature extraction based on a deep learning model, SoftMax classification, and the identification of the best models based on accuracy. Additionally, a 50% dropout on features and serial feature fusion are employed to achieve a fused-feature vector, along with 3-fold based cross-validation as part of this scheme. The analysis involved 1500 images for each class, and the K-Nearest Neighbour classifier achieved an accuracy of 94%.

title: FPGA based TMDS Encoding and Decoding Protocol for Communication Interface Applications
authors: Ganesh Racha, Srinivasa Rao Perumalla, Yedukondalu Kamatham, Karthik Gupta Telukunta, Murtaza Ahmed Farooqui, Nagireddy Manaswini
publish: 2025 5th Asian Conference on Innovation in Technology (ASIANCON)
abstract: The present portable communication devices need high speed data transmission to support different interfaces and display technologies. These communication devices transmit data between transmitter and receiver blocks using a communication interface protocol. The interface is used for data transferring of image/audio/video processing applications. This work deals with the design of Transition Minimized Differential Signaling (TMDS) technology protocol based encoder and decoder using Verilog HDL and FPGA device targeting Spartan-7 FPGA and AMD Vivado EDA tools. The TMDS protocol supports video transfer interfaces for providing better flexibility and efficiency. This work proposes TMDS encoder and decoder algorithm to support best interfacing and high speed communication.

title: Development of a Wearable IoT-LoRaWAN Prototype for Continuous Patient Telemonitoring
authors: Nur Hayati, Rayhan Jatrashoma, Muhamad Yusvin Mustar, Willy Nasrullah, Magfirawaty, Berli Kamiel
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electronic and Electrical Engineering and Intelligent System (ICE3IS)
abstract: This study presents the development of a wearable prototype for continuous patient telemonitoring using IoT-LoRaWAN technology. The system measures oxygen saturation (SpO2) and heart rate, with real-time data accessible via an Android application. Performance evaluation was conducted by comparing the system readings against a commercial pulse oximeter across 100 samples. The results indicate an average accuracy of 98% for heart rate and 99% for SpO2, with maximum observed errors of $7 \%$ and $11 \%$, respectively. These variations are attributed to the absence of sensor enclosures and finger movement during measurements. The prototype demonstrates strong potential for remote patient monitoring in rural and hard-to-reach areas.

title: Design and Comparative Analysis of Arithmetic Logic Unit Using Full Adder in SCL 180nm CMOS Technology
authors: Dinesh Kumar Choudhary, D. S. Ajnar, Rupali Mahant, R. C. Gurjar, Rajesh Khatri, Anand Yadav
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Advances in Computing Research On Science Engineering and Technology (ACROSET)
abstract: This paper discusses the design and comparative analysis of an ALU (Arithmetic logic unit) using different types of full adders in SCL 180nm CMOS technology. This ALU is a two-bit unit that performs two basic operations binary addition and the AND operation. In this ALU an opcode is used for performing two basic logical operations, meaning 0 is used for addition and 1 is used for the AND operation. This ALU is perform quickly logical operations. It makes for computational work. In this design the main aim is to minimize the number of transistors, low power consumption, minimum delay and high performance. The design and comparative analysis of ALU are along with simulation results and this proposed design in SCL 180nm technology using Cadence Virtuoso EDA tools.

title: Gamified Conversational AI Tool for Improving Social and Emotional Skills in Children with Autism Spectrum Disorder
authors: Kanagamalliga S, Vinayagam P, Sowmithra R, Reshma S
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Innovative Data Communication Technologies and Application (ICIDCA)
abstract: An AI-powered conversational support tool has been proposed to enhance communication skills among children with Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD). The tool has been designed to address limitations found in traditional interventions, such as reduced accessibility, limited personalization, and low engagement. By employing chatbot technology integrated with lightweight machine learning and natural language processing models, scenario-based conversations have been simulated to provide children with safe opportunities to practice social interaction. Visual and emotional cues, including emojis and icons, have been incorporated to support emotion recognition and strengthen connections between feelings and responses. Guided conversational flows with hints, prompts, and feedback have been provided to explain appropriate and inappropriate responses while suggesting improvements. Gamification elements have been included to maintain engagement, and real-time feedback with progress tracking has been offered for parents and educators. The system has been designed with accessibility in mind, providing features such as text-to-speech, clear fonts, simple user interfaces, and multilingual options. By offering personalized, adaptive, and inclusive social coaching, the tool has been intended to empower children, parents, and educators with a scalable digital solution that fosters confidence, consistency, and motivation in social communication while reducing dependency on therapist availability.

title: A Review of Mitigation Techniques using Machine Learning to Secure Internet of Things
authors: Ruchi Chauhan, Kiran V. Ajetrao
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Advances in Computing Research On Science Engineering and Technology (ACROSET)
abstract: Internet of Things (IoT) is improving way of life with easy access to smart devices around us. The rapid growth of these devices introduces notable security challenges, such as vulnerabilities to hacking, data breaches, and unauthorized access. These issues can compromise privacy, critical infrastructure, and sensitive data. Although IoT has the latent quality to improve automation, efficiency, and consumer comfort across various applications, traditional security methods fall short of evolving threats. This paper explores the security challenges in IoT and their impact. It highlights application of Machine Learning (ML) in developing advanced mitigation systems for next-generation IoT. Additionally, Intrusion Detection Systems (IDS) and trust mechanisms strengthens security architecture by supervising network traffic and assuring device integrity. Integrating IDS, trust mechanisms, and ML approaches is vital for protecting the evolving IoT landscape. This paper aims to review different mitigation techniques used to secure IoT.

title: An Investigational Assessment on the Progressions of Breast Cancer Diagnosis via Medical Image Processing
authors: Shalini Sharma, Arpit Kumar Sharma
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Advances in Computing Research On Science Engineering and Technology (ACROSET)
abstract: Certainly, breast cancer (BrC) becomes one of the severe worldwide health concerns, imposing consistent developments in diagnostic procedures to augment primary identification and treatment. This paper will study and analyze how breast cancer recognition can be achieved through machine learning (ML) as well as how medical image processing (IP) serves as a crucial domain of study, pointing to improve initial detection and diagnostic accuracy. This methodology seeks to utilize several medical imaging practices, for example, magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) and sonography/ultrasound, alongside advanced computational methods to assess and diagnose such images. This review paper will examine the most recent advancements in breast cancer analysis through the applications of medical IP procedures. The recognition of breast cancer will adopt a multi-dimensional strategy. Mammography, which employs X-rays, continues to be a primary screening technique, while ultrasound and MRI provide complementary imaging views. Biopsy acts as a definitive diagnostic tool, involving tissue removal for microscopic examination and subsequent treatments. The findings derived from these ML and IP strategies will reveal numerous promising advancements in the diagnosis of BrC that leads to provide the suitable and timely treatment. Consequently, previous interventions as well as tailored procedure plans may become feasible that could significantly influence the final health of the patient.

title: An In-depth Review of Methods and Approaches for the Early Monitoring of Alzheimer's Illness
authors: Garima Gole, Kailash Chandra Bandhu
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Advances in Computing Research On Science Engineering and Technology (ACROSET)
abstract: Health care research is always evolving, exploring basic health, medicine, and wellness concerns. It includes multidisciplinary studies on health care policy, practice, and delivery. Researchers aim to improve patient-centred, safe, and effective health care. Researchers study area, socioeconomic status, race, and ethnicity differences. They want everyone to have inexpensive healthcare. Assessing the effects of telemedicine, digital health tools, and other medical innovations on individuals. Investigations are underway into how wearable technologies and electronic health records can improve patient health. Investigating sickness trends, risks, and preventative medication. Alzheimer's diagnosis is the healthcare system's biggest challenge. A neurodegenerative illness, Alzheimer's disease (AD) grows with time. It is the main reason of dementia, a group of symptoms that affect memory, thinking, and behaviour. Alzheimer's disease has three phases: mild, moderate, and severe. Age, inheritance, mild cognitive impairment, brain infections, and head trauma may cause it. Alzheimer's detection has been extensively studied. After reviewing the literature, this study discovered that different studies used different diagnostic criteria to detect early Alzheimer's disease. There were many restrictions. Based on a review of many research, this study demonstrated that many diagnostic methods for one patient allowed diagnosing disease of Alzheimer at an early stage. Machine Learning can help to identify Alzheimer's disease early from MRI, PET, and EEG pictures. simultaneously Building a hybrid model and hyper-tuning it with many diagnosis approaches can improve Alzheimer's Medical conditions detection.

title: Three-Layer Multi-Objective VRP Solver: Modified AGE-MOEA-II, Greedy Split Delivery, and 2-opt
authors: Erwin Nugroho, Abba Suganda Girsang
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electronic and Electrical Engineering and Intelligent System (ICE3IS)
abstract: Efficient transportation planning is essential for reducing operational costs in logistics. This study addresses the Multi-Objective Vehicle Routing Problem (MOVRP) involving heterogeneous fixed fleets, pickup-and-delivery, time windows, and split deliveries. A novel three-layer solution framework is proposed which integrates a modified Adaptive Geometry Estimation based MOEA (AGE-MOEA-II) for vehicle assignment, greedy algorithm for split delivery refinement, and 2-opt algorithm for route optimization. Enhancements such as nearest-neighbor sampling, Best-Cost Route Crossover (BCRC), and hybrid mutation method are incorporated into AGE-MOEA-II to improve feasibility and convergence. Comparative experiments on real-world data from XYZ Transportation demonstrate that the proposed method outperforms both modified AGE-MOEA and NSGA-II variants configured with identical operators. Experimental results show that the proposed method produces feasible solutions while achieving higher average hypervolume (0.80440), better average vehicle usage, travel distance, and number of splits. Compared to the manual routing method used at the company, the proposed method reduces vehicle usage by $3.03 \%$, total travel distance by $13.05 \%$, delivery splits by $6.40 \%$, and computation time by $93.50 \%$. These results highlight the effectiveness of incorporating problem-specific modifications into evolutionary algorithms for solving real-world constrained MOVRP applications.

title: Taming AI through Human-in-the-Loop Control and Ethical Supervision
authors: Tanya Mathur, Rachit Jain, Shruti Dubey, Tarika Singh Sikarwar
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Advances in Computing Research On Science Engineering and Technology (ACROSET)
abstract: Artificial Intelligence (AI) is transforming industries & redefining human experience, but its accelerated development creates urgent concerns around safety, control & values alignment. This paper presents the idea of "taming" AI, applying structures & procedures to make AI systems transparent, responsible & aligned with human values. It analyze alignment techniques like Inverse Reinforcement Learning & Human-in-the-Loop systems, as well as critical control processes like kill switches & regulatory supervision. It explores main challenges like explainability, bias, robustness, & energy efficiency. Using a multidisciplinary perspective, it emphasize the legal & ethical necessity of AI regulation & calls for coordinated effort from technologists, policymakers & society. The aim is not merely to reduce risks but to unlock AI's potential for transformation in a safe, secure & fair way. Hence this work helps to create a future where AI respects people, builds public trust, & supports progress for everyone in society.

title: Smart Retrofitting of Mechanical Water Meters Using Image Processing and IoT Approach
authors: Mahdi Asgharpour, Mohammad Arabian
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Control, Instrumentation and Automation (ICCIA)
abstract: With the worsening global water crisis, intelligent and accurate monitoring of consumer usage has become a vital component of sustainable water resource management. This paper presents a smart system designed to enhance the functionality of existing mechanical water meters by leveraging imaging technology and wireless communication. The proposed device periodically captures images of the meter's dial using a camera module and transmits them—either directly or via a local hub in multi-unit buildings—to a central server. The images are then processed using image processing algorithms to extract the consumption data. The system is based on an Internet of Things (IoT) architecture and is supported by dedicated software platforms for service providers and consumers to monitor and manage consumption data. Key advantages include the elimination of manual readings, support for volumetric pricing, anomaly detection, and alignment with smart city development goals. This solution offers a scalable and cost-effective approach to digitizing legacy water infrastructure.

title: Using Microneedle Array Electrodes for Transcutaneous Temporal Interference Stimulation: A Pilot Study on Sensory Threshold and Electroencephalogram
authors: Yonggang Liang, Pengxu Sun, Guangfa Xiang, Jixu Huang, Guanglin Li, Peng Fang, Naifu Jiang
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Biomedical Signal and Image Processing (ICBIP)
abstract: Transcutaneous temporal interference stimulation (TIs) is an emerging neuromodulation technique with growing potential for rehabilitation. However, optimal electrode designs and stimulation parameters remain underexplored. This pilot study explores the use of microneedle array electrodes (MAEs) for transcutaneous TIs, focusing on sensory thresholds and corresponding electroencephalogram (EEG) responses. Five healthy participants were recruited to assess the sensory threshold for transcutaneous TIs with different parameters, including pulse widths of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$100 \mu \mathrm{s}$</tex> and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$200 \mu \mathrm{s}$</tex> at a frequency of 4000 Hz. The study compared MAEs with conventional “wet” and “dry” electrodes in terms of stimulation thresholds and cortical responses. The results indicated that MAEs significantly reduced the stimulation threshold, with enhanced stability and adhesion due to their ability to penetrate the stratum corneum without affecting the dermis. EEG data revealed a clear P200 component, confirming somatosensory cortex activation in response to TIs. These findings suggest that MAEs offer a promising alternative to traditional electrode types, providing reliable and efficient stimulation for non-invasive neuromodulation applications.

title: DRL-Based Navigation of Mobile Robot in Unknown Environment
authors: Daniya Rehman, Harshaa Vardhana KV, Nargarjun N H, Karthikeya Katragadda, Rashmi Ugarakhod
publish: 2025 IEEE 15th International Conference on System Engineering and Technology (ICSET)
abstract: Autonomous robot navigation in dynamic, partially observable environments remains a challenge for traditional planners like A*. This work combines Deep Reinforcement Learning (DRL) with GRU/LSTM sequence models pretrained on expert A* trajectories for improved sample efficiency and stability. Two methods are tested: DDPG with Prioritized Experience Replay and SAC with LSTM actor-critic networks. In a 2D LIDAR-based simulation, SAC+LSTM shows faster learning, higher rewards, and better trajectories, demonstrating that sequence modeling enhances DRL-based navigation.

title: Machine Learning Approach for Soybean Peeling detection in the Soybean Peeling Machine
authors: Christofer Andrew Hadiprodjo, Winda Astuti, Ezra Peranginangin, Suryadiputra Liawatimena, Mahmud Iwan Solihin
publish: 2025 8th International Conference of Computer and Informatics Engineering (IC2IE)
abstract: Tempe is a traditional Indonesian food that has gained widespread recognition both domestically and internationally as a healthy source of plant-based protein. One of the critical steps in Tempe production is the peeling of soybean skins, a process that is traditionally performed manually. This method is labor-intensive and often results in uneven skin removal, potentially affecting the quality of the final tempe in terms of both texture and taste. In recent years, various efforts have been made to develop more efficient soybean peeling machines. However, most existing equipment operates mechanically and lacks an integrated quality monitoring system, making it challenging to ensure the consistency and cleanliness of the peeled soybeans. Meanwhile, advances in camera and machine learning technologies have demonstrated their potential in agricultural applications, such as sorting and classifying rice, onions, and other crops based on quality and cleanliness. This concept can be adapted to the soybean peeling process to enable more intelligent monitoring and control. By integrating image processing and machine learning technologies, it is expected that a more efficient and reliable soybean peeling machine can be developed, producing cleaner and higher-quality peeled soybeans and thereby supporting the production of higher-quality tempe. The detection system for the soybean final product involved machine Learning of YOLO (You Only Look Once) which is a relatively new machine learning technique. The effectiveness of the proposed system is evaluated experimentally. The results show that the proposed YOLOv8-based system achieved strong performance, with a precision of 81%, recall of 81%, and mAP@0.5 of 85%.

title: Optimal Path Planning of Articulated Robot Based on Sensor Data Fusion
authors: Niusha Tabrizi, Elahe Radmanesh, Behzad Moshiri
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Control, Instrumentation and Automation (ICCIA)
abstract: This article describes a remotely controlled robot that simulates the dynamics of articulated vehicles, designed to follow predefined paths while avoiding obstacles. Accurate positioning and location tracking of the robot at each moment is essential, which is achieved through sensor data fusion. First, raw and noisy data from several sensors are collected; then, these data are fused from different sources to provide more accurate and reliable position estimates. Once the position is determined, path planning guides the robot to its destination while avoiding obstacles. Two approaches are applied: an offline approach, where obstacle positions and dimensions are predetermined and MATLAB is used for path planning, and an online approach, where two ultrasonic sensors detect obstacles in real time and a dedicated algorithm for path planning is employed.

title: Gain Improvement of NMHA by Folded Structure at 1MHz for Undersea Application
authors: Badrul Amin Azahari, Kamilia Kamardin, Yoshihide Yamada, Muhammad Syamim Fitri Othman, Noorlindawaty Md Jizat, Idnin Pasha Ibrahim, Nozomu Ishii, Masaharu Takahashi, Naobumi Michishita
publish: 2025 IEEE International RF and Microwave Conference (RFM)
abstract: Undersea communication is a key component of emerging sixth-generation <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(6 \mathrm{G})$</tex> mobile networks. Due to the strong propagation attenuation in seawater, lowfrequency operation around 1 MHz is preferred for achieving practical communication distance. However, the large wavelength around 30 meters at 1 MHz, the antenna gain of a wearable antenna will be reduced. In this paper, a normal-mode helical antenna (NMHA) is employed as an efficient antenna. Firstly, self-resonant antenna structure is designed. Secondly, to increase the antenna gain, two elements folded, and three element folded structures are designed. Thirdly, for undersea use, antenna containing capsules is optimized. Then, antenna gain is evaluated through power density calculation. At antenna structure of single, double and triple folded cases, antenna gain of −24.44 dBi, −16.21 dBi, and −10.01 dBi are obtained respectively.

title: Modeling and Supervisory Control Design of on Board Computer Based on Petri Nets Tool
authors: Alireza Ahangarani Farahani, Mahdi Esmaeili Dashiri
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Control, Instrumentation and Automation (ICCIA)
abstract: In this paper, a logical model of the On-Board Computer and Data Handling (OBC&DH) subsystem of a small satellite is developed using the Petri Nets tool. In the first step, the various components of the OBC-including execution timings, potential faults, and logical operations-are modeled individually. In the second step, these component models are synchronized. In satellite systems, the OBC plays a pivotal role in scenario execution, data management, communications handling, logical control, health monitoring, and decision-making. Therefore, providing a clear, accessible, and graphically supported model-one that can also be translated into mathematical form-is of considerable value. Such modeling supports the design of supervisory control systems aimed at preventing faults in the OBC. This paper demonstrates how Petri Nets can be applied to implement redundancy strategies within the OBC&DH system.

title: Offset-Free Reference Tracking of Fractional-Order Systems Using Fractional-Order Model Predictive Control
authors: Hossein Hassanzadeh Yaghini, Hamed Kharrati
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Control, Instrumentation and Automation (ICCIA)
abstract: This paper introduces, for the first time, an offset-free Fractional-Order Model Predictive Control (FOMPC) framework designed for fractional-order systems. Its main innovation is the use of a fractional-order cost function instead of the integer-order costs employed in conventional MPC. The framework features a state and disturbance observer to achieve offset-free tracking, ensuring precise reference following despite system disturbances and model approximation errors. Numerical simulations demonstrate that the proposed FOMPC not only effectively eliminates disturbances but also significantly surpasses conventional MPC in terms of control accuracy and tracking performance, thereby establishing a new benchmark for controlling fractional-order systems.

title: Effect of IOT, Social Media, Social Value Creation on Social Innovation
authors: Agus Ryanto, Manggala Dhamma, Yuni Shara, Dicky Hida Syahchari
publish: 2025 8th International Conference of Computer and Informatics Engineering (IC2IE)
abstract: This research aims to examine the influence of the Internet of Things (IoT), social media, and social value creation, talking about social innovation in heritage tourism Yogyakarta, Indonesia. Digital stuff is advancing really quickly, technology has changed the way people interact with cultural heritage and has played a key role in opening new opportunities to support inclusivity and sustainable tourism practices. Using a quantitative research design, data were collected through a structured questionnaire distributed to 150 respondents, including students, workers, and community members involved in tourism-related activities. The independent variables in this research are the Internet of Things, Social Media, and Social Value Creation, while the dependent variable is Social Innovation. The results of data analysis using SmartPLS indicate that all three independent variables really have a big, positive impact on social innovation. Among them, IoT has the strongest impact, indicating that technological infrastructure plays a key role in enabling community-based innovation and stakeholder collaboration in tourism. Social media helps people become more visible and easier to interact. In addition, creating social value also helps preserve and encourage a stronger, more positive culture within our organization. These results really show how important it is to integrate digital technology with local community values to promote new ideas that are easy to access and actually help all stakeholders. This research contributes to the literature by providing a conceptual framework that harmonizes technological adoption, community participation, and social outcomes in the heritage tourism sector. The implications of this research indicate that policymakers and practitioners should support smart tourism initiatives that are attuned to cultural identity and local needs.

title: Generating Two-Level, GPU-Aware Mappings for Distributed Tensor Computations
authors: Botao Wu, Martin Kong
publish: 2025 34th International Conference on Parallel Architectures and Compilation Techniques (PACT)
abstract: We introduce a two-level scheme to generate GPUaware MPI/NCCL code for distributed tensor computations. Our generator takes the specification of a linearized Directed Acyclic Graph (DAG) of tensor operators and produces a global mapping solution that considers MPI communication (inter and intranode) and the local computation. The core of our generator is a new bit-vector representation that compactly models mappings as well as communication directions along the grid. We incorporate the 2-level mapping decisions into a non-linear formulation which is optimized in an iterative fashion with the Z3 SMT solver. The new mapper supports both NVIDIA NCCL, MVAPICH-gdr, allowing for better portability. We demonstrate the efficiency of our mapping generator on a set of matrix- and tensor- DAGs, on two multi-GPU clusters with NVLink or PCIe intra-node interconnect, and compare against the COSMA library and CTF framework, achieving speedups ranging from 2.6× (over COSMA) to 18× (over CTF).

title: A Comparative Study of 4G and 5G Impact on the Performance of Networked Control Systems
authors: Ehsan Badfar, Babak Tavassoli
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Control, Instrumentation and Automation (ICCIA)
abstract: This paper presents a comparative study of the impact of 4 G and 5 G wireless networks on the performance of networked control systems (NCS). Round-trip time (RTT) measurements are experimentally collected under both network conditions and modeled as a Markov process to capture stochastic delay dynamics. A delay-aware state-space model is developed, and mode-dependent optimal control and filtering strategies are applied to a benchmark system comprising three parallel DC-DC converters. The proposed framework is evaluated through simulation using realistic network delay data. Results show that 5G significantly outperforms <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{4 G}$</tex> in terms of control accuracy, estimation quality, and cost function minimization, highlighting its potential for time-sensitive applications such as autonomous and industrial control systems. This work offers quantitative insights into how emerging wireless technologies affect closed-loop control performance.

title: Machine Learning (ML) and Deep Learning (DL) Based Detection of Bacterial Heart Rot (BHR) in Pineapple Leaves
authors: Zakirah Zaludin, Nurul Syahirah Khalid, Nor Dalila Binti Nor Danial, Mohd Nasir Ayob, Mohd Zamri Hasan, Ismail Ishaq Ibrahim
publish: 2025 IEEE 15th International Conference on System Engineering and Technology (ICSET)
abstract: Bacterial Heart Rot (BHR) is a major disease affecting pineapple (Ananas comosus) cultivation, with detrimental impacts on agricultural sustainability and productivity. Conventional or traditional detection methods are often hindered by inconsistency and subjectivity. BHR infected fruits, even when harvested, exhibit accelerated spoilage, reduced shelf life, and increased post-harvest losses. Consequently, growers and farmers experience significant economic losses due to decreased marketable yield and the necessity for additional disease management interventions. Hence, this study investigates the possibility using Artificial Intelligence (AI) techniques for the detection and classification of BHR severity in pineapple leaves. A comparative analysis is conducted between a deep learning model utilizing Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN) and a traditional machine learning algorithm employing K-Nearest Neighbors (KNN). Both models are trained and tested on image-based datasets and evaluated using standard performance metrics, including accuracy, precision, recall, and confusion matrices. Experimental results indicate that while both models demonstrate reasonable classification performance, the CNN-based approach achieves superior accuracy and generalization capability. These findings proved the potential of AI-driven systems in supporting precision agriculture by facilitating timely, scalable, and reliable disease detection in crop management practices.

title: Leveraging AI Development Tools to Accelerate Learning, UI Implementation, and Educational Support in Mobile and Web Application Development
authors: Perry Weinthal, David Jaramillo, Alexandro Galvez-Vega, Alonzo Velez, Joshua Thaw
publish: 2025 IEEE Digital Education and MOOCS Conference (DEMOcon)
abstract: In recent years, tools powered by artificial intelligence have made their way into the hands of student developers, instructors, and teaching assistants. This paper shares our firsthand experience integrating these tools into courses focused on mobile and web application development. Our goal was to see how they could help students learn faster, build cleaner interfaces, and get better support while working through real-world projects.We used AI assistants to help students pick up new languages and frameworks more quickly. These tools let them ask questions in plain language and get working code or explanations right away—especially helpful when they were stuck or trying something new. They also sped up the process of turning user interface designs into actual code and helped with debugging, documentation, and version control.From a teaching standpoint, we leaned into a more hands-on, project-driven approach. This cut down on the risk of copy-paste dishonesty and made it easier to see who really understood the work. TAs also used the same tools—alongside platforms like Slack and Discord—to guide students with quick, clear answers without giving too much away.Overall, we found that these tools didn’t just boost productivity—they helped make the learning process more focused and more fair. When used carefully, they can support a deeper kind of engagement with the material and help instructors meet students where they are.

title: Recent Results of Machine Learning in Predicting Student Performance: A Systematic Literature Review
authors: Sandamini Neththikumara, M. W. P. Maduranga
publish: 2025 IEEE Digital Education and MOOCS Conference (DEMOcon)
abstract: The use of Artificial Intelligence (AI), particularly Machine Learning (ML), has gained momentum in education due to its potential to enhance learning outcomes and institutional effectiveness. One key application is the prediction of student academic performance, which supports early intervention and personalized education strategies. This systematic literature review investigates research on ML-based student performance prediction. Twenty peer-reviewed articles published between 2015 and 2024 were analyzed. The review focuses on the ML models employed, input features used, datasets analyzed, and evaluation metrics reported. Commonly used algorithms include Decision Trees, Random Forests, Support Vector Machines, and Logistic Regression. Frequently used input features include academic history, attendance, online activity, and class participation. Studies utilized both proprietary and public datasets, such as the UCI Student Performance dataset. Accuracy levels varied, with some models particularly deep learning and ensemble approaches achieving over 90% prediction accuracy. Despite promising outcomes, challenges remain. These include issues with data quality, limited model transparency, lack of external validation, and ethical concerns around data use and bias. This review highlights current trends, research gaps, and potential future directions for ethical and scalable implementation of ML in education.

title: Cost-Effective Image deduplication in Cloud Media Storage using Image Hashing and Deep Learning
authors: Bollipelly PruthviRaj Goud, M. Nagaratna
publish: 2025 5th Asian Conference on Innovation in Technology (ASIANCON)
abstract: The rapid growth of cloud computing demands efficient storage solutions to handle increasing amounts of user generated data (text, audio, and video). While cloud storage ensures availability, duplicate content such as near identical images in apps like Selfie World, wastes space and escalates costs. To mitigate this, we propose a perceptual hashing system that prevents redundant uploads by comparing SHA-256 encrypted keys. Newly generated keys are indexed and matched against existing keys to block duplicates. We combine multiple hashing techniques for near duplicate detection and employ a VGG16 based convolutional neural network (CNN) to improve accuracy. Experiments show that our approach reduces redundant storage for images or videos while preserving data integrity, achieving a maximum duplicate ratio of 1:40 with hash-based filtering. This optimisation significantly reduces costs without compromising accessibility.

title: Robust Person Identification via Multi-View Nose Images and Dimensionality Reduced Deep Features
authors: Vijay Katkar, Amruta Hingmire, Avinash Golande, Vinodkumar Bhutnal
publish: 2025 5th Asian Conference on Innovation in Technology (ASIANCON)
abstract: This paper presents a nose image-based person identification approach leveraging deep feature extraction and dimensionality reduction. A dataset comprising 7749 augmented nose images from 369 individuals was created using multi-view imaging and rotation-based augmentations. Deep features were extracted using the MobileNetV3-Small pre-trained model and reduced to various dimensions (350-500) using Kernel PCA. These features were classified using Decision Tree, Random Forest, XGBoost, SVM, and KNN models. Experimental results reveal that SVM consistently achieved superior performance, attaining 99.27% accuracy at 500-dimensional features. The findings demonstrate the effectiveness of combining transfer learning, Kernel PCA, and SVM for robust and accurate person identification using nose images.

title: Research on the SAR airport identification method based on improved ResNet and Data enhancement
authors: Lu Zhiyuan, Yang Wenhui, Li Dongtao, Meng Jun, Yu Yao, Shao Yuanzheng
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Intelligent Perception and Computer Vision (CIPCV)
abstract: In the field of synthetic aperture radar (SAR) image analysis, the effective identification of airports is crucial for national security and aviation management. While the existing identification methods face challenges such as limited data volume and interference. To this end, this paper presents an method based on improved ResNet50 network and data augmentation. On the basis of the classical ResNet50 network, the efficient channel attention (ECA) module is integrated to improve the accuracy of feature extraction, and the optimizer is used for adaptive learning rate adjustment to improve the training effect of the network. In terms of data set processing, this paper enriches the original image, mirroring and enhances the original image, and improves the generalization ability and anti-interference ability of the model. The experimental results show that the method achieves good recognition rate on the test set and shows robustness to noise interference.

title: A Tubular IPMC Sensor for Omnidirectional Flow Sensing under DC Stimulus
authors: Ning Tian, Libin Xue, Kejie Zhao, Hong Lei
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Mechatronics Technology (ICEEMT)
abstract: The artificial lateral line system, developed based on the sensing mechanism of fish lateral lines, provides a novel approach for detecting underwater environments, enabling underwater robots to achieve highly sensitive and accurate flow field perception. Ionic polymer-metal composites (IPMCs), which possess inherent underwater sensing and actuation properties, can be utilized as artificial lateral line sensors to collect information on flow. At present, most single IPMC flow sensors exhibit only onedimensional sensing capability; moreover, due to the intrinsic sensing mechanism of IPMC materials, these sensors are insensitive to DC stimuli. Therefore, IPMC sensors with twodimensional steady-state flow field sensing capability can offer stronger spatial perception and more comprehensive flow information for artificial lateral line systems. This paper presents a two-dimensional flow field sensor based on tubular IPMC, discusses methods for model decoupling and dimensionality reduction, and characterizes the sensor’s two-dimensional perception performance in laminar flow. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed tubular IPMC sensor can not only perceive DC flow excitation but also provide directional information, thereby achieving two-dimensional steady-state flow field sensing capability.

title: Comparison of Hybrid Parent Selection of RPL Protocol on Smart Grid Network
authors: Kanabadee Srisomboon, Kitipoth Wasayangkool, Natthinan Sakulpakdee, Wilaiporn Lee
publish: 2025 Research, Invention, and Innovation Congress: Innovative Electricals and Electronics (RI2C)
abstract: Multi-parent parent selection is the alternative method of RPL’s parent selection function which splits the data packets to parents according to the parents’ quality. Generally, multi-parent parent selections face the issue of performance tradeoff between PDR and network lifetime. In this paper, we provides a comparative analysis of the Trilateral Smart Switching (TSS) algorithm and Multipath TCP with Parent Forwarding (MPTCPF) for advanced metering infrastructure networks. The simulation results demonstrate that TSS consistently offers longer network lifetime and greater reliability than MPTCPF across a range of transmission distances and parent node configurations. While both methods maintain high packet delivery for short distances and smaller message sizes, TSS shows a clear advantage as network conditions become more challenging, including longer distances and larger data transmissions. TSS’s adaptive parent selection and load balancing strategies enable it to better withstand communication overhead and adverse channel conditions, maintaining robust performance where traditional approaches struggle. Additionally, increasing the number of parent nodes generally reduces network lifetime due to overhead, but TSS effectively mitigates this impact. Overall, these findings highlight the benefits of adopting TSS for applications requiring durable and dependable communication, particularly in demanding environments such as smart grid and industrial IoT networks.

title: Analysis of Drive Wheel Control Strategies for Large Electric Wheel Mining Trucks
authors: Qi Wu, Jian Liu, JunFeng Wang
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Computer Information Technology (AICIT)
abstract: The control of traction motors in electric wheel systems is central to the operations of large mining trucks, playing a vital role in ensuring safe and stable vehicle performance. Currently, large mining trucks operate under harsh conditions characterized by significant voltage fluctuations and high traction torque demands, which present substantial challenges for motor control. To address these issues, this study adopts Direct Torque Control (DTC), recognized for its superior dynamic response, to regulate the traction motors of large mining trucks. Based on the principles and mathematical models of induction motors and inverters, this paper analyzes the causes of torque ripple in conventional DTC when applied to traction induction motors. To mitigate these issues, an improved switching frequency scheme and an adaptive neural network-based controller are proposed, aiming to optimize the control structure and enhance DTC performance. The effectiveness of the proposed strategy is validated through experiments conducted on a traction motor test platform for large mining trucks.

title: Path planning of complex AGV system in tobacco feeding workshop
authors: Delun Shi, Hao Pang, Xingke Li, Zhenan Yu, Xiongwei Zeng, Anqi Hu, Mingli Xie, Wei Xu
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Computer Information Technology (AICIT)
abstract: In complex AGV cooperative operation scenarios, traditional path planning algorithms struggle to address the real-time coordination of dynamic obstacle avoidance and path conflicts. Clarifying spatiotemporal constraints in AGV path planning and overcoming the frequent occurrence of spatiotemporal path conflicts and low planning efficiency during AGV system operation are critical challenges. Consequently, this paper transforms the AGV path planning problem into a path optimization problem by constructing a grid map model of the tobacco feeding workshop. Meanwhile, an Improved Grey Wolf Optimization (IGWO) algorithm is proposed by enhancing the population initialization process of the original Grey Wolf Optimization (GWO) algorithm. This method aims to meet the requirements of AGV system path planning.

title: MEG Spectral Biomarkers of Alzheimer's Disease: Integrating MEG and MRI Features Using the BioFIND Dataset
authors: Alwani Liyana Ahmad, Ibrahima Faye, Zamzuri Idris, Jose Sanchez-Bornot, Roberto C. Sotero, Damien Coyle, Yaman Hamed
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Biomedical Signal and Image Processing (ICBIP)
abstract: Background: Alzheimer's disease (AD), the leading cause of dementia, disrupts brain communication through amyloid-beta and tau protein accumulation, leading to memory and cognitive impairments. Magnetoencephalography (MEG) and magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) offer non-invasive approaches to investigate these changes. Objective: To assess the value of combining MEG power spectral density with MRI-derived brain volumetrics and to evaluate a novel classification approach using sign-constrained logistic regression with L1 regularization (GLMNET). Methods: The BioFIND dataset, including MEG from 324 participants (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1 5 8 ~ M C I}$</tex>, <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1 6 6 ~ H C}$</tex>) and MRI for most subjects, was analysed. MEG source localization was performed using linearly constrained minimum variance (LCMV) beamforming and exact low-resolution electromagnetic tomography (eLORETA), which were applied separately for MEG's magnetometer (MAG) and gradiometer (GRAD) signals. MRI regional volumes were extracted with Freesurfer. Correlation-based feature preselection for different thresholds <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(0: 0.05: 0.25)$</tex> was applied, and classification was conducted using Monte Carlo of a replicated 10fold nested cross-validation. Results: Highest performance was obtained by combining LCMV MAG and GRAD with MRI features at 0 -correlation threshold, with an accuracy of 77.9 % and F1 score of 75.7 %. Conclusions: This study demonstrates the effectiveness of MEG MAG GARD integrated with MRI in distinguishing healthy ageing from cognitive decline. By comparing classification performance for different combinations, selected through multiple source localization methods and varying correlation thresholds, their potential importance was assessed more robustly.

title: Compact Corner Truncated Coplanar Waveguide Fed Monopole Antenna for UWB Applications
authors: Arslan Kiyani, Hijab Zahra, Fatima Ghulam Kakepoto, Umair Rafique, Syed Muzahir Abbas
publish: 2025 IEEE International RF and Microwave Conference (RFM)
abstract: A corner-truncated planar monopole antenna, utilizing coplanar waveguide (CPW) for ultra-wideband (UWB) applications, is proposed. With overall dimensions of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$28 \times 24 \times 0.787 \text{mm}^{3}$</tex>, the antenna features a rectangular radiating patch incorporating circular, square, and rectangular corner truncation configurations. The truncation of all four corners contributes to bandwidth enhancement. The antenna demonstrates excellent performance for UWB systems, offering an ultra-wide bandwidth ranging from 3.1 to 18.75 GHz. Critical design parameters, including return loss and radiation patterns, are thoroughly investigated. The proposed antenna demonstrates favorable impedance matching and consistent radiation patterns across almost the entire frequency band of interest.

title: Application of Internet Networks for Monitoring Irrigation and Fertilization of Oil Palm Using MQTT
authors: Karin Dwi Purnomo, Noveri Lysbetti Marpaung, Sakti Hutabarat, Edy Ervianto, Nurhalim Dani Ali, Rahyul Amri
publish: 2025 International Conference on Smart-Green Technology in Electrical and Information Systems (ICSGTEIS)
abstract: Oil palm productivity depends heavily on environmental conditions such as soil moisture, temperature, and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{p H}$</tex>. Manual irrigation and fertilization are often inefficient in large plantations. This study proposes an IoT-based monitoring system using the MQTT protocol to automate irrigation and fertilization. The system employs ESP32 microcontrollers with soil moisture, DHT22, and pH sensors. Data is transmitted via Wi-Fi to a HiveMQ broker, displayed on a Node-RED dashboard, and sent to users through Telegram notifications. The system was tested over seven days with two daily sessions. QoS analysis including throughput, packet loss, delay, and jitter showed excellent packet loss (0%), stable delay and jitter, and an average QoS index of 3.02 (“Satisfied”). Although throughput fell into the “Very Bad” category due to small packet sizes typical of lightweight IoT applications, this did not significantly impact system performance. Harvest yields also increased after implementation, though further validation with a control group and longer-term studies are required. The results indicate that the MQTT-based IoT system has potential to improve irrigation efficiency and productivity in oil palm plantations while optimizing water use.

title: Navigating the Relief Paradox: Harnessing Ai in Education for Quality Learning (Sdg 4) Among It Students
authors: Abricam S. Tinga, Valerie Vanessa M. Madajas, Suzette Crisostomo, Ronel F. Ramos, Mark Frederick V. Salonga, Victoria M. Reyes
publish: 2025 IEEE 15th International Conference on System Engineering and Technology (ICSET)
abstract: Artificial Intelligence (AI) is reshaping higher education by streamlining tasks, supporting personalized learning, and enhancing student engagement. Yet, these benefits coexist with risks of dependence, reduced critical thinking, and inequities-a duality termed the relief paradox. This study examined the perceptions of 138 IT students at FEU Institute of Technology to explore how they experience both the relief and paradoxical burdens of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$A I$</tex> in education, with attention to Sustainable Development Goal 4 (SDG 4) on inclusive and equitable quality education. Using a descriptiveanalytic design, validated survey instruments, and both descriptive and inferential statistics, results showed that students generally recognized AI's potential to reduce workload and improve inclusivity, while also expressing concern over ethical issues and overdependence. The study underscores the need for balanced integration of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$A I$</tex> in education, offering recommendations for curriculum, policy, and capacity-building to ensure responsible adoption.

title: A Comparative Analysis of LSTM Architectures for Ship Trajectory Prediction Using AIS Data
authors: I Wayan Sudiarsa, I Made Oka Widyantara, Made Sudarma, Ni Made Ary Esta Dewi Wirastuti
publish: 2025 International Conference on Smart-Green Technology in Electrical and Information Systems (ICSGTEIS)
abstract: Accurate ship trajectory prediction is critical for enhancing maritime safety and efficiency. While Long ShortTerm Memory (LSTM) networks are well-suited for this task, the choice of architecture can significantly impact performance. This paper presents a comparative analysis of four distinct LSTM-based models for ship trajectory prediction using highfrequency Automatic Identification System (AIS) data. We implement and evaluate four architectures: a standard (Vanilla) LSTM, a Stacked LSTM, a Bidirectional LSTM (BiLSTM), and a Sequence-to-Sequence (Seq2Seq) model. The models were trained on preprocessed trajectory data from a single vessel (MMSI 525003337) in the waters north of Bali. Performance was evaluated based on the spatial error calculated using the Haversine distance. The results indicate that the Stacked LSTM architecture achieved the lowest average spatial error of 0.573 km, outperforming the Vanilla LSTM (0.842 km) and the BiLSTM (0.856 km) for single-step prediction. This study demonstrates that a moderately deep architecture can provide a better balance of feature extraction and generalization for this type of trajectory data, offering valuable insights for the development of more robust maritime surveillance systems. Future work will enhance the model by incorporating Speed Over Ground (SOG) and Course Over Ground (COG) as additional input features, applying systematic hyperparameter optimization (e.g., Optuna or grid search), and conducting more fine-grained error analysis based on maneuver type and trajectory length.

title: MCL: Enhancing Cyber Threat Intelligence Entity Extraction based on Multi-level Contrastive Learning
authors: Yiyang Li, Dan Du, Jie Cheng, Hongna An, Xiaomeng Li, Ang Xia, Yaqiang Gong, Dongxu Han
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Computer Information Technology (AICIT)
abstract: Named Entity Recognition (NER) is a fundamental task in Cyber Threat Intelligence (CTI) analysis. However, it faces the challenge of lacking expert-annotated data. Existing supervised methods often require a large number of labeled samples to achieve good performance, whereas using Large Language Models (LLMs) for annotation introduces the problem of noise. To overcome these limitations, this paper proposes an NER framework that combines LLM-based data augmentation with multi-level contrastive learning. First, the framework leverages an LLM to expand a high-quality seed dataset by generating positive samples through meaning-preserving paraphrasing and hard negative samples by introducing errors such as boundary and type confusion. This enriches the training data without relying on direct, error-prone annotation. Second, the model is trained using multi-level contrastive loss: At the entity level, it pulls representations of the same entity type closer while pushing those of different types apart; at the sentence level, it ensures that semantically consistent sentence pairs are closer in the representation space. Experimental results on the CDTier and LADDER benchmark datasets demonstrate that the proposed method significantly outperforms traditional pre-trained fine-tuning models and LLM-prompting-based baselines in both precision and recall, validating the framework’s effectiveness.

title: A Comprehensive Review of Blockchain-Enabled Federated Learning and Hybrid Deep Learning Models for Cybersecurity Threat Detection
authors: Sangeetha N, M Kumaresan, A Suresh Kumar
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Innovative Data Communication Technologies and Application (ICIDCA)
abstract: The amount of cyber threats in a distributed environment that is dynamically growing cannot be addressed anymore through mere detection and secure learning practices. In this survey we can see the privacy preserving systems that incorporate the federated learning with that of blockchain to increase the confidence, the scaling ability and the adversarial attack resistance. Repeat neural networks that run via attention are presented since they are ideal at classifying threats due to their ability to diminish dimensions and federated models are provided that are trained to decrease reconstruction hyperparameters to accomplish triumph in attack detection. Comparative studies were also reported to use benchmark datasets like CICIDS2017, which they also consider as performance measures such as accuracy, precision, sensitivity, specificity, F1-score and MCC. This study internalizes the current practices and methods of research, research gaps, and future as far as modeling secure and efficient designs in decentralized systems are involved. This level of literature review will provide any researcher or practitioner with the knowledge of the existing state of the art regarding the development of techniques and methods to the border between blockchain, optimization and federated learning to provide the next generation solutions to the safeguarding of cybersecurity.

title: A Comparative Analysis of Two Level, Three Level and Multilevel H-Bridge Inverter Topologies
authors: Pankaj Ramtekkar, Jagdish Chaudhari
publish: 2025 5th Asian Conference on Innovation in Technology (ASIANCON)
abstract: Multilevel inverter technology has become a key enabler for high-power, medium-voltage energy control, driven by significant advancements in power electronic converters over recent decades. Despite offering numerous advantages, multilevel inverters face reliability concerns due to complex switching patterns and increased stress on semiconductor components. This paper presents a comparative simulation and analysis of cascaded H-bridge inverters with two, three, five, and seven voltage levels using MATLAB. The analysis focuses on evaluating performance by measuring Total Harmonic Distortion (THD) in the output voltage and current waveforms using Fast Fourier Transform (FFT). Furthermore, it examines the voltage and current stress on individual switches. The results indicate that increasing the number of inverter levels reduces both switch stress and harmonic content, thereby improving overall power quality. These insights underscore the suitability of higher-level inverter topologies for applications like electric vehicles (EVs), where efficient and reliable power conversion is essential.

title: SDLA-Net: Text-to-Image Generation Method Based on Semantic Disentanglement and Local Refinement Alignment
authors: Xuanxuan Huang, Fengguang Zhou, Zhijun Zhou, Guanxiu Wang
publish: 2025 10th International Seminar on Computer Technology, Mechanical and Electrical Engineering (ISCME)
abstract: With the development of natural language processing and generative adversarial networks, text-to-image generation has become a key research area in cross-modal tasks, with wide applications in artistic creation and virtual scene design. However, in long-text scenarios, irrelevant semantic information can introduce noise, while multiple key objects and attributes are often misaligned or missing in the generated images. To address these issues, this paper proposes a text-to-image generation method based on semantic disentanglement and local refinement alignment. The approach uses a stacked generative adversarial network that integrates multi-granularity text features-including sentence-level, entity-level, and word-level-with visual features. A semantic disentanglement and alignment module first employs an attention mechanism to filter redundant features and extract key visual contexts. An entity fusion block then aligns salient entity features with corresponding image regions. Finally, a generator conditioned on sentence-level features ensures global semantic consistency. Experiments on the LN-COCO and LN-OpenImages datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed method for generating images from long and complex textual descriptions.

title: Optimized Blood Matching System
authors: Tarun Koda, Veera Reddy Aduru, Asritha Gulipilli, Gokul Sumanth Nallagonda, Veena Sravanthi Geddapu
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Innovative Data Communication Technologies and Application (ICIDCA)
abstract: A web-based tool called the Optimized Blood Matching System (OBMS) was created to improve the effectiveness and precision of blood transfusion administration. Developed as part of an academic project, OBMS allows users to register their blood group and location, enabling the system to identify both exact and compatible alternative donor matches through a Basic compatibility algorithm. Initially implemented within a college environment, the system facilitates donor registration among students and faculty, ensuring a reliable local donor network while validating its effectiveness. The Optimized Blood Matching System (OBMS) introduces several innovative features that distinguish it from existing donor management platforms. It integrates real-time GPS with privacy-preserving communication to ensure both efficiency and data security. Unlike conventional systems that focus solely on donor–recipient matching, OBMS establishes a unified ecosystem that connects donors, recipients, and blood banks. To further enhance user trust, it incorporates a call privacy feature in which personal phone numbers remain hidden during communication. Additionally, the system provides instant notifications filtered by Geo location, allowing nearby donors to be alerted promptly during emergencies. While initially deployed in a college environment, OBMS is designed to scale seamlessly to hospitals and large community networks, thereby extending its impact to a broader health care infrastructure OBMS shows how technology- driven solutions may improve emergency response and guarantee timely blood availability by increasing match accuracy, cutting down on search time, and maximizing health care resources.

title: Performance Comparison of Palm Olein Oil and Mineral Oil as Insulating Liquids in Distribution Transformers
authors: Pawin Jiamklin, Chatchai Suppitaksakul, Ouichai Siriwajana, Chalermsak Wuttisela, Nattakorn Maneewan
publish: 2025 International Conference on Power, Energy and Innovations (ICPEI)
abstract: This paper presents a comparative study of insulating liquids performance in distribution transformers using mineral oil and palm olein oil. Two 100 kVA transformers with matching specifications are used in this study. Testing is conducted according to IEC and IEEE standards, covering temperature rise test, insulation system test, and electrical resistance test. The test results provide fundamental information on the feasibility of using palm olein as a biodegradable alternative insulating fluid for distribution transformers. It can also be used as information to improve the potential of palm oil for use as a suitable liquid insulator in the future.

title: A Human-Centric AI Tutoring System: Integrating Explainability and Personalization for Improved Learning Outcomes
authors: Suhail. T, K. Rajakumari
publish: 2025 5th Asian Conference on Innovation in Technology (ASIANCON)
abstract: Intelligent Tutoring Systems (ITS) have transformed the online learning scenario, but in many ways are lacking a certain explainability and a high level of personalization, hindering trust and engagement among learners. A humanistic framework for AI tutoring that combines explainable AI and adaptive learning approaches, aiming to enhance cognitive and emotional learning processes. The system uses a Weighted Learner Vector (WLV) as a profiler, SHAP and LIME for transparent feedback, and its instructional plan is powered with reinforcement learning. Training and validation were done using the EdNet data, whereas Unity ML-Agents were used to simulate it in real time. An analysis of experimental data indicates 42.2 percent improvement of learner engagement, 65.2 percent decrease of misconceptions, and an average 30% gain of post-test scores. The system also demonstrated a 68.3% decrease in latency, a Feedback Trust Index of 0.902, and high emotional adaptability. These results demonstrate that the system has the potential to provide successful, credible, and individualized tutoring sessions to various populations of learners.

title: Non-destructive interconnection reliability validation by warpage for ball grid array packages using digital image correlation
authors: Seongkyu Choi, Minjeong Sohn, Hyunwoo Nam, Hyunwoo Jung, Eun-Ho Lee, Tae-Ik Lee
publish: 2025 20th International Microsystems, Packaging, Assembly and Circuits Technology Conference (IMPACT)
abstract: Heterogeneous integration and large-area system-in-package (SiP) designs accelerate thermomechanical reliability risks because coefficient of thermal expansion (CTE) mismatch induces package warpage and localized strain at solder interconnections. Although finite element analysis (FEA) has been widely used to study package reliability, its application to large-scale packages often requires simplification of heterogeneous material structures. Digital image correlation (DIC), in contrast, is a non-contact, full-field optical method capable of sub-pixel accuracy, and has emerged as a complementary technique to shadow moiré for package warpage measurement. Nevertheless, most prior studies have investigated warpage and strain separately, and their direct correlation in realistic board-level packages remains unclear. In this study, we explore a non-destructive approach that links global warpage to local strain in a 400-µm-pitch BGA assembly by combining full-field 3D DIC, micro-scale 2D DIC, and FEA calibrated with measured material properties. Under heating to 125 °C, the chip-only package transitioned from a cry mode to a flatter tendency (net warpage ≈33.9 µm), while the board-level package maintained a saddle mode with nearly unchanged warpage (≈ 5.5 µm) due to PCB bending stiffness. Despite this, 2D DIC revealed strain localization at the solder periphery and adjacent solder mask, which was not fully captured by simplified FEA. These findings demonstrate that suppressed global warpage at the board level corresponds to redistribution of bending deformation into localized strain, supporting DIC as a non-destructive basis for interconnection reliability assessment.

title: Internet of Things (IoT)-Based Fire Evacuation System: A Design Science Research Approach
authors: Yakob Utama Chandra, Kobthong Ladkoom, Chanata Somanawattana, Anderes Gui
publish: 2025 Research, Invention, and Innovation Congress: Innovative Electricals and Electronics (RI2C)
abstract: Big cities with skyscrapers, particularly Jakarta, may face the risk of fires, thus demanding the need for an effective evacuation system. The current evacuation systems are still conventional and often based on the shortest route, frequently overlooking security aspects critical during fires. This study uses the design science research method with six stages, namely problem identification, define objective, design and development, demonstration, evaluation and communication. At each stage there is a process that can be learned to provide results that are in accordance with the objectives of this study, then designs an innovative and adaptive prototype of a fire evacuation system utilizing advanced technology including data processing units, sensors, actuators, communication protocols, and algorithms designed to enhance safety. The objective of this system is to identify and demonstrate evacuation routes that are not only the shortestbut also the safest based on dynamic surrounding conditions during fire disasters. Thus, this system has significant potential to improve the safety of building occupants.

title: KEEBA: A Novel Key Exchange-Free Encryption for IoT Gateway Communications Using Email-Based Authentication
authors: Longwani Chimenge Perry, Kaira Pious
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Internet of Things and Intelligence Systems (IoTaIS)
abstract: This paper introduces KEEBA (Key Exchange Elimination Through Email-Based Authentication), a novel encryption protocol that eliminates explicit key exchange through gateway-mediated email authentication. Unlike conventional methods that depend on key exchange and risk interception or man-in-the-middle attacks, KEEBA leverages local gateways to perform cryptographic operations while IoT sensors communicate using lightweight protocols. Encryption keys are dynamically derived from email authentication credentials and normalized service prefixes, enabling both sender and recipient to generate identical keys independently, without transmission. Experimental evaluation demonstrates that KEEBA achieves faster encryption and decryption times and requires less memory than RSA, AES, and KUDOS, while preserving strong security. By removing the need for key exchange, the protocol resists interception attacks and mitigates a critical vulnerability in resource-constrained environments. KEEBA offers a lightweight, secure, and attack-resilient alternative for IoT ecosystems, particularly in sensor networks where computational resources are limited. This approach ensures end-to-end security without compromising efficiency, making it a promising solution for next-generation IoT applications.
