title: LoRaBridge: LoRaWAN based Range Extension for Zigbee Devices and Automations
authors: Henri Ruotsalainen, Tobias Dam
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Internet of Things and Intelligence Systems (IoTaIS)
abstract: ZigBee-based home automation devices are popular with consumers for simple tasks like smart lighting, detecting occupancy, or monitoring temperature. Although such devices can be mounted flexibly e.g. in an apartment, the wireless range of the ZigBee protocol prohibits installations to far away locations such as cellars or attics. Furthermore, a ZigBee home automation gateway usually requires an Internet connectivity, which further complicates setups, where a home WLAN/LAN is not directly available. To improve the range of ZigBee, we propose the LoRaBridge home automation hub, which utilizes a bi-directional LoRaWAN connection to carry device data and home automation configurations between the hub and a user gateway. To reduce LoRaWAN link loading we apply dictionary based compression and payload reduction techniques. According to the experimental validation results, our system can forward data from several ZigBee devices and configure easily remote automations using only a single LoRaWAN link. Additionally, with our payload reduction techniques the worst case data transmission latency due to LoRaWAN signaling can be reduced from hours to minutes.

title: DiabBot: An AI-Powered Chatbot for Diabetes Risk Assessment, Prevention, and Management Using Machine Learning
authors: Dipti Theng, Soumin Mujumdar, Vidhi Binwal
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Internet of Things and Intelligence Systems (IoTaIS)
abstract: Diabetes Mellitus is a health problem that occurs in more than 537 million adults in the world, which poses serious threats such as under-diagnosis, lack of accessibility to diagnostic facilities, inefficiency in risk assessment because of manual operations, and lack of compliance to treatment. The conventional methods of diagnosis are still expensive, time consuming and not always available to the underserved and rural areas. The present paper presents DiabBot, an AI-based chatbot that combines the concepts of Machine Learning (ML) and Natural Language Processing (NLP) to provide a full range of diabetes care by providing real-time risk analysis, tailored prevention, and continuous management. DiabBot uses an XGBoost classifier which has been optimized using the RandomizedSearchCV to predict diabetes risks based on clinical and lifestyle parameters using the Pima Indians Diabetes Dataset. The model has a 78% accuracy and recall maximized to 82; this is because it focuses on the early detection of at-risk individuals. Gemini NLP model allows us to interact naturally in the form of a conversation, create unique diet plans, exercise plans, and lifestyle advice taking into consideration the user preferences and allergies. The system architecture is based on a React.js front-end and Flask back-end, and has built-in modules, such as meal planner, exercise tracker, nutrition chatbot, and the capability to search doctors in the city using Maps API. The collaboration between patients and healthcare providers is easy, and this is done by means of structured health reports generated using the jusPDF library. The experimental analysis shows that DiabBot is characterized by 78% prediction. In contrast to the current diabetes chatbots, which mainly rely on ML models, and do not have the full NLP capabilities, DiabBot is a complete end-to-end platform that is built around risk assessment, prevention, and management in one interactive platform. DiabBot fills the basic shortcomings of the current healthcare system by providing personalized, affordable, and accessible diabetes care through predictive analytics and a chat robot that communicates with patients, which is especially valuable to less-privileged population segments with access to traditional healthcare options.

title: "Application of Electronic Nose Technology for Aroma Profiling and Quality Assessment of Seasonings"
authors: Kornkanok Chujan, Varanya Somaudon, Teerakiat Kerdcharoen
publish: 2025 International Conference on Power, Energy and Innovations (ICPEI)
abstract: Seasonings such as fish sauce, seasoning sauce, soy sauce, and oyster sauce are essential for augmenting taste and fragrance in culinary practices. Their sensory attributes are shaped by ingredients, fermentation, and production techniques. Conventional sensory evaluation techniques dependent on human panels frequently exhibit subjectivity and inconsistency. This study utilizes an electronic nose (e-nose) with eight sensors to detect volatile organic compounds (VOCs) emitted from four types of spice sauces. Principal Component Analysis (PCA) was employed to examine sensor responses, derive aromatic characteristics, and classify scent profiles. The findings indicate that the electronic nose successfully differentiated among sauce varieties, with Sensor 4 exhibiting the greatest sensitivity to critical volatile organic chemicals, including sulfur compounds and amines. PCA demonstrated clear clustering patterns among samples, indicating variations in raw materials and processing methods. These findings validate the efficacy of e-nose technology as a dependable instrument for product categorization, differentiation, and quality assurance in the food sector. The integration of sensor-based VOC detection with statistical modeling underscores the potential for real-time quality evaluation in food production settings.

title: Single VCII-based Negative Capacitance Multiplier
authors: Montree Siripruchyanun
publish: 2025 Research, Invention, and Innovation Congress: Innovative Electricals and Electronics (RI2C)
abstract: A negative capacitance multiplier (NCM) based on a second generation voltage conveyor (VCII) is introduced in this article. The circuit implementation comprises only 1 VCII and 3 passive elements composed of 2 resistors and 1 capacitor. Its multiplying capacitance can be controlled by the 2 external resistors without any circuit condition. The proposed topology is very understandable and can operate for a wide range of frequencies with very low sensitive to temperature variation. The total power consumption of the proposed NCM is 0.182mW at ±1V supply voltages.

title: AI Technology Empowering ESP Teaching: Practical Methods for Enhancing Learning Outcomes
authors: Lingbo Wang
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Computer Information Technology (AICIT)
abstract: This paper explores how to use artificial intelligence (AI) technology to improve the teaching quality of ESP (English for Specific Purposes) teaching. It first introduces the basic principles and functions of AI technology, then explains the positioning and objectives of ESP course, on this basis, the teaching model has shifted from the traditional teacher-student structure to a teacher-artificial intelligence-student structure, integrating the cultivation of human-computer collaborative abilities into the teaching system. The article explores the methods of AI-assisted teaching: teachers utilize AI technology to develop learning resources, conduct teaching activities through intelligent online platforms, and design output-oriented teaching activities that incorporate the cultivation of human-computer interaction; students work on output-oriented tasks with the help of AI, thereby enhancing their professional competence, language proficiency, and information literacy. Practice has shown that these measures can significantly improve students' learning outcomes and teachers' teaching efficiency, providing new ideas and methods for ESP teaching.

title: Educational Artificial Intelligence Fact-Checking System
authors: Chawalit Kimchuwanit, Panita Wannapiroon, Prachyanun Nilsook
publish: 2025 Research, Invention, and Innovation Congress: Innovative Electricals and Electronics (RI2C)
abstract: Artificial intelligence (AI) systems for fact-checking when integrated into educational processes have become a potential approach to enhancing decision-making and learning outcomes. This research brings together knowledge from various fields to examine the role of AI in supporting fact-checking in the context of education. Create content that is appropriate for individual learners and allocate resources effectively to promote learner achievement, while addressing ethical issues and governance frameworks that emphasize fair access and responsible use. This research uses the analysis of the co-occurrence network of keywords from academic articles to map the knowledge of AI systems for fact-checking in the academic sector. The size of the node shows the frequency of its appearance. The color of the nodes reflects the main topic groups, which are divided into five groups: (1) cybersecurity and privacy, (2) AI applications in mental health, public health, and learning accessibility, (3) industrial systems and educational technology infrastructure, (4) sustainability and smart environments that support contextual learning, and (5) crisis response and public policy, especially misinformation management in situations such as COVID-19.

title: Fermat Spiral Spoof Plasmonic Skyrmions for Ultra-Compact and High-Sensitivity Sensing
authors: Zechen Tian, Houtong Qiu, Hongyi Li, Jindi Huang, Fuheng Wang, Zhuo Li, Liangliang Liu
publish: 2025 18th IEEE United Conference on Millimeter Waves and Terahertz Technologies (UCMMT)
abstract: This work presents a fermat spiral spoof plasmonic skyrmions for ultra-compact and high-sensitivity dielectric materials sensing. Compared with Archimedes spiral configurations, the proposed Fermat spiral structure exhibits broadband quasi-equidistant multi-mode resonances similarly and robustness while maintaining skyrmions topological field distributions. In addition, owing to the progressively decreasing spacing of the Fermat spiral, the resonator achieves significantly reduced dimensions while preserving the same effective waveguide length. Simulation results demonstrate that the proposed sensor achieves a normalized sensitivity of up to 5.81% while achieving a 30.16% size reduction compared to conventional designs. These features provide a new configuration approach for dielectric material measurement sensors at deep subwavelength scales.

title: Design of a Curved Conformal Microstrip Patch Antenna
authors: Zijia Yu, Lin Guo, Yunfei Qiang
publish: 2025 18th IEEE United Conference on Millimeter Waves and Terahertz Technologies (UCMMT)
abstract: Conformal antennas have garnered significant attention in modern wireless systems due to their ability to seamlessly integrate with curved platforms while preserving aerodynamic and structural integrity. This paper presents a curved conformal microstrip patch antenna array, achieving a 20 % fractional bandwidth with active VSWR below 3.0 under scanning conditions of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\pm \mathbf{2 0}^{\circ}$</tex> in azimuth and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\pm \mathbf{4 5}^{\circ}$</tex> in elevation. The low structural profile (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$0.13 \lambda_{0}$</tex>) and lightweight construction further demonstrate its suitability for aerospace and mobile platforms requiring stringent size-weight compliance.

title: Design of a Broadband Circularly Polarized Reflectarray with High Polarization Purity
authors: Fan Wu, Yantao Ao
publish: 2025 18th IEEE United Conference on Millimeter Waves and Terahertz Technologies (UCMMT)
abstract: In this paper, a novel broadband circularly polarized reflectarray covering the entire Ka-band is proposed. An S-shaped patch structure is embedded at the center of the electric dipole to achieve circularly polarized reflection functionality. Based on the element rotation method, phase modulation for incident circularly polarized waves can be achieved. The simulated results show a 3-dB gain bandwidth and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$1.5-\text{dB}$</tex> axial ratio bandwidth of 42.4% and 42.4%, respectively. The peak aperture efficiency of 58.2% is obtained. The operating bandwidth of the reflectarray covers the entire <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$K a$</tex>-band, demonstrating excellent broadband performance. The proposed reflectarray finds versatile applications across various fields, including satellite communication networks and advanced radar systems.

title: Circularly Polarized Transmitarray Antenna Based on Receiver-Transmitter Metasurface
authors: Yixuan Zhu, Gang Zhao, Longjie Cheng
publish: 2025 18th IEEE United Conference on Millimeter Waves and Terahertz Technologies (UCMMT)
abstract: This work proposes a novel circularly polarized (CP) transmitarray antenna featuring rotatable linear-to-circular polarization conversion elements for efficient wavefront manipulation. The novel transmitarray cell is able to convert x-polarized incident waves to left-hand circularly polarized (LHCP) wave. A compact 208-element array fed by a horn antenna achieves remarkable performance characteristics: the peak gain is 22.5 dBic at 9.8 GHz, corresponding to an aperture efficiency of 58%. The 3 -dB gain bandwidth is 36.3%, while the axial ratio (AR) bandwidth is <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{2 5. 6 \%}$</tex>. Simulated characteristics confirm the design's effectiveness in combining broadband CP radiation, compact structure, and high gain performance, making it particularly suitable for modern communication systems.

title: A Novel Space-Mapping-Based Multiphysics Optimization Approach for Four-Pole Waveguide Filters
authors: Xiao Yang, Haitian Hu, Wei Zhang, Feng Feng, Zhiguo Zhang
publish: 2025 18th IEEE United Conference on Millimeter Waves and Terahertz Technologies (UCMMT)
abstract: Space mapping, a well-established surrogate-based technique for accelerating electromagnetic (EM) design, is extended here-for the first time-from EM-only optimization to the multiphysics optimization of high-power microwave filters. Multiphysics analysis, which integrates EM with additional physical domains, is critical for accurately designing high-performance microwave components. In this paper, we review a technique that exploits space-mapping-based surrogate model consisting of two mapping functions with a EM domain coarse model to perform the multiphysics optimization. The coarse model leverages EM single-physics responses, approximated by an artificial neural network (ANN) to reduce the need for repeated EM simulations. Frequency and explicit input mappings further refine the surrogate model, while parallel evaluation of EM and multiphysics samples supports efficient model construction. A trust region algorithm adapted to this framework improves convergence behavior. By exploiting inexpensive EM data, the proposed method enables larger and more effective optimization steps, achieving superior performance compared to conventional multiphysics optimization methods that do not use space mapping. The approach is demonstrated and validated through the design of a high-power waveguide filter.

title: Path Loss Prediction at Terahertz Frequency Band in Indoor Environment Based on the Fusion Strategy
authors: Xu Zhang, Yuanjian Liu, Shuangde Li
publish: 2025 18th IEEE United Conference on Millimeter Waves and Terahertz Technologies (UCMMT)
abstract: This study investigates a convolutional neural network (CNN) integrated with gradient boosting decision trees (GBDT) for wireless channel modeling in an indoor environment. The model is applied to predict path loss at 280-290 GHz, and its performance is compared with CNN, GBDT, and RF models. It is indicated by the comparison of multiple sets of parameters that the prediction accuracy of CNN is improved by this algorithm.

title: Highly Stretchable Shape Memory Hydrogels with Silk-Fibroin Semi-Interpenetrating Networks for Drug-Delivery Microrobot
authors: Zhengdong Feng, Jiaqi Xie, Wei Li
publish: 2025 18th IEEE United Conference on Millimeter Waves and Terahertz Technologies (UCMMT)
abstract: Shape memory hydrogels (SMHs) provide hydrophilic and stimuli-responsive platforms for biomedical devices but suffer from mechanical fragility. To address this issue, we reinforced poly (acrylic acid) (PAA) based SMHs with biocompatible silk fibroin (SF) via UV-initiated co-crosslinking. Benefited from the semi-interpenetrating networks, PAA-SF6% binary SMHs exhibit remarkably improved mechanical stretchability that is more than 10-times larger comparative to neat PAA analogues without deteriorating the shape memory functionality. On this basis, a bioinspired microrobot mimicking lotus seedpod was engineered to execute programmable shape transformations-shrink to seal active substances in holes, and recover to release them. This microrobot is promising for drug delivery that can be delicately controlled by thermal and biochemical stimuli. The strategic SF incorporation not only strengthens the deformability of general SMHs, but also expands the operational scope of SMHs in advanced biomedical engineering applications.

title: Sub-THz 2-D Beam Scanning SSPP Leaky-Wave Antenna Based on Series Feeding Network
authors: Yuanxi Cao, Wencheng Hou, Jianxi Gao, Sifan Wu, Sen Yan
publish: 2025 18th IEEE United Conference on Millimeter Waves and Terahertz Technologies (UCMMT)
abstract: A spoof surface plasmon polariton (SSPP) leaky-wave antenna (LWA) is proposed to achieve passive 2-D frequency beam scanning in the sub-THz band. The antenna is composed of two layers of waveguide components, i.e., the LWA array and the series feeding network. The top LWAs front-to-end series by the bottom series feeding network, achieving a compact structure. The orthogonal phase gradients from the LWA itself and the series feeding network make the antenna generate the frequency scanning beams with different beam directions in both pitch and azimuth planes. Moreover, to improve the beam scanning range of the antenna, SSPP is used to enhance the dispersion characteristics of the LWA units and the series feeding network, making the design can realize 2-D <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\pm 30^{\circ}$</tex> steered beams within 0.26 to 0.33THz.

title: A Compact Wideband Power Divider MMIC Based on GaAs IPD Technology
authors: Yuchen Liu, Anqi Wu, Bing Bai, Bo Fan
publish: 2025 18th IEEE United Conference on Millimeter Waves and Terahertz Technologies (UCMMT)
abstract: The traditional wilkinson power divider has been widely used in RF system. However, it has large size and narrow bandwidth, which gradually shows the disadvantages in increasingly miniaturized RF systems. In this work, a dual-channel equal power divider MMIC is presented based on GaAs IPD technology. This device uses the lumped elements to replace the quarter wavelength transmission lines in the wilkinson structure, enabling a highly compact power divider design. The divider in this work operates in a frequency range of 12GHz - 18GHz with an insertion loss of less than 0.8 dB and isolation greater than 20 dB. The input and output return losses better than <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$15 / 20 ~\text{dB}$</tex>. Meanwhile, the entire power divider chip occupies an area of only <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$0.72 \times 0.75 ~\text{mm}^{2}$</tex>.

title: De-Embedding of Two-Port Test Fixture for RF Device by Using U-Net Neural Network
authors: Haoran Mu, Haipeng Guo, Xi Wang, Yanjie Chen, Shukai Hu, Huaiqiang Yu
publish: 2025 18th IEEE United Conference on Millimeter Waves and Terahertz Technologies (UCMMT)
abstract: This paper presents a de-embedding approach based on a U-Net neural network. A 3D full-wave electromagnetic simulation model of both the fixture and the device under test (DUT) is developed to generate the scattering parameters(S parameter) of the combined system with fixture and DUT as well as the DUT alone. These data serve as the inputs and outputs for training the U-Net model. The results demonstrate that the proposed U-Net-based method can accurately predict the S-parameters of the DUT, thereby enabling effective fixture de-embedding. The predicted results achieve a mean absolute percentage error (MAPE) of less than 8.2% and a coefficient of determination <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\left(R^{2}\right)$</tex> exceeding 0.8.

title: Design of W-Band SIW Cross-Coupling Filter Based on Mems Technology
authors: Peng Lin, Tao Xiu, Lijie Fu, Shaozhi Wang, Shixian Li, Weiwei Wu, Naichang Yuan
publish: 2025 18th IEEE United Conference on Millimeter Waves and Terahertz Technologies (UCMMT)
abstract: In this paper, we present the design of a W-band Substrate-Integrated-Waveguide (SIW) cross-coupled bandpass filter utilizing Micro-Electro-Mechanical Systems (MEMS) technology. The filter features a two-layer silicon substrate with four TE <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">${}_{101}$</tex>-mode resonators, employing through-silicon via (TSV) technology. The cross-coupling topology is achieved by incorporating a magnetic coupling window and an electrical coupling slot between resonators within the same layer, as well as circular electrical irises between different layers. This configuration generates transmission zeros (TZs) on both sides of the passband, with the coupling coefficients adjustable to modify the location of the TZs. Through simulation optimization, the bandpass filter demonstrates a passband of 91.5 to 96.5 GHz, a return loss exceeding -15 dB, an insertion loss of less than 1.56 dB, and two TZs located at 88.9 GHz and 100.4 GHz. Notably, the filter's volume is only <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(0.625 \times 0.375) \lambda_{0}$</tex>.

title: Triple-Mode Resonant Wideband Vehicular Antenna with Enhanced Backfire Gain
authors: Jia-Long Zhang, Wei Zhou, Wen-Jun Lu
publish: 2025 18th IEEE United Conference on Millimeter Waves and Terahertz Technologies (UCMMT)
abstract: A triple-mode wideband resonant microstrip patch antenna with enhanced backfire gain is proposed. The antenna consists of a 2.0-wavelength sectorial magnetic dipole, a 0.75-wavelength annular sector reflector, and a 0.25-wavelength rectangular director. According to the principle of the Yagi-Uda antenna, the backfire radiation characteristic is significantly improved by incorporating a reflector and a director. Both numerical simulations and experimental measurements indicate that the fractional bandwidth is enhanced to 37.8% (4.28 to 6.16 GHz) with backfire gain of 8.5 dBi in the azimuth plane.

title: Frequency-Scanning Antenna Design Based on Bandpass Filters
authors: Yuchen Qian, Xin Guo, Wen Wu
publish: 2025 18th IEEE United Conference on Millimeter Waves and Terahertz Technologies (UCMMT)
abstract: Based on the theory of antenna arrays, this paper summarizes that different phase control networks can present different variation trends of phase differences. Accordingly, the filter theory is utilized to design phase control networks that can achieve bi-directional scanning, positive scanning, and negative scanning. The proposed networks' layouts are realized through full-wave simulation. The phase shift values that can be realized in the operating frequency band are <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$+87.6^{\circ}$</tex> to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$-96.6^{\circ},+176.3^{\circ}$</tex> to 0° and 0° to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$-173.1^{\circ}$</tex>, and the theoretical beam scanning ranges are <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$+32.7^{\circ}$</tex> to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$-36.6^{\circ},+78.4^{\circ}$</tex> to 0° and 0° to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$-74.1^{\circ}$</tex>.

title: Beyond the Generalization Illusion: A Production MLOps Framework for Federated Behavioral Malware Detection with Real-Time Drift Adaptation
authors: Mohammed El-Hajj
publish: 2025 9th Cyber Security in Networking Conference (CSNet)
abstract: This paper identifies critical limitations in current behavioral malware detection systems, particularly the "generalization illusion" where high laboratory accuracy fails to translate to novel threats in operational environments. Through comprehensive literature analysis across 42 recent studies, we identify three fundamental research gaps: (1) inadequate evaluation protocols that overestimate real-world performance by 12.3% through conventional random-split validation, (2) privacy constraints preventing effective collaborative threat intelligence sharing across organizations, and (3) operational fragility against concept drift where models rapidly degrade as malware behaviors evolve. We propose a novel framework integrating Leave-One-Experiment-Out (LOEO) validation for proper generalization assessment, privacy-preserving federated learning for collaborative security without raw data sharing, and real-time drift detection with automated retraining mechanisms. Our methodology establishes a production-grade MLOps implementation that demonstrates enterprise scalability through containerized microservices architecture. This methodology paper establishes the theoretical foundation for addressing these challenges, with comprehensive empirical validation across 2.74 million behavioral samples from 104 malware experiments to follow in subsequent work.

title: Decrypting Secrets From Wwii: When Rusty Cipher Machines Turn Out to Be Great Storytellers
authors: Carola Dahlke, Robert Jahn
publish: 2025 IEEE History of Electrotechnology Conference (HISTELCON)
abstract: In 2017, the Deutsches Museum receives an unknown cipher machine. This causes a veritable cascade of studies on the object history, its encryption mechanism, and its inventor Fritz Menzer. After 8 years of joint research, a museum curator and a filmmaker publish a thoroughly researched documentary about their findings. In seven episodes, they uncover Menzers secret life, and identify his central role for German cryptology.

title: Adaptive Collaboration and Deployment of Large AI Models for Smart Grid Management
authors: Duanjiao Li, Gao Liu, Changyu Li, Jiahong Ning, Linkun Yu, Jianguo Zhang, Ning Ding, Ping Feng
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Control, Robotics and Cybernetics (CRC)
abstract: Power grids stand at the intersection of novel opportunities and challenges as they evolve towards smarter and more efficient energy management systems. Large AI models have showcased exceptional computational and learning capabilities in data processing, load balancing, and demand response. At the same time, intelligent grid systems can enhance the performance of these models through strategic coordination and integration. Building upon this foundation, we introduce the GridAI, an Adaptive Framework for Collaborative Deployment of Large AI Models within the Smart Grid Ecosystem. A unique aspect of this study lies in leveraging large AI models in a distributed fashion, ensuring adaptability to the dynamic and decentralized nature of modern power grids. To address the inherent challenges of uneven energy resource distribution, the architecture employs cloud-edge-end collaboration within the AI models to optimize grid performance through resource allocation, demand forecasting, and fault prediction. Moreover, the framework adapts to dynamic environments by employing distributed model partitioning, parallel inference, and real-time aggregation techniques. Subsequently, we delve into a case study of GridAI within renewable energy integration, discussing pivotal energy distribution, grid stability, and system reliability technologies. In essence, GridAI presents a cutting-edge and pragmatic blueprint for the seamless optimization of large AI models within future smart grid systems.

title: Beyond Marketing: a Holistic Analysis of 3D Audio Workflows for Live Music Production
authors: Claudia Rinaldi, Stefano Giacomelli, Tiziano Salvi, Mauro Galbiati, Carlo Centofanti, Fabio Graziosi
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th International Symposium on the Internet of Sounds (IS2)
abstract: This paper investigates remote spatial audio production by analyzing alternative capture and rendering workflows for live and recorded events. Three microphone configurations are addressed: a compact cardioid array, a diffuse omnidirectional array, and a second-order Ambisonics microphone. Each setup is combined with spatialization strategies including Vector-Based Panning, Ambisonics Equivalent Panning, and KNN interpolation, resulting in a set of workflows that differ in terms of spatial resolution, envelopment, and computational complexity. The framework integrates commercial tools such as SPAT Revolution and MACH1 with open-source solutions including SSR and IEM, ensuring interoperability and replicability across different production contexts. From a networking perspective, the system relies on Dante with PTP-based clock synchronization and VPN-secured transport, providing reliable and low-latency multi-channel distribution across geographically distributed sites. The comparative description of these workflows highlights trade-offs in terms of channel mapping, processing load, and rendering flexibility, offering concrete guidelines for system design. While formal perceptual evaluations are planned as future work, the present contribution already provides a systematic technical basis for assessing remote spatial audio pipelines. The proposed workflow is demonstrated through a case study applicable to networked music performances and large-scale public events.

title: A Novel Ultra-Wideband Three-Dimensional Electromagnetic Absorber
authors: Hao Shen, Borui Bian, Dan Zhang, Yue Juan, Peidong Tong
publish: 2025 18th IEEE United Conference on Millimeter Waves and Terahertz Technologies (UCMMT)
abstract: This paper presents a novel ultra-wideband three-dimensional electromagnetic absorber. The proposed absorber is composed of a three-dimensional (3-D) lossy layer structure and a two-dimensional (2-D) magnetic material (MM) layer. The 3-D lossy layer structure is constructed using cross-oriented FR-4 dielectric substrates. On the front side of each substrate, two cascaded lossy metallic strips integrated with open-ended coplanar striplines (CPS) elements are printed, while the backside contains a single lossy metallic strip. The 2-D magnetic material is filled at the bottom of the 3-D lossy layer structure. The absorber achieves an ultra-wide absorption bandwidth from 0.99 GHz to 18 GHz with a reflection coefficient of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$|\mathrm{S}_{11}| \leqslant-10 ~\text{dB}$</tex>, corresponding to a fractional bandwidth (FBW) of 179.1%. The overall thickness of the proposed absorber reaches only 0.066 wavelength at the lowest absorption frequency. Moreover, it maintains angular stability up to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$45^{\circ}$</tex> under transverse electric (TE) polarization and up to 60° under transverse magnetic (TM) polarization. To investigate its operating mechanism, an equivalent circuit model is established. The results obtained from the equivalent circuit simulation are in good agreement with the full-wave simulation results.

title: EmoLoop: A Bi-Directional System for Emotion-Driven Interaction Between Remote Audiences and Live Performers
authors: Nicusor Amarie, Gianluca Fadda, Anderson Augusto Simiscuka, Vlad Popescu, Maurizio Murroni
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th International Symposium on the Internet of Sounds (IS2)
abstract: This paper presents EmoLoop, a bi-directional interactive system designed to create real-time emotional feedback loop between performers and a distributed audience during music or theatre events. The proposed system collects emotional data from the audience using different feedback methods, such as EEG signals from wearable headbands, facial expression analysis through VR headsets, and interaction with smartphones. These emotional states, expressed as valence/arousal values or emotion categories, are used to control various parameters of the performance, like spatial audio, lighting, and scenographic elements, both on stage and in virtual environments. EmoLoop also includes a real-time feedback system that gives performers useful cues based on the audience’s emotions. Communication between components is managed with protocols like OSC, MQTT, WebSockets, MIDI, and ArtNet to ensure low-latency transmission. The architecture is modular and flexible, and the paper explains its components, integration, and possible use cases. EmoLoop offers a new approach to participatory performance, where emotions play a central role in shaping the artistic experience, in line with current research in the Internet of Sounds (IoS) and Internet of Musical Things (IoMusT).

title: Glorious Contributions of Two Great Western Widows in the Resurrection of Science Research in India
authors: Suchanda Banerjee, Probir Kumar Bondyopadhyay
publish: 2025 IEEE History of Electrotechnology Conference (HISTELCON)
abstract: Two great western widows played critically important roles in the resurrection of physical science research in India through creation of solid state device technology for detection of wireless waves and its prompt transfer to the United States to begin commercialization and further research in the first decade of the twentieth century This paper outlines this fascinating history.

title: CNN-Based Mineral Classification: Epoch Performance Analysis and Web Usability Evaluation
authors: Firyyal Tasha Adhna, Muhammad Lulu Latif Usman, Toni Anwar
publish: 2025 8th International Conference of Computer and Informatics Engineering (IC2IE)
abstract: This study addresses the challenge analyze system mineral identification, which traditionally relies on manual observation and expert interpretation—methods that are often subjective and time-consuming. While several machine learning models have been applied to image-based mineral classification, limited research has explored how training dynamics, particularly epoch variation, affect model performance. To bridge this gap, we present a web-based mineral classification system using a Convolutional Neural Network (CNN), enabling users to upload mineral images and receive instant predictions via an accessible interface. The model is evaluated using five different epoch values (10, 25, 50, 75, 100) to analyze its learning behavior over time. The dataset consists of 5,610 labeled images from seven mineral classes, divided into 80% training and 20% validation sets. The model achieves its highest accuracy of 0.74 at epochs 10 and 50, with stable performance across other epochs. Weighted precision and recall reach 0.78 and 0.74, respectively, outperforming macro metrics due to class imbalance. Usability testing with five participants was conducted using Single Ease Question (SEQ), System Usability Scale (SUS), and Net Promoter Score (NPS). SEQ results ranged from 5.4 to 6.0, SUS scored 81.5 (excellent), and NPS recorded 100% promoter responses. These findings demonstrate the system’s potential for reliable classification and positive user experience, particularly for educational applications in geoscience.

title: Robust Control Strategy for Quadrotor Landing in Dynamic Environments Using LPV-MPC
authors: Kaveh Hooshmandi
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Control, Instrumentation and Automation (ICCIA)
abstract: This study presents a control methodology for the autonomous landing of a quadrotor UAV, using a Linear Parameter Varying (LPV) strategy. A Model Predictive Control (MPC) technique, typically used for linear systems, is made applicable by first converting the quadrotor's mathematical model into an LPV representation. This conversion improves the controller's adaptability to dynamic flight environments, leading to enhanced stability and reliability during the landing process. A significant contribution of this research is the development of a comprehensive LPV model and the corresponding implementation of an LPV-MPC controller that governs the complete system. This contrasts with previous approaches that utilized only partial models. By encompassing the entire system dynamics, this method facilitates more accurate prediction and optimization. While this approach is more computationally intensive, the feasibility of real-time operation is secured by modern high-speed processors. The proposed control scheme also improves the quadrotor's resilience to environmental disturbances, such as wind gusts and irregular landing terrains, which is critical for preventing instability. The efficacy of this strategy was validated using MATLAB simulations for both takeoff and landing, with results verifying the controller's ability to ensure precise, stable, and safe landings.

title: The Development of Electronic Spoken Language Technology in Eastern Germany
authors: Rüdiger Hoffmann
publish: 2025 IEEE History of Electrotechnology Conference (HISTELCON)
abstract: The historical acoustic-phonetic collection (HAPS) of the TU Dresden documents the development of speech technology from the emergence of experimental phonetics to the introduction of computers in laboratories for spoken language processing. While the focus so far has been on recording the inventory of ca. 1.000 exhibits of the HAPS, the accompanying archive holdings are now being evaluated. This paper describes the development of technical speech communication at the TU Dresden, where an own chair for this subject was set up at a very early stage. The chair, headed by W. Tscheschner, was one of the most important in this subject in the Eastern Bloc. The paper offers insights into the successful development of a subject under the special conditions of the Cold War in the Eastern German state until its end in 1990.

title: AI-Based Anomaly Detection for Enhanced Cybersecurity in IoT Networks
authors: Mamdouh Muhammad, Sushmetha Arumugam, Loui Al Sardy
publish: 2025 9th Cyber Security in Networking Conference (CSNet)
abstract: Intrusion Detection Systems (IDSs) play a crucial role in securing Internet of Things (IoT) networks, which are increasingly exposed to sophisticated cyber threats. This paper presents an adaptive, reconstruction-based IDS leveraging multiple class-specific Long Short-Term Memory Autoencoders (LSTM-AEs), each trained on a single traffic class (Normal, DDoS-HTTP, DDoS-TCP, DDoS-ICMP). Unlike conventional anomaly detection that models only normal traffic, our approach performs multi-class classification by comparing reconstruction errors across all class-specific models. Evaluated on the Edge-IIoTset dataset, the method achieved a macro-averaged F1-score of 0.9963, underscoring the suitability of LSTM-AE architectures for fine-grained, threat-specific detection in realistic IoT environments.

title: A Miniaturized Ultrawideband Electric Probe with High Resolution
authors: Yichun Fang, Kuiwen Xu
publish: 2025 18th IEEE United Conference on Millimeter Waves and Terahertz Technologies (UCMMT)
abstract: This article presents a broadband electric probe with high spatial resolution. The stripline design of its coupling section achieves excellent spatial resolution while maintaining wideband impedance matching. To further extend the bandwidth, the probe incorporates a coaxial via array and a vertical Radio Frequency (RF) connector package design. The proposed probe is fabricated on a three-layer printed circuit board (PCB). The manufacturing process of the PCB is compatible with large-scale production, which significantly reduces the cost of the probe compared to commercially available alternatives. The probe operates from 10 MHz to 40 GHz and provides a spatial resolution of 0.46 mm at 1 GHz. Its overall dimensions are 55.7 mm × 10.2 mm, with both the coupling and transmission parts having a width of 2.8 mm, making it suitable for most testing scenarios.

title: Numerical Analysis of GAN HEMT Irradiation Effects Based on Physics-Based Compact Model
authors: Wenkang Ji, JunHao Shen, Yijun Sheng
publish: 2025 18th IEEE United Conference on Millimeter Waves and Terahertz Technologies (UCMMT)
abstract: In this paper, a physics-based compact model reflecting the effect of space proton irradiation on GaN HEMTs' electrical performance is developed. It is found that proton irradiation triggers electrical performance degradation mainly through the displacement damage effect, causing device-internal defect. This degradation is mainly manifested in the forward drift of the threshold voltage, the decrease of the transconductance and the drain saturation current The defect density is calculated using SRIM software and add it to the compact model. Finally, it is verified by experimental data in the literature that the compact model fits well and can provide quantitative criteria for device irradiation degradation prediction, radiation protection design, etc.

title: Compact Filtering Power Divider with Independently Controllable Cutoff Frequencies
authors: Wujun Zhao, Anqi Zhang
publish: 2025 18th IEEE United Conference on Millimeter Waves and Terahertz Technologies (UCMMT)
abstract: In this work, a textured structure is introduced into the rectangular waveguides to excite the effective spoof surface plasmon polaritons (ESSPPs) mode, enabling independent control of the cutoff frequency. Leveraging the transmission characteristics of the ESSPPs mode, a filtering power divider (FPD) is designed. The FPD is constructed as a five-layer rectangular waveguides structure with a compact size, where each layer has an inherent effective dielectric constant determined by its width and the filled dielectric material. This allows flexible control over the geometric parameters of each layer and the corresponding dielectric materials. Additionally, by flexibly adjusting the heights of the first and fifth layers, both equal and unequal power division can be achieved. Furthermore, introducing isolation layers into the ESSPP layers realizes good isolation. Theoretical analysis and simulation results demonstrate that the FPD features a compact structure, low loss, independent controllability of cutoff frequencies, and controllable power division.

title: Binocular Visual Depth Estimation Algorithm Based on SGBM-YOLO
authors: Hao Huang, Feizhe Huang, Boyu Qian, Qiangju Xu, Kexue Sun
publish: 2025 18th IEEE United Conference on Millimeter Waves and Terahertz Technologies (UCMMT)
abstract: To address the limitations of low accuracy in traditional lightweight methods for depth estimation, this paper proposes a stereo vision-based framework that integrates SGBM and YOLOv5 algorithms. Through a heterogeneous computing architecture, the framework enables co-optimized detection and ranging. Specifically, we enhance the SGBM algorithm by improving its multi-path cost aggregation scheme and edge constraint strategy, thereby boosting matching accuracy in low-texture regions. Dynamic disparity correction windows are constructed based on YOLO detection bounding boxes to reduce ranging errors for small objects. Furthermore, stereo camera calibration, distortion correction, and subpixel disparity optimization are employed to improve ranging precision. Experimental results demonstrate that the framework achieves an average processing rate of 8.76 frames per second (FPS) on CPU-only platforms, with disparity output errors of less than 1.9% within a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1 0}$</tex>-meter distance.

title: Switchable Passband Active Frequency Selective Surface
authors: Xuewei Zhang, Min Shi, Liang Fang, Bao Wang
publish: 2025 18th IEEE United Conference on Millimeter Waves and Terahertz Technologies (UCMMT)
abstract: This paper proposes a butterfly dipole-based second-order bandpass frequency selective surface (FSS). By integrating PIN switch diodes, an active frequency selective surface (AFSS) with a switchable passband is designed. The on/off states of the PIN diodes can be controlled by applying an external voltage bias, thereby altering the operational mode of the bandpass frequency selective surface. This enables the AFSS to achieve wideband transmission and full-band shielding effects. The results demonstrate that in the transmission state, the proposed AFSS exhibits polarization insensitivity within the frequency range of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$8-9.5 \text{GHz}$</tex>, with an insertion loss of less than 1 dB under oblique incidence. In the shielding state, the AFSS achieves a rejection level of over 10 dB across the entire frequency band. Additionally, the bias feed network for the PIN diodes is a key feature of this AFSS. By utilizing the unit cell structure itself as part of the feed network, the design eliminates the need for additional feed networks. This work provides a novel design approach for addressing the increasingly complex and dynamic challenges in stealth radome and electromagnetic protection applications.

title: Interpretable Reduced-Dimensional Neural Space Mapping for Microwave Filter Inverse Modeling
authors: Shaobo Sun, Weicong Na, Taiqi Bai, Wanrong Zhang
publish: 2025 18th IEEE United Conference on Millimeter Waves and Terahertz Technologies (UCMMT)
abstract: This letter proposes an advanced inverse modeling method that combines the neural space mapping (NSM) inverse modeling method with vector fitting (VF) based dimensionality reduction technique. Using vector fitting and its pole-residue decomposition technique, the high-dimensional S-parameters are transformed into a low-dimensional pole-residue physical feature, ensuring physical interpretability while reducing dimensionality. Specifically, we design a novel inverse model structure and a two-stage model training algorithm. It effectively reduces the input dimensionality and the volume of fine data, thereby decreasing computational costs and shortening modeling time. The feasibility of the proposed method is demonstrated through two microwave filter design examples.

title: On-Chip Bandpass Filter Based on Spoof Surface Plasmon Polaritons with GaAs Substrate for Millimeter-Wave Applications
authors: Huiwen Ren, Kai Lu, Jiemin Wu, Di Bao
publish: 2025 18th IEEE United Conference on Millimeter Waves and Terahertz Technologies (UCMMT)
abstract: This paper presents an on-chip bandpass filter based on spoof surface plasmon polaritons (SSPPs). The proposed filter achieves its low-frequency cutoff through coupling generated by truncated ground planes, while the intrinsic high-pass characteristics of SSPPs establish the high-frequency cutoff. Simulation results demonstrate excellent filtering performance in the 45-65 GHz band, with out-of-band rejection exceeding 40 dB and insertion loss lower than 1.8 dB. It employs a non-conventional miniature SSPP structure that simultaneously reduces electrical dimensions and achieves a narrower passband. The filter bandwidth can be tuned by adjusting SSPP dimensions, significantly simplifying the design process.

title: Linearity Optimization of Pin Diode-Based Radio Frequency Switch Topology
authors: Changye Xie, Xiong Chen, Yubin Peng, Xiaolong Zhao, Yongning He
publish: 2025 18th IEEE United Conference on Millimeter Waves and Terahertz Technologies (UCMMT)
abstract: In RF transceiver systems, the intermodulation distortion (IMD) of RF switches can degrade the performance of microwave and RF communication systems. To suppress IMD in PIN diode RF switches in both ON and OFF states, this paper proposes an improved Li topology. The key modifications are: 1) adding a PIN diode-resistor network to the shunt branch, and 2) replacing the single series diode with a dual-diode structure. This approach significantly improves the linearity in the ON state while maintaining the high linearity in the OFF state. In the 2-3 GHz band, the third-order input intercept point (IIP3) in the ONstate is improved by about 8 dBm compared to the original Li topology, and the IIP3 in both ON and OFF states exceed 75 dBm.

title: The Hidden Dangers of “Objective” Technologies: An Analysis Through Time
authors: Ishita Sarraf
publish: 2025 IEEE History of Electrotechnology Conference (HISTELCON)
abstract: Science and technology have long been regarded as objective and incapable of discrimination. However, history has shown that these “objective” technologies are used as tools of discrimination and oppression by those in power to minoritize communities. Today, AI technology is being used in the same way. In this paper I will show that even though technology has advanced, the pattern of racial discrimination has not changed. The same tools for discrimination that were used in the past are used today; just with fancy bells and whistles attached to them. I will describe three “objective” historical scientific innovations chronologically, and their corresponding modern-day “objective” AI technological counterparts. In offering a brief history of technological discrimination, this paper encourages the reader to take a stand against biased technologies by advocating for fair and transparent AI practices that truly benefit all.

title: Performance Analysis of Terahertz Multi-Sheet Beam Folded Waveguide TWTs Under Nonuniform Conditions
authors: Fengying Lu, Yanan Ma
publish: 2025 18th IEEE United Conference on Millimeter Waves and Terahertz Technologies (UCMMT)
abstract: This paper investigates the influence of structural and beam current nonuniformities on the output performance of terahertz multi-sheet beam folded waveguide traveling-wave tubes (TWTs). Using three-dimensional particle-in-cell (3D-PIC) simulations, we examine two primary sources of nonuniformity: variations in beam current distribution across multiple sheet beams and differences in beam tunnel height. The study considers several current allocation cases under a fixed total current, as well as beam tunnels with equal and unequal height distributions, while maintaining the same total aperture area. Simulation results show that directing higher current to the central beam improves output performance. For beam tunnel geometry, the simulation indicates that a more uniform height distribution among the beam tunnels contributes to a more uniform electric field distribution, which in turn enhances output performance. This insight into uniformity offers practical guidance for the fabrication and experimental testing of multi-sheet beam folded waveguide TWTs in future applications.

title: Optimising Embedded Neural Network Inference in Smart Traps for Fruit Pest Detection via Quantization-Aware Training and FPGA Acceleration
authors: Lucas C. Freitas, Isadora V. Dias, Victor R. S. Santos, Paulo R. Ferreira, Julio C. B. De Mattos, Lisane B. De Brisolara
publish: 2025 XV Symposium on Computing Systems Engineering (SBESC)
abstract: Deploying deep learning models in embedded agricultural systems requires balancing predictive performance with strict hardware constraints such as memory, power, and latency. This work uses quantization techniques, specifically post-training quantization (PTQ) and quantization-aware training (QAT), to optimize convolutional neural networks for real-time pest detection in smart traps. Using the Brevitas framework for quantization and FINN for hardware generation targeting FPGAs, we evaluate a range of weight and activation bit-width configurations. Our results show that QAT significantly outperforms PTQ, particularly in aggressive low-bit scenarios, achieving high accuracy while drastically reducing hardware resource utilization. Among the proposed solutions, one achieves 87.47% accuracy while using less than 10% of the LUTs required by its full-precision counterpart. Comparative analysis with standard models such as ResNet18 and MobileNet further validates the effectiveness of our approach. This study highlights the practicality of QAT-driven quantization for edge Artificial Intelligence applications in agriculture. It paves the way for future work, including power, latency, and throughput profiling, to support large-scale deployment.

title: Discrete Adapted Artificial Protozoa Optimizer for Path Planning
authors: Yan Jie Choo, Muhammed Basheer Jasser, Bibi Aamirah Shafaa Emambocus, Samuel-Soma M. Ajibade, Hui Na Chua, Abdulraqeb Alhammadi
publish: 2025 IEEE 15th International Conference on System Engineering and Technology (ICSET)
abstract: Path planning is a crucial part of autonomous navigation, where the objective is to search for an optimal collision-free path between a start point and a goal within an environment containing static or dynamic obstacles. While classical algorithms such as A* and Dijkstra's ensure optimality in static maps, they are somehow limited in their adaptability and computational efficiency when applied to large-scale or uncertain environments. Swarm Intelligence (SI) algorithms, which draw inspiration from the collective behaviors of social organisms, have shown great promise in solving these difficulties. Following up on the results of our earlier published survey on SI-based path planning, this work presents a discrete version of the Artificial Protozoa Optimizer (APO) for grid-based path planning. The proposed method encodes the paths as a series of coordinates and integrates biologically inspired behaviors including autotrophic foraging, heterotrophic foraging, reproduction, and dormancy, into the discrete search process to achieve exploration–exploitation balance. The algorithm is evaluated in a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$20 \times 20$</tex> obstacle-dense environment. Experimental results show that the discrete APO consistently produces near-optimal, smooth, and obstacle-free paths at lower computational costs, demonstrating its viability for real-time autonomous robotic navigation.

title: Sentiment Analysis on Customer's Interest in Social Commerce Using Support Vector Machine (SVM)
authors: Hasiah Mohamed, Aidil Ridzuan Ghazali, Norulhidayah Isa, Ummu Fatihah Mohd Bahrin, Aruna Azariah Rajendram, Juliana Jaafar
publish: 2025 IEEE 15th International Conference on System Engineering and Technology (ICSET)
abstract: Social commerce, which integrates social media and e-commerce platforms, has transformed digital retail by enabling direct transactions within interactive environments such as TikTok Shop and Instagram Shop. Understanding customer sentiment in this domain is critical for improving engagement and service quality. This paper develops and evaluates a sentiment analysis model for Malaysian social commerce using the Support Vector Machine (SVM) algorithm. A dataset of 253 Twitter reviews was collected, translated, preprocessed, and balanced to 326 samples through oversampling. Text features were extracted using Term Frequency-Inverse Document Frequency (TF-IDF) with unigrams. The proposed SVM model achieved a maximum accuracy of 91.18 % and an F1-score of 90.90 % under a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$90: 10$</tex> split. Baseline comparisons showed that SVM outperformed Naïve Bayes, Logistic Regression, and Random Forest, confirming its suitability for small-to-medium datasets. A graphical user interface (GUI) prototype was also implemented, enabling real-time sentiment classification for practical deployment. While results are promising, limitations include the small dataset size, unigramonly feature representation, and focus on Malaysian reviews. Future work will expand toward larger, multilingual datasets, adopt advanced embeddings (e.g., Word2Vec, BERT), and explore hybrid SVM-deep learning approaches to improve robustness and contextual understanding.

title: POSTER: IRISX: A Dynamic Trade-off System for Performance Portability on Multi-Accelerator Platforms
authors: Sanil Rao, Mohammad Alaul Haque Monil, Het Mankad, Narasinga Rao Miniskar, Keita Teranishi, Jeffrey Vetter, Franz Franchetti
publish: 2025 34th International Conference on Parallel Architectures and Compilation Techniques (PACT)
abstract: Contemporary high performance computing, cloud, and embedded systems are equipped with various combinations of heterogeneous processors. This has led to the development of portable abstractions to target these heterogeneous systems. However, these abstractions fail to deliver performance portability as they cannot easily modify key parameters such as the amount of concurrency, the representation of the computation graph, the kernel implementation, and data transfers for varying problem sizes and hardware architectures. To address this wide parameter space, this work presents IRISX, a framework that dynamically finds the performance portable solution based on application characteristics and underlying hardware. By changing the representation of the computation at the kernel level, task level, and graph level, IRISX finds the appropriate set of heterogeneous processors that provides the best performance while ensuring portability to different heterogeneous systems.

title: A high-precision measurement method for large space workpieces
authors: Jianhua Cheng, Qinglong Liu, Xiaonan Wang, Guanbao Ren
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Computer Information Technology (AICIT)
abstract: A high-precision measurement system is developed that integrates an optical tracker for data scanning with a laser tracker for global control, addressing the limitations of traditional optical three-dimensional (3D) scanning methods. Conventional approaches often suffer from dependency on artificial markers, error accumulation, and low efficiency in large-scale metrology. The system incorporates a custom-designed "leapfrog fixture" that enables real-time, high-accuracy pose transfer between the handheld optical scanner and the laser tracker, eliminating the need for physical markers. By combining the laser tracker’s absolute measurement capability with the optical tracker’s dynamic scanning, the system achieves seamless, real-time integration of data within a unified coordinate frame. This design effectively prevents errors caused by multi-station relocation and manual data registration. Experimental validation and practical applications demonstrate that the proposed method substantially improves measurement accuracy for large-scale workpieces. It is particularly well-suited for automated in-line inspection in high-end manufacturing sectors, such as aerospace and precision equipment production.

title: An Adaptive ADMM Method for Distributed DC Optimal Power Flow
authors: Ziyang Zhang, Chao Yang, Jian Liu
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Computer Information Technology (AICIT)
abstract: This paper investigates the direct current distributed optimal power flow with carbon emission trading (DC-DOPF-CET) problem. In recent years, the Alternating Direction Method of Multipliers (ADMM) has been employed to solve OPF problems. The ADMM exhibits rapid convergence for systems with complex structures and high dimensions, but it is heavily dependent on the specific choice of penalty parameter. Therefore, this paper proposes the adaptive ADMM updating strategy during ADMM iterations to reduce computational time and enhance convergence. This paper validates the proposed method by considering carbon emission trading (CET) within the standard IEEE 30 system and IEEE 118 system. The convergence results show that the convergence performance of our approach is significantly better than that of the standard ADMM-based distributed optimization algorithms.

title: ScaleMoE: A Fast and Scalable Distributed Training Framework for Large-Scale Mixture-of-Experts Models
authors: Seohong Choi, Huize Hong, Tae Hee Han, Joonsung Kim
publish: 2025 34th International Conference on Parallel Architectures and Compilation Techniques (PACT)
abstract: The size of pre-trained models has continuously increased to support growing demands for solving more complex problems. Especially, mixture-of-experts (MoE) model has become the most popular approach, enabling systems to easily train extremely large-scale models with relatively lower computational requirements. However, the current distributed training frameworks cannot achieve scalable performance for these large-scale MoE models due to substantial communication overheads. In this paper, we propose ScaleMoE, a fast and scalable distributed training framework for large-scale MoE models. We first identify three problems in state-of-the-art distributed training frameworks: high all-to-all communication overheads, severe load imbalance in expert selection, and insufficient consideration of heterogeneous networks. We propose three novel optimizations to resolve these problems. First, to reduce communication volumes, we propose adaptive all-to-all communication that eliminates unnecessary zeros caused by zero padding. Second, to address the load imbalance in expert selection, we propose dynamic expert clustering that rebalances experts using a novel clustering methodology. Lastly, to further minimize communication overheads, we propose topology-aware expert remapping that carefully maps experts to GPU devices while considering heterogeneous network bandwidths. Our evaluations show that ScaleMoE achieves scalable performance, reducing all-to-all communication overheads by up to $\mathbf{8 1 \%}$. In general, ScaleMoE significantly improves system performance, achieving a speedup of up to $3.3 \times$ compared to the state-of-the-art framework.

title: Slow Wave Half-Mode Substrate Integrated Transmission Line Based on Microstrip Polyline Double-Layer Patterning
authors: Yuhui Niu, Yong Mao Huang
publish: 2025 18th IEEE United Conference on Millimeter Waves and Terahertz Technologies (UCMMT)
abstract: This work reports a slow wave substrate integrated waveguide transmission line based on double-layer-patterned microstrip polylines. Periodically patterning microstrip polyline unit cells onto a substrate integrated waveguide can effectively generate slow wave effect, thus achieving a size reduction in the SIW transmission line size. The simulation results show that the passband of the double-layer patterned slow wave substrate integrated waveguide transmission line is <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$3.27-7.73 \text{GHz}$</tex>, with a relative bandwidth of 81.1%, an in-band insertion loss less than 0.9 dB, and a return loss better than 15 dB. Specifically, compared to the single-layer patterning slow wave substrate integrated waveguide transmission lines of the same outer size, the cutoff frequency of double-layer patterned slow wave transmission lines has been reduced by 0.78GHz.

title: A Miniaturized Stacked Patch Antenna Design Based on LTCC Technology
authors: Boxiang Wan, Weiwei Wang, Hui Gu, Kuiwen Xu, Shichang Chen
publish: 2025 18th IEEE United Conference on Millimeter Waves and Terahertz Technologies (UCMMT)
abstract: This paper presents the design of a compact X-band microstrip antenna using low-temperature co-fired ceramic (LTCC) technology. The proposed structure features a dual-layer configuration with parasitic patches that introduce multiple resonant points, thereby significantly improving bandwidth. Simulation results show a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$10$</tex>-dB impedance bandwidth from 7.7 <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$GHz$</tex> to 9.2 GHz (17.7 % relative bandwidth), with gains exceeding 6 dBi throughout the band. The compact size of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$20 ~\text{mm} \times 20 ~\text{mm} \times$</tex> 2.537 mm makes it highly suitable for integrated RF front-end applications.

title: Development of an Automated Essay Scoring (AES) System for Writing Detection and Evaluation using Natural Language Processing (NLP)
authors: Efthan Homeric, Winda Astuti, Marisa Paryasto
publish: 2025 8th International Conference of Computer and Informatics Engineering (IC2IE)
abstract: The rapid advancement of artificial intelligence presents a new challenge to academic integrity, requiring tools that can distinguish AI-generated content from human writing. Traditional plagiarism detectors are often insufficient against AI-paraphrased text, and existing evaluation tools frequently struggle to provide deep, qualitative assessments, creating a need for a more comprehensive and integrated solution. The purpose of this work is to create and implement a web-based Automated Essay Scoring (AES) system that integrates an AI text detector and an intrinsic plagiarism detector to improve the efficiency and objectivity of the assessment process. The system's architecture combines three distinct analytical modules. For AI content detection, a RoBERTa-based classification model was fine-tuned on a large corpus of human and AI-generated texts, achieving an accuracy of 99.99%. For automated scoring, a BERT-based regression model was trained on the ASAP dataset, achieving a Quadratic Weighted Kappa (QWK) score of 0.767, indicating substantial agreement with human raters. For intrinsic plagiarism, a stylometric analysis using an Isolation Forest algorithm detects writing style inconsistencies by extracting features like vocabulary richness and sentence complexity. Finally, all quantitative results from these modules are synthesized by a Large Language Model (Gemini) to provide objective and constructive qualitative feedback. The primary result of this research is a functional web application that generates a multi-faceted analysis report. This report includes a predicted score, AI detection confidence, detailed technical writing metrics, and a list of stylistically anomalous segments, all presented on an intuitive user interface. By combining these quantitative and qualitative insights, this work provides a holistic, efficient, and consistent tool for comprehensive essay evaluation, assisting both educators and students in upholding academic integrity while fostering writing improvement.

title: Research on Target Recognition and Localization Technology for Unmanned Autonomous Flying Boom Aerial Refueling
authors: Mingzhe Li, Wenjing Hei, Xudong Tan, Zewen Sun, Pengyuan Qi
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Control, Robotics and Cybernetics (CRC)
abstract: Aerial refueling is a method of rapidly replenishing fuel for aircraft in mid-air. With the advancement of technology, unmanned autonomous flying boom aerial refueling has gained popularity due to its unique advantages. However, despite extensive research, many methods still face challenges such as insufficient accuracy and weak interference resistance. Based on this, we have developed a visual positioning system focused on precise localization. By utilizing target recognition and tracking methods, we process images from visual sensors to determine the position of the target point. Further, through three-dimensional reconstruction methods, we calculate the relative pose of the target in three-dimensional space. Additionally, we have designed anti-interference algorithms to address issues such as strong light and obstructions. In simulated scenarios, we have achieved satisfactory localization results.

authors: Mai Peng, Delaram Yazdani, Danial Yazdani, Zeneng She, Wenjian Luo, Changhe Li, Juergen Branke, Trung Thanh Nguyen, Amir H. Gandomi, Shengxiang Yang, Yaochu Jin, Xin Yao
