title: Streamlined Circuit Design: Cost–Effective Solutions Using Nuvoton Microcontrollers
authors: Harshita, Kumkum, Somya Garg, Ruhani, Kavita Sharma, S.R.N. Reddy
publish: 2025 5th Asian Conference on Innovation in Technology (ASIANCON)
abstract: In complex hardware systems simplicity, cost-efficiency, and reliability are key considerations for designing a circuit. Circuit designing with minimal hardware components and to have cost-effective and power-efficient IoT application is a priority for researchers and industry practitioners. This study focuses on the development of an efficient, low-hardware circuit utilizing the Nuvoton W78E052D microcontroller, chosen for its versatility, affordability, and robust features in embedded applications. By strategically reducing the number of components, the proposed design not only reduces production costs but also improves reliability and ease of assembly, making it suitable for mass production. Through a systematic approach, we explore optimized configurations of essential components and connections to maximize performance while minimizing costs and reducing space utilization. Moreover, the implementation of embedded functionalities using the Nuvoton W78E052D provides a more flexible and scalable design that can be adapted to varied applications. This work provides a practical reference for building a foundational embedded system circuit in a resource-constrained environment, offering a pathway to making durable, accessible, and cost-effective embedded solutions.

title: Malware in Motion: Taxonomy and Trends in Network Traffic Analysis
authors: Nabanita Roy, Raj Gaurang Tiwari, Sangita Roy
publish: 2025 5th Asian Conference on Innovation in Technology (ASIANCON)
abstract: The evolution of modern malware has introduced sophisticated evasion techniques that use covert network channels such as DNS tunneling, HTTPS beaconing, and peer-to-peer overlays. It can easily bypass traditional endpoint security and facilitate unauthorized data transfers. This research focuses on advancing network-based detection mechanisms to counter such threats. It proposes a comprehensive classification system that organizes detection methods into static and dynamic categories, as well as signature-based, anomaly-based, and machine-learning-driven approaches. A detailed analysis is conducted using widely recognized cybersecurity benchmark datasets, including CTU-13, UNSW-NB15, and CIC-IDS2017, to evaluate the effectiveness of various detection strategies through standardized performance metrics. The study also highlights the persistent challenges in dealing with encrypted traffic, identifying concept drift in evolving attack patterns, and achieving accurate real-time threat detection. In addressing these limitations, the research explores the integration of federated learning models to preserve data privacy, and the role of explainable artificial intelligence (XAI) in improving transparency and trust in automated decisions. Future directions include adaptive systems for IoT traffic monitoring and edge-based threat analytics.

title: Multimetric Evaluation of LLMs on Major Indian Language Translation Tasks
authors: Aswathi Padmavilochanan, Rasula Prashanth
publish: 2025 5th Asian Conference on Innovation in Technology (ASIANCON)
abstract: This study conducts a multi-metric evaluation of ten Large Language Models (LLMs) for translating four major Indian languages—Hindi, Tamil, Telugu, and Malayalam—into English. The selected models span proprietary and open-source systems and are chosen from the top performers on the LMSYS leaderboard. Translation quality is assessed using both automated metrics and human evaluations across criteria such as fluency, adequacy, and semantic preservation. The paper addresses linguistic challenges like morphological complexity and idiomatic usage and highlights translation limitations in culturally embedded texts. Results indicate that while models such as Gemini 2.0 Flash and Claude 3.5 Sonnet are consistently strong, translation quality remains language-dependent. The study aims to support multilingual NLP in low resource settings by offering comprehensive performance insights and task-relevant qualitative analysis

title: Application of MQTT Protocol to Visualize the Behavior of Autonomous Vehicle in a Virtual Environment
authors: Vaidehi M, Vaibhav Magadum, Sharadhi Hegde, Shravya R, Sahaj Gupta
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Innovative Data Communication Technologies and Application (ICIDCA)
abstract: This study focuses on the design and implementation of an MQTT Protocol to Visualize the Behavior of Autonomous Vehicle in a Virtual Environment using the IoT technology. The primary motive of the study is to stimulate and monitor the behavior of autonomous vehicle in a virtual environment. A virtual environment having vehicle-to-environment interaction. The existing traditional vehicles will soon be replaced by autonomous vehicles due to advancements in the field of IoT in Transport. Hence, there should be a system which allows interaction between vehicles and environment in a connected ecosystem. Based on the changes in the environment the autonomous vehicles should be able to adapt changes. As the existing system completely depends on the Sensor data and Perception Systems but these are limited to a self-environment. The paper focus on building a network in which each vehicle take decision based on the behavior of the other vehicles and choose most efficient path based on the accidents and geofences. This study proposes a system which constantly monitor and sends data such as speed, battery life, GPS location, etc. to a centralized system using various sensors, low powered wireless communication protocol (MQTT) to collect, assess and alert using Internet of Things (IoT). The results demonstrate the feasibility and effectiveness of IoT technology for enhancing Autonomous Vehicle Network. The collected data can be used in implementation of Fleet Management System which help to visualize the performance of the Autonomous Vehicles in form of Graphs and Charts.

title: Machine Learning Applications for Classification and Detection of Cybercrime: Performance Analysis of Three Models
authors: Indu Bharti Jain, G S Pradeep Ghantasala, Shivani Baidwal, Pradeepta Kumar Sarangi, Rajesh Sharma R, Akey Sungheetha
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Advances in Computing Research On Science Engineering and Technology (ACROSET)
abstract: Cybercrime is one of the most emerging crime areas in this digital era. The increasing popularity of social media, coupled with the notion of freedom of speech, has led some individuals to engage in disruptive behavior online. Developing real-time monitoring systems to address digital criminal activities is a complex yet highly effective approach for the swift detection of cyberattacks. Machine Learning (ML) offers automated solutions to tackle these challenges. Various ML algorithms can be utilized in cybersecurity to prevent attacks and reduce security risks. Cyberbullying, a form of harassment on social media, often leads to legal complications. This study examines three machine learning models: Decision Tree, Logistic Regression and Random Forest. The dataset used consists of user tweets sourced from Kaggle. From the experiments it has been found that Logistic Regression performs comparatively better than the other models, achieving an accuracy rate of 77%.

title: Inertia Estimation for Power System Based on Feature Identification and Model Tuning
authors: Siran Yang, Xinyan Liao, Yibo Li, Ling Yang
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electrical Engineering and Mechatronics Technology (ICEEMT)
abstract: Accurate estimation of inertia in power systems is important to ensure grid stability. This paper proposes a CoXBO (Convolutional-XGBoost with Bird Optimization) algorithm. The algorithm uses convolutional neural network to identify the inertia-related features of the original operation data, establishes the mapping relationship between the features and the inertia value through extreme gradient boosting tree, and at the same time, introduces the bird mating optimizer to optimize the hyperparameters of the regression model to improve the estimation accuracy. The simulation results show that the proposed method is highly accurate for inertia estimation and has strong practical application value.

title: AI-Powered Offline Voice Assistant for Rural Communities
authors: Umesh R, Sudharasan Dev K, Praveen Kumar M
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Innovative Data Communication Technologies and Application (ICIDCA)
abstract: This paper discusses the design and evaluation of an offline, AI-enabled voice assistant that employs Whisper-based speech recognition; lightweight, large language models (LLMs) using Ollama; and pyttsx3-based text to speech (TTS). The offline nature of the voice assistant was designed, in part, to tackle privacy concerns associated with technology that requires a connection to the internet, while still enabling the conversational interactions defined at the beginning of this section. Three LLMs—Gemma 2B, Phi-3, and Mistral—were tested, using a varied set of multilingual and domain-specific contextual prompts (including agriculture, health, and general knowledge, etc.) for their ability to generate appropriate responses. Functional characteristics of the assistant include session memory and a visual modular architecture that enable components and included features to be easily upgraded and interchanged. The Whisper API, in combination with a TTS engine, provided accurate recognition instance-to-instance while TTS produced plausible responses that maintained a natural sense of pacing and development throughout. Performance testing demonstrated between 75% and 90% transcription accuracy in quiet and moderate noise environments, respectively, and an average response time of 2.5 seconds, with significantly lower latency for repeat requests. The fact that the assistant is developed to run on any device with at least 2GB of shared RAM means it will also run on low-resourced or rural technologies. Relative to cloud-hosted alternatives, the proposed voice assistant also has the benefit of privacy, offline reliability, and independence from cloud-based data services and the dangers associated with the widespread, unchecked, use of those services. While the experimental results demonstrate that Mistral model performed the most balanced in terms of response accuracy and clarity (followed by Gemma and Phi-3).

title: AI-Driven Real-Time Wind Speed Prediction using LSTM Optimized with Chaos Game Optimization
authors: Maria Liviya L, Meghana A, Jerish S D, Mahalakshmi G, Monica R, Kingsy Grace R
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Innovative Data Communication Technologies and Application (ICIDCA)
abstract: Effective forecasting of wind speed can directly maximize energy generation from wind and creates an additional benefit for long-term sustainable development. In this paper, forecasting wind speed through the application of Long Short Term Memory (LSTM) neural network using the CGO algorithm is proposed. Historical wind data, including wind directions and timestamps, are used to train the model to capture the time-dependent and nonlinear characteristics of wind behavior. Integrated Chaos Game Optimization (CGO) hyper parameter tuning has supported the model by using very high prediction accuracy and low error margins. The system tests model performance with Mean Absolute Error (MAE) and represents results via time series graphs in comparison with observed wind speeds.

title: Corn Leaf Disease Detection using VGG-16
authors: V. Lakshman Narayana, Ch. Naga Priyanka, SD. Gousia Parveen, R. Triveni, K. Pravalika, T. Deepthi Mery
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Innovative Data Communication Technologies and Application (ICIDCA)
abstract: Corn leaf diseases are one of the most common diseases that can be considered important to crop health, and it increases agricultural productivity. Conventional disease diagnosis techniques usually based on manual inspection often become laborious, time-consuming, and susceptible to human errors. To solve these issues, deep learning approaches can be used to automate and improve the precision of disease classification. This research addresses the identification of and classification for diseases affecting corn leaves based on photos using the VGG-16 CNN model. The VGG-16 architecture was utilized and proven to be deeper and even more efficient in carrying out classification-based image tasks, so the intricacies from the images of corn leaves could further enhance the accuracy in the classification of the three categories: Northern Leaf Blight, Common Rust, and Healthy leaves. A pretrained model VGG-16 was used for optimization and training for the recognition of specific diseases of maize leaves. It uses high performing indicators like accuracy, precision, recall, and F1-score for evaluating the model. From the result, the VGG-16 model appears to be a reliable model for the early diagnosis and treatment of the maize leaf diseases. It may help in controlling the losses of crops for their farmers and in the detection and cure of diseases much earlier.

title: Research on Low-Speed Operation Strategy for Permanent Magnet Synchronous Motors Using an Active Flux Observer with a LADRC Speed Loop
authors: Junnuo Xin, Xiaohong Wang, Xiaojun Gao
publish: 2025 10th International Seminar on Computer Technology, Mechanical and Electrical Engineering (ISCME)
abstract: Permanent magnet synchronous motors (PMSMs), favored for their high efficiency and ease of maintenance, are widely used in household appliances and industrial applications. Sensorless control techniques enhance system reliability while reducing cost, garnering substantial interest. Conventional sensorless algorithms typically estimate rotor position via back electromotive force (EMF) or magnetic flux. However, at low speeds, the back EMF is weak, significantly degrading observer performance. In contrast, magnetic flux remains relatively constant over the entire speed range, making it more suitable for low-speed applications. To improve low-speed sensorless performance, this paper proposes an active flux observer that integrates both voltage and current models. To enhance load-handling capabilities, a Linear Active Disturbance Rejection Control (LADRC) scheme is adopted for the speed control loop. This paper first analyzes the magnetic flux model of the motor, then presents the active flux observer and its implementation. Subsequently, the application of LADRC in the speed loop and its parameter tuning are discussed. Finally, simulation results are provided, comparing the proposed method with conventional PI control to verify its effectiveness.

title: Big Data Learning for Forecasting and Reducing Energy Consumption in Mobile Communication Systems
authors: Anusha Peyyala, Boyapati Purna ChandraSekhar, Varsha D. Jadhav, Bhiksha Gugulothu, Srikanth Karumuri, S. S. Sivaraju
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Innovative Data Communication Technologies and Application (ICIDCA)
abstract: The exponential growth of mobile data services has created unprecedented challenges in terms of energy efficiency and sustainable network design. This study applies big data learning and predictive analytics to investigate the influence of traffic load, user density, and signal strength on energy consumption in cellular systems. Using historical datasets and Taguchi-based experimental design, the analysis identifies critical parameters and their contribution rates through signal-to-noise ratio and ANOVA methods. The results reveal that traffic load exerts the highest impact on energy consumption (90.5%), followed by active users (3.8%), with signal strength contributing minimally (0.75%). Predictive modeling further highlights the optimal configuration for minimizing energy usage: a traffic load of 900 Mbps, 4000 users, and signal strength of -85 dBm. By integrating big data-driven insights with predictive optimization strategies, this research provides a scalable framework for designing energy-efficient and sustainable mobile networks to meet rising global demand for data-intensive services.

title: Quantitative Effect of Sawing-Line Width on QFN Thermal Deformation
authors: Jie-Ming Li, Mei-Ling Wu
publish: 2025 20th International Microsystems, Packaging, Assembly and Circuits Technology Conference (IMPACT)
abstract: With growing demands for packaging reliability, QFN packages often encounter warpage issues during thermal processes. This study investigates the deformation behavior of a 17.1 mm × 16.4 mm QFN lead frame under heating, focusing on the impact of varying sawing-line widths. A three-dimensional thermo-mechanical model, incorporating material and thermal parameters, was implemented within the ANSYS platform to replicate the heating-induced deformation of the QFN lead frame. The simulation applied a temperature ramp from 25°C to 200°C under a 1 Block strip configuration with different sawing widths (0.3 / 0.7 / 0.9 mm). Results show that increased sawing-line width reduces peak deformation near the region due to enhanced local stress relief, while deformation trends remain symmetrical. These findings highlight the role of geometric design in managing thermal warpage and suggest that optimizing sawing-line width is an effective cutting approach to improve structural stability in QFN packaging.

title: CNN-CNN Methodology for Fault Assessment and Categorization in an Active Distribution System Integrated with Distributed Generations
authors: Chirag Patel, Nilesh Chothani, Siddharth Joshi, Sawan Rathod
publish: 2025 International Conference on Smart-Green Technology in Electrical and Information Systems (ICSGTEIS)
abstract: In the period of active implementation of the active distribution and the creation of Distributed Generation (DG), the number of locations that are associated with faults has acquired a significantly difficult-to-detect aspect due to the floating and uncontrollable nature of the power that is injected. The paper gives a hybrid Convolution Neural Network (CNNCNN) implementation of a multi-fault study of the 6-bus IEEE having decentralized RES. The specified model is going to be set up in a way that it will carry out three functionalities primarily as follows: by the kind of fault, by the line of the fault and the exact position of the fault. Depending on the measurement of voltage and current values in critical locations within the grid, the initial CNN learns necessary spatial and temporal affairs, than the second CNN introduces criticality in the identification of faults. This multilayering increases the sensitivity of the subtle variations in the signal dynamics occasioned by the different possible types of fault and grid combinations. According to the various cases, i.e., balanced and unbalanced faults, different ground resistances, and dynamic conditions of continuous RES, significant tests of simulation on PSCAD were performed. The framework showed strong versatility and consistent dynamics in the fluctuation of fault types and system (state). The CNN-CNN is competent in relation to fault diagnosis, boundary identification of lines, as well as, the position of the line, which plays a large role towards real-time monitoring of smart grids. It is efficient and stable, and will be sure to be used in future AI-controlled protection systems of a contemporary distribution network.

title: Bratayuda: A Multisensor Smart Bra for Breast Cancer Detection and Monitoring using Biometric Variation Analysis and Hybrid CNN-GRU
authors: I Komang Chandra Yogananda, I Komang Gede Jefri Suparjana, Assyifa Dewanda Parend, Ilham, Gabriella Sunsugos Sianturi, Lie Jasa
publish: 2025 International Conference on Smart-Green Technology in Electrical and Information Systems (ICSGTEIS)
abstract: Breast cancer remains a significant global health challenge, with current detection methods like imaging and biopsy being invasive, costly, and often inaccessible for continuous monitoring. To address these limitations, this paper introduces Bratayuda, a multisensor smart bra designed for effective breast cancer detection and monitoring. Bratayuda integrates temperature, texture, and oxygenation sensors to capture real-time biometric variations in breast tissue, which are key indicators of pathological changes. The collected data is analyzed using a novel hybrid deep learning model that combines a Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) for spatial feature extraction and a Gated Recurrent Unit (GRU) for temporal pattern recognition. This model is integrated within an Internet of Medical Things (IoMT) framework, providing users and healthcare professionals with a website interface for monitoring disease progression and receiving timely recommendations. By offering an independent, accurate, non invasive, comfortable, and affordable solution, Bratayuda presents a promising technological advancement to facilitate early diagnosis, improve patient outcomes, and contribute to the global fight against breast cancer.

publish: 2025 Research, Invention, and Innovation Congress: Innovative Electricals and Electronics (RI2C)

abstract: On behalf of the Department of Electrical Engineering, Udayana University, it is with immense pleasure and a sense of great honor that we extend our warmest welcome to you to the 2025 International Conference on Smart Green Technology in Electrical and Information Systems (ICSGTEIS 2025). The purpose of the conference is to provide a platform for the exchange of findings, ideas, innovations, and visions related to smart and green technologies.

title: Low-Loss Reconfigurable Intelligent Surface Design Based on the Grey Wolf Optimizer
authors: You-Cheng Chen, Kun-Leng Yang, Cheng-Hao Cheng, Shih-Cheng Lin, Sheng-Fuh Chang
publish: 2025 IEEE International RF and Microwave Conference (RFM)
abstract: This paper presents an innovative 1-bit low-loss Reconfigurable Intelligent Surface (RIS) unit cell designed for operation in the 4.7 GHz band. By applying distinct reverse voltages to the varactor diode, the unit cell achieves reconfigurability between on and off states. The Grey Wolf Optimizer (GWO) algorithm is integrated into the design process to optimize the structure of the unit cell, using a segmented patch design to meet stringent performance requirements. Specifically, the optimization aims to maintain reflection loss below 3 dB across the <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$4.5-4.9 \text{GHz}$</tex> band while achieving a phase difference of at least <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$180^{\circ} \pm 20^{\circ}$</tex> between the two states. Simulation results validate that the optimized unit cell meets these criteria, achieving a minimal reflection loss of 1.1 dB and consistent phase performance within the target frequency range. Building upon this, a 1-bit RIS prototype based on the optimized unit cell was fabricated, and experimental measurements confirm its effective beamforming capability, with a scanning range of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\pm \mathbf{40}^{\circ}$</tex>. Under test conditions with a 15° incident angle, a 0.45 m distance to the RIS, and a20° reflection angle, the prototype achieved a maximum gain of 18.7 dBi, highlighting its efficiency and practical applicability.

title: Enhanced Facial Palsy Detection Through Deep Convolutional Neural Networks
authors: S. Kiruthiga, C. Anbuananth, V. Dhilipkumar
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Innovative Data Communication Technologies and Application (ICIDCA)
abstract: Facial paralysis affects millions of individuals worldwide, severely impairing quality of life by disrupting facial muscle control and expression. Early and accurate diagnosis is critical to enabling timely intervention and optimizing treatment outcomes. In this study, we present an innovative deep learning based framework for the automatic detection and assessment of facial paralysis from clinical images. Our method leverages deep convolutional neural networks (DCNNs) to analyze facial features, capturing subtle asymmetries and irregularities that indicate nerve dysfunction. The proposed system is trained on a heterogeneous dataset comprising multiple severities and etiologies of paralysis, allowing it to robustly differentiate between normal and impaired facial expressions. Beyond binary classification, the model also provides clinically relevant insights into the severity and progression of the condition, assisting physicians in treatment planning and longitudinal monitoring.By integrating state-of-the-art architectures in computer vision with domain expertise in neurology and facial anatomy, our system achieves a detection accuracy of 95%. It offers a non-invasive, cost-effective, and scalable solution suitable for deployment across diverse healthcare settings, including hospitals and remote clinics.

title: Hydraulic Pressure Control of Master Cylinder in Fully Decoupled Electro-Hydraulic Braking System
authors: Yongrong Hu, Sanbao Hu, Xiaohe Deng
publish: 2025 10th International Seminar on Computer Technology, Mechanical and Electrical Engineering (ISCME)
abstract: Aiming at the complex nonlinear dynamics, hysteresis, and oscillation issues inherent in fully-decoupled electro-hydraulic brake systems, a master-cylinder hydraulic pressure control strategy was proposed. First, the structure and operating principles of the fully decoupled electro-hydraulic braking system were analyzed, and mathematical models of the system were established for controller design. Second, a multi-closed-loop cascade control strategy was proposed, in which the pressure control layer employed particle swarm optimization-based active disturbance (PSO-ADRC), the position control layer adopted proportional-integral (PI) control with feedforward control, and the motor utilized a speed-current dual closed-loop control method. Finally, the proposed hydraulic pressure control strategy was validated through co-simulation using MATLAB/Simulink and AMESim. The results demonstrate that the proposed control method can rapidly and precisely track the desired hydraulic pressure, with dynamic response errors constrained within 0.5 MPa and steady-state errors below 0.1 MPa. Compared with conventional active disturbance rejection control (ADRC), it exhibits faster response speed, smaller errors, and superior pressure control performance.

title: Environment-Coupled Power Grid Vulnerability Assessment Model for Earthquakes and Storms
authors: Ke Wang, Jing Zhou, Yongshun Chen, Lai Tian
publish: 2025 10th International Seminar on Computer Technology, Mechanical and Electrical Engineering (ISCME)
abstract: Traditional single-hazard assessment models suffer from limited accuracy due to overlooking hazard chain effects, geo-environmental interactions, and computational bottlenecks. This paper proposes a multi-hazard vulnerability assessment framework for power grids, integrating geographic environmental matrices and dynamic failure propagation. First, transmission lines are decoupled into tower nodes and virtual nodes, enabling dimension-reduced line damage calculation and supporting provincial-scale transmission grid simulation. Second, it constructs two environmental matrices and three meteorological matrices to drive coupled hazard physics, quantifying the “hazard-environment-grid” transmission mechanism and addressing the lack of spatial-temporal coupling in existing models. Finally, a sequential Monte Carlo model is designed, incorporating a power redistribution-driven cascading failure propagation algorithm. Simulations show: 1) Under various weather conditions and multi-level earthquake scenarios, the model improves grid fault detection by 30% compared to traditional single-simulation methods; 2) In multi-level storm scenarios, it accurately captures the time-accumulated coupling effects of “heavy rainfall-strong wind-flooding-lightning”, with predicted cascading failure blackout processes matching observations from Hainan’s Typhoon Kalmaegi. The results demonstrate the model’s effectiveness as an efficient tool for multi-hazard grid defense.

title: Enhancing Banking Security Using Blockchain with Random Forest and Autoencoder Networks
authors: M. Karthikeyan, Ramaraju SVSV Palla, Prem Singh, S. Pragadeeswaran, Shrikant Dnyandeo Bhopale, Pawan Mandal
publish: 2025 5th Asian Conference on Innovation in Technology (ASIANCON)
abstract: The banking sector has experienced a significant transformation in the age of electronic commerce, as internet banking has expanded the range of payment options accessible to consumers. However, individuals' financial and mental well-being are jeopardized due to the increase in fraud that has followed this transformation. This research examines how digital transformation can be more effectively safeguarded against fraudulent transactions with the implementation of AI and ML frameworks. Prior to feature extraction through a feature selection methodology, the proposed architecture utilizes preprocessing approaches such as addressing missing values and eliminating duplicates. The primary focus is the hybrid AE-LSTM model, which enhances predictive performance by integrating AE and LSTM networks. The hybrid model attains a 97.32% accuracy rate, surpassing the individual AE and LSTM models, as evidenced by case studies utilizing real-time transaction data. These results indicate that hybrid machine learning models are effective in improving fraud detection capabilities. The study emphasizes the potential of integrating blockchain with machine learning to enhance the security and transparency of financial services. Collectively, the findings indicate a promising outlook for the banking sector's initiatives to use blockchain and machine learning in the creation of more intelligent and safe fraud prevention systems.

title: Counterfactual Explanations for Enhanced Interpretability in Cross-Site Scripting (XSS) Detection
authors: Alphin Kayalathu Mathew, Ashwin M, Vysakh Kani Kolil, Devi Rajeev
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Innovative Data Communication Technologies and Application (ICIDCA)
abstract: Machine learning (ML) models are vital for detecting Cross-Site Scripting (XSS) attacks in web security, but are often hindered by their opaque decision-making processes. To address this, we propose a novel interpretability framework combining Local Interpretable Model-agnostic Explanations (LIME) and Diverse Counterfactual Explanations (DiCE) to enhance the transparency of an XSS detection model. Our approach utilizes lexical and structural URL features to train four ML models, Random Forest (RF), Support Vector Machine (SVM), Multi-Layer Perceptron (MLP), and Logistic Regression, with RF achieving superior performance (99.28% accuracy, 99.11% precision, 98.29% recall, and a 98.70% F1-score) after hyperparameter optimization via 5-fold cross-validation and Grid Search. LIME identifies critical features like html_attr_background, html_tag_svg, and url_special_characters as key indicators of XSS attacks, while DiCE generates actionable counterfactuals, demonstrating how minimal feature adjustments can shift predictions from malicious to benign. This framework enhances trust and provides actionable insights for security practitioners, improving the deployment of ML in security critical contexts.

title: Ghost-YOLOv5 Enhanced Visual SLAM for Dynamic AR Environments
authors: Xinyuan Jiang, Lu Zhang, Hongyong Fu, Yan Zhang, Xinlong Qi, Xiaoxiao Guo
publish: 2025 10th International Seminar on Computer Technology, Mechanical and Electrical Engineering (ISCME)
abstract: In augmented reality, precise visual registration is critical for aligning virtual content with real-world scenes, especially in dynamic environments. Traditional visual SLAM systems, such as ORB-SLAM3, assume static scenes and suffer performance degradation in the presence of moving objects. This paper proposes a lightweight and efficient AR visual registration framework by integrating an enhanced YOLOv5 object detector—Ghost-YOLOv5—with ORB-SLAM3. The detector incorporates GhostConvV2 and C3GhostV2 modules to significantly reduce model size and computational load while preserving detection accuracy. Exported via TorchScript and deployed using LibTorch, Ghost-YOLOv5 enables real-time detection of dynamic regions, whose corresponding features are excluded from SLAM processing. Experimental results on the TUM dynamic dataset demonstrate substantial improvements in SLAM accuracy and AR registration stability. Real-time performance (>30 FPS) is achieved on an NVIDIA RTX 3090 GPU, indicating the system’s potential for practical deployment in dynamic environments, with hardware acceleration considerations.

title: AlphaNAS: Efficient Architecture Search for Large Language Models
authors: Prudhvi Krishna Thandra
publish: 2025 5th Asian Conference on Innovation in Technology (ASIANCON)
abstract: The proliferation of large language models (LLMs) has revolutionized natural language processing but poses challenges due to their resource-intensive nature. In response, the LLaMA-Adapter approach and similar efforts aim to make LLMs more accessible and efficient. Building on this, I introduce AlphaNAS, a theoretically grounded framework for discovering high-performing and computationally economical architectures for LLMs. Combining Monte Carlo Tree Search (MCTS) with a surrogate model, AlphaNAS efficiently explores the vast architecture space of LLMs. Through iterative updates of the surrogate model, AlphaNAS provides accurate estimates of architecture performance and computational cost, guiding informed decision making during the search process. While our discussion focuses on theoretical aspects, future work includes empirical validation and exploration of hardware-aware optimization and pruned architectures. AlphaNAS lays the groundwork for discovering architectures that balance performance and efficiency, contributing to advancements in natural language generation tasks and the broader AI ecosystem.

title: Deep Learning-based Visual Recognition for Real-Time Webcam Applications
authors: Kanagamalliga S, Anbusuhantha S
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Innovative Data Communication Technologies and Application (ICIDCA)
abstract: A real-time visual recognition system utilizing webcam streams and deep neural networks is presented in this work. The approach is designed to process live video frames captured by a standard webcam, enabling objects to be detected and classified instantly. The system is implemented using Python and OpenCV, with a pre-trained Deep learning (DL) model integrated to ensure both speed and accuracy. Incoming frames are pre-processed, passed through the network, and analyzed to extract object categories along with bounding box coordinates, which are then rendered on the display in real time. Emphasis is placed on cost-effectiveness, allowing deployment without high-performance GPUs, while still maintaining satisfactory frame rates and detection accuracy. By employing a lightweight yet robust model, adaptability to various application domains such as security surveillance, automation, and educational demonstrations is ensured. The performance is evaluated based on detection accuracy, confidence threshold, and processing speed, with results indicating reliable operation for typical real-time scenarios. Potential enhancements such as multi-camera integration, motion tracking, and cloud-based storage are identified to extend the system’s capabilities. The work demonstrates how conventional webcam hardware can be transformed into an intelligent visual recognition tool by leveraging deep neural networks, thus contributing to accessible and practical computer vision solutions.

title: Automated Skin Cancer Detection and Risk Prediction using ResNet50
authors: Peer Shaheda, Rithika Gade, Rudraraju Akshaya, Sabbani Samhitha, M. Shereesha
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Innovative Data Communication Technologies and Application (ICIDCA)
abstract: Skin cancer is a significant public health issue all over the world, and detection at an early stage is crucial in enhancing treatment. This paper introduces an automated skin cancer detection and risk estimation system based on ResNet50, which is a deep convolutional neural network renowned for its hierarchical image feature extraction capabilities. The system interprets dermoscopic images using an end-to-end pipeline that involves image preprocessing, handcrafted and deep feature extraction, and classification into benign or malignant lesions. The model proposed also has a severity-based risk prediction layer that predicts the risk using morphological features to classify malignant cases into low-risk or high-risk classes. This layered approach is designed to support clinical decision-making by enabling accurate lesion identification and risk prioritization for timely medical intervention.

title: Precision Farming Redefined: IoT-Enabled Soil Monitoring and Machine Learning Approaches for Crop Recommendations
authors: Amita Shukla, Krishna Kant Agrawal
publish: 2025 5th Asian Conference on Innovation in Technology (ASIANCON)
abstract: The Internet of Things (IoT) has significantly transformed various domains, with farming emerging as one of its key beneficiaries. This study examines how the Internet of Things might support precision farming, namely in the fields of crop system recommendation and nutrients in the soil measurement. Farmers may more precisely evaluate soil health and ascertain nutrient levels by combining IoT-capable sensors with live data analytics. The study provides an in-depth review of existing research on IoT applications that enhance crop management and optimize soil nutrients. It highlights advanced sensor technologies which are crucial for gathering accurate soil data. The study also addresses the creation of forecasting algorithms that base crop recommendations on nutritional profiles and environmental factors using artificial intelligence techniques. The findings demonstrate how IoT-driven systems support smarter agricultural decision-making, leading to improved crop yields and better resource management. Overall, the review enhances current understanding of IoT-based precision farming and identifies opportunities for future innovation. By merging emerging technologies with traditional farming practices, this research contributes toward addressing the challenges of modern agriculture and promotes more sustainable and efficient farming solutions.

title: Automatic Microsleep Detection System Based on Eye Aspect Ratio Images
authors: Farah Diska Vellayati, Yessi Jusman, Muhammad Risqi Nurrahman, Erika Loniza, Kurnia Chairunnisa
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electronic and Electrical Engineering and Intelligent System (ICE3IS)
abstract: Digital image processing can enhance the effectiveness of microsleep detection systems, hence addressing the issue of tiredness in motor vehicle drivers. This study aims to develop a microsleep detection device equipped with an infrared camera for visualization. The method involved utilizing the eyeaspect ratio (EAR) value. The device was constructed with an infrared camera as a means of capturing facial visualization, specifically focusing on the driver’s eyes. Moreover, the Raspberry Pi analyzed the images by computing the eye ratio value based on the set limit. If the ratio value fell below the predetermined limit, the tool produced an auditory signal as a warning indication that the driver was experiencing microsleep. The average response time recorded for those who did not wear glasses was 1.5 seconds, with a standard deviation of 0.18. The duration for responders wearing glasses was 1.7 seconds, with a standard deviation of 0.24. The highest level of accuracy was achieved in participants who did not wear glasses in both bright and dark environments, reaching a perfect score of $100 \%$. The test findings on the impact of distance and camera resolution on performance suggested that the tool accurately detected objects within a range of 20 to 60 cm.

title: BERT-based Transfer Learning for Two-Class Sentiment Detection in Indonesian X apps Comments
authors: Muhammad Aamir Nashrullah, Pradini Puspitaningayu, Hapsari Peni Agustin Tjahyaningtijas, Yulia Fransisca, Muhamad Bagus Fikril Alan
publish: 2025 Eight International Conference on Vocational Education and Electrical Engineering (ICVEE)
abstract: This study develops a binary sentiment detection framework for Indonesian slang-rich X (Twitter) comments using BERT-based transfer learning. The informal nature of Indonesian digital discourse, characterized by context-dependent slang (e.g., "santuy" [chill] masking sarcasm or "jayus" [failed humor] implying negativity), challenges conventional sentiment analysis tools. The proposed method fine-tunes the pre-trained "indobert-base-uncased" model on a heterogeneous dataset of Indonesian X comments covering three topics: East Java governor performance, cellular service providers, and movie reviews. Preprocessing includes slang normalization via a custom dictionary, stopword removal (combining NLTK and Sastrawi), and Sastrawi-based stemming. The model achieved 92% test accuracy, with word clouds identifying key sentiment indicators like "mantap" (positive) and "lebay" (negative). Contextual analysis revealed BERT’s capacity to disambiguate slang, such as distinguishing sarcastic versus genuine uses of "woles" (relaxed). The results underscore transfer learning’s efficacy in adapting global NLP architectures to low-resource languages like Indonesian, where slang dominates digital communication. This work provides a scalable solution for real-time sentiment monitoring without manual lexicon updates, addressing the limitations of rule-based approaches. It highlights BERT’s potential to navigate linguistic fluidity in socio-culturally dynamic environments, offering actionable insights for businesses and researchers aiming to decode public sentiment in Indonesia’s evolving social media landscape.

title: Anomaly Detection in Network Traffic
authors: Sonam Sharma
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Advances in Computing Research On Science Engineering and Technology (ACROSET)
abstract: With the exponential rise in internet usage, ensuring the security and stability of network traffic has become a critical challenge. Anomaly detection plays a key role in identifying unusual network activities that may indicate cyber threats such as Distributed Denial-of-Service (DDoS) attacks, malware infections, and unauthorized access. Traditional rule-based detection systems struggle against evolving attack patterns, necessitating the use of machine learning and deep learning techniques for real- time anomaly detection. Experimental results demonstrate that ML-based anomaly detection models significantly outperform traditional methods, achieving high accuracy and low false- positive rates. This paper presents a comprehensive study on anomaly detection in network traffic, exploring various method- ologies, challenges, and future research directions.

title: Optimized Energy-Efficient IoT Healthcare Systems Using Hierarchical Deep Reinforcement Learning
authors: Ballari Supraja, Kiran Kumar. V, Krishna Kumar. N
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Advances in Computing Research On Science Engineering and Technology (ACROSET)
abstract: We present a new energy focused IoT healthcare structure in this paper with Hierarchical Deep Reinforcement Learning (HDRL) to optimise performance of an IoT healthcare structure on various levels of systems decision-making. In contrast to conventional architectures, the suggested model includes two-level reinforcement learning framework, namely Proximal Policy Optimization (PPO) at the cloud tier and Deep Q-Network (DQN) at the edge. This integration has enabled the system to be quicker in a real-time manner although it has the long-term strategic planning. Due to the extensive simulation with Python, TensorFlow and OpenAI Gym, a 40 percent decrease in energy usage and a 7 percent better patient outcomes are identified. The given system is robust, scalable, and can be possibly introduced into reality to implement intelligent IoT in healthcare. Future extensions could think of validation with the real-world, and privacy-preserving mechanisms.

title: Mdff-Net: A Multi-Domain Feature-Fusion Network for Robust Deepfake Video Detection
authors: Sravanthi Thota, RV Prakash
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Advances in Computing Research On Science Engineering and Technology (ACROSET)
abstract: The rapid evolution of generative adversarial and diffusion models has made it effortless to fabricate photorealistic "deepfake" videos, undermining public trust and posing serious social, political, and security risks. Existing detectors largely focus on spatial artifacts in individual frames, rendering them brittle when post-processed or confronted with newer generation methods that conceal pixel-level cues. We propose Multi-Domain Feature-Fusion Network (MDFF-Net), the first real-time framework that learns and fuses complementary spatial, temporal, and frequency evidence within a single, end-to-end architecture. MDFF-Net employs three specialized encoders Swin-V2 for RGB textures, TimeSformer Lite for motion dynamics, and a lightweight ResNet for log-magnitude Fourier spectra whose tokens are aggregated via a lightweight multi-head cross-attention module that adaptively re-weights each modality per clip. To improve reproducibility, we additionally provide a concise pseudo-code summary of the training and fusion algorithm within the paper, beyond releasing code and pre-trained weights. To train the model, we introduce a two stage strategy are modality specific pre training followed by joint fine-tuning on a diverse union of FaceForensics++, DFDC, Celeb-DF, DeepfakeBench, and an in-the-wild 2024 compilation. Extensive experiments show that MDFF-Net achieves 98.7% AUC on FaceForensics++ and 95.2%, AUC on DeepfakeBench, surpassing state of the art fusion baselines by up to 7.4 percentage points while sustaining 41 fps on a single RTX 4090 GPU. Ablation studies confirm that removing any branch degrades accuracy, and replacing cross-attention with concatenation reduces mean AUC by 2.9 points. Grad-CAM visualizations demonstrate interpretable, modality-specific focus on blending boundaries, physiological motion, and spectral artifacts. MDFF-Net’s code, pre-trained weights, and evaluation scripts will be released to foster practical adoption and stimulate future research on holistic deepfake forensics.

title: A Federated Learning Framework for Privacy-Preserving Heart Stroke Prediction in Distributed Healthcare Systems
authors: Parul Datta, Viswanathasarma Ch, V. Malathy, Balajee Maram, Alok Misra, U D Prasan
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Advances in Computing Research On Science Engineering and Technology (ACROSET)
abstract: Stroke is considered one of the most significant health problems in the world, as it kills more than 6.5 million people every year, so timely and correct identification of this disease is a significant issue. The classic models of centralized machine learning are efficient but represent a significant threat to data privacy and security because of the sharing and storing of sensitive patient data on centralized servers. To resolve this, we introduce a federated learning (FL) framework that will allow collaborative stroke prediction through training models on decentralized hospital data without having access to raw clinical records. The assessments on multi-institutional datasets indicate that the FL model yields an average prediction error of 92.4, an AUC of 0.94, and it is quite robust even when the data is non-IID and heterogeneous. Furthermore, secure aggregation led to a 28 percent decrease in the overhead of communication and the addition of the differential privacy property meant that the phenomenon of data leakage was not observed and only a minor 1.2 percent decrease in accuracy was incurred.

title: Comprehensive Models and Techniques for Processing Image, Text, Time Series, and Graph Data
authors: V. Suresh Kumar, M. S. Nidhya, Ira Nath, Kamalakar Ramineni, K. Sherin, Balajee Maram
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Innovative Data Communication Technologies and Application (ICIDCA)
abstract: This study presents a comparative evaluation of prominent machine learning approaches across three data modalities: text, image, and graph data. For text data, Transformer-based models such as BERT and GPT demonstrate overwhelming superiority with a 95% effectiveness rate, reflecting their contextual understanding and scalability. In image data analysis, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs) and YOLO dominate with effectiveness scores of 95% and 90% respectively, underscoring their capability in feature extraction and object detection. For graph-structured data, Graph Attention Networks (GATs) and Spatio-Temporal Graph Neural Networks (GNNs) lead with 92% and 90% effectiveness, showcasing their relevance in capturing complex node relationships and temporal patterns. The findings emphasize the importance of selecting specialized architectures tailored to data type to achieve optimal performance in machine learning applications.

title: Data-Driven Prediction of Football Player Positions Using Gradient Boosting Ensemble Models
authors: Nalini S Jagtap, Santoshkumar Chobe, Swati Nikam, Pallavi G. Patil, Suvarna Patil
publish: 2025 5th Asian Conference on Innovation in Technology (ASIANCON)
abstract: Position of football players is a key aspect that should not be underestimated regarding the efforts of teams to optimize their performance, game scouting, and game strategy. The proposed research ventures a machine learning algorithm with FIFA player data as the inputs and classifies the athletes into 30 positions in the field. The most important of them are data reprocessing, feature selection and class balancing. It uses a Gradient Boosting Classifier, which provides high precision through the analysis of such aspects as finishing, positioning, tackling, dribbling of the players. The model is used to analyze 5000 instances and measure precision, recall, F1-score and accuracy. The outcomes demonstrate a promising opportunity of using ensemble learning in sports analytics and provide an automated method of predicting the roles and a way of guiding data-driven solutions in the player development and team composition.

title: Safety and Security Management System Utilizing Facial Recognition, Deep Convolutional Neural Network (DCNN)
authors: Benjamin L. Cornelio, Nordy D. Siason
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Intelligent Perception and Computer Vision (CIPCV)
abstract: This study aims to develop a comprehensive assessment of a computer vision-based system designed for security and safety applications particularly in distinguishing between authorized and unauthorized users. The challenges of organizations across various industries constantly face this issue an evolving landscape of risks and threats that affects any organization or establishments. Establishing strong safety and security management systems is essential for enterprises to effectively mitigate these risks and safeguard their resources. Generally, the study aims to develop computer vision-based system capable of identifying security and safety threats in real time. To Utilize biometrics, such as facial recognition to accurately record the attendance of bonafide members of the organization. Then, set up a system that will allow pertinent stakeholders to get security notifications and vital updates, keeping them informed and allowing them to react appropriately to problems or threats as they arise. The researchers chose to have a developmental method of research. Through meticulous analysis, it was found that while the system effectively identifies faces and detects facial recognition, concerns regarding functionality and maintainability arise, primarily attributed to suboptimal plug-and-play camera quality. The overall evaluation based on the precision, recall and accuracy of the system. Conclusions drawn from the study highlight the critical impact of camera quality, processor performance, and hardware components on the system's operational efficacy. Practical recommendations advocate for the adoption of high-performance servers and high-definition cameras connected to a network to streamline operations.

title: Hybrid Deep Learning Framework for Accurate Skin Cancer Classification Using VGG-19 and Inception-Based Feature
authors: Sreedhar Kollem, Samineni Peddakrishna, Satrughan Kumar, Chandrasekhar Sirigiri, T. Venkatakrishnamoorthy
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Advances in Computing Research On Science Engineering and Technology (ACROSET)
abstract: Skin cancer is among the most frequent forms of cancer globally, and successful treatment solely relies on early and accurate diagnosis. Recent developments in deep learning technology have dramatically enhanced automated skin lesion classification performance and accuracy. The objective of this study is to develop a robust deep learning-based classification pipeline that can effectively discriminate between malignant and benign skin lesions through hybrid feature extraction and performance classification. The pipeline begins with a dermatological image dataset, which is then processed using preprocessing operations like resizing, normalization, data augmentation, and K-fold cross validation to ensure maximum data diversity and model generalizability. To extract robust and complementary features, we designed a hybrid dual-path architecture combining VGG-19 and InceptionV3. VGG-19 captures localized, fine-grained lesion details, while InceptionV3 captures multi-scale contextual information. The concatenated features are passed to a custom dense classifier trained specifically for dermatological image classification. Performance of the model is subsequently confirmed in terms of traditional sensitivity, specificity, and accuracy measures. Experimental results determine that the proposed hybrid model classifies superior to the individual models.

title: Cloud-Based Business Intelligence with AutoML for Financial Risk Management, Budget Optimization, and Accounting Simulations Using Cloudsim
authors: Rajeswaran Ayyadurai, Karthikeyan Parthasarathy, Naresh Kumar Reddy Panga, Jyothi Bobba, V R Prasaath
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Advances in Computing Research On Science Engineering and Technology (ACROSET)
abstract: Cloud-based business intelligence, Automated Machine Learning and CloudSim link to manage financial risk alongside budgetary optimization. It allows dynamic and real-time processing of data plus predictive analytics automation, which complements the proposed system for corporate decision-making and scalability. AutoML optimizes financial projections and resource allocation, while CloudSim simulates accounting situations to inform risk management and budgeting strategies better. Evolutionary and machine-learning algorithms are used in this approach to adapt in real time to financial perturbations while preserving accuracy and efficiency. The results show that the system enhances budget optimization, reduces financial risks, and increases the accuracy of financial projections, contributing to greater automation and scalability of corporate finance. With this data integration, all businesses can automate complex financial processes and operations, and even ensure sustainable financial management. Most importantly, the improved system will also help improve operational effectiveness, financial decision making and business resilience within a fast-changing economic environment

title: The Reduction of Energy Consumption in EVs by Using Sliding Mode Control of PMSM coupled with Planetary Gear in Transmission System
authors: Varin Cholahan, Tassaphan Suwannatat
publish: 2025 International Conference on Power, Energy and Innovations (ICPEI)
abstract: Electric Vehicles (EVs) are increasingly significant in modern transportation and industrial applications. To optimize energy consumption in EVs, it is crucial to evaluate a dynamic model of the transmission system, such as the Electric Motor, Gears, and Control system strategy. This document develops a dynamic model of the transmission system utilized in the E-Rickshaw, a lightweight EV manufactured in India. The proposed model incorporates a Planetary Gear (PG) and a Differential Gear (DG), linked to a Permanent Magnet Synchronous Motor (PMSM) instead of the old DC Motor and spur gear. A mathematical model with a focus on the transmission systems and the driving forces of the vehicle has been developed. In addition, the Sliding Mode Control (SMC) technique is constructed to stabilize the vehicle’s speed and inner d-q current loops. Finally, to verify that the proposed model meets the desired performance criteria, numerical simulations are conducted to validate the responses of the dynamic system and compare the performance to previous research.

title: Crowding Mechanism-Based GA-PTS Technique for PAPR Suppression in OFDM Systems
authors: Hao Lu, Peng Zhou, Peng Wang, Xiaojun Yan
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Networks, Communications and Information Technology (CNCIT)
abstract: In orthogonal frequency division multiplexing (OFDM) systems, excessively high peak-to-average power ratio (PAPR) severely degrades power efficiency and nonlinear distortion performance. Partial transmit sequence (PTS) technique is an effective approach for reducing PAPR, but its complexity is high because of its large combination of phase factors. Although the PTS method combined with genetic algorithm (GA) can reduce the computational complexity, it has the problem of premature convergence and is easy to obtain suboptimal solutions. In this paper, a GA-PTS method based on crowding mechanism is proposed to suppress PAPR. By introducing the crowding degree strategy of Hamming distance, the population diversity is enhanced and the premature convergence is avoided, so as to search the optimal phase factor combination more efficiently to suppress PAPR. The results of the simulation indicate that the algorithm put forward can substantially decrease the PAPR value in comparison to the conventional GA-PTS method. The PAPR performance is close to the PTS method under a certain number of populations and genetic generations, but the complexity is greatly reduced.

title: PELC: Power-Efficient and Low-Cost IoT-Based Real Time Operating System Enabled Solution For Biodiversity Application
authors: Karminder Singh, Milanpreet Kaur Sandhu, Suman Kumar
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Internet of Things and Intelligence Systems (IoTaIS)
abstract: Biodiversity conservation is an essential component of healthy ecosystems, and evidence of their decline in the face of multiple factors is a serious concern. Existing solutions are based on high-end processor devices, which have a complex nature in terms of structure and requirements for Linux and other heavy operating systems. Hence, the proposed system builds a biodiversity system on a resource-constrained hardware platform that features a lightweight Zephyr-based real-time operating system (RTOS). The designed system drives multimedia applications decisively and in power-efficient form by exploiting various features of RTOS, including parallel task scheduling, resource management, and synchronization between tasks. The system also designed a customized printed circuit board (PCB) that includes an nrf5340 system-on-chip (SoC), camera, SD card, 4G module, and power management circuit for providing an integrated solution for stable operation. Due to the IoT-based application, the message queuing telemetry transport (MQTT) protocol is used for transmitting and receiving captured data to the cloud. The proposed system also offers a cloud-based processing architecture to manage the captured data on the cloud for real-time operation. The developed web page and web portal enable remote monitoring of captured data and inferences of insect species classification.

title: Polyglot Persistence in Microservices: Managing Data Diversity in Distributed Systems
authors: Merita Kasa Halili, Festim Halili, Diellza Mustafai Veliu, Anila Nuhiji
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Internet of Things and Intelligence Systems (IoTaIS)
abstract: Microservices architectures have become the foundation for developing scalable and modern software systems, but they also bring significant challenges in managing heterogeneous and distributed data.The pragmatic solution is polyglot persistence, the deliberate use of several different database technologies adapted to a given microservice requirement - is one such strategy.This paper examines polyglot persistence in microservice based systems. This paper brings together theoretical concepts with evidence from practical implementations and comparative benchmarks of standard database platforms. A comparative framework is applied to relational, document, key-value, column-family and graph databases to assess scalability, consistency, query expressiveness, operational overhead and integration ease. Empirical data drawn from industry case studies such as Netflix, Uber, and Shopify, and survey data illustrate real-life adoption trends and challenges.These findings demonstrate that polyglot persistence increases adaptability / performance / domain alignment but also governance / operational complexity. To cope with such trade-offs, architectural patterns such as saga workflows, event sourcing, and outbox integration are discussed.

title: EffiSwin - Cross-Attention Based EfficientNet-Swin Transformer for Fine-Grained Food Classification
authors: Vidhi Bhamare, Sandhya Arora
publish: 2025 5th Asian Conference on Innovation in Technology (ASIANCON)
abstract: In smart food services, health tracking, and nutritional monitoring, food image classification is essential. However, while Vision Transformers (ViTs) are powerful, they are computationally demanding and inefficient for real-world applications, whereas typical convolutional neural networks (CNNs) have trouble grasping global context. In this research EffiSwin, a unique hybrid architecture is proposed that leverages a multi-head cross-attention fusion mechanism to combine the global context modelling of Swin Transformer with the local feature extraction capabilities of EfficientNet-B0. To further improve performance, label-aware MixUp is presented, which uses a lot less parameters to attain competitive accuracy while managing long-tail class distributions better. Using attention-based heatmaps, our model provides faster inference and better interpretability while achieving 87% accuracy on the Food-101 dataset, exceeding conventional ResNet-ViT hybrids. EffiSwin provides a workable solution for reliable food recognition in a variety of intricate classification tasks by striking a novel balance between accuracy, explainability, and deployment efficiency.

title: Correlation-Driven Smart Monitoring for Legacy Filling Machines
authors: Kittiched Kaivijit, Montagon Krutrarak, Chaiyong Soemphol
publish: 2025 International Conference on Power, Energy and Innovations (ICPEI)
abstract: This study investigates key process parameters affecting the speed of a legacy beverage filling machine by analyzing second-level sensor data collected via an existing SCADA/MQTT infrastructure. Correlation and regression analyses are applied to identify the most influential variables, particularly beer flow, CO2 flow, and setpoint speed. The results confirm that flow-related parameters play a dominant role in determining line performance, while polynomial regression provides a more accurate representation of nonlinear process interactions than linear models. The findings offer practical guidelines for monitoring and diagnosing speed variations using a limited set of available sensors, without requiring major hardware upgrades. Overall, this work demonstrates how data-driven approaches can improve production reliability and provide a foundation for future predictive maintenance in brewery operations.

title: A CLAHE-MIRNet-YOLOv5 Pipeline for Vehicle Detection in Night Vision Surveillance
authors: Venkatesh, Akash, Abhiraj N, Mahesh Panwar, Manish Suhag, Sunil
publish: 2025 5th Asian Conference on Innovation in Technology (ASIANCON)
abstract: In traditional methods for vehicle detection, particularly at night, issues like low brightness, poor contrast, and heavy noise made it difficult to detect vehicles accurately. Standard object detection models are unable to figure out detail aspects such as color and texture, in aerial images, which are much smaller and less comprehensible objects. To address the issues, this paper created a unique framework that, first of all, performs nighttime image enhance ment through defogging and uses a deep learning model, called MIRNet to enhance features particularly low light images. These images are then passed to YOLOv5, which detects vehicles in the image with a unique ID, and track each frame in the image with a lightweight template matching. The experimental results illustrate efficiency of model, with the scores of 92.4 percentage for detection, and 86.1 percentage for tracking on the UAVDT dataset and 90.4 percentage for detection and 83.3 percentage for tracking on the VisDrone dataset. The proposed work outperformed state of the art, especially under low light conditions. The main advantage of this proposed work is lightweight design, efficient approach and accurate detection and tracking of vehicles in nighttime conditions.

title: Cloud-Edge Collaborative Learning: Real-Time IoT Data Processing with GoLang Microservices for Agriculture
authors: Ashish Gawande
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Internet of Things and Intelligence Systems (IoTaIS)
abstract: Agriculture is entering a new digital era, with IoT devices generating a large amount of data from soil sensors, drones, livestock trackers, and greenhouse controllers. Traditional cloud-only systems send all this data to remote servers, which causes delays, excessive network usage, and a dependence on constant internet connectivity. This paper introduces a GoLang‑based cloud–edge collaborative learning framework. In this design, edge devices handle tasks such as local inference, anomaly detection, and actuator control that require rapid processing. At the same time, the cloud collects anomaly data, retrains AI models, and sends updated TinyML models back to the edge. This paper provides clear technical guidance, including GoLang microservice code, JSON formats, Kafka topic, MQTT message structures, and Kubernetes deployment examples. A basic evaluation reveals that the system can respond in under 250 ms, reduce bandwidth usage by approximately 80%, and scale effectively to support large farms.

title: UAV Based Real-time Accident Detection using Machine Learning and Edge AI Devices
authors: Harsh Chaudhary, Ruchi Gajjar, Rutvik Patel
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Advances in Computing Research On Science Engineering and Technology (ACROSET)
abstract: The increasing number of personal vehicles has escalated the risk of road accidents, highlighting the need for advanced accident detection systems. Many machine-learning models are available for accident detection. We propose a machine learning-based model for accident detection using YOLOv5 and YOLOv9. These models are trained on a dataset of 3310 images covering varied light scenarios, achieving 65-70% confidence. Deployed on edge AI devices like Raspberry Pi 4B and NVIDIA Jetson Orin Nano, our model enables real-time processing and detection through live video feed from drones. This approach enhances detection accuracy and efficiency, providing a scalable solution for road safety. Our work advances current models by effectively addressing cutting-edge machine learning and edge AI technology, potentially saving lives through timely accident detection and response.

title: Cancer Detection Using MobileNet and CNN Models for Identification of Skin Diseases Using Deep Learning Technology
authors: Mukesh Patidar, Praveen Bhanodia, Kamal Kumar Sethi, Anil Bhushan
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Advances in Computing Research On Science Engineering and Technology (ACROSET)
abstract: Skin cancer is one of the most common types of cancer in the world. It is important to find skin cancer early so that it can be treated effectively and more people can survive. This work proposes a sophisticated deep learning-based healthcare solution for the automatic classification of skin lesions (abnormal area) into benign (non-cancerous) and malignant (cancerous) classes using MobileNet and Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) models. The suggested model takes advantage of the pre-trained MobileNet architecture as a feature extractor and then adds custom dense and dropout layers for the best classification. The system was trained and tested using a balanced dataset of 1,000 dermoscopic images. The model attained an impressive accuracy of 91%, with precision, recall, and F1-score values all ranging around 0.90 for both classes. The confusion matrix analysis also validated the model's strength, accurately classifying 474 benign and 433 malignant cases with a reasonable level of misclassification. The model also had a log loss of 0.49 and a Cohen's Kappa score of 0.81, which reflects substantial agreement between predicted and actual labels. These findings verify that the suggested deep learning method is efficient and accurate for real-time and automated skin cancer detection, which can assist dermatologists in early diagnosis and planning for treatment.
