title: Nearfield Phase-Free Retrieval Based on Source Reconstruction with Grey Wolf Optimizer-Adaptive Differential Evolution Algorithm
authors: Maohan He, Cenle Wang, Shuyuan Chu, Juliang Lv, Teng Li
publish: 2025 18th IEEE United Conference on Millimeter Waves and Terahertz Technologies (UCMMT)
abstract: This paper proposes a hybrid Grey Wolf Optimizer and Adaptive Differential Evolution (GWO-ADE) algorithm with source reconstruction for near-field phase-free characterization. It proposes a method requiring only dual-plane amplitude measurements for full-phase reconstruction, eliminating the need for phase data. This approach integrates electromagnetic field theory with the hybrid GWO-ADE optimization algorithm to estimate equivalent source distributions. Phase information across measurement planes is extracted via field propagation using the reconstructed source model. Numerical experiments validate the algorithm's high-accuracy phase retrieval capability with reduced computational cost, while its hybrid optimization design effectively avoids local optima entrapment.

title: The Role of Technology Museums in Preserving and Exhibiting Objects of Technological History and their impact on Society
authors: Sadhana Attavar
publish: 2025 IEEE History of Electrotechnology Conference (HISTELCON)
abstract: Technology museums serve as vital institutions for the preservation interpretation and dissemination of technological heritage. This paper explores the vital role of technology museums in preserving and exhibiting the objects related to the history of technology. It also demonstrates the impact that technology museums have in educating the public and fostering dialogue about the relationship between technology and society. Case study of some of the technological collections of Visvesvaraya Industrial and Technological Museum in Bangalore India are discussed.

title: Attention-Augmented BiLSTM with Ensemble Learning for Fault Diagnosis in Industrial Processes
authors: Hamed Soltani, Behzad Moshiri
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Control, Instrumentation and Automation (ICCIA)
abstract: Fault detection and diagnosis (FDD) is a critical challenge due to the increasing complexity of systems and the prevalence of high-dimensional, complex industrial processes. This paper proposes a supervised deep learning framework that integrates an attention mechanism with a Bidirectional Long Short-Term Memory (BiLSTM) network to extract discriminative temporal features from multivariate process data. Finally, three classifiers-Support Vector Machine (SVM), Random Forest (RF), and XGBoost-were trained using the extracted features. To enhance classification performance, these classifiers were then combined using the stacking method, and Gradient Boosting was used as the meta-learner in this method. The Tennessee Eastman Process (TEP) dataset was used to evaluate the suggested approach. The results shows that the attention-augmented BiLSTM model outperforms standard BiLSTM in feature extraction and classification framework, achieves an average accuracy of 97 % in detecting faults, and demonstrates strong robustness against sensor noise, maintaining high diagnostic performance even under 40 % Gaussian noise levels

title: Hera: A Heterogeneity-Aware Multi-Tenant Inference Server for Personalized Recommendations
authors: Yujeong Choi, John Kim, Minsoo Rhu
publish: 2025 34th International Conference on Parallel Architectures and Compilation Techniques (PACT)
abstract: While providing low latency is a fundamental requirement in deploying recommendation services, achieving high resource utility is also crucial in cost-effectively maintaining the datacenter. Co-locating model workers is an effective way to maximize query-level parallelism and server throughput, but the interference caused by concurrent workers at shared resources can prevent server queries from meeting its SLA. Hera utilizes the heterogeneous memory requirement of multi-tenant recommendation models to intelligently determine a productive set of colocated models and its resource allocation, providing fast response time while achieving high throughput. Hera achieves an average 37.3% improvement in effective machine utilization, enabling 26% reduction in required servers, significantly improving upon the baseline recommendation inference server.

title: Robust Data-Driven QFT Synthesis in the Presence of High Uncertainty
authors: Mahdi Sadigh Dallali, Ali Khaki Sedigh
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Control, Instrumentation and Automation (ICCIA)
abstract: This paper presents a Data-Driven approach to Quantitative Feedback Theory (DD-QFT) design methodology directly from experimental frequency-domain data, entirely bypassing the need for a parametric plant model. The approach first characterizes plant uncertainty by collecting multiple Frequency Response Functions (FRFs) via input-output data and Fast Fourier Transform (FFT) analysis. At each frequency, the proposed method identifies a “worst-case” response by selecting the sample with minimum normalized distance to critical stability point. Controller synthesis is formulated as a constrained optimization problem, where a fixed-structure controller is designed to shape the open-loop response of this worst-case plant to a desired frequency-domain target. The method is validated on a second-order system with significant parametric uncertainty, demonstrating that the designed controller ensures robust closedloop performance, with all step responses closely matching a reference model.

title: CPC: Coordinated Page Cache for Serverless Computing
authors: Keun Soo Lim, Yunjay Hong, Jongheon Jeong, Sam Son, Donguk Kim, Yeonhong Park, Jae W. Lee, Jinkyu Jeong
publish: 2025 34th International Conference on Parallel Architectures and Compilation Techniques (PACT)
abstract: Virtual machine-based serverless computing suffers from high memory overhead due to data duplication. This duplication occurs not only across function (or VM) images but also within in-memory caches shared between VMs. Such redundancy limits the scalability and efficiency of serverless computing infrastructure. While existing memory deduplication techniques can help, they are ill-suited to serverless computing due to their high CPU overhead and delayed deduplication, which often comes too late to provide meaningful memory savings given the short lifetime of a function. However, serverless platforms inherently know which functions (or VMs) will be executed in advance, presenting a unique opportunity for proactive memory optimization. In this paper, we propose CPC, a proactive deduplication scheme that enables efficient page sharing across microVMs, lightweight variants of traditional VMs, in serverless environments. Upon function submission, CPC deduplicates identical files across function images using existing techniques. During function execution, CPC leverages this deduplication information to further deduplicate redundant cache data across VMs and the hypervisor. Comprehensive experiments using serverless function benchmarks show that CPC reduces memory consumption by up to 32.0% compared to AWS Lambda when hosting heterogeneous functions on a shared worker node. Furthermore, with Azure Functions traces, CPC achieves a 41.2% reduction in 99th percentile tail latency by reducing unnecessary instance evictions through more efficient memory utilization.

title: Investigation on AI-Powered Digital Health in Parkinson's Disease Diagnosis
authors: Jieming Zhang, Sungwook Hur, Yongho Lee, Tai-Myoung Chung
publish: 2025 IEEE 15th International Conference on System Engineering and Technology (ICSET)
abstract: Parkinson's disease (PD) is a progressive neurodegenerative disorder affecting millions worldwide, characterized by a range of motor and non-motor symptoms. Accurate early diagnosis and effective long-term management are critical for pre-serving the quality of life of patients yet remain challenging in clinical practice. Recent advances in artificial intelligence (AI), particularly in deep learning, are transforming how PD is detected and treated. This investigation provides a comprehensive examination of the current state and emerging trends in AI-powered digital health for PD. We first explore diagnostic applications of deep learning, highlighting how Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs), Graph Convolutional Networks (GCNs), and related architectures are used to analyze handwriting, gait, and voice data for objective PD detection during early stages. These methods have demonstrated high accuracy in identifying PD-related patterns and hold promise for scalable remote screening. Next, we discuss clinical impact, integration challenges, and future directions for diagnostic AI tools. This investigation underscores the growing role of AI in enabling personalized, data-driven, and accessible care for individuals with PD.

title: Mountain Antennas - Climax and Farewell of Commercial VLF Technology
authors: Peter Kurz, Hugo Wyss
publish: 2025 IEEE History of Electrotechnology Conference (HISTELCON)
abstract: Wireless telegraphy of the <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$1920^{\text{ies}}$</tex> and earlier used Very Low Frequency (VLF) transmission, requiring enormous-sized aerials like the spokes of the wheel antenna at Radio Central, Long Island. A special kind of VLF antenna was the so-called Mountain Antenna spanning between mountain tops. Only two such Mountain Antennas were ever erected for commercial purposes: One in an extinct volcano in Malabar/Java, the other on the Herzogstand in Bavaria. They both suffered from design faults, though, which are investigated in this paper, and never reached their contemplated efficiency. In the end, they became redundant as VLF transmission technology was replaced by the use of short waves (except for special applications like submarine communications).

title: A Decoupled VR and Real-time Audio System for Distributed Musical Collaboration
authors: Alberto Boem, Ovidiu Costin Andrioaia, Domenico Stefani, Alessandra Micalizzi, Luca Turchet
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th International Symposium on the Internet of Sounds (IS2)
abstract: Musical collaboration in virtual reality (VR) faces a fundamental technical challenge: achieving the ultra-low latency required for ensemble synchronization while maintaining the rich spatial interactions characteristic of Shared Virtual Environments. This paper presents a proof-of-concept for a hybrid decoupled architecture that addresses these competing requirements of real-time graphics, interactions, and audio through strategic layer separation. Our system combines dedicated real-time audio hardware for networked music performance (Elk LIVE) with consumer head-mounted displays running a custom-made social VR application (made with the Ubiq framework). These two subsystems are connected through lightweight control messaging infrastructure. We evaluated the system through deployment with 12 musicians across three distributed groups, measuring technical performance metrics and user experience through standardized questionnaires. Results show that the audio subsystem maintained consistent latency with minimal packet loss, while VR layer performance varied significantly. Participants achieved moderate levels of social presence and creativity support, with evidence suggesting that audio consistency enables musical focus even when visual performance degrades. Our findings indicate that decoupled architectures might resolve the tension between musical precision and VR immersion requirements, providing design principles for next-generation Musical Metaverse systems that prioritize temporal consistency over absolute performance optimization.

title: Comparing Singing Lessons in Mixed Reality, Video, and In-Person
authors: Leonard Bruns, Benedict Saurbier, Tray Minh Voong, Wiebke Blume, Tobias Rotsch, Michael Oehler
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th International Symposium on the Internet of Sounds (IS2)
abstract: This within-subjects study compared three one-to-one singing lesson modalities — Mixed Reality (MR), tablet-based video conferencing, and in-person instruction. Thirty vocal students each completed all three formats in a fully counterbalanced design. Before and after each lesson we assessed task-specific self-efficacy, post-performance, self-evaluation, interaction naturalness, audio support quality (remote only), cognitive load, and social presence. We also continuously recorded electrodermal activity (EDA) and heart rate variability (HRV). No reliable differences emerged in self-efficacy or self-evaluation across conditions, though self-efficacy consistently predicted self-evaluation accuracy. Interaction naturalness was highest in-person and similar in video and MR, whereas MR yielded significantly higher perceived audio quality than video. MR produced substantially greater social presence than video. Contrary to expectations, cognitive load ratings of intrinsic and extraneous load did not differ by modality, while the effort to maintain task-related focus (germane load) was slightly lower in MR than in-person. EDA and HRV showed no significant modality effects, except a non-significant trend toward lower arousal in MR. These findings suggest that MR singing lessons can match — and in some respects exceed — standard video conferencing while approximating many benefits of face-to-face teaching, with no increase in cognitive burden and even reduced effort to maintain focus.

title: Effect of Dataset Quantity and Feature Variability on Machine Learning Performance for ECG-Based Diabetes Prediction
authors: Muhamad Ramadhani, Dodon Turianto Nugrahadi, Mohammad Reza Faisal, Muliadi, Dwi Kartini, Friska Abadi, Favorisen Rosyking Lumbanraja
publish: 2025 8th International Conference of Computer and Informatics Engineering (IC2IE)
abstract: Diabetes is a chronic disease that often goes undetected in its early stages, potentially leading to severe complications if left untreated. Non-invasive and reliable early screening methods are required to improve patient compliance compared to traditional invasive monitoring techniques. While ECG signals have been extensively studied for heart disease detection, their application for diabetes classification remains underexplored, with previous studies on the D1NAMO dataset reporting limited accuracy. This study addresses this gap by applying R-peak detection for ECG segmentation and systematically evaluating the effect of dataset quantity and feature variability on model performance. Three classical machine learning algorithms (SVM, KNN, and DT) were evaluated under multiple dataset quantity and feature variability configurations. Experimental results indicate that DT achieved the highest accuracy of 85.30% with 5000 samples and 500 ECG features. These results underscore the capability of tree-based algorithms to deliver precise and efficient non-invasive diabetes predictions. The outcomes provide a foundation for further exploration of advanced methods to enhance robustness and adaptability in clinical practice.

title: Multi-level Architecture for IoT-based Android Ransomware Detection and Family Attribution
authors: Ines Gharbi, Amit Agarwal, Abdelouahid Derhab, Mohamed Belaoued, Abdelouahab Amira, Kamel Barkaoui
publish: 2025 9th Cyber Security in Networking Conference (CSNet)
abstract: Due to the proliferation of the Internet of Things (IoT), Android-based IoT devices are increasingly targeted by sophisticated ransomware threats. To address this issue, we propose a hierarchical architecture for ransomware detection and family attribution that leverages solely API call sequences extracted from Android apps. The architecture is designed to analyze a continuous stream of apps. It comprises three sequential levels: (1) Malware detection to distinguish benign apps from malware, (2) Ransomware detection to differentiate ransomware from other malware types, and (3) Ransomware family attribution to assign detected ransomware to its actual family. This architecture is novel in that it differs from the single-level approaches proposed in the literature and considers all types of apps, including benign, ransomware, and other malware types. In addition, we extensively evaluated the architecture on the CICAndMal2017 dataset by combining different models and data pre-processing methods, which enables the evaluation of a total of 135 machine learning workflows across all levels. The evaluation results show accuracies of 92% and 100% were obtained for ransomware detection and ransomware family attribution, respectively.

title: Influence of Moisture Content on the Complex Refractive Index of Ceramics
authors: Emil John Y. Magaway, Alex Cendrowicz, Zhenyu Zhang, Miguel Navarro-Cía
publish: 2025 18th IEEE United Conference on Millimeter Waves and Terahertz Technologies (UCMMT)
abstract: The high sensitivity of THz to water makes it an ideal tool for detecting moisture changes within samples. This work is a drying study of two low-porosity ceramic samples, Sample B and T. Both samples were submerged in water for 5 minutes and their THz responses were recorded every 30 minutes using a transmission mode THz-TDS system, until fully dry. The effective dielectric properties of the ceramics were extracted at frequencies up to 0.5 THz. The data displayed an inverse proportionality between the effective <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$n$</tex> and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\alpha$</tex> of the samples and drying time, with a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$6.5-7 {\%}$</tex> decrease seen in effective <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$n$</tex> and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$55-60 {\%}$</tex> reduction in a from measurements taken 30 minutes following submersion to 210-240 minutes after. The strong correlation between effective dielectric properties and moisture content is showcased and highlights the potential of THz techniques for moisture monitoring.

title: A Circularly Polarized Coplanar Antenna Using Spoof Surface Plasmons
authors: Haowen Quan, Jiayuan Lu, Anqi Zhang, Leilei Liu
publish: 2025 18th IEEE United Conference on Millimeter Waves and Terahertz Technologies (UCMMT)
abstract: This study presents a circularly polarized antenna through spoof surface plasmons in coplanar structure. Distinct from conventional cross-layer phase delay line implementations requiring multilayer substrate arrangements, the SSP topology enables full integration of functional components within a single metallization plane, thereby significantly simplifying the fabrication process while maintaining electromagnetic performance integrity. Numerical simulations demonstrate an operational bandwidth spanning <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$2.006-2.532 \text{GHz}(24.1 \%$</tex> fractional bandwidth) with impedance matching characteristics below -10 dB return loss. The circular polarization efficacy spanning <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$2.482 \text{GHz}-2.520 \text{GHz}$</tex> by a 38 MHz axial-ratio bandwidth (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$AR <3 dB$</tex>) centered at 2.4 GHz. Radiation pattern analysis reveals stable gain characteristics maintaining <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$7.5 \boldsymbol{\pm} 0.2$</tex> dBic.

title: Harmonic Control Class Based on 0.25-μm GaAs pHEMT Process Wideband High Efficiency Power Amplifier Design
authors: Zhicong Ye, Ke Liu, Linqi Zeng, Zhihao Zhang, Gary Zhang
publish: 2025 18th IEEE United Conference on Millimeter Waves and Terahertz Technologies (UCMMT)
abstract: In this article, a broadband high-efficiency power amplifier (PA) based on harmonic control for Sub 6G applications is proposed. The high efficiency performance is achieved by controlling the harmonic termination impedance of the last-stage transistor so that both the secondary and tertiary impedances are located in the harmonic high efficiency region. The output matching network proposed in this paper can control the second and third harmonic impedances while matching the fundamental impedance to suppress the second and third harmonics. The proposed amplifier architecture and design idea are simulated and tested on a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{0. 2 5}-\boldsymbol{\mu} \mathrm{m}$</tex> GaAs pHEMT process for verification. The test results show that the PA has a Power Added Efficiency (PAE) greater than 50 % and an output power greater than 25.9 dBm in the bandwidth range of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$1.6 \sim 2.8 \text{GHz}$</tex>, and the PAE reaches a maximum of 57.3 % when the PA operates at 2 GHz with an output power of 26.7 dBm and a small-signal gain of greater than 30 dB, the simulation and test results of each performance of the circuit basically match, and the overall circuit size is <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$1.7 ~\text{mm}^{2}$</tex>. In comparison with other works, the amplifier proposed in this paper achieves a larger bandwidth and higher efficiency.

title: High Power Continuous Wave Measurement Based on a Four-Way Power Divider
authors: Fan Yang, Guo Liu, Yingjian Cao, Zewei Wu, Wei Jiang, Jianxun Wang, Yelei Yao, Yong Luo
publish: 2025 18th IEEE United Conference on Millimeter Waves and Terahertz Technologies (UCMMT)
abstract: The gyrotron travelling wave tubes (gyro-TWTs) are progressively evolving towards higher output power and broader bandwidth, generating substantial demand for advanced high-power microwave measurement techniques. The power handling capacity of traditional water loads is fundamentally limited by the properties of microwave-transparent dielectric materials. To overcome this critical limitation, this work proposes an innovative approach employing a four-way power divider integrated with distributed water loads to absorb and measure power. The proposed methodology has successfully demonstrated effective absorption and precise measurement of microwave radiation at a high-power continuous wave (CW) of 104 kW.

title: A 160GHz wideband LNA with Dual-Peak-Gmax Cores in 40nm CMOS for 6G Applications
authors: Jionghua Zheng, Jiaxuan Li, Wenman Han, Jingfeng Du, Yijing Zhong, Yinggang Li
publish: 2025 18th IEEE United Conference on Millimeter Waves and Terahertz Technologies (UCMMT)
abstract: This article presents a 160GHz wideband low-noise amplifier (LNA) implemented in a 40nm CMOS process for emerging 6G sub-THz applications. A three-stage common-source(CS) topology incorporating dual-peak-<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$G_{\text {max }}$</tex> cores is proposed to overcome the gain-bandwidth trade-off at high frequencies. Post-layout simulations demonstrate a peak power gain of 15.5dB at 160GHz, with 17GHz 3-dB bandwidth from 145 to 162 GHz. Return loss <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$S_{11}$</tex> and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$S_{22}$</tex> remain below -10 dB over <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$144-162 \text{GHz}$</tex>. The minimum noise figure is 8.38 dB at 160 GHz while consuming 73.2 mW from a 1.2 V supply.

title: Preliminary Studies on Radially Resonant Bent Sensing Textile Circular Sector Microstrip Patch Antenna
authors: Nuo Chen, Zi-Qiang Liu, Ke Ma, Yu-Cheng Luo, Xiao-Hui Li, Wen-Jun Lu
publish: 2025 18th IEEE United Conference on Millimeter Waves and Terahertz Technologies (UCMMT)
abstract: This article proposes a radially resonant, circumference short-circuited circular sector flexible microstrip patch antenna (MPA) for bent sensing. Unlike conventional rigid patch antennas, the flexible microstrip patch antenna fabricated on a denim substrate demonstrates excellent bendability and conformal adherence to curved surfaces. When deployed as an RFID tag, it enables bent detection by monitoring shifts in resonant frequency. A comparative analysis of bent-sensing sensitivity has been conducted among the proposed antenna under radial resonance, classical rectangular patch antenna and circular patch antenna. The results reveal that the radially resonant circular sector MPA with a short-circuited circumference exhibits superior sensitivity under specific bending orientations.

title: Uav Air-Ground Terahertz Channel Characterization in Urban Environments
authors: Jie Yang, Jiayuan Cui, Yue Su, He Jiang, Chenxi Wang, Houjun Sun, Jianjun Ma
publish: 2025 18th IEEE United Conference on Millimeter Waves and Terahertz Technologies (UCMMT)
abstract: This paper investigates UAV air-ground channel behavior at terahertz frequency in urban street environments through raytracing. It analyzes the impact of building dimensions, street configurations, and surface materials on channel performance. Findings indicate minimal geometric influence on path loss but increased delay spread with larger urban structures; small-scale fading follows a Rician distribution.

title: Connecting MIDI Interfaces to the Musical Metaverse
authors: Gregorio Andrea Giudici, Domenico Stefani, Alberto Boem, Luca Turchet
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th International Symposium on the Internet of Sounds (IS2)
abstract: The integration of physical control surfaces with virtual reality environments presents significant challenges, particularly in the Musical Metaverse where users are musicians who are often encumbered by their instruments while engaging in musical practices. This paper presents MUSMET-Bridge, a standalone embedded system designed to connect USB MIDI control surfaces directly to standalone VR headsets through wireless networks, reducing the interaction overhead introduced by the use of a laptop. The system offers superior portability through its pocket-sized design powered by standard power banks, eliminates cable clutter that complicates performance setups, and provides plug-and-play operation that abstracts technical complexity from end users. The system was designed for MIDI-to-OSC message conversion for controlling Musical Metaverse applications, and was tested with the PatchWorld XR platform. We conducted a comparative evaluation study that examined the setup procedures and user experience between the proposed system and conventional laptop-based workflows using TouchOSC. Our results indicate a reduced setup complexity, with MUSMET-Bridge reducing average setup time while achieving comparable usability scores and maintaining identical responsiveness and precision for musical expression. The system demonstrates potential for enhancing accessibility to the Musical Metaverse while reducing the interaction overhead associated with current computer-mediated connection setups.

title: ConsistencyDrive: Efficient End-to-End Autonomous Driving with Consistency Models
authors: Junli Wang, Qichao Zhang
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Control, Robotics and Cybernetics (CRC)
abstract: Diffusion models have demonstrated remarkable success in image generation and robotics, leveraging their powerful multi-modal representation capabilities. However, their application in autonomous driving presents a critical challenge: balancing inference speed with performance. To address this challenge, we propose ConsistencyDrive, an end-to-end driving policy with multi-modal trajectory generation for autonomous vehicles based on fast-sampling consistency models. By integrating a consistency-constrained ordinary differential equation (ODE) for trajectory learning, ConsistencyDrive can generate high-quality, multi-modal trajectories in a single inference step while maintaining strong performance. To enhance trajectory smoothness and accelerate convergence, we introduce a reconstruction loss constraint during training. In addition, we design a multi-modal trajectory scorer to select the optimal trajectory from multi-model generated trajectories. Experimental results on the challenging NAVSIMv2 closed-loop benchmark demonstrate that ConsistencyDrive achieves superior performance, strong generalization, and a significant improvement in inference speed.

title: Design of All Dielectric Metasurface Absorber Based on High Permittivity Ceramics
authors: Liyang Li, Shaobo Qu, Jun Wang, Jiafu Wang, Mingde Feng, Mingbao Yan, Jingli Wang
publish: 2025 18th IEEE United Conference on Millimeter Waves and Terahertz Technologies (UCMMT)
abstract: This paper uses high-permittivity ceramics to design an all dielectric metasurface absorber, which can form a good absorption effect through dielectric resonances. The absorption efficiency can reach over 90 %. This design uses an integrated connected structure, which facilitates the use of mature technologies such as solid-state sintering or 3D printing for production. Ceramic materials have advantages such as high temperature resistance, oxidation resistance, corrosion resistance, and high power resistance. This design method can adjust resonance to achieve absorption of different bandwidths and frequencies, and has potential application value.

title: Deep Learning Assisted Inverse Design of Parameters for Liquid Crystal Reconfigurable Coded Metasurface Units
authors: Wuhao Cao, Yuyang Zhang, Silin Guo, Qiangju Xu, Kexue Sun
publish: 2025 18th IEEE United Conference on Millimeter Waves and Terahertz Technologies (UCMMT)
abstract: Traditional liquid crystal (LC) metasurface design methods are not suitable for real-time applications due to their high time cost and huge computational effort. To address this problem, we propose a deep learning assisted inverse design method for LC reconfigurable coding metasurfaces units. Our method employs a convolutional autoencoder to compress highdimensional binary masks into a latent vector space. Then, a lightweight feed-forward neural network predicts structural parameters and latent vectors directly from the target multifrequency response, thus enabling global design and significantly reducing the search space. Experimental results show that the proposed method achieves a 10<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">4</sup> times faster design speed on the test set compared to the NSGA-II algorithm while achieving comparable performance. Therefore, the proposed framework is capable of fast and accurate design of programmable LC metasurfaces. Its excellent real-time and practical performance make it well suited for large-scale real-time reconfigurable systems that require fast iterations.

title: Flexible Wrapper for Ensemble Machine Learning Trees Targeting High-Performance HBM-FPGAs
authors: Icaro G. S. Moreira, Olavo Silva, Lucas Bragança, Racyus D. G. Pacífico, Ricardo Ferreira, José Augusto M. Nacif
publish: 2025 XV Symposium on Computing Systems Engineering (SBESC)
abstract: Machine learning (ML) increases the demand for real-time inference and efficient hardware-based acceleration. This paper evaluates decision tree ensemble implementations on FPGA platforms coupled with High Bandwidth Memory (HBM). While traditional implementations often deploy hundreds of trees ("jungles") to maximize accuracy, our work demonstrates that carefully designed compact ensembles ("copses") can achieve comparable accuracy while better aligning with the architectural constraints of modern FPGA-HBM systems. We present a flexible wrapper for the automatic implementation of ML models, particularly tree-based models, on hardware. In addition, we developed a custom tree-based architecture with a variable pipeline aimed at maximizing throughput. By distributing smaller tree ensembles across parallel processing modules with direct HBM access, we eliminate the performance bottlenecks associated with large monolithic implementations that necessitate complex interconnection networks. We implemented the accelerator on the Xilinx Alveo FPGA platform, using 32 HBM channels, and performed the experiments in a realistic high-performance HPC cluster. Our results demonstrate that the accelerator processes 17 billion samples and low logic resource utilization while leveraging the high memory bandwidth of HBM.

title: MuMeNet: A Network Simulator for Musical Metaverse Communications
authors: Ali Al Housseini, Jaime Llorca, Luca Turchet, Tiziano Leidi, Cristina Rottondi, Omran Ayoub
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th International Symposium on the Internet of Sounds (IS2)
abstract: The Metaverse, a shared and spatially organized digital continuum, is transforming various industries, with music emerging as a leading use case. Live concerts, collaborative composition, and interactive experiences are driving the Musical Metaverse (MM), but the requirements of the underlying network and service infrastructures hinder its growth. These challenges underscore the need for a novel modeling and simulation paradigm tailored to the unique characteristics of MM sessions, along with specialized service provisioning strategies capable of capturing their interactive, heterogeneous, and multicast-oriented nature. To this end, we make a first attempt to formally model and analyze the problem of service provisioning for MM sessions in 5G/6G networks. We first formalize service and network graph models for the MM, using "live audience interaction in a virtual concert" as a reference scenario. We then present MuMeNet, a novel discrete-event network simulator specifically tailored to the requirements and the traffic dynamics of the MM. We showcase the effectiveness of MuMeNet by running a linear programming based orchestration policy on the reference scenario and providing performance analysis under realistic MM workloads.

title: Multimodal Input Fusion Network for Pediatric CT Denoising: Cross-Attention Between CT and Iodine Maps
authors: Weihao Zhang, Chaogang Lu, Hairui Wang, Xiaomei Wu, Zhongwei Qiao, Shengjie Yan
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Biomedical Signal and Image Processing (ICBIP)
abstract: This manuscript proposes a Multimodal input Residual Encoder-Decoder Network (MultimodalInputRED-CNN) leveraging complementary information from CT images and iodine maps to enhance pediatric CT image denoising while preserving diagnostically critical details. The MultimodalInputRED-CNN featured a Multimodal input residual encoder-decoder network with three key components: (1) a specialized dual-branch encoder that processes CT images with 5 <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\times 5$</tex> convolution kernels for noise suppression and iodine maps with <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$3 \times 3$</tex> kernels for detail preservation; (2) an innovative crossattention mechanism that computes channel and spatial attention weights to adaptively fuse features based on local image characteristics; (3) a noise confidence assessment module that dynamically adjusts the influence of iodine map features according to noise conditions. The method was evaluated on pediatric lower limb CT images under various noise scenarios. Under Gaussian noise conditions, the MultimodalInputRED-CNN achieved a PSNR of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$33.79 \pm 1.31 ~\text{dB}$</tex> and SSIM of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$0.9560 \pm 0.0163$</tex>, outperforming NAFNet by <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1. 2 3 ~ d B}$</tex>. For mixed noise, our LPIPS score of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$0.0349 \pm 0.0037$</tex> represented a 36.4 % improvement over EDCNN. Ablation studies showed removing iodine map input resulted in a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1. 7 6 ~ d B}$</tex> PSNR drop. The MultimodalInputRED-CNN overcomes limitations of traditional single-input methods when processing complex anatomical regions, providing a new technique for improving pediatric low-dose CT imaging with potential clinical value.

title: The Flexible Antenna with Reconfigurability Characteristics for Military Applications
authors: Nur Alia Arinah Roslan, Izni Husna Idris, Mohd Taufik Jusoh, Kamilia Kamardin, Noor Amalina Ramli, Mohamad Rijal Hamid
publish: 2025 IEEE International RF and Microwave Conference (RFM)
abstract: This paper presents a flexible antenna design with reconfigurability characteristics intended for integration into military uniforms to support effective communication in the field. The proposed antenna consists of a tapered slot and a slotted stub using Rogers as the substrate. The antenna operates in two different modes: wideband and narrowband. In wideband mode, the antenna operates from 1.0 GHz to 3.0 GHz, while in narrowband mode, the antenna operates at 1.575 GHz. The reconfigurability is achieved by using PIN-diode switches. The antenna is designed and simulated using CST Studio Suite software to evaluate its performance, including S11, surface current distribution, radiation pattern, and gain. The flexible antenna has potential for military communication during the operations.

title: Robust State-of-Health Estimation in Second-Life Li-Ion Batteries Using Ensemble Learning and Noise-Injected Training
authors: Mahdi Alinaghizadeh Ardestani, Nika Rahmani
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Control, Instrumentation and Automation (ICCIA)
abstract: Accurate State of Health <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(\text{SoH})$</tex> estimation is crucial for reusing retired lithium-ion batteries safely. Existing methods lack robustness against real-world sensor noise and disturbances. We propose a noise-augmented training method with feature clipping to improve prediction reliability under measurement imperfections. Our approach enhances model resilience in industrial environments, where noise and calibration drift degrade performance. Evaluations show Random Forest Regression outperforms other models, achieving a 25 % lower RMSE (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{0. 8 5 \%}$</tex> vs. <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1. 1 4 \%}$</tex>). This demonstrates its effectiveness for practical second-life battery applications, balancing speed and accuracy. The method's noise-resistant design ensures reliable SoH estimation, supporting sustainable battery reuse in energy storage systems.

title: A Novel Residual Self-Attention Deep Architecture for Mpox Classification Using Dermoscopic Images
authors: Muhammad Attique Khan, Saddaf Rubab, Majid Ali Khan
publish: 2025 IEEE 15th International Conference on System Engineering and Technology (ICSET)
abstract: The rapid spread of monkeypox (mpox) across several nations has made the current outbreak a serious public health concern. Early detection and diagnosis are essential for mpox to be effectively treated and managed. In this paper, we propose a novel deep residual self-attention architecture for Mpox classification from dermoscopic images. The proposed model is based on the number of residual blocks and attention modules added in two fashions. Two residual inverted bottleneck blocks are added in the first phase, and weights are computed spatially. In the second phase, squeeze the refined residual blocks through a self-attention module and fuse their information into a single-weight matrix. The resultant weight matrix is finally passed to the fully connected layer. During the training phase, hyperparameters are optimized using Bayesian Optimization (BO) to facilitate smooth learning of the model. In the testing phase, features are extracted from the depth concatenation layer and passed to the shallow neural network classifier for the final classification. The proposed model is evaluated on two publicly available datasets and obtained <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{9 5. 7 0 \%}$</tex> and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{8 5. 9 0 \%}$</tex> accuracy. A comparison with existing techniques shows that the proposed model outperforms the SOTA techniques.

title: Warpage Resistance of Glass Substrate Containing Through-Glass-Vias: A Numerical Analysis
authors: Yu-Lin Shen, Luo Li
publish: 2025 20th International Microsystems, Packaging, Assembly and Circuits Technology Conference (IMPACT)
abstract: The use of glass substrates and through glass vias (TGVs) has garnered significant attention as an emerging trend in microelectronic packaging, particularly for applications demanding high-frequency operation, thermal stability, and integration with photonics. This paper reports a numerical study on the warpage resistance of glass substrate containing TGVs. The resistance is characterized by the bending rigidity of the plate-like structure. A series of finite element analyses are performed, taking into account the square array of TGVs inside the glass matrix. The simulations utilize a representative composite structure, with appropriate boundary conditions to ensure symmetry and periodicity. Various TGV concentrations under both the unidirectional bending and biaxial bending are considered. Bending rigidity is determined by the prescribed curvature and the reaction moment obtained from the computational analysis. It is found that a higher TGV fraction results in a greater bending rigidity and thus warpage resistance, which is due to the higher stiffness of copper compared to glass. When plastic yielding of copper is taken into consideration in the modeling, the TGV/glass interface region near the free surfaces is prone to localized plastic deformation. Permanent warpage occurs after the bending moment is completely removed. Implications of the numerical findings on potential damage of the TGV structure are discussed.

title: A Gesture Recognition Method of Surface Electromyography Signal Based on Dual-View Fusion Network
authors: Xiangdong Peng, Xiao Zhou, Ganbo Cao, Jing Li, Yi Liu, Shuqiang Guo
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Biomedical Signal and Image Processing (ICBIP)
abstract: In the field of human-computer interaction research, how to improve the accuracy of gesture recognition has always been a research hotspot. Among the existing gesture recognition studies based on surface electromyography (sEMG), one is a method based on deep learning, which mainly uses convolutional neural networks to capture the spatial morphological information of multi-channel sEMG or using a long short-term memory network to extract time-dependent information of single-channel sEMG, but without considering the correlation of electrode arrangement. The other method is to combine traditional features with deep learning, which mainly stacks and replaces the validated time-domain and frequency-domain features, but lacks the evaluation of feature importance. In order to solve the above problems, this paper takes sEMG as the research object and aims to improve the performance of gesture recognition, and proposes a neural network framework for sEMG gesture recognition based on dual-view fusion. The framework extracts the temporal and spatial features of the signal through the time-domain image subnetwork, extracts the time-frequency domain statistical features of the signal through the feature set image subnetwork, and uses the dual-view feature level and decision-making level fusion strategy of the time-domain image subnetwork and the feature set image subnetwork to obtain the recognition results. Experimental results in Ninapro's DB2 and DB4 databases show that the proposed method has higher recognition accuracy than the existing sEMG gesture recognition methods. The proposed method will provide a reference for promoting the academic research and popularization of gesture recognition based on Smeg signals.

title: Overview of mmWave Radar and Antenna Advances in Contactless Vital Signs Monitoring
authors: Sahar Saleh, Intan Sorfina Zainal Abidin, Tale Saeidi, Nick Timmons, Azniza Abd Aziz, Shahanawaz Kamal, Qusay Shihab Hamad
publish: 2025 IEEE International RF and Microwave Conference (RFM)
abstract: Remote Vital Signs Monitoring (RVSM) using Doppler radar provides a non-invasive, contactless solution for applications such as chronic care, emergency triage, and elderly monitoring. This paper reviews recent advances in mmWave Frequency Modulated Continuous Wave (FMCW) radar and high-performance antennas, such as Multiple Input Multiple Output (MIMO) and leaky-wave designs, which improve the detection of subtle cardiopulmonary signals in complex environments. Unlike prior reviews, we offer a comparative analysis of system architectures and antenna configurations, emphasizing their trade-offs in sensitivity, robustness, and scalability. Challenges such as respiratory harmonics, motion artifacts, and multi-target interference still hinder reliability. We highlight key radar and antenna setups that enhance detection sensitivity and robustness. With growing interest in smart healthcare across Asia, particularly in Malaysia, we also discuss regional deployment prospects. Future directions include adaptive signal processing, reconfigurable antennas, and low-power architectures for scalable, real-time RVSM systems.

title: ANG: Accelerating NFA processing on GPUs via Exploring Multi-Level Fine-Grained Parallelism
authors: Yuguang Wang, Yunmo Zhang, Zeyu Liu, Junqiao Qiu, Zhenlin Wang
publish: 2025 34th International Conference on Parallel Architectures and Compilation Techniques (PACT)
abstract: Finite Automata (FA) processing is a core computation in various real-world applications. Over the past decades, extensive efforts have been dedicated to accelerating FA processing on modern parallel platforms, particularly GPUs, due to their high memory bandwidth and massive hardware parallelism. As Non-deterministic Finite Automata (NFA)-based applications have strong and growing demands for real-time data analytics nowadays, reducing latency in automata processing has become a critical priority. However, existing approaches face significant challenges when limited parallelism is exposed in NFA computations. In this work, we explore opportunities of introducing fine-grained parallelism from various sources and addressing the limitations of fast NFA processing. Specifically, by analyzing different NFA parallelization schemes, we identify the major performance issue caused by insufficient state-level parallelism in conventional designs. To overcome the bottleneck, this work introduces speculative parallelization tailored for GPU-based NFA processing, thus effectively exploiting fine-grained parallelism across multilevels, with a particular focus on input-chunk-level parallelism. To realize speculative parallelization in practice, we develop $A N G$, a latency-oriented NFA processing framework that overcomes key implementation challenges on GPUs. We evaluate the efficiency of ANG on a set of representative NFAs with diverse properties. Experimental results demonstrate that ANG achieves significant performance improvement compared to state-of-theart techniques, with reaching $11.74 \times$ speedup on average (and up to $49.88 \times$ in extreme cases).

title: A Y-Band Ultra-Wideband Branch Waveguide Coupler Design Based on Rectangular Waveguides
authors: Xinru Ye, Jun Yuan, Yinian Feng, Bo Zhang
publish: 2025 18th IEEE United Conference on Millimeter Waves and Terahertz Technologies (UCMMT)
abstract: In this paper, a novel offset branch waveguide structure based on an <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$E$</tex>-plane coupler is proposed to realize an ultra-wideband terahertz coupler operating at a center frequency of 330 GHz. The design achieves a 3 dB coupling over the frequency range from 260 to 400 GHz, with amplitude flatness better than <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$0.7 d B$</tex>, return loss exceeding <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$17.2 d B$</tex>, and port isolation greater than <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$16.5 d B$</tex> across the band. At the center frequency, the amplitude flatness is below <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$0.12 d B$</tex>, and the relative bandwidth reaches 42.4%, demonstrating excellent performance for ultra-wideband applications in terahertz transceiver systems.
